On October 17, 2016, the Target completed bankruptcy proceedings with respect to CORE Entertainment Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries. See “Endemol Shine’s Business—Legal Proceedings—Core Media Group.” As a result, CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc.’s shares in CORE Entertainment Inc. were cancelled such that CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. no longer owns CORE Entertainment Inc. or any of its subsidiaries nor has the right to manage their businesses. The loss of control over these businesses triggered their immediate deconsolidation from the consolidated statement of financial position of the Target as of the date of loss of control, which was October 17, 2016. Therefore, the audited consolidated financial information of the Target as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016 includes the operations of CORE Entertainment Inc. and its subsidiaries from January 1, 2016 to October 17, 2016, such that the comparability of these financial statements with the financial statements of the Target as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, presented elsewhere in this offering memorandum, is limited. See “Endemol Shine’s Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements.”_ xxii ----- Endemol Shine’s consolidated financial statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16, and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on November 9, 2017. Endemol Shine has adopted IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019, which has an impact on its reported consolidated assets, liabilities, income statement and cash flow statement. In implementing IFRS 16, Endemol Shine prepared the Unaudited Interim Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 under the modified retrospective approach pursuant to which comparative results are not restated. Accordingly, Endemol Shine’s results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 (which were prepared after the first application of IFRS 16) are limited in comparability to its results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 (which were prepared before the first application of IFRS 16). See “Endemol Shine’s _Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Changes to Accounting Standards—IFRS 16.”_ As a result of the application of IFRS 15, since January 1, 2018, the description of revenue in the consolidated statement of comprehensive income was replaced with revenue from contracts with customers. In this offering memorandum, we refer to revenue independent of whether we are referring to Endemol Shine’s revenue prior to, on or after January 1, 2018. Unless otherwise indicated, and other than for percentages and ratios, the financial information of Endemol Shine for the twelve months ended September 30, 2019 represents the mathematical calculation of subtracting the applicable financial information for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 from the applicable financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018 and adding the applicable financial information for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, without accounting for the difference regarding the first application of IFRS 16, under which the Unaudited Endemol Shine Interim Financial Statements for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 have been prepared. The financial information of Endemol Shine for the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, has not been audited or reviewed by Endemol Shine’s auditors, is not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and has been prepared for illustrative purposes only. This information is not necessarily representative of Endemol Shine’s results of operations for such a period or any future period or any financial position at any past or future date. The contents of any website, including the websites of Endemol Shine or any affiliate of Endemol Shine, do not form any part of this offering memorandum.

This offering memorandum contains non-IFRS measures and ratios, including EBIT, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Adjusted Free Cash Flow, cash conversion ratio, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma EBITDA, Pro Forma EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin, direct gross profit, direct gross profit margin and other measures and ratios that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. We present non-IFRS measures because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. These non-IFRS measures and ratios, such as EBIT, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Adjusted Free Cash Flow, cash conversion ratio, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma EBITDA, Pro Forma EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin, direct gross profit, direct gross profit margin and other measures and ratios are not measurements of our or Endemol Shine’s performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or profit for the year or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. The non-IFRS measures we present may also be defined differently from the corresponding terms under the Indentures. The non-IFRS measures have limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered in isolation, or as an alternative to, or a substitute for, profit/(loss) for the period or other financial statement data presented in our or Endemol Shine’s consolidated financial statements as indicators or financial performance. Some of the limitations of these non-IFRS measures are that: - they do not reflect our or Endemol Shine’s cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our or Endemol Shine’s working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our or Endemol Shine’s debt; - they do not reflect our or Endemol Shine’s tax expenses or the cash that we or Endemol Shine may be required to use in order to pay taxes; - they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our or Endemol Shine’s statements of cash flows; - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we or Endemol Shine consider not to be indicative of, respectively our or Endemol Shine’s ongoing operations; xxiv ----- - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA-based measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements; - some of the exceptional items that we or Endemol Shine eliminate in calculating certain EBITDAbased measures reflect cash payments that were made, or will be made in the future; and - certain adjustments made in calculating Adjusted EBITDA, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA contain estimates that our management or that of Endemol Shine believes reflect the underlying results of operations and are therefore subjective in nature. Furthermore, you should carefully consider the risks and limitations of the non-IFRS financial measures, as they are based in part on our management’s or Endemol Shine’s management’s assumptions regarding the future impact of actions that have not yet been implemented. For example, there is a risk that the synergies that we seek to achieve, including in connection with the Endemol Shine Acquisition, may not be realized in the anticipated timeframe and that the magnitude of cost savings may be less than expected.

Certain numerical figures set forth in this offering memorandum, including financial data presented in millions or thousands and percentages, have been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data in this offering memorandum may vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in “Banijay’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and “Endemol Shine’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” are calculated using the numerical data in the consolidated financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer or the Target, respectively, or the tabular presentation of other data (subject to rounding) contained in this offering memorandum, as applicable, and not using the numerical data in the narrative description thereof.

In this offering memorandum, all references to “euro,” “EUR” and “€” are to the single currency of the Member States participating in the third stage of economic and monetary union pursuant to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as amended or supplemented from time to time; all references to “pounds,” “GBP” or “£” are to pounds sterling, the lawful currency of the United Kingdom; and all references to “U.S. dollars,” “USD,” “US$,” “dollars” and “$” are to the lawful currency of the United States of America. xxv -----

CURRENCY PRESENTATION AND EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The tables below set forth, for the periods indicated, the period end, average, high and low exchange rates published by Bloomberg (London Composite Rate). The Bloomberg (London Composite Rate) is a “best market” calculation, in which, at any point in time, the bid rate is equal to the highest bid rate of all contributing bank indications and the ask rate is set to the lowest ask rate offered by these banks. The Bloomberg (London Composite Rate) is a mid-value rate between the applied highest bid rate and the lowest ask rate. The average rate for a year means the average of the Bloomberg (London Composite Rates) on the last day of each month during a year. The average rate for a month, or for a partial month, means the average of the daily Bloomberg Composite rate during that month, or partial month, as the case may be. The below rates may differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of our financial statements and other financial information appearing in this offering memorandum. Our inclusion of these exchange rates is not meant to suggest that the U.S. dollar amounts actually represent such euro amounts, or that such amounts would have been converted at a particular rate, if at all. On January 17, 2020, the exchange rate between the U.S. dollar and the euro was $1.1095 per €1.00.

We are the largest independent content producer based on revenues and content production hours for the year ended December 31, 2018. We create, develop, sell, produce and distribute television formats and programs and digital content for a wide range of customers, and we believe we are positioned at the forefront of content production and distribution as a premier home for the industry’s leading on- and off-screen talent. We produce both scripted and non-scripted content across all major genres, including reality shows, entertainment and talk shows, game shows, factual entertainment and drama, through approximately 120 production entities across 22 countries and with content in 19 languages. We have produced successful, long-running formats and programs such as Big Brother, MasterChef, Peaky Blinders, Survivor, Temptation Island, Keeping Up with the _Kardashians, Wife Swap, Black Mirror, Don’t Forget The Lyrics!, The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds, Versailles, Fort Boyard, Money Drop, Deal or No Deal and Occupied. Our broad brand portfolio and large creative platform_ position us to continue to create, nurture and drive new formats for broadcasters and digital platforms. We generate revenues through the sale of the programs we create and produce and the distribution of formats and programs for which we hold intellectual property rights and/or rights to revenues generated by these formats and programs. We approach broadcasters with our concepts and formats, timelines and budget plans for production and broadcasters typically fully fund the production budget before production begins. Broadcasters and digital platforms pay us a fee in consideration for our delivery of the programs. For non-scripted programs, this fee generally finances the production costs and comprises the profit we generate from non-scripted programs. On the other hand, financing scripted programs generally requires several financing sources, consisting primarily of commitments from broadcasters (several broadcasters can be part of the financing plan) and other secondary sources, such as tax credits and rebates, and financing from distributors, including from time to time our distribution subsidiaries, through a distribution advance. We begin the production process only once a format has been developed, programs based on such format have been sold to a broadcaster or digital platform and financing has been fully arranged. As such, our business model is largely derisked and is characterized by a highly variable cost structure. Our successful formats generally continue to be aired for multiple seasons and are often rolled out across multiple geographies, providing a strong source of recurring revenues and cash flow visibility. For the year ended December 31, 2018, we generated 79.0% of our pro forma production revenues from returning programs. We employ creative talent to develop original formats and produce television programs based on our analysis of trends in the industry and the demands of customers and, thanks to the scope of our business following the Endemol Shine Acquisition, we have access to a wide variety of industry-leading talent and highquality creative content. We own intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of formats and programs, with our content library including approximately 85,000 hours of content. We estimate that we generated the majority of our pro forma production revenues from our owned IP formats for the year ended December 31, 2018. We retain (either through full ownership or control pursuant to distribution contracts with third-party producers) the intellectual property rights to most of our formats and programs. Such IP rights are assets that we generally distribute internationally and from which we seek to generate secondary revenues, such as licensing of distribution rights to broadcasters and digital platforms and sales of finished tapes and branded 1 ----- content, to supplement the initial production revenue. We distribute and license the majority of the content we own and control through our key distribution subsidiaries, Banijay Rights Limited and Endemol Shine International Limited. Our customers include broadcasters, such as BBC, Fox, TF1, France Télévisions, Channel 4 and MTV, and digital platforms, such as Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Facebook Watch, Google and Viaplay. No single broadcasting group accounted for more than 8.5% of our pro forma production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018. Our customer base includes approximately 500 traditional broadcasters and digital platforms as of December 31, 2018, including over 300 customers in Europe and the United States, our main geographic markets. For the year ended December 31, 2018, the Combined Group generated pro forma revenues of €2,602.7 million, with production revenues accounting for €2,147.3 million (82.5% of our pro forma revenues), distribution revenues accounting for €290.9 million (11.2% of our pro forma revenues) and secondary revenues accounting for €164.5 million (6.3% of our pro forma revenues). The charts below present the breakdown of the Combined Group’s pro forma revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018 by business, pro forma production revenues by genre and pro forma production company revenues by geography.

We believe that the following strengths differentiate us from our competitors and provide us with competitive advantages in the markets in which we operate:

Subsubsection Title: Attractive Market Benefitting from Favorable Growth Trends and Opportunities
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the global television and digital content industry, which benefits from a number of favorable drivers and growth trends. The global television industry was valued at approximately €386 billion in 2018. The television industry’s key revenue streams (pay TV subscriptions, advertising and license fees) are all expected to continue growing over the 2019 to 2023 period, and subscription-based video on demand (“SVOD”) revenues are also expected to continue growing at a CAGR of approximately 13.9% from 2019 to 2023. The share of SVOD players in content spend is expected to grow to approximately 20% in 2025. We benefit from a well-diversified content offering, which allows us to take advantage of growth in our industry and markets (which is largely a 3 ----- function of television viewership levels and viewing patterns), and to deliver formats suitable for a wide range of clients in the markets in which we operate. Viewership levels drive our customers’ revenues and therefore impact their level of spending on the content we produce. The following graphs set forth global television market size by revenue and by content spend by platform.

See “Industry.” We produce content through approximately 120 production entities, and the Combined Group has access to markets in which Banijay did not previously operate, such as Mexico and Brazil. We benefit from broad geographical coverage and portfolio diversification, resulting in significant ability for our formats and programs to travel through our production companies and be distributed through our distribution business. We have developed best-in-class internal format-sharing practices and, due to our size and decentralized organizational structure, we believe we can tailor our formats and programs to our target customers more easily than other large production groups. If we produce a successful program in one country, we can often replicate and develop the underlying format in other countries. In 2018, 61 of our formats had traveled to a different country following initial airing in the country where the format was originally developed, with 44 Endemol Shine formats having traveled to one or more new territories and approximately 17 Banijay formats having traveled to over ten countries. We are an independent producer, exclusively focused on providing innovative content to our broad customer base, which includes traditional broadcasters and digital platforms. Most of the largest television content producers in the world (in terms of revenues) are affiliated with an entertainment group or a distribution network. Our independence enables us to serve customers, without the limitations faced by controlled producers regarding, for example, the content, style and format of their production. Our independence allows us to innovate, deliver original, differentiated programs and work with a large pool of creative talents and clients. In addition, we also benefit from regulations in certain of the markets in which we operate, including those that require broadcasters to commission a certain percentage of their programs from independent producers, such as the Directive (EU) 2018/1808 concerning the provision of audiovisual media services requiring broadcasters to allocate at least 10% of broadcasting time to programs created in Europe by independent producers. In addition, our main shareholders, LOV Group and Vivendi, are industry experts who understand the television production and distribution business and are focused on developing original content. We believe that the size of the Combined Group enables us to invest in a broad range of creative talents around the world and to allocate funding to the production and development of more new formats and pilots, providing us with more opportunities to create successful new formats and programs.

Subsection Title: Global Television Market Size by Revenues (in € billions)

Subsubsection Text: 11.4% 13.6% 17.1% 217 176 158 37 18 24 35 24 28 53 36 40 80 82 89 2018 2020 2025 SVOD share of provider content spend SVOD Premium (pay TV, including sports) Thematic Network TV The global content production industry was valued at approximately €158 billion in 2018, representing approximately 41% of global television industry revenues. Content production revenues have grown in recent years and are projected to continue growing at a CAGR of approximately 4.7% from the period between 2020 to 2025, underpinned by (i) the rise of OTT platforms (particularly global SVOD players such as Disney+, Netflix and Amazon Prime Video) that drive both supply and demand for content and increase levels of competition between and among broadcasters and digital platforms, as well as total investment in content production, (ii) increasing competitive pressure on broadcasters that pushes them to increase their content investment in order to retain their audiences (particularly vis-à-vis OTT platforms), (iii) growing influence of Asian content markets, particularly as large importers of content from Europe and North America and (iv) continued demand for highbudget drama content, which is a strong driver for viewership. As a large independent producer, we believe we are particularly well-positioned to benefit from these trends. For example, we believe that digital platforms such as Netflix or Amazon Prime Video will demand an increasing amount of new content (notably for non-scripted) in order to reach as many viewers as possible. The graph below sets forth the breakdown of scripted and nonscripted TV content of SVOD players globally.

Subsubsection Title: High Degree of Diversification Across Geographies, Content Type, Format and Customers
Subsubsection Text: We are a global producer of television programs and we generate production revenues in 22 countries, including 14 countries in Europe (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, the Nordic Countries, Poland, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom), three countries in the Americas (Brazil, Mexico and the United States), three countries in Asia Pacific (Australia, India and New Zealand) and two countries in the rest of the world (Israel and Russia). Thanks to our portfolio of successful formats and programs that can be adapted to a variety of audiences across multiple geographies, we believe we are well-positioned to maintain and grow our share in our current markets. In addition, our distribution business enables us to license our portfolio of formats and programs around the world, including to customers located in markets in which we do not currently maintain production operations, and generates revenues with high margins due to the relatively limited costs incurred in managing our portfolio of existing formats and programs. We deliver our programs and formats to a large customer base of broadcasters and digital platforms. Certain of our production companies, such as Banijay Production Media, Adventure Line Productions, Bunim/Murray Productions, and Endemol Shine UK Ltd. have produced television content for more than 20 years and we benefit from long-standing relationships with broadcasters and other customers. We believe that our ability to propose original formats with a cost-efficient production process has increased customer loyalty. In addition, we often have multiple contracts, which address multiple formats and geographies, with individual customers. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2018, our largest broadcasting customer represented 8.5% of our pro forma production revenues and our five largest broadcasting customers collectively represented 30.0% of our pro forma production revenues. The following graphs set forth the breakdown of our _pro forma production revenues by customer and by format for the year ended December 31, 2018._

In the year ended December 31, 2018, the Combined Group would have collectively generated €135.3 million in production revenues from FAANG (with Banijay and Endemol Shine having generated €35.8 million and €99.5 million, respectively), as compared to €115.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2017 (with Banijay and Endemol Shine having generated €37.2 million and €78.3 million, respectively), and €71.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2016 (with Banijay and Endemol Shine having generated €7.0 million and €64.0 million, respectively). The increase in demand for non-scripted content by FAANG, and by OTT players more generally, presents an important growth opportunity for our business.

Notes: Only includes platforms with data for all years or that reached an uptake of over 200,000 subscribers within the time period presented. Content is only counted once across platforms and geographies. Excludes documentaries. 4 ----- We are OTT platform agnostic, which allows us to benefit from the growth of video on demand (“VOD”) services, due to our existing relationships with global VOD players such as Netflix and Amazon Prime Video, and we aim to work with new VOD players, such as Disney+. Our broad and diversified content portfolio, which includes approximately 85,000 hours of content, further positions us as a key partner for OTT platforms. For example, Banijay successfully sold its first original series Pine Gap to Netflix in Australia and is currently producing Young Wallander, a prequel to its Swedish crime format Wallander for Netflix in the United Kingdom, while Endemol Shine successfully sold Peaky Blinders and Black Mirror to Netflix. In addition, while the television content production market remains fragmented, we operate a fully integrated business, which enables us to both produce and distribute our programs and formats. Our size has also allowed us to develop internal policies and standardized production processes that we can offer to our customers.

Subsection Title: Spending on Content (in € billions) Global Library Hours of Reality, Comedy and Entertainment TV (Non-scripted) (in thousands)
Subsubsection Title: Broad and Diversified Portfolio of Formats and Programs Generating Primary and Secondary Revenues
Subsubsection Text: We believe our broad and diversified portfolio of formats and programs reduces our exposure to decreases in demand for a particular genre, format or program. Banijay has historically focused on producing non-scripted content across various genres, such as reality shows, game shows, entertainment and talk shows, but has recently diversified its business to include increased production and distribution of scripted content. Endemol Shine already has significant expertise in producing successful scripted programs, such as Peaky Blinders and Black _Mirror, and non-scripted programs, such as Big Brother and MasterChef. Non-scripted programs are generally_ less capital-intensive and more profitable than scripted programs because they have shorter production cycles and their budgeted production costs are covered in full before production begins. Viewership levels of non-scripted programs, our core business, have increased in the last decade. For example, viewership of MasterChef has increased in existing and new territories and has benefitted from new forms of distribution such as digital platforms (including YouTube). In 2019, there were 53 confirmed series of MasterChef, which is the highest number of confirmed series of MasterChef in a calendar year since 2005. Scripted programs, on the other hand, generally require a longer development period and higher production costs, but can generate significant secondary revenues. This is particularly true with respect to secondary revenue potential if such scripted programs are in English because they can often be sold to a broad base of customers around the world, including local and global digital platforms that are increasingly demanding new ready-to-air programs. For the year ended December 31, 2018, non-scripted programs, scripted programs and other programs represented 79.9%, 18.5% and 1.6% of our pro forma production revenues, respectively, which we believe is generally an appropriate mix for the Combined Group although we may seek to slightly increase the proportion of revenue generated by our scripted programs in the coming years. The following graphs show our pro forma revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018, by business (production revenues, distribution revenues and secondary revenues) and our _pro forma production revenues by genre (scripted, non-scripted and other):_

Subsection Title: Revenues by Business** **_Pro Forma Production Revenues by Genre
Subsubsection Title: Track Record of Creating High Quality, Non-scripted and Scripted Programs with Enduring Global Appeal
Subsubsection Text: Although our diversified portfolio allows us to capitalize on different formats and programs, we benefit from the success of blockbusters and long-running programs, such as MasterChef, Big Brother, The Challenge, _Keeping Up with the Kardashians, Survivor, Don’t Forget the Lyrics!, Beat Your Host and Paradise Hotel. We_ have increasingly focused on formats that, once produced for one market, can be licensed internationally to reach customers in other markets. For example, we have developed successful international formats, such as _MasterChef. Premiered in 1990, MasterChef was the most traveled food format in the world in 2018 and has_ been sold across over 180 territories, with over 400 series to date. We are the exclusive distributor of MasterChef globally and we license this format to our operating companies and to third-party producers for local adaptations. Other examples of successful formats include our factual entertainment format Wife Swap, which was originally developed in the United Kingdom and is currently airing in 14 countries, and our entertainment format game show All Against 1, which was initially launched in Denmark and has since been adapted in six countries. _Survivor also has a successful 22-year track record and has been adapted in more than 40 countries, with new_ sales of the format in seven new countries in two and a half years. We re-booted our reality show format _Temptation Island and relaunched it in the United States in 2018 and subsequently sold the program in France,_ Spain, Germany and Finland (in addition to Belgium and the Netherlands, where the program was already broadcasted). Our largest and top ten formats were diversified across multiple customers and contributed 8.1% and 24.7% of our pro forma production revenues, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2018. Once we have developed a format in a given country, we have a better understanding of the production process and the associated costs. We also leverage this expertise to assess production costs when negotiating with broadcasters in other countries to adapt the format. We systematically try to retain intellectual property rights to the formats and programs we produce, which is key to maximizing distribution and other secondary revenues. This business model enables us to generate additional revenues from the licensing of the format in other markets as well as from the production of local adaptations of our formats and programs by our other production companies in markets in which we operate. Our revenues from our distribution business complement revenues from sales to broadcasters and digital platforms and generate higher margins because our costs are limited once a format has been developed and a program has been produced. We operate an integrated business with a broad range of resources to create, develop, produce and distribute television content. We have resources dedicated to every stage of the television content production and distribution business. We have key partnerships with successful and creative talents around the world who work with us to produce original content at local and international levels. Our distribution companies then allow us to distribute our formats and programs and monetize our successful formats and programs by generating secondary revenues. As a result, we are able to effectively control costs at each stage of television content development, production, sale and distribution. In addition, we face minimal risk of a loss due to production costs in relation to our non-scripted programs, as broadcasters generally provide full financing for these programs. We have developed various policies at the Group-level to ensure that if one of the formats or programs for which we own or control intellectual property rights is sold in a country in which we have a presence, it must be produced by one of our production companies, which have exclusive access to our catalogue. These policies enable us to maximize the circulation of our formats within the Combined Group and preserve our integrated business model.

Subsection Title: Revenues by Business** **_Pro Forma Production Revenues by Genre
Subsubsection Title: Cash Generative and Resilient Business Model Supported by Strong Financial Performance, Cash Flow Visibility and Flexible Cost Structure
Subsubsection Text: Over the last three years, Banijay has achieved a significant improvement in the generation of its Adjusted EBITDA, which has grown from €103.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €117.4 million for the 7 ----- year ended December 31, 2018, while Adjusted EBITDA margin levels remained stable at 14.2% throughout the period. This is higher than the 11.7% average EBITDA margin over the last three years of the producers that we consider to be our main competitors, such as ITV Studios, Fremantle and Red Arrow, as well as other industry players such as LionsGate—Television and MGM Television. Banijay has also maintained strong cash generation, with Adjusted Free Cash Flow ranging from €73.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €98.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Banijay’s average cash conversion ratio (defined as Adjusted Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) for the same period was 67.8%. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, Banijay’s Adjusted EBITDA was €132.6 million and Adjusted EBITDA margin was 14.5%. Following the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition, we believe that our cash conversion ratio will normalize in the short-term, supported by low capital expenditures for the Combined Group. We also intend to continue to implement our acquisition schemes based on earn-outs and put options in order to limit our cash interest expense. We believe we have a largely de-risked business model. Our revenue benefits from the longevity of our returning formats, such as Survivor, Wife Swap, Big Brother and MasterChef, with the majority of our formats airing for more than one season, which generates long-term revenue streams and significant visibility into our operating performance as we secure budgeted revenues through contracts signed early in the production process. As demonstrated in the graph below, our business model is also supported by the stable level of content spend, which has been resilient during recent economic downturns, as compared to advertisement spend. The chart below compares TV advertising spend, total content spend (excluding sports rights) and original content spend over the 2005 to 2018 period. 35 30 25 20 15 10

Subsection Title: Revenues by Business** **_Pro Forma Production Revenues by Genre
Subsubsection Text: 6.3% 18.5% 1.6% 79.9% Non-scripted Scripted Other 11.2% 82.5% Production revenues Distribution revenues Secondary revenues 12.8% 1.3% 85.9% Non-scripted Scripted Other 21.3% 1.7% 76.9% Non-scripted Scripted Other Furthermore, our diversified portfolio of formats and programs enables us to have a resilient business model supported by “360-degree” monetization of our formats and programs, from the development and production of new formats and programs to be sold to broadcasters and digital platforms, to the licensing of existing formats to 6 ----- third parties and the sale of programs to generate distribution revenues and secondary revenues. We benefit from an extensive library of approximately 85,000 hours of content, including valuable owned intellectual property rights and programs, and we have a successful track record of monetizing these programs, including through new technologies, such as mobile applications and games. For example, the program Mr. Bean has been sold to over 195 territories, downloaded over 40 million times, generated multiple lines of merchandizing from plush toys to Apple iMessage stickers, generated over 5.7 billion views on YouTube and become the number one TV entertainment brand on Facebook with over 8.7 billion views. In addition, our distribution and secondary revenues businesses generate high margins, providing royalties to production companies and owners of intellectual property rights, as we incur limited direct costs to maintain our library of programs.

Subsubsection Title: Highly Experienced and Strongly Committed Management Team with Proven Track Record of Identifying and Retaining Key Managers and Creative Talents
Subsubsection Text: The Combined Group has a highly experienced and professional senior management team, consisting of Stéphane Courbit, Chairman and founder of Banijay, Marco Bassetti, CEO, and Sophie Kurinckx, CFO. Both Stéphane Courbit and Marco Bassetti have a successful track record of television content production. Since 2007, Banijay has become a leading independent producer of television programs based on revenues. Our management team has a strong track record of delivering on their budget and has demonstrated strong M&A capabilities, successfully integrating new businesses into the Group, such as the acquisitions of Zodiak and Castaway which outperformed the expected synergies and revenue contribution at the time of these acquisitions. In addition, our senior management team is familiar with Endemol Shine, with both Stéphane Courbit and Marco Bassetti having previously held senior positions at Endemol Shine and certain members of Banijay’s local senior management teams having been former managers within Endemol Shine. Furthermore, we benefit from the support of our shareholders, including, DeA and Vivendi, two groups that have invested in the distribution of content and broadcasters. Unlike some of our competitors, the Combined Group is led by industry experts who understand our creative talents and local production managers. This common culture and vision between our management team and our creative talents have allowed us to attract and retain successful managers, employees and partners. For example, some of our key managers and creative talents have managed to enter into framework production agreements with broadcasters, which cover several programs over a number of years and which are usually difficult to obtain from broadcasters. We have entered into earn-out or put option agreements with certain of the founders and key managers of companies we have acquired, to ensure the commitment of local management teams and to discourage their departure by rewarding them based on their respective production companies’ performance. Following the completion of the Transactions, we expect certain key managers of the Combined Group will indirectly own 7.8% of the shares of the Senior Notes Issuer through wholly-owned or majorityowned intermediate holding companies. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Earn_outs.”

TV advertising Total content spend (ex sports rights) Original content spend Source: Ampere Analysis Markets—Advertising, Content. For the year ended December 31, 2018, 21.0% and 79.0% of the Combined Group’s pro forma production revenues were generated, respectively, by new programs (first season) and returning programs (more than one season). As of November 2019, Banijay had already contracted approximately 52% of its estimated revenues for the year ending December 31, 2020 and Endemol Shine had already contracted approximately 48% of its estimated production revenues for the year ending December 31, 2020. We only commence the production for a format once a broadcaster or digital platform has agreed to purchase the format and the production costs have been fully funded. We also use the services of a significant number of freelance production artists and technicians depending, in part, on the level of television production activity in which we are engaged. In addition, we attract, retain and incentive talents via long-term incentive plans which are generally contingent and calculated based on the performance of the relevant format over a specified time period. Therefore, our production costs and a significant share of our staff costs are based on our performance and activity levels and are variable in nature. Our fixed costs represented 29.7% of our pro forma operating costs (meaning all costs included in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA) for the year ended December 31, 2018, while Banijay’s and Endemol Shine’s respective fixed costs (meaning all costs incurred independently of the level of activity) for that same period represented 25.0% and 31.7% of operating costs. Including the impact of the synergies expected to be achieved as a result of the Endemol Shine Acquisition, our fixed costs would have represented 27.8% of our pro forma operating costs for the year ended December 31, 2018. See “—Summary Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data of the Combined _Group—Key Performance Measures.”_ 8 ----- We operate an asset-light model with limited ongoing capex requirement, and low working capital requirements. For the year ended December 31, 2018, non-scripted programs, scripted programs and other programs represented 79.9%, 18.5% and 1.6% of our pro forma production revenues, respectively. Non-scripted programs are generally less capital-intensive and more profitable than scripted programs because they have shorter production cycles and their budgeted production costs are covered in full before production begins. We believe the Combined Group’s split between scripted and non-scripted content is generally well-suited to our operations, and while we may seek to slightly increase the proportion of revenue generated by our scripted programs in the coming years, we do not expect to invest significantly to develop our scripted content business as we expect that third-party financing sources will largely incur the upfront investment costs and that we will benefit from our existing catalogue’s distribution revenue. In addition, we intend to continue to promote financial discipline to maximize cash generation and reduce our leverage following the completion of the Transactions.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to Attract and Retain Key Personnel and Talents
Subsubsection Text: We rely on our management team to implement our growth strategies and our creative talents to produce formats that address our customers’ needs. Attracting, cultivating and retaining talents has been, and will remain, critical to our success. We plan to continue to attract and retain highly skilled personnel, particularly for their creative talent. We intend to further strengthen our entrepreneurial culture by continuing to incentivize our local managers to foster the high flexibility, independence and autonomy of each of our subsidiaries. For example, we have implemented a long-term incentive plan that rewards key personnel and talents based both on the performance of their production company and the performance of the Group, which we intend to extend to key talents employed by Endemol Shine (see “Management—Remuneration and Other Benefits”). We have also developed a bonus scheme at the Group-level to incentivize creative talents responsible for the creation and development of successful formats that are adapted in our key markets and have generated a certain production value for the Group, which we intend to adapt for the Combined Group to continue incentivizing format circulation. 9 ----- Following the Endemol Shine Acquisition, we intend to put more focus on retaining key talents than acquiring new talents. In the past, we developed expertise in acquiring and retaining key talent, offering such individuals the possibility of entering into joint venture agreements with us, such as Deepak Dhar, the CEO of Banijay Asia and David Goldberg, the CEO of Banijay Studios North America. This is especially attractive to talents who would like to maintain their independence but are interested in a strong partnership with us, and we expect this to be even more attractive following the acquisition of Endemol Shine. In a joint venture with us, talents benefit from our broad creative network, access to financing, information, contacts and, most importantly, catalogue of formats, our major brands and our distribution capacity. In addition, they may be able to sell us their remaining shareholding once the business has developed successfully because, if a joint venture is successful, we may acquire the remaining share capital in the production company on pre-agreed financial terms while retaining the talents who partnered with us. As of September 30, 2019, Banijay had established five joint ventures with local partners. Joint ventures allow us to be involved in the early stages of potential successes and, in the long term, to secure the possibility of acquiring a controlling interest for a price based on a pre-existing formula that takes into account our investment and support. We have talent management systems in place in order to anticipate departures and plan for successions in the event of any departures.

Subsubsection Title: Sustain Strong Production Profitability in Key Markets
Subsubsection Text: We have a successful track record of developing profitable new formats and programs and intend to continue creating popular formats and programs that address major trends in the markets in which we operate, such as trends in entertainment shows and scripted programs in our key markets, such as France, the United States and the United Kingdom. For the year ended December 31, 2018, 21.0% and 79.0% of the Combined Group’s pro forma production revenues were generated, respectively, by new programs (first season) and returning programs (more than one season). For example, in 2019, we launched Boyardland in France, an entertainment series based off of our long-running franchise Fort Boyard, and in 2013, we launched the _MasterChef Junior series in the United States, a variation of our successful MasterChef series._ We focus our strategy on developing the most profitable non-scripted formats, such as game shows or talk shows that can be broadcast daily with the potential for high returns, and formats for the most profitable primetime and access prime-time slots. We intend to apply Banijay’s production guidelines for non-scripted formats to Endemol Shine in order to monitor creation risk and maximize cash generation by limiting overhead costs, determining the price of a program based on margins and prohibiting deficit financing or key man clauses. Similarly, we expect the size of the Combined Group to enable us to fund a larger number of high-quality pilots with lower expected risk as these pilots would be amortized on a larger scale. In addition, Endemol Shine benefits from a creative award scheme to incentivize talents to develop successful formats, and we intend to apply these incentives to the Combined Group following the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition. We have several entertainment formats in our pipeline that we believe have a strong international appeal because of their subject matter and the current viewing trends and audience demands. These formats include Don’t, a family game show co-produced with actor Ryan Reynolds, and entertainment formats produced by Bear Grylls, which we believe could generate significant production and secondary revenues in the future. Furthermore, we intend to leverage Endemol Shine’s expertise in the scripted business, reflected in successful programs such as Black Mirror or Peaky Blinders, to continue to develop blockbuster formats with high production margins. Having previously invested heavily in creating a strong scripted business and a broad portfolio of established scripted shows and brands, we believe that the Combined Group has more limited exposure to box office failures and will contribute to higher profitability in our production revenues, particularly as we introduce our established business model and best practices to its operations. We produce scripted programs in the majority of the 22 countries in which we operate. While we may seek to slightly increase the proportion of revenue generated by our scripted programs in the coming years, we do not expect to invest significantly to develop our scripted content business, as we expect third-party financing sources will largely incur the upfront investment costs and that we will benefit from the existing catalogue’s distribution revenue. We mainly target scripted programs with high profitability that can run for a long period of time, such as Occupied, or daily soap operas, such as Familie in Belgium and Il Paradiso delle Signore in Italy. We also aim to optimize tax rebates by producing such formats in countries that offer the most significant tax credits and rebates and greatest access to all required resources on a cost-efficient basis. Following the Endemol Shine Acquisition, we intend to retain an increasing portion of the intellectual property rights to our formats and programs, particularly in the United States and the United Kingdom. 10 -----

Subsubsection Title: Foster Format Circulation and Develop New Returnable and Traveling Hits
Subsubsection Text: Our goal is to continue to focus on high premium formats and programs that can travel to other territories, like Survivor, MasterChef, Temptation Island, All Together Now and Big Brother have already done, and be easily distributed globally to broadcasters and digital platforms, which are regularly looking for new content. The distribution business of the Combined Group, through Banijay Rights Limited and Endemol Shine International Limited, has been successful in selling or licensing a catalogue of approximately 85,000 hours of content, including to customers in markets where we do not produce content. We also intend to increase the size of our program portfolio to reach new customers in emerging markets, such as India, where we believe there is great potential for growth in terms of viewers and where the same program can be produced for different territories in different languages. For the year ended December 31, 2018, we generated 11.2% of our pro forma revenues from our distribution business, and formats that have already been developed and produced, together with existing programs, can be distributed with comparatively high margins. Endemol Shine has a successful track record of circulating its formats to multiple territories and we intend to leverage Endemol Shine’s expertise to further increase the value of these blockbuster formats. For example, the format Your Face Sounds Familiar was originally developed by Endemol Shine in Spain in 2011 and led to two spin-off formats, Your Face Sounds Familiar Kids and Your Face Sounds Almost Familiar. The format has been produced in 39 territories, with a strong presence in Central Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America, and 170 series of the program have aired since launch. Furthermore, Endemol Shine’s local managing directors are incentivized to develop adaptable formats in-house with an international appeal that can generate distribution and other secondary revenues. We intend to apply this strategy, as well as Banijay’s proven format-sharing practices, to the Combined Group and to focus on developing know-how in our different markets in order to create traction for an upcoming format developed in another country. For example, we intend to leverage Banijay’s ability to revamp dormant formats, such as the reboot of Temptation Island, in the United States in 2018, then in Germany, Spain and France in 2019, and currently in ten countries. In addition, we intend to develop our relationships with third-party producers to secure the production and distribution rights of premium content even when they are not developed by one of our production companies. We target premium scripted content in the English language, which generally can be easily distributed internationally and is well-suited to the catalogue of many OTT platforms, as well as formatted non-scripted content which can often be adapted by our companies all over the world. We focus on sourcing partnerships and deals that generate positive returns and making selective investments in intellectual property rights and producers that we believe can deliver new long-running formats. While we plan to continue to monitor our business and consider investment and expansion opportunities as they arise, we believe that our current geographic diversification is already a key strength of our business.

Subsubsection Title: Monetize Content and Secondary Revenue Globally
Subsubsection Text: We intend to increase our secondary revenues by better monetizing our large catalogue of approximately 85,000 hours of content. For the year ended December 31, 2018, we generated 6.3% of our pro forma revenues from our secondary revenues. We aim to increase secondary revenues by taking advantage of in-program digital technologies and other features, such as votes, SMS, polling or calls while a program is airing. We also develop sponsorships with on-air partners to integrate product placement in our programs and to supplement broadcasters’ production budgets. In addition, we focus on developing branded content and partnerships with brands to establish content supplier agreements with key global broadcasters. We try to retain ancillary rights when negotiating with broadcasters to be able to develop merchandizing, branded events and experiences and off-air licenses. For example, we have entered into brand licensing arrangements for the program MasterChef _Cruise. We are also able to monetize content with low development costs through digital platforms with live-_ streaming capabilities. Moreover, we monetize content with the development of games based on intellectual property rights which we retain in connection with our formats. We have also leveraged our know-how with in-house talents by creating talent agencies which generate secondary revenues for the Combined Group, having followed the model of the talent management agency managed by Brainpool.

Subsubsection Title: Strengthen our Market Opportunities, Notably by Increasing our Business with Local and Global VOD Providers
Subsubsection Text: Our customer base has rapidly increased in recent years for both production and distribution activities, due in part to the growth of both types of VOD platforms (advertisement-based video on demand (“AVOD”) and 11 ----- SVOD) at local, regional and international levels. We now count AVOD platforms such as Facebook Watch (Ball in the Family and The Real World) and SVOD platforms such as Netflix (Young Wallander, Pine Gap, _Peaky Blinders and Black Mirror), Amazon Prime Video (Pastewka) or Viaplay (Hidden, The Restaurant and Straight Forward) among our customers, and Endemol Shine has commercial relationships with platforms that_ we intend to further develop, such as Samsung TV Plus. For the year ended December 31, 2018, pro forma production revenues from FAANG amounted to €135.3 million. We also produce an increasing number of shows for the SVOD platforms of traditional broadcasters. In Germany and the Netherlands, for example, we sell non-scripted reality programs such as Temptation Island or Survivor to VOD platforms of linear broadcasters such as RTL, for primary airing on the RTL VOD platforms, Videoland or TV NOW. We intend to further develop our business with VOD platforms, in particular AVOD platforms. For example, in 2018, Snapchat commissioned their first show with us, Endless Summer. We aim to pursue our efforts to sell more content to these new players, whose number and audience are rapidly increasing, and to benefit from the competition among them.

Subsubsection Title: Successfully Integrate Endemol Shine with our Existing Business and Unlock Synergy Value
Subsubsection Text: Strategic acquisitions enable us to expand into new end-markets and geographic segments and enlarge our business in existing markets. The Endemol Shine Acquisition will increase our international footprint and will place us as a premier home for the industry’s leading on- and off-screen talent. Banijay plans to leverage its management’s collective experience in integrating new businesses, as it did with Zodiak and Castaway which outperformed the expected synergies and revenue contribution at the time of these acquisitions, and rationalizing costs to effectively bring Banijay and Endemol Shine into a single operating group, particularly as Banijay’s senior management team is familiar with Endemol Shine, with both Stéphane Courbit and Marco Bassetti having previously held senior positions at Endemol Shine and certain members of Banijay’s local senior management teams having been former managers within Endemol Shine. Our plan is to (i) define a target structure in each country for business and support functions in order to identify key talents in each territory, (ii) on-board existing clients by showing them benefits and opportunities associated with the Combined Group and pushing our package deals, (iii) incentivize talents in the Combined Group by rolling out Banijay’s long-term incentive plan to Endemol Shine’s talents and retain key industry talents and (iv) integrate and simplify central functions across the Combined Group and implement cash pooling and new tax optimization schemes. We intend to fully achieve approximately €60 million of annualized run-rate cost savings and synergies in connection with the Endemol Shine Acquisition from the start of the third year following the Acquisition Completion Date. Our total estimated cost synergies include (i) operating cost savings of approximately €39.6 million relating to headcount reductions as a result of integrating local management teams in countries where both Banijay and Endemol Shine operate, (ii) indirect cost savings of approximately €18.5 million related to the integration of corporate, IT and other headquarter functions through a shared overhead structure for the Combined Group and (iii) rent-related cost savings of approximately €2.0 million by concentrating operations in the countries where both Banijay and Endemol Shine operate. We expect to incur approximately €59.0 million in estimated one-off costs in the first 24 months following the Acquisition Completion Date to implement synergies from the Endemol Shine Acquisition, including severance costs relating to headcount reductions and termination costs relating to rent and service contracts. Although it is our objective to reach the projected synergy levels from the start of the third year following the Acquisition Completion Date, no assurance can be given that such levels will be achieved in the timeframe indicated or at all or that additional unanticipated costs will not arise. See “—Summary Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data of the Combined _Group—Other Pro Forma Financial Information.”_

Subsubsection Title: Continue to Focus on Profitability with Financial Discipline
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to maintaining a prudent financial policy and intend to reduce our leverage by maximizing our operating efficiency, improving our productivity and optimizing our working capital and capital expenditures. In order to achieve these goals, we plan to continue to focus on profitable and sustainable growth through further fixed and variable cost reductions, increasing cost efficiencies and unlocking synergies through our vertically integrated business model. We aim to further increase our operating productivity and efficiency by continued benchmarking of our performance against local and international market competitors and maintaining success-based long-term incentive programs to attract and retain talent. 12 -----
We intend to further strengthen our business by focusing on the following key strategic objectives.

On the Issue Date, we will use the proceeds of the issuance of the Euro Senior Secured Notes to (A) redeem all of Banijay’s outstanding Existing Notes, (B) repay all amounts outstanding under Banijay’s Existing Senior Credit Facilities, (C) refinance the consideration paid for the Bear Grylls Acquisition, (D) fund cash to the balance sheet of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, which we intend to use as part of the financing of the Endemol Shine Acquisition and (E) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing ((A), (B), (C), (D) and (E) collectively, the “Refinancing”). If the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, the portion of the proceeds of the Euro Senior Secured Notes remaining on the balance sheet of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be used for the general corporate purposes of the Group, including the payment of certain fees and expenses in connection with the Endemol Shine Acquisition. See “Use of Proceeds.” In order to complete the Refinancing, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will on-lend on or around the Issue Date a portion of the proceeds of the Euro Senior Secured Notes by way of one or more proceeds loans (the “Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loans”) to its subsidiaries that entered into intercompany loans with the Senior Notes Issuer in 2017 to receive a portion of the proceeds of the issuance of the Existing Notes and borrowings under the Existing Senior Credit Facilities. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer and these subsidiaries will use the proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loans to repay these intercompany loans and other intercompany debt, such as vendor notes, to the Senior Notes Issuer, which will use these proceeds to repay the Existing Notes and the Existing Senior Credit Facilities. See “Corporate and Financing Structure.”

On October 25, 2019, we entered into the Endemol Shine Acquisition Agreement to acquire the entire share capital of the Target from the Sellers. Following the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will hold 100% of the shares of the Target. The consummation of the Endemol Shine Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including clearance by the antitrust authorities. Under the terms of the Endemol Shine Acquisition Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer has agreed to take all necessary steps to obtain the required clearances after the signing of the Endemol Shine Acquisition Agreement. If these conditions are not satisfied on or prior to January 25, 2021, and such date has not been extended by the parties, the Endemol Shine Acquisition Agreement may be terminated. The Endemol Shine Acquisition Agreement contains customary warranties and indemnities given by the Sellers and the Target as to capacity, title and disclosure as well as customary covenants given by the Sellers regarding, among other things, the conduct of the business and the affairs of Endemol Shine pending the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition. The Sellers’ liability for any breach of a warranty is subject to certain thresholds and limitations. The consummation of the Endemol Shine Acquisition (including the repayment of certain existing indebtedness owed by the Target and certain of its subsidiaries, as well as the payment of estimated transaction fees and expenses) is expected to require an aggregate of €2,018.0 million (equivalent) in a combination of debt financing and equity. The Endemol Shine Acquisition, the repayment of certain existing debt of Endemol Shine, and the related transaction fees and expenses will be financed through (i) (A) the issuance of the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes in the aggregate principal amount of €725.0 million (equivalent) and (B) drawings under the EUR Term Loan B and the USD Term Loan B in the aggregate principal amount of €953.0 million (equivalent) ((A) and (B) collectively, the “Acquisition Financing”), (ii) €275.0 million of cash funding to be provided by Financière LOV S.A.S. and Fimalac, together through LDH, and by Vivendi to Banijay Group Holding, which will contribute such funds to the Senior Notes Issuer, which will in turn contribute such funds to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, by way of an equity contribution (the “Equity Contribution”) and (iii) the portion of the proceeds of the issuance of the Euro Senior Secured Notes remaining 13 ----- on the balance sheet of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will advance the proceeds of the Senior Notes Offering to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer by way of one or more proceeds loans (the “Senior Notes Proceeds Loan”). The proceeds of the Acquisition Financing and the Equity Contribution will be used as further described under “—Sources and Uses of the Transactions.” There can be no guarantee that the Endemol Shine Acquisition will be consummated. If the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will not be required under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture to redeem the Euro Senior Secured Notes and the proceeds from the Euro Senior Secured Notes will be applied towards the Refinancing, while the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption, as more fully described under “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” If the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, the_ commitments under the EUR Term Loan B and the USD Term Loan B will be canceled, but the Euro Senior Secured Notes will remain outstanding, and drawings up to €75.0 million (equivalent) will remain available under the Revolving Credit Facility to fund the ongoing operations of Banijay. If the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, the Revolving Credit Facility will be automatically designated as a super senior liability in accordance with, and subject to, the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement.

Pending the consummation of the Endemol Shine Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the offering of the Dollar Senior Secured Notes into the Dollar Senior Secured Notes Escrow Account and the gross proceeds from the offering of the Senior Notes into the Senior Notes Escrow Account. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and will be pledged on a first-priority basis in favor of the relevant Trustee on behalf of the holders of the respective series of the Notes. See “Summary—The _Offering—Collateral.” The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the_ satisfaction of certain conditions, including the consummation of the Endemol Shine Acquisition within one Business Day following release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts. If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption. The Special Mandatory Redemption Price for the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes, as applicable, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such Special Mandatory Redemption. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Transactions—The Endemol Shine Acquisition is subject to certain conditions, uncertainties and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuers may redeem their respective Dollar Senior Secured Notes and Senior Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest.”_ On the Issue Date, the gross proceeds of the Euro Senior Secured Notes will not be placed into an escrow account and are intended to be used as set forth in “Use of Proceeds.” The Euro Senior Secured Notes are not subject to a special mandatory redemption and, as a result, will remain outstanding even if the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated and the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes are redeemed pursuant to a special mandatory redemption applicable to those Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the _Endemol Shine Acquisition—The Euro Senior Secured Notes are not subject to a special mandatory redemption and will remain outstanding even if the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, in which case the amount available under the Revolving Credit Facility would be limited and such facility will be automatically designated as a super senior liability in accordance with, and subject to, the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement.”_

We refer to the Offering, the Refinancing, the Acquisition Financing, the Endemol Shine Acquisition and the repayment of certain existing debt of Endemol Shine, each as described below, collectively as the “Transactions.” On the Issue Date, we expect to consummate the Offering, the Refinancing and the Acquisition Financing. On the Acquisition Completion Date, we expect to consummate the Endemol Shine Acquisition and the repayment of certain existing debt of Endemol Shine. See “Use _of_ _Proceeds,”_ “Capitalization,” “Description _of_ _Other_ _Indebtedness_ _and_ _Financing _Arrangements,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of the Senior Notes.”_

Subsection Title: Sources and Uses of the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: Sources and Uses of the Refinancing
Subsubsection Text: The expected estimated sources and uses of the funds necessary to consummate the Refinancing are shown in the table below. Actual amounts may differ from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the issue price of the Euro Senior Secured Notes, accrued interest on the debt being repaid and the actual date of repayment of such debt.

Subsection Title: Sources and Uses of the Transactions
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, we intend to use the proceeds of the offering of the Euro Senior Secured Notes to (i) redeem all of Banijay’s outstanding Existing Notes, (ii) repay all amounts outstanding under Banijay’s Existing Senior Credit Facilities, (iii) refinance the consideration paid for the Bear Grylls Acquisition, (iv) fund cash to the balance sheet of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, which we intend to use as part of the financing of the Endemol Shine Acquisition and (v) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing. 14 ----- On the Acquisition Completion Date, we intend to use the proceeds of the offering of the Dollar Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes, together with the Equity Contribution, and amounts drawn under the Senior Facilities and the portion of the cash proceeds of the offering of the Euro Senior Secured Notes remaining on our balance sheet, to (i) acquire 100% of the share capital of the Target, (ii) refinance certain existing indebtedness of the Target and (iii) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions.
