Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Success of New Formats and New Programs
Subsubsection Text: We produce both scripted and non-scripted content across all genres, including reality shows, entertainment and talk shows, game shows, adventure shows and drama. Our creative talents are a key element of our success and are constantly working to address customers’ demands or to anticipate trends in the industry. We work with our customers to develop original formats that may become long-running programs if they receive good ratings, making them a success. Periods in which we and our customers have successfully anticipated trends produce more favorable results. Usually a successful program will run until viewers’ preferences change or until broadcasters decide to replace the program, in which case they may ask us to develop a new format. If a new program is successful, this will have a positive effect on the profitability of the local production company that produced the program, since broadcasters will typically renew the program for several seasons. In addition, it will have a positive impact on the Group’s revenues, since a popular program in one country will often be successful in other countries with a similar audience, either by the production in such country by one of our production companies or by licensing the format to third-party production companies in the countries where we are not present. For the year ended December 31, 2018, new shows accounted for 32.2% of our production revenues and we generated 26.3% of our production revenues from programs that have aired for a period between two and five seasons and 41.5% of our production revenues from programs that have aired for more than five seasons. Non-scripted formats benefit from lower production costs, a shorter development period and more advantageous financing arrangements, because the broadcaster who purchases the non-scripted format fully funds production costs. For the year ended December 31, 2018, we generated 85.9% of our production revenue from non-scripted programs. Our ability to accurately anticipate new trends and/or changes in consumer preferences and needs, as well as focus our development efforts towards that goal, gives us the opportunity to potentially create the next television blockbuster and accordingly will positively impact our revenues. However, our revenues from broadcaster sales will not be negatively impacted if a new program is not successful because the initial price for the sale of the program is not determined based on its success. Different factors are taken into account when determining a program’s price. The budget that the broadcaster wishes to allocate for the relevant time slot is a key element (since budgets are lower for day time slots than they are for access prime-time or prime-time slots). The pricing also takes into account production costs based on the type of program and the format fee payable for the format rights. The average format fee differs from one country to another but, in our experience, is usually between 5% and 7% of the production budget. In addition, the format fee will be higher if the format is successful and/or has already been successfully aired in certain markets. The price of a program is also based on our bargaining power with broadcasters. Even if a program is not successful in a specific market, we will try to produce the format in another market where we are present or license it to another producer in markets where we do not operate. We can also distribute the program through our Banijay Rights Limited subsidiary and continue to derive distribution and secondary revenues from that program.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Development of the Production of Scripted Programs
Subsubsection Text: Scripted programs generally require a longer and more extensive development and production process, incurring higher costs than non-scripted programs. Because of these higher production costs, scripted programs also tend to generate lower margins than non-scripted programs, but they can deliver higher revenues, 121 ----- particularly future intellectual property revenues when we manage to retain part of the intellectual property rights. We believe our split between scripted and non-scripted content is generally well-suited to our operations, and while we may seek to slightly increase the proportion of revenue generated by our scripted programs in the coming years, we do not expect to invest significantly to develop our scripted content business, as we expect that third-party funding sources will largely incur the upfront investment costs and that we will benefit from the existing catalogue’s distribution revenue. The financing of scripted programs requires financing commitments from broadcasters and co-producers but also from distributors which may be our distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited. We may therefore be required to prefund development costs for a scripted program. The timing of the upfront payments and final payments, as well as the participation of Banijay Rights Limited in the financing of scripted programs impact our working capital requirements. In addition, we rely on tax credits in certain jurisdictions as part of the financing of a scripted program. However, we may only be able to claim such tax credits after having finalized the production of the program, which may require the Group to prefund a larger share of the upfront production costs and capital expenditures. Changes in working capital are impacted by the timing of a production and program delivery and by the production of scripted and non-scripted programs. Since non-scripted programs are mainly produced in less than a year, working capital requirements related to our non-scripted business are mainly impacted by fluctuations in the numbers of non-scripted programs we produce. We may record cut-off impacts related to non-scripted activity at the end of each year if some large-scale programs are still under production. On the other hand, scripted productions have a longer production cycle, usually over two years, and higher working capital requirements. Our working capital related to scripted activity can be impacted significantly by cut-off issues at the end of the year.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our primary customers today are broadcasters and digital platforms. The number of broadcasters has increased in recent years, which in turn has increased the number of customers available to purchase our programs. At the same time broadcasters are facing increasing competition from companies that deliver video content over the internet, commonly referred to as over-the-top or “OTT programming.” With the growth of OTT programming, viewers’ video content consumption preferences may shift away from broadcasters and existing viewing habits. Younger viewers have already started to shift toward using mobile devices or computers rather than televisions. As a result, many of our customers and potential customers are compelled to find new original formats and programs to deliver content to viewers via the internet. We expect this pressure to become even greater as digital platforms such as Netflix and Amazon Prime Video continue to grow. We expect to benefit from this customer diversification as we have historical relationships with many broadcasters and have already developed strong commercial relationships with digital platforms. We expect this diversification to continue as OTT companies increasingly focus on non-scripted content, a genre in which we have strong production know-how. In addition, we are increasingly focusing on formats or programs which, once produced for a local market, can be sold or licensed internationally to customers in other markets, such as broadcasters or digital platforms.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have developed our business around two sources of income: sales of programs to broadcasters and digital platforms and international distribution of our content through our subsidiary Banijay Rights Limited. We own intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of formats and programs representing approximately 20,000 hours of television content. We distribute and license the content we own through Banijay Rights Limited to a traditional customer base of television broadcasters and to digital platforms. Our distribution business generates revenues with high margins because we have limited costs in connection with managing our portfolio of existing programs. For the year ended December 31, 2018, our distribution and secondary business generated revenues of €110.7 million, which represented 13.4% of our total revenues. For the year ended December 31, 2018, our distribution business generated an Adjusted EBITDA of €19.7 million, which represented 16.7% of our total Adjusted EBITDA. We intend to further develop our distribution business and develop other sources of secondary revenues, such as revenues from advertising, live entertainment or branded content. We expect this trend to have a positive impact on our revenues, EBITDA and EBITDA margin.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Fluctuation in Our Revenues from Period to Period
Subsubsection Text: We only recognize revenues from the sale of a program to a broadcaster or digital platform at the time of the program’s delivery. This creates a mismatch between the revenues we actually receive in connection with such sale and the revenues recognized in our financial statements. For example, we occasionally receive production 122 ----- advances from broadcasters before production is complete and these advances are not recognized in our revenues until the delivery of the program. As of September 30, 2019, we had received production advances in the amount of €192.0 million relating to programs delivered or to be delivered in the last quarter of 2019 or in 2020. In addition, we have entered into contracts for a period longer than a year with some of our customers in France and the Nordic Countries. Broadcasters can also decide to make changes to a program during the production process, which may cause delays in the delivery of the program and therefore impact our revenues. In addition, we offer our customers a period of time during which they can reject or return our programs and until the expiration of this period, we may not be able to recognize the related revenues. Accordingly, our revenues and results of operations may fluctuate from period to period and the results of one period may not be representative of the results of any future period.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: To grow our business, we continually assess our markets for opportunistic acquisitions of similar businesses and assets, such as the acquisitions of PortoCabo in July 2018 in Spain, Good Times in June 2019 in Germany, ITV Movie in July 2019 in Italy, Funwood Media in October 2019 in Spain and Italy and The Natural Studios in October 2019 in the United Kingdom. We generally focus on acquiring companies with specific creative talents, such as a popular host or successful producer, and structure our acquisitions to incentivize such talents to continue to work for us and to create further value. For example, since the completion of the Bear Grylls Acquisition, we control the production of all shows featuring Bear Grylls. To that effect, we enter into various earn-outs or put option agreements with certain of these talents, who are often the sellers of the targets. Payments pursuant to earn-outs or put options are generally contingent and calculated based on the performance of the acquired company over a specified time period following the acquisition. This period generally corresponds to an exclusivity period during which the key managers and creative talents agree to work exclusively for us. The key commercial points include the performance metrics underlying the contingent payments, the earn-out or put option period (usually in an eight-year range), and the timing and the structure of the contingent payment. We account for these earn-outs and put options as a financial liability on our balance sheet rather than financial debt, because the amounts owed under these incentive agreements vary depending on the performance of the business and because they do not bear interest. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Contractual Obligations and _Contingent Liabilities.” If the opportunity arises, we may also decide to acquire companies in order to own the_ intellectual property rights to their catalogue of formats and programs. For example, since the completion of the Castaway Acquisition, we own the intellectual property rights to the Survivor format. Following the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition, we will further expand our catalogue of formats and programs, including on a more global basis. We may also acquire intellectual property rights without acquiring a production company. For example, we acquired in October 2016 the intellectual property rights and contracts associated with the popular game show The Legacy (known as Les 12 Coups de Midi in France and L’Eredità in Italy). In December 2018, we also acquired the intellectual property rights to the Intervilles format and its derivatives (including Jeux sans _frontières), which has been relaunched in Italy, Spain and Greece and will soon be relaunched in France. We also_ establish joint ventures with popular local producers and talents to develop new production companies in certain markets. For example, we launched Banijay Asia in April 2018, a joint venture in India with a local partner. If a joint venture is successful, we may acquire the remaining share capital in the production company based on a pre-agreed price calculation formula. In the event that a joint venture is not successful and incurs significant losses, we try to negotiate clauses in the related agreement with the other party to limit any potential losses we may incur in connection with such joint venture. Acquisitions affect our results of operations in several ways. First, our results for the period during which an acquisition takes place are affected by the inclusion of the results of the acquired entity into our consolidated results. Second, the results of the acquired businesses after their acquisition may be positively affected by synergies. Additionally, we may experience an increase in operating expenses, such as staff costs, as we integrate the acquired business into our Group. Finally, because acquired entities are consolidated from their date of acquisition, the full impact of an acquisition or disposal is only reflected in our financial statements in the subsequent period.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: General Economic Conditions in Our Markets
Subsubsection Text: Macroeconomic factors in the geographic markets in which we operate affect our results of operations. Broadcasters’ purchases of licenses for our formats and programs have grown through various economic cycles because viewers continue to watch television and demand new content throughout such cycles. However, broadcasters generate lower advertisement revenues during economic downturns and therefore may try to reduce their budgets allocated to the purchase or production of new programs. During these periods, broadcasters 123 ----- become more risk averse and are reluctant to finance the production of untested, new programs to a certain extent. We have been resilient to economic downturns in the past because we relied on revenues from successful, long-running programs but a new downturn may affect our future results of operations.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The size of the global television production market continues to grow but is experiencing a shift in key revenue components. According to Oliver & Ohlbaum, the global television industry was valued at approximately €386 billion in 2018 and revenues are projected to reach approximately €389 billion in 2019. The industry’s key revenue streams which include pay TV subscriptions, advertising, license fees and subscriptions and licensing fees from SVOD use, are all expected to continue growing from 2019 to 2023 at a CAGR of approximately 1.9%. The global content production industry was valued at approximately €158 billion in 2018, representing approximately 41% of global television industry revenues. Content production revenues have grown in recent years and are projected to continue growing at a CAGR of approximately 4.7% from the period between 2020 to 2025. We expect growth in the television production market in terms of revenues to continue to be influenced by viewership levels and customers’ demand for new programs in order to reach as many viewers as possible, particularly via digital platforms that are available on mobile devices as video consumption continues to increase partly due to a shift from viewings on television to mobile phones and tablets. We also expect customers’ demand for original formats and programs in emerging markets to continue to be driven by a growing middle class. Our revenues will be impacted from period to period by our ability to penetrate, and the continued growth in, these emerging markets.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our reported results of operations and financial condition are affected by exchange rate fluctuations. We are exposed to both transactional and translational risk due to these fluctuations. Transactional risk arises when our subsidiaries execute transactions in a currency other than their functional currency. We currently have production companies in 16 countries. As a result, we generate a significant portion of our revenues and incur a significant portion of our expenses in currencies other than euro, our reporting currency. The primary currencies in which we generated revenues in the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, were the euro, the U.S. dollar and the pound sterling. Where we are unable to match revenues received in foreign currencies with costs paid in the same currency, our results of operations are affected by currency exchange rate fluctuations. For example, a stronger euro will increase the cost of euro-denominated supplies for our non-euro businesses and conversely decrease the cost of non-euro supplies for our euro businesses. Our subsidiaries generally execute their sales to broadcasters and digital platforms and incur most of their materials costs in the same currency. As a result, we currently do not seek to reduce the effect of exchange rate fluctuations through the use of derivative financial instruments, except in connection with a few local productions. During the year ended December 31, 2018, 16.0% of our revenues were generated in U.S. dollars and 12.0% of our revenues was generated in GBP. We also face translational currency exchange risk. We present our consolidated financial statements in euro. As a result, we must translate the assets, liabilities, income and expenses of all of our operations with a functional currency other than euro into euro at then-applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of these currencies against the euro may affect the value of our assets, liabilities, income and expenses with respect to our non-euro businesses in our consolidated financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency, which creates translation risk. These translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods and result in significant changes to the carrying value of our assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity. For example, because we prepare our consolidated financial statements in euro, the decrease of the value of the U.S. dollar compared to the euro, pound sterling and other major currencies in 2018 negatively affected our reported results of operations. See “—Key Accounting _Policies—Foreign Currency Translation.”_

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The following are key factors that have significantly affected our results of operations and financial condition and liquidity or which we expect to significantly affect (or continue to affect) our results of operations in the future.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: _IFRS 16_ Our financial statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on November 9, 2017. Since January 1, 2019, IFRS 16 has replaced IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations and we have recognized on our balance sheet lease liabilities in relation to leases which had previously been classified as 124 ----- “operating leases” under the principles of IAS 17 Leases. Under IFRS 16, the lessee recognizes an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and a financial liability for lease payments. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases. Lease liabilities are measured at the present value of lease payments to be made over the lease term. Rights-of-use of leases are being amortized over the contracts’ duration. As a consequence, lease expenses have been restated from external expenses while higher financial interests and depreciation and amortization have been recognized. In addition, IFRS 16 has impacted the presentation of our cash flow statement. Actual lease payments, which were previously part of operating profit / (loss) or movements in payables within net cash generated from operating activities, have now been classified into a payment of lease liability within financing activities. Cash flows from operating activities have been positively impacted and cash flows from financing activities have been negatively impacted. Though presented in different parts of the consolidated cash flow statement, actual total pre-tax cash payments remain unchanged. We have elected to use the exemptions on short-term and low-value leases. We have adopted IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective method with the date of initial application of January 1, 2019. As of January 1, 2019, the impact of IFRS 16 adoption led to a provisional impact of €68.4 million of both right-of-use assets and lease liabilities, with therefore no impact in the net equity. Discounted rates are an area of significant judgement and estimation, particularly given the term of our leases, which have an average duration of 5.3 years as of September 30, 2019. The weighted average discount rate applied to the lease liabilities on January 1, 2019, was 2.4%. Had we adopted IFRS 16 on January 1, 2018, we estimate that the implementation of IFRS 16 would have resulted in an increase of €13.2 million in EBITDA as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018. This estimate is based on our leases as of January 1, 2019, excluding the contribution from Brainpool, and the impact of IFRS 16 on our results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This information may not be indicative of the impact of the first application of IFRS 16 on our right-of-use assets, lease liabilities and EBITDA for any future period. In implementing IFRS 16, we prepared the Unaudited Interim Banijay Financial Statements for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 under the modified retrospective approach pursuant to which comparative results are not restated. Accordingly, our results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 (which were prepared after the first application of IFRS 16) are limited in comparability to our results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 (which were prepared before the first application of IFRS 16).

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: We have completed a number of selective acquisitions of varying sizes from 2016 to the date of this offering memorandum, which impact the comparability of our financial results between periods. Since we consolidate the results of operations of each acquired business in our financial statements from the completion date of each acquisition, our historical financial periods are not directly comparable to one another. Following the closing date of an acquisition, our results are consolidated with the results of the acquired business, and are thereafter impacted by the revenues and expenses of the acquired business. See “—Factors Affecting Our Results of _Operations—Acquisitions and Joint Ventures.” As we continually assess our markets for opportunistic_ acquisitions of similar businesses to grow our business, including in connection with the Endemol Shine Acquisition, our financial statements in the future will vary from our historical consolidated financial statements contained in this offering memorandum. Set forth below are brief descriptions of certain of our significant acquisitions since the beginning of 2016. _Banijay Zodiak Merger_ On February 23, 2016, we completed the Banijay Zodiak Merger, a reverse merger pursuant to which Banijay Holding, the holding company of the Group prior to the Banijay Zodiak Merger, was merged into Zodiak, which was renamed Banijay Group S.A.S. upon completion of the reverse merger. However, under reverse acquisition accounting principles, Banijay Holding is treated as the accounting acquirer and Zodiak is treated as the accounting acquiree. As a result, the audited consolidated financial information of the Senior Notes Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016 includes (i) the operations of the accounting acquirer (Banijay Holding) from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016, and (ii) the operations of the legal parent (the Senior Notes Issuer, formerly Zodiak) from February 23, 2016, the date of the completion of the Banijay Zodiak Merger, to December 31, 2016. See note 6.2 to the Audited Banijay Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Therefore, the Senior Notes Issuer’s 125 ----- financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016, do not fully represent the results of operations and financial condition of the entire business and the comparability of these financial statements with the financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, presented in this offering memorandum is limited. _Brainpool_ In December 2018, our subsidiary, Banijay Germany, took control over Brainpool following a reorganization in the management team of that entity, and as a result Brainpool has been fully consolidated for the purpose of the financial statements (including the balance sheet) of the Group for the year ended December 31, 2018. Therefore, the Senior Notes Issuer’s financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, do not fully represent the results of operations and financial condition of the entire business and the comparability of these financial statements with the financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer as of and for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2017, presented in this offering memorandum is limited. As of September 30, 2019, we owned 50% of the outstanding share capital of Brainpool. _Bear Grylls_ In October 2019, the Senior Notes Issuer acquired 51.0% of the issued and outstanding share capital of The Natural Studios, the direct parent company of BGV Media Limited.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenues are recognized to the extent that it is probable that the economic benefits will flow to the Group and the revenues can be reliably estimated. Revenues are measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of rebates, pay-backs, some specific grants, subsidies and co-producers’ contributions. We only recognize revenues from the sale of a program to a broadcaster or digital platform at the time of the program’s delivery.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Operating expenses consist primarily of production costs, net of co-producers’ contributions, grants and subsidies, consisting mainly of the costs of scripts, actors, directors, equipment rentals, technical costs, participants, hosts, sets and format fees.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: External expenses consist of advertising expenses, the employment costs of freelance workers, outsourcing expenses, provisions and impairment losses on current assets and other expenses from operations.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Staff costs consist of salaries and staff remuneration, including payroll expenses (including for freelance production artists and technicians) and share-based payment expenses under IFRS 2 that may be converted into cash on the realization of certain performance milestones: (i) expenses related to share purchase or subscription plans; (ii) expenses related to plans allocating free shares; and (iii) expenses related to exceptional bonus plans indexed on the increase in equity value. We also use the services of a significant number of freelance production artists and technicians. This number varies from time to time depending, in part, on the level of television production activity in which we are engaged.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Taxes and duties consist of taxes other than current income tax. 126 -----

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Depreciation and Amortization of Intangible and Tangible Assets
Subsubsection Text: Intangible and tangible assets are carried at cost and depreciated on a straight-line basis over their useful life. Scripted programs are amortized based on the revenues method. See “—Key Accounting Policies— _Depreciation and Amortization.”_

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Current Impairment Losses and Provisions, Net of Reversals
Subsubsection Text: Current impairment losses and provisions, net of reversals, consist of impairment losses, provisions and reversals. Provisions are recorded only if (i) the Group has a present payment obligation as a result of a past events, (ii) it is likely that an expense will be required to settle such obligation and (iii) a reliable estimate can be made as to the amount of such payment obligation. The charges relating to provisions are accounted for as profit or loss, net of any contingent reimbursement. If the effect of the time value of money is material, provisions are discounted using a discount pre-tax rate that reflects, where appropriate, the risks specific to that payment obligation. When discounting, the increase in the provision due to the passage of time is recognized in finance costs.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Other Current and Non-current Operating Income and Expenses
Subsubsection Text: Other current and non-current operating income and expenses consist of income and expenses that are both unusual in nature and significant in terms of value at the Group-level. We present such income and expenses separately in our income statement in order to facilitate the understanding of the recurring operating performance of which such income and expenses are not part.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance income consists of income from long-term investments and loans, other interest and similar income and gains.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Interest expense consists primarily of interest on bank loans, bonds and shareholder loans and expenses related to interest rate derivatives used to hedge the variable interest rates on our senior bank debt.

Subsubsection Text: Other finance income (costs) consists primarily of discounting costs and reevaluation costs related to earnouts and put option liabilities.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Profit (loss)—Non-controlling interests . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1.6 3.5 1.9 118.8% Profit (loss)—Attributable to the owners of Banijay Group . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (4.3) 19.1 23.4 n/r (a) Change in value and percentage change represent the absolute difference and percentage difference, respectively, between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, based on the appropriate mathematical formula. Accordingly, decreases in cost items are shown as positive changes in the change in value column, and negative changes in the percentage change (%) column, and increases in cost items are shown as negative changes in the change in value column, and positive changes in the percentage change (%) column. (b) Our historical consolidated statement of profit or loss for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 were prepared under IAS 17, and our historical consolidated statement of profit or loss for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 was prepared under IFRS 16. Depreciation prepared on an IAS 17 basis represents depreciation, excluding depreciation of right-of-use assets that were accounted for as operating leases prior to the first application of IFRS 16. Amortization prepared on an IAS 17 basis represents amortization, excluding amortization of lease premiums which, following the first application of IFRS 16, are included within right-of-use assets on our balance sheet, with depreciation charged accordingly. _Revenues_ Revenue increased by €88.9 million, or 16.2%, from €548.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €637.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to (i) changes in the scope of consolidation, which had a positive impact of €69.7 million on our revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, mainly due to the consolidation of Brainpool in Germany in December 2018 (€45.1 million), the integration of Shauna Events (€12.2 million) and the acquisitions of PortoCabo, Good Times, ITV Movie and Screen Media (collectively, €12.2 million), (ii) the organic growth of our business (€30.3 million), driven by the timing of delivery of certain programs and new productions in 2019, and which was partly offset by programs not renewed, and (iii) positive foreign exchange impact (€4.2 million) driven by favorable fluctuations in the EUR/USD exchange rate, partially offset by negative changes in the EUR/SEK exchange rate. 128 ----- This increase in revenue occurred despite the unfavorable (on a comparable basis) non-recurrence in 2019 of two one-off events that had a net positive impact of €15.2 million in 2018, namely: (i) the revenue contribution of a significant intellectual property license over a seven-year period, which was recognized in full in the nine months ended September 30, 2018 and (ii) the delivery of the third season of Versailles, one of our leading scripted international programs. _Operating Expenses, External Expenses and Staff Costs_ Operating expenses, external expenses and staff costs increased by €66.3 million, or 14.2%, from €467.7 million, or 85.3% of revenues, for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €533.9 million, or 83.7% of revenues, for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the operating expenses, external expenses and staff costs of Brainpool, which was consolidated in our results of operations in December 2018, and to the growth of our business. This increase was partly offset by the impact of IFRS 16 (€11.6 million). _Depreciation and Amortization of Intangible and Tangible Assets_ Depreciation and amortization of intangible and tangible assets increased by €4.6 million, or 14.2%, from €32.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €37.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the impact of IFRS 16 (€11.3 million), partly offset by the negative impact (€5.9 million) of more fiction programs being delivered and amortized in the nine months ended September 30, 2018, compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2019, due to the seasonality of scripted production. _Current Impairment Losses And Provisions, Net of Reversals_ Current impairment losses and provisions, net of reversals increased by €0.1 million, or 13.0%, from €0.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €0.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the reversal of provisions related to bad debt for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, following payments from customers. _Other Current Operating Income (Expenses)_ Other current operating income/expenses increased by €0.4 million, from an expense of €0.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to an income of €0.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the impact of the reclassification of the profit share to ITV in Castaway from other current operating expenses in the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to operating expenses in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. _Other Non-Current Operating Income (Expenses)_ Other non-current operating expenses decreased by €12.0 million, or 58.5%, from €20.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €8.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the non-recurrence of the costs incurred in the nine months ended September 30, 2018, following the cancellation of Koh Lanta during its nineteenth season (the French version of Survivor) after an incident between two contestants in 2018. This decrease was partly offset by severance costs incurred in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. _Interest Expenses_ Interest expenses decreased by €1.6 million, or 8.9%, from €18.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €16.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the interest accrued during the nine months ended September 30, 2018, on a shareholder loan that was repaid in full in December 2018. _Other Finance Income (Costs)_ Other finance costs increased by €0.4 million from €5.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to €5.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to a financial expense of €1.2 million related to IFRS 16 in the nine months ended September 30, 2019, partly offset by higher interest income on current accounts with equity investments. 129 ----- _Income Taxes_ Income taxes increased by €7.0 million, from €4.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €11.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. We computed income tax expense for the ninemonth periods ended September 30, 2019 and 2018 using the projected effective tax rate method (based on the latest approved budget after certain restatements related to our long-term incentive plan), after restating the profit/(loss) before tax from certain selected items with no tax impact. _Profit (Loss) for the Year_ Profit for the year increased by €25.5 million, from a loss of €2.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018 to a profit of €22.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the reasons stated above.

Subsubsection Text: Profit (loss)—Non-controlling interests . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2.0 2.0 0.0 0.3% Profit (loss)—Attributable to the owners of Banijay Group . . . . . . . . . 23.3 10.9 (12.4) (53.3)% (a) Change in value and percentage change represent the absolute difference and percentage difference, respectively, between the results for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2017, based on the appropriate mathematical formula. Accordingly, decreases in cost items are shown as positive changes in the change in value column, and negative changes in the percentage change (%) column, and increases in cost items are shown as negative changes in the change in value column, and positive changes in the percentage change (%) column. _Revenues_ Revenues decreased by €20.0 million, or 2.4%, from €846.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to €826.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to an adverse foreign exchange impact of €17.0 million, mainly on the EUR/USD and EUR/SEK foreign exchange rates, and a negative impact of €45.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, following the cancellation of certain 130 ----- significant programs (such as Koh Lanta in France following an incident between two contestants, El Programa _de Ana Rosa in Spain following the departure from Cuarzo of Ana Rosa Quintana and the cancellation of Project Runway in the United States). This decrease was partly offset by a change in scope of consolidation, which had a_ positive impact of €23.0 million on our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018, due to the acquisition of PortoCabo in Spain, Wonder Television in the United Kingdom, Terence Films and Shauna Events in France, and by the organic growth of our business, which had a net positive impact of €19.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. _Operating Expenses, External Expenses and Staff Costs_ Operating expenses, external expenses and staff costs decreased by €30.4 million, or 4.2%, from €725.7 million, or 85.7% of revenues, for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €695.3 million, or 84.1% of revenues, for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower production revenues as well as lower expenses in connection with our long-term incentive plan, following a review of this plan in 2018. _Depreciation and Amortization of Intangible and Tangible Assets_ Depreciation and amortization of intangible and tangible assets increased by €3.7 million, or 7.2%, from €50.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €54.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to higher amortization of fiction production costs in connection with higher intellectual property sales of fiction formats over the period. This increase was also due to a reversal of impairment in 2017 in connection with a provision of the former Zodiak business that was depreciated at the time of the Banijay Zodiak Merger, and which did not recur in 2018. _Current Impairment Losses and Provisions, Net of Reversals_ Current impairment losses and provisions net of reversals decreased by €2.2 million from an income of €1.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to an expense of €1.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to allowances for doubtful accounts, primarily in the United States. _Other Current Operating Income and Expenses_ Other current operating income and expenses increased by €0.3 million, or 18.8% from an expense of €1.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to an expense of €1.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the full year impact of the share of the profits before tax from Castaway due to ITV in the United Kingdom. _Other Non-Current Operating Income (Expenses)_ Other non-current operating expenses increased by €14.5 million from €8.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €22.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the cancellation of Koh Lanta during its nineteenth season (the French version of Survivor) and, to a lower extent, higher acquisition costs in 2018. _Interest Expenses_ Interest expenses increased by €1.2 million, or 5.1%, from €23.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €24.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the full year impact of the refinancing completed in July 2017, which resulted in higher interest expenses for the full year 2018, partly offset by the write-off of transaction costs incurred in connection with our previous financing arrangements in 2017 and not recurring in 2018. _Other Finance Income (Costs)_ Other finance income/costs increased by €4.4 million from a finance income of €3.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to finance costs of €1.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to (i) a positive net impact of €7.0 million in 2017, which did not recur in 2018, related to the refinancing of certain convertible bonds subscribed in February 2016 by a subsidiary of Vivendi and (ii) a 131 ----- negative foreign exchange impact of €1.0 million. This decrease was partly offset by the net positive impact of €4.1 million following a change in valuation of earn-out rights resulting from an update of our business plan and of the discount rate applied to such rights. _Income Taxes_ Income taxes decreased by €5.7 million, from an expense of €15.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to an expense of €9.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the decrease of the federal income tax rate in the United States from 35% to 21%, which resulted in a positive impact of €1.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, and the lower basis of profit before tax in the United States and in France. _Profit (Loss) for the Year_ Profit (loss) for the year decreased by €12.4 million, or 49.1%, from €25.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €12.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons described above.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Profit (loss)—Non-controlling interests . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1.8 2.0 0.2 9.8% Profit (loss)—Attributable to the owners of Banijay Group . . . . . . . . . 20.6 23.3 2.7 12.9% (a) Change in value and percentage change represent the absolute difference and percentage difference, respectively, between the results for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016, based on the appropriate mathematical formula. Accordingly, decreases in cost items are shown as positive changes in the change in value column, and negative changes in the percentage change (%) column, and increases in cost items are shown as negative changes in the change in value column, and positive changes in the percentage change (%) column. 132 ----- _Revenues_ Revenues increased by €120.1 million, or 16.5%, from €726.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €846.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily related to a change in scope of consolidation, which had a positive impact of €62.0 million on our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly attributable to the Banijay Zodiak Merger (amounting to €43.2 million) as well as the consolidation of Castaway, L’Officina and DRY Media in Italy. This increase was also due to the organic growth of our business, which had a net positive impact of €67.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly in the United States with new programs sold to Netflix (Bill Nye) or Facebook Watch (Ball in the Family) and in France with a new daily game show sold to France Télévisions “Tout le monde a son mot à dire.” This increase was partly offset by an adverse foreign exchange impact for €9.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly on the EUR/GBP and EUR/USD foreign exchange rates. _Operating Expenses, External Expenses and Staff Costs_ Operating expenses, external expenses and staff costs increased by €116.8 million, or 19.2%, from €608.9 million, or 83.8% of revenues, for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €725.7 million, or 85.7% of revenues, for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to growth of our business in connection with the increase in revenues described above, the full-year impact of the integration of Zodiak and to an increase in expenses related to our long-term incentive plans for certain key managers of the Group, which we implemented in 2017 (see “Management—Remuneration and Other Benefits”). This increase was partially offset by the positive impact of costs savings related to synergies implemented in 2016 following the Banijay Zodiak Merger. _Depreciation and Amortization of Intangible and Tangible Assets_ Depreciation and amortization of intangible and tangible assets increased by €14.7 million, or 40.8%, from €36.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €50.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the impact of the Banijay Zodiak Merger (amounting to €8.1 million) and to the development of our scripted business, which led to higher depreciation of our production costs. _Current Impairment Losses and Provisions, Net of Reversals_ Current impairment losses and provisions, net of reversals, decreased by €7.4 million from a loss of €6.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to an income of €1.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the reversal of provisions related to loss-making contracts and bad debt for the year ended December 31, 2017, and to a change in the estimated future revenues from our existing catalogue of programs following the completion of the Banijay Zodiak Merger, which had an impact of €4.8 million on our current impairment losses for the year ended December 31, 2016, and did not recur in 2017. _Other Current Operating Income and Expenses_ Other current operating income and expenses decreased by €4.2 million from an income of €2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to an expense of €1.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the impact of the share of the profits before tax from Castaway due to ITV in the United Kingdom in 2017, as well as to showrunner costs incurred in the United States for our program Versailles in 2017. _Other Non-Current Operating Income (Expenses)_ Other non-current operating expenses decreased by €18.1 million, or 68.6%, from €26.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €8.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to non-current operating expenses in the year ended December 31, 2016, due to restructuring costs incurred in connection with the Banijay Zodiak Merger. _Interest Expenses_ Interest expenses increased by €9.4 million, or 65.6%, from €14.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €23.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to (i) the 133 ----- refinancing completed in February 2016 in connection with the Banijay Zodiak Merger, which resulted in higher interest expenses for the first half of 2017, (ii) the interest on the Existing Notes and Existing Senior Credit Facilities for the second half of 2017, and (iii) the amortization of the transaction costs of the refinancing in 2017. _Other Finance Income (Costs)_ Other finance income/costs decreased by €17.2 million from finance costs of €13.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to finance income of €3.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to (i) a positive net impact of €7.0 million in 2017 related to the refinancing of certain convertible bonds subscribed in February 2016 by a subsidiary of Vivendi, (ii) a positive variation in foreign exchange rates of €2.6 million and (iii) an impact of €2.8 million from a change in valuation of earn-out rights resulting from an update of our business plan and to the discount rate applied to such rights. _Income Taxes_ Income taxes increased by €17.4 million from an income of €2.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to an expense of €15.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the recognition in 2016 of carried-forward tax losses of the Zodiak and its subsidiaries following the Banijay Zodiak Merger. _Profit (Loss) for the Year_ Profit (loss) for the year increased by €2.8 million, or 12.7%, from €22.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €25.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the reasons described above.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes, notably, the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flow to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including, but not limited to, working capital needs, capital expenditures, debt service obligations, contractual obligations and acquisitions. Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis has been our generation of cash flow from operations and drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, non-recourse factoring agreements, production financings and other corporate liquidity resources. Following the Transactions, our principal source of liquidity is expected to be our cash flow from operations, as well as drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility, non-recourse factoring agreements, production financings and other corporate liquidity resources. Our liquidity requirements arise primarily to fund acquisitions, meet our debt service obligations, fund our working capital needs and, to a lesser extent, fund capital expenditures. Our ability to generate sufficient cash for our ongoing operations depends on our operating performance, which in turn depends, to some extent, on general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in “Risk Factors.” We believe that, based on our current level of operations as reflected in our results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2018, our cash flow from operating activities, cash on hand and the availability of borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility will be sufficient to fund our operations, capital expenditures and debt service for at least the next twelve months. However, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flow from operations to meet such financing needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to meet our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Notes, the Senior Facilities or on our other debt when due. If our cash flow from operating activities are lower than expected, we may be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms to us, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and our cost of capital depend on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial institutions and capital markets, restrictive covenants in our debt agreements and our general financial performance. On the Issue Date, we will have access to funds under the Revolving Credit Facility, the availability of which will be subject to certain conditions. Giving effect to the Refinancing only, the amount available under the Revolving Credit Facility is expected to be €75.0 million (equivalent), and giving further effect to the remainder of the Transactions, the amount available under the Revolving Credit Facility is expected to be €170.0 million 134 ----- (equivalent). We anticipate that we will be highly leveraged for the foreseeable future. Our high leverage may have important negative consequences for you. See “Risk Factors.” There are also limitations on our ability to obtain additional debt or equity financing. See “Description of Other Indebtedness and Financing _Arrangements.” In addition, any additional indebtedness that we do incur could reduce the amount of our cash_ flow available to make payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby, and increase our leverage.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow from operating activities decreased by €17.7 million, or 18.3%, from a cash inflow of €96.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to a cash inflow of €78.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the seasonality of our productions, in particular following the growth in our scripted business in the Nordic Countries, with shows expected to be delivered in the last quarter of 2019, partly offset by a positive impact related to the first application of IFRS 16 of €10.5 million. Net cash flow from operating activities increased by €57.3 million, or 75.1%, from a cash inflow of €76.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to a cash inflow of €133.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the positive effect of the organic growth of our business and of change in working capital driven by improvement in working capital requirements due to a favorable timing of invoicing and the continuous implementation of a disciplined cash collection approach at the level of our operating subsidiaries. This increase was partly offset by the impact of non-recurring items, such as the cancellation of season 19 of Koh Lanta in France. Net cash flow from operating activities decreased by €26.0 million, or 25.4%, from a cash inflow of €102.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to a cash inflow of €76.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the negative effect of change in working capital driven by the deliveries of capital intensive scripted productions as well as certain tax credits not yet cashed in and growth in our business. This decrease was also due to a non-recurring cash outflow related to payments made in connection with certain incentive plans, which were partially reinvested in equity by the beneficiaries of the Group.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow used in investing activities decreased by €47.6 million, or 52.8%, from an outflow of €90.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to an outflow of €42.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to (i) lower earn-out payments in the nine months ended September 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2018, as well as (ii) the seasonality of our scripted productions. 135 ----- Net cash flow used in investing activities decreased by €76.3 million, or 51.6%, from a cash outflow of €148.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to a cash outflow of €71.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the consideration paid for the Castaway Acquisition in 2017, and the positive impact of the consolidated cash from Brainpool in 2018, partly offset by the schedule of earn-out payments in 2018 and higher investments related to the timing of scripted productions. Net cash flow used in investing activities increased by €69.8 million, or 89.3%, from a cash outflow of €78.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to a cash outflow of €148.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the consideration paid for the Castaway Acquisition in 2017, partly offset by lower investments related to the timing of scripted productions.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flow from (used in) Financing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow used in financing activities increased by €21.5 million, or 74.4% from an outflow of €28.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to an outflow of €50.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to (i) the dividends paid to LDH and Vivendi (€12.1 million) and (ii) the negative impact of IFRS 16 on the treatment of rental payments for €10.5 million. Net cash flow from financing activities decreased by €126.9 million, from a cash inflow of €68.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to a cash outflow of €58.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the impact of the refinancing in July 2017. Net cash flow from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018, is primarily due to the reimbursement of the shareholder loan granted in 2017 by Banijay Group Holding for €26.2 million, the payment of the first instalment on the Existing Senior Term Loan (€3.8 million), the payment of financial interests related to the new financial structure for €17.1 million, the reimbursement of credit lines and dividends paid. Net cash flow from financing activities increased by €52.4 million, from a cash inflow of €15.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to a cash inflow of €68.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. Net cash flow from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2017, is primarily due to the refinancing of our indebtedness following the Banijay Zodiak Merger through the issuance of the Existing Notes (€365.0 million) and the Existing Senior Term Loan (€60.0 million euro-equivalent), an increase in share capital in connection with the reinvestment of certain key managers (€8.1 million) partly offset by the repayment of a part of a shareholder loan to Banijay Group Holding for €39.1 million, the payment of €12.5 million of transaction costs related to the refinancing and the payment of financial interests for €10.2 million (of which €4.1 million related to a former ORAN (obligation remboursable en actions ou en numéraire)). Net cash flow from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2016, is primarily related to the refinancing of our indebtedness before the Banijay Zodiak Merger with the issuance of senior credit facilities (€300 million) and former ORANs (obligation remboursable en actions ou en numéraire) (€100 million), as well as an increase in share capital subscribed by Vivendi (€100 million) partly offset by the exit of certain minority shareholders of the Group (€192.3 million).

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: 136 ----- (1) The difference between total working capital does not correspond to the change in working capital presented in our cash flow statement due to (i) the current portion of earn-outs and put option liabilities included in the above working capital, (ii) certain items included in the change in working capital in our cash flow statement but not our balance sheet and (iii) to non-cash items having an impact on working capital for the period, such as change in consolidation scope and foreign exchange impact. Changes in working capital are impacted by the timing of production and program delivery and by the production of scripted and non-scripted programs. Because non-scripted programs are mainly produced in less than a year, working capital requirements related to our non-scripted business is mainly impacted by fluctuations in the number of non-scripted programs we produce. We may record cut-off impacts related to non-scripted activity at the end of each year if some large-scale programs are still under production. On the other hand, scripted productions have longer production cycles, usually over two years, and higher working capital requirements. Our working capital related to scripted activity can be impacted significantly by cut-off issues at the end of the year. In addition, we sometimes finance a large part of our scripted programs through tax credits or subsidies paid after the delivery of the program, which has an impact on our working capital for the year during which we produce the program but have not yet delivered it.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have implemented an automated cash pool for our subsidiaries. The master account holders are the Senior Notes Issuer and Senior Secured Notes Issuer and all other members are connected via their local banks to the cash pool. Local positive bank balances are transferred automatically to the master account holders at the end of each bank working day and bank balances at local banks are automatically balanced by the master account holders at the end of the bank working day. As needed, we also have other credit lines, including, following consummation of the Transactions, under the Revolving Credit Facility, available for utilization.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Capital expenditures for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 amounted to €19.2 million, compared to €39.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018. This decrease was mainly related to the seasonality of our scripted productions, mainly in the Nordic Countries. Our capital expenditures for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 consisted primarily of (i) scripted production costs, mainly in the Nordic Countries, of €9.8 million, (ii) intellectual property rights of €3.6 million and (iii) investments in technical equipment of €5.8 million. Capital expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to €52.1 million, compared to €47.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. Our capital expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2018, consisted of (i) production costs for scripted programs of €34.0 million, (ii) investments in intellectual property rights of €8.9 million and (iii) investments in technical equipment of €9.2 million. Capital expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2017 amounted to €47.2 million, compared to €56.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016. Our capital expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2017, consisted of (i) production costs for scripted programs of €29.1 million, (ii) investments in intellectual property rights of €11.3 million and (iii) investments in technical equipment of €6.8 million. Capital expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2016 amounted to €56.3 million and consisted of (i) production costs for scripted programs of €37.6 million, (ii) investments in intellectual property rights of €10.1 million and (iii) investments in technical equipment of €8.6 million. For the year ending December 31, 2019, we expect to incur capital expenditures in the amount of approximately €40 million, consisting primarily of scripted production costs and investments in technical 137 ----- equipment. Endemol Shine does not present production costs and investments in intellectual property rights as part of capital expenditures. See “Endemol Shine’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures.” After giving effect to the Transactions, we expect_ to incur capital expenditures in the amount of approximately €17 million for the year ending December 31, 2020, excluding scripted production costs and consisting primarily of investments in technical equipment. We plan to fund our future capital expenditures with cash from operating activities.

(4) Represents cash payments due under existing lease liabilities that are expected to remain outstanding following the completion of the Refinancing, of which €68.9 million resulted from the application of IFRS 16. See “Capitalization” and “Description of Other _Indebtedness and Financing Arrangements—Other Financing Arrangements.”_ (5) Represents cash payments due under liabilities for earn-outs and put option liabilities that are expected to remain outstanding following the completion of the Refinancing. In connection with the acquisition of companies in various jurisdictions, we have entered into, and will continue to enter into, earn-outs or put option agreements with certain key managers and creative talents of these companies, when they are the sellers of such companies, to incentivize them to continue to work with us following the relevant acquisition. Although we do not use a standard earn-out agreement across all such acquisitions, payments pursuant to such earn-outs are generally contingent and are calculated based on the performance of the acquired company over a specified time period following the acquisition. This period also corresponds to an exclusivity period during which key managers or creative talent agree to work exclusively for our Group. We usually pay a portion of the acquisition purchase price on the acquisition completion date and the remaining portion in installments over the exclusivity period, which vary based on the performance of the acquired company. The key commercial points involved in negotiating these earn-out agreements are the performance metric on which we base the contingent payments, the establishment of the earn-out period (usually in an eight-year range), and the timing and the structure of the contingent payments. As of September 30, 2019, we had €60.9 million of other long-term and other current liabilities to reflect earn-outs and put option agreements that remain outstanding. We expect approximately €3 million will be reinvested by one of our key managers in 2020. 138 ----- _Following the Transactions_ The following table identifies our contractual obligations and the principal payments we would have been obligated to make as of September 30, 2019, giving effect to the Transactions.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Represents the aggregate principal amount of the Euro Senior Secured Notes offered hereby. If the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, the Euro Senior Secured Notes will remain outstanding. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Endemol Shine _Acquisition—The Euro Senior Secured Notes are not subject to a special mandatory redemption and will remain outstanding even if the Endemol Shine Acquisition is not consummated, in which case the amount available under the Revolving Credit Facility would be limited and such facility will be automatically designated as a super senior liability in accordance with, and subject to, the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement.”_ (2) Represents the euro-equivalent of the aggregate principal amount of the Dollar Senior Secured Notes offered hereby. See “The Transactions.” (5) As of September 30, 2019, and after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had €44.6 million (equivalent) outstanding under the Borrowing Base Facility. These credit facilities include factoring or assignment of receivables or future receivables to finance the development, production and operation of our programs, audiovisual or digital content.
