(8) Represents cash payments due under existing lease liabilities that are expected to remain outstanding following the completion of the Refinancing, of which €68.9 million resulted from the application of IFRS 16 for Banijay and €154.3 million resulted from the application of IFRS 16 for Endemol Shine. See “Capitalization” and “Description of Other Indebtedness and Financing Arrangements— _Other Financing Arrangements.”_ (9) Represents cash payments due under liabilities for earn-outs and put option liabilities, with respect to Banijay, and liabilities for earn-outs and put options recorded on balance sheet with respect to Endemol Shine, that are expected to remain outstanding following the completion of the Transactions (excluding cash payments due under liabilities for earn-outs and put option liabilities resulting from the Bear Grylls Acquisition). In connection with the acquisition of companies in various jurisdictions, we have entered into, and will continue to enter into, earn-outs or put option agreements with certain key managers and creative talents of these companies, when they are the sellers of such companies, to incentivize them to continue to work with us following the relevant acquisition. Although we do not use a standard earn-out agreement across all such acquisitions, payments pursuant to such earn-outs are generally contingent and are calculated based on the performance of the acquired company over a specified time period following the acquisition. This period also corresponds to an exclusivity period during which key managers or creative talent agree to work exclusively for our Group. We usually pay a portion of the acquisition purchase price on the acquisition completion date and the remaining portion in installments over the exclusivity period, which vary based on the performance of the acquired company. The key commercial points involved in negotiating these earn-out agreements are the performance metric on which we base the contingent payments, the establishment of the earn-out period (usually in an eight-year range), and the timing and the structure of the contingent payments. 139 -----

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are party to various customary off balance sheet arrangements. See note 5.9 to the Audited Banijay Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Because of the international nature of our operations, we are exposed to currency risks with respect to various currencies. Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flow of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates relates primarily to our operating activities (when revenues or expense is denominated in a different currency from our presentation currency). In addition, operating companies may, under strict conditions, opt for hedging currency risks from firm commitments and forecasted transactions. The currencies giving rise to these risks are primarily the euro, the U.S. dollar and pound sterling. As of December 31, 2018, sales in entities located in the United States represented 16.0% of our revenues. A decrease of 5% or an increase of 5% of the U.S. dollars foreign exchange rate would have an impact on the consolidated revenues of €(6.4) million and €7.1 million, respectively. As of December 31, 2018, sales in entities located in the United Kingdom represented 12.0% of our revenues. A decrease of 5% or an increase of 5% of the pound sterling foreign exchange rate would have an impact on the consolidated revenues of €(4.7) million and €5.2 million, respectively. The risks arising from currency exposures are regularly reviewed and hedged when appropriate. We use flexible forward contracts to hedge the exposure to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates. At year end, these instruments had remaining maturities of less than one year. We have identified three types of foreign currency risks.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We face currency risk due to the translation of the functional currency of certain of our divisions, which differs from our reporting currency. Translational exposure does not give rise to an immediate cash expense or income, but we nevertheless closely monitor our translational exposure.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flow of financial instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. Our interest rate risk policy is aimed at minimizing the interest rate risks associated with our financing and thus at the same time optimizing the net interest costs. This policy translates into a certain desired profile of fixed-interest and floating-interest positions, including cash and cash equivalents.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk represents the accounting loss if one of our counterparties fails to perform in accordance with the terms of our agreements. Credit risk is related to financial instruments such as cash and cash equivalents, receivables and derivative financial instruments. As part of our risk management, we evaluate the credit of potential counterparties to derivative financial transactions or cash transactions before we agree to enter into a commercial relationship. We manage our credit risk according to policies, procedures and controls determined by us regarding the credit risk management of our customers. We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities (primarily for trade receivables) and from our financing activities, including deposits with banks and financial institutions, foreign exchange transactions and other financial instruments. We do not believe that we have a significantly concentrated exposure to credit risk because we have a large number of customers and no single broadcasting group generated more than 10.1% of our production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018. In order to reduce our credit risk, our operating companies purchase credit insurance where appropriate, and in some cases, demand parent company guarantees or other security interests. To further mitigate our credit risk, our operating companies may sell part of their receivables on a nonrecourse basis. We periodically analyze the balances of each major customer in order to determine the need for provisions or impairment. 140 -----

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the management of currency and interest rate risks, liquidity management represents a key element of our financial management. Liquidity risk arises from our potential inability to meet our financial obligations to our suppliers and financing providers. The goal of liquidity management is to secure our ability to service our commitments and to make payments when required. Our liquidity situation is closely monitored and rolling forecasts of cash flow and cash holdings are prepared regularly. We operate several legal entities in several countries. To address the liquidity risk, we have put in place cash pooling agreements in Europe, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Nordic Countries. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Cash Pooling Arrangements.” We also monitor with high frequency our cash balances and cash forecasts. When required, additional debt or equity-based money transfers between our entities are implemented. We also manage financial liabilities and related derivative contracts on the basis of the remaining contractual maturities of these instruments.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk represents the risk that our income and expenses, future cash flow or fair value of financial instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market prices. Market risk comprises currency risk, interest rates risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. Our financial policy is aimed at minimizing the effects of fluctuations in currency exchange and interest rates on its results in the short-term and following market rates in the long term.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations are accounted when using the acquisition method. The cost of an acquisition is measured as the aggregate of the consideration transferred, measured on the acquisition date, at fair value, and the amount of any non-controlling interest in the target. For each business combination, the acquirer measures the non-controlling interest in the target either at fair value or at the proportionate share of the target’s identifiable net assets. Acquisition costs incurred are expensed. When we acquire a business, we assess the financial assets and liabilities assumed for appropriate classification and designation in accordance with the contractual terms, economic circumstances and pertinent conditions as of the acquisition date. This includes the separation of embedded derivatives in host contracts by the target. If the business combination is achieved in stages, the acquisition date fair value of the acquirer’s previously held equity interest in the target is remeasured to fair value as of the acquisition date through profit and loss. Any contingent consideration to be transferred by the acquirer will be recognized at fair value at the acquisition date. Subsequent changes to the fair value of the contingent consideration which is deemed to be an asset or liability will be recognized either in profit or loss or as change to other comprehensive income. If the contingent consideration is classified as equity, it will not be remeasured until it is finally settled within equity. Goodwill is initially measured at cost, being the excess of the consideration transferred over our net identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed. If this consideration is lower than the fair value of the net assets of the subsidiary acquired, the difference is recognized in profit or loss. After initial recognition, goodwill is measured at cost less any accumulated impairment losses. For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill acquired in a business combination is, from the acquisition date, allocated to each of our CGUs that are expected to benefit from the combination, irrespective of whether other assets or liabilities of the target are assigned to those units. Where goodwill forms part of a CGU and part of the operation within that unit is disposed of, the goodwill associated with the operation disposed of is included in the carrying amount of the operation when determining the gain or loss on disposal of the operation. Goodwill disposed of in this circumstance is measured based on the relative values of the operation disposed of and the portion of the CGU retained.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our presentation currency is the euro. Each entity of the Group records transactions and items in the statement of financial position in its functional currency. Transactions denominated in a currency other than the functional currency are recorded at the spot exchange rates prevailing on the date of the transactions. 141 ----- Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in a currency other than the functional currency of the entity are translated at the closing rates. Exchange differences resulting from the settlement of these transactions and from the translation of monetary items are recognized in the income statement. Non-monetary assets denominated in a currency other than the functional currency continue to be translated against the rate at initial recognition and will not result in exchange differences. On combination, the statement of financial position of subsidiaries whose functional currency is not the euro are translated into euro at the closing rate. The consolidated statements of comprehensive income of these entities are translated into euro at the average rates for the relevant period. Exchange differences arising from the translation of the net investment in entities with a functional currency other than the euro are recorded through other comprehensive income in the translation reserve. The same applies to exchange differences arising from borrowings and other financial instruments in so far as they hedge the currency risk related to the net investment. On disposal of an entity with a functional currency other than the euro, the cumulative exchange differences relating to the translation of the net investment are recognized in the income statement.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenues are recognized to the extent that it is probable that the economic benefits will flow to the Group and the revenues can be reliably estimated. Revenues are measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of rebates, pay-backs, grants, subsidies and co-producers’ contributions.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Production revenues are recognized when programs are delivered to the customer. Standard criteria to establish revenue recognition are: (i) usually, a customer’s acknowledgement of receipt (such as a delivery notice signed or approved by the customer); (ii) the delivery of a certain number of programs; or (iii) the expiration of the period stated in the contract to reject or return the product. In the event of the partial delivery of the same program over several periods of time (such as for a series), revenues, costs and margins are recognized according to the time of such partial deliveries. Production revenues are booked net of grants, subsidies and co-producers’ contributions.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Distribution Revenues (From the Sale of Programs)
Subsubsection Text: Distribution revenues are recognized when the rights are transferred to the customer: (i) on the basis of a signed contract or a deal memo; (ii) when the related rights are opened; and (iii) for the full revenues (revenues are not spread over the licensing period), as it is an access to right.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Revenues from Other Rights and Services
Subsubsection Text: Other rights and services include merchandising, music rights, other ancillary revenues and digital services. Merchandising revenues are recognized when the rights are transferred to the customer: (i) on the basis of a signed contract or a deal memo; (ii) when the licensing period begins; and (iii) for the full revenues (revenues are not spread over the licensing period). Minimum guarantees are recognized as revenues when the above criteria are met. Further payments are recognized as revenues when received. 142 ----- Revenues from music rights are recognized as revenues when received. Revenues and costs related to the rendering of services are recognized on completion of the service rendered as long as they can be estimated reliably. A service can be considered delivered when the milestones specified in the contract have been reached. However, if the contract specifies and schedules several completion milestones, then revenues and costs can be recognized partially according to the defined completion milestones. For practical reasons, when services are performed by an undetermined series of actions over a specified period of time, revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the specified period, unless there is some evidence that some other method better represents the stage of completion (as described above). When the outcome of the transaction cannot be estimated reliably, revenues shall be recognized only to the extent of the expenses recognized.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: When we act as an agent rather than as a principal in a transaction, the revenues recognized is the net amount of commission earned by us.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Grants and subsidies are recognized when there is reasonable assurance that the grant will be received and all attached conditions will be fully complied with. Grants and subsidies that are strictly related to the financing of a given program are deducted from production costs. When they relate to an asset, grants and subsidies are directly deducted from the carrying amount of the asset and released to the amortization and depreciation calculated on the net amount over the useful life of the asset. All other grants and subsidies, such as government grants or income tax credits such as the Crédit d’impôt _cinéma in France, are recognized as “Other operating income” when granted._

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: An asset (liability) is classified as current when it is expected to be realized (settled) within twelve months after the end of the reporting period, with the exception of deferred taxes which are shown as non-current assets and liabilities.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: When there are indications that the carrying amount of a non-current asset (whether intangible or tangible asset) may exceed the estimated recoverable amount (the higher between its value in use and its fair value less costs to sell), the possible existence of an impairment loss is investigated. If an asset does not generate sufficient independent cash flow, the recoverable amount is determined for the CGUs to which the asset belongs. In assessing the value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market interest rates and the risks specific to the asset. All financial assets are reviewed for impairment. If there is objective evidence of impairment as a result of one or more events after initial recognition, an impairment loss is recognized in the income statement. The annual impairment tests are performed at year end. The recoverable amount of the CGUs concerned is based on a value-in-use calculation. The model is based on a four-year forecast of discounted cash flows, plus a terminal value. The net discounted cash flows are calculated before tax. Intangible assets are recorded at cost. As for audiovisual rights, they are depreciated on an accelerated basis following the decline in the net value of the asset following its initial broadcast. Other intangible and tangible assets are depreciated on a straight-line basis over the useful lives of the assets. The management of the Group uses its experience to estimate the remaining useful life and residual value of an asset. When the recoverable amount of a non-current asset is less than its carrying amount, the carrying amount is impaired to its recoverable amount and an impairment charge is recognized in the income statement. An impairment loss is reversed when there has been a change in estimate that is relevant for the determination of the asset’s recoverable amount since the last impairment loss was recognized. 143 ----- The key assumptions in the cash flow projections relate to the market growth for the CGUs and the related revenues projections. The growth assumptions for these cash generating units are based on the growth of the global and regional markets for our products and services. The terminal value for the period after four years is determined with the assumption of a 2.0% growth rate.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Intangible assets include: (i) format rights acquired from a third party or through business combinations; (ii) our portfolio of programs, whether acquired or internally developed, for which we have the legal right to distribute and to receive revenues from the distribution of these programs; (iii) production contracts or customer contracts, acquired through business combinations, for the production of television programs; (iv) costs incurred for scripted productions, for which the group retains the intellectual property and expects material revenue, that are not yet finalized and have not been delivered to the customer; and (v) other intangible assets, such as rights to the film adaptation of books or software. _Initial Recognition_ The initial recognition of intangible assets is at cost, except for those acquired in a business combination, which are recognized at fair value. _Depreciation and Amortization_ Following initial recognition, intangible assets are carried at cost less any accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses. Audiovisual rights are considered to have a definite useful life. Intangible assets should be depreciated based on the consumption of the associated economic benefits and on the remaining useful life of the asset. Therefore, audiovisual rights are depreciated on an accelerated basis following the decline in the net value of the asset after its initial broadcast. Intangible assets acquired in a business combination are depreciated as follows: - catalogue: on a straight-line basis over a ten-year period; and - customer contracts: on a straight-line basis over the duration of the contract. The depreciation period and the amortization method are reviewed at least once per year, generally at the end of the financial year. Changes in the expected useful life or the expected projections of economic benefits of the asset are accounted for by changing the depreciation period or method, as appropriate, and are treated as changes in accounting estimates. Property, plant and equipment are recorded at their acquisition cost, less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis over the useful life of such fixed assets. The residual value, the useful life and depreciation methods of the fixed assets are reviewed and adjusted, if necessary, at the end of each financial year.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Leases are recognized by the lessee as an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and as a financial liability for lease payments. At the inception of a lease contract, a lease liability is recognized to make lease payments and right-of-use assets representing the right to use the underlying assets. Lease liabilities are measured at the present value of lease payments to be made over the lease term. Right-of-use of leases are amortized over the lease’s duration. In the income statement, depreciation and amortization is recognized as the counterpart of the asset amortization and financial interest is recognized as the counterpart of the finance lease discounting effect. In the cash flow statement presentation, actual lease payments are classified as payments of lease liability within financing activities. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases that are not booked as an asset or a financial liability, which are booked as external expenses in the income statement and their related cash flows are classified in cash generated from operating activities. 144 -----

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following are certain of the key accounting policies applied by us in preparing our consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: In the process of applying our accounting policies, our management has made the following judgments, which have the most significant effect on the amounts recognized in our consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: Revenues from the sale of goods is recognized when the group has substantially transferred the control over the goods sold to the customer.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax assets related to compensating tax losses are recognized as long as it is probable that we will generate enough profit for tax purposes in order to set off these deferred tax assets. In order to determine the value of the deferred tax assets arising from tax losses compensating, a considerable degree of management assessment is required regarding the probable timing and level of the future taxable profits, combined with future fiscal planning strategies.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: The key assumptions concerning the future and other key sources of estimates that have a significant risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of revenues, costs, assets and liabilities in the year ended December 31, 2018, are described in “Main estimates and accounting assumptions” in Note 5.3.2 of the Audited Banijay Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. We base our assumptions and estimates on parameters available when the consolidated financial statements were prepared. Existing circumstances and assumptions about future developments, however, may change due to market changes or circumstances arising beyond our control. Such changes are reflected in the assumptions when they occur.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: We have granted share subscription rights, purchase options, phantom shares and free shares to certain employees of the Group under various incentive plans. In particular, we entered into new incentive agreements with certain key employees in 2017, which consist of phantom shares and free shares depending on the employee. The amounts due under these incentive plans depend on certain assumptions with respect to future profits of the Group or future profits of the relevant subsidiaries, as well as on the equity value of the Group (using a fair market value approach based on the expected value creation of the Group, the volatility of the industry and an appropriate discount rate).

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Title: Earn-out Payments / Put Option Rights in Favor of Minority Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: Following external growth transactions, we may commit to pay former or minority shareholders either earnouts or an acquisition price adjustment pursuant to put options on their remaining shareholdings, based on prices depending on future profits. Related debts are accounted for in the balance sheet at their present value. We estimate these debts using assumptions on future profits and calculate scheduled cash outflows using a discount rate.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: Uncertainties exist with respect to the interpretation of complex tax regulations, changes in tax laws, and the amount and timing of future taxable income. Given the wide range of international business relationships and the long-term nature and complexity of existing contractual agreements, differences arising between the actual results and the assumptions made, or future changes to such assumptions, could necessitate future adjustments to tax income and expense already recorded. We establish provisions, based on reasonable estimates, for possible consequences of audits by the tax authorities of the respective countries in which it operates. The amount of such provisions is based on various factors, such as experience of previous tax audits and differing interpretations of tax regulations by the taxable entity and the responsible tax authority. Such differences of interpretation may arise on a wide variety of issues depending on the conditions prevailing in the respective domicile of our companies. 145 ----- Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses to the extent that it is probable that taxable profit will be available against which the losses can be utilized. Significant management judgment is required to determine the amount of deferred tax assets that can be recognized, based upon the likely timing and the level of future taxable profits together with future tax planning strategies.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Judgments, Estimates and Assumptions
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires our management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of revenues, expenses, assets and liabilities, the accompanying disclosures, and the disclosure of contingent liabilities. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could result in outcomes that require a material adjustment to the carrying amount of the asset or liability affected in future periods.

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For information regarding recent and pending changes to our accounting policies, see “Standard and interpretations that are not yet effective have not been applied by anticipation by the group” in Note 5.3 of the Audited Banijay Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. 146 -----

Section Title: BANIJAY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion of our financial condition and results of operations in the periods set forth below, based on data extracted from the financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer as discussed under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” You should read this discussion in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included under “Selected Historical Financial Information,” and our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The following presentation and analysis contain forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, involve risks and uncertainties. For the reasons explained under “Disclosure Regarding Forward- Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this offering memorandum, our future results may differ materially from those expected or implied in these forward-looking statements._

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Endemol Shine’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine’s primary customers are broadcasters and digital platforms. The number of broadcasters has increased in recent years, which has increased the number of customers available to purchase Endemol Shine’s programs and therefore impacts its revenues. At the same time, broadcasters are facing increasing competition from companies that deliver video content over the internet. With the growth of OTT programming, viewers’ video content consumption preferences may shift away from broadcasters and diverge from existing viewing habits. Younger viewers have already started to shift toward using mobile devices or computers rather than televisions. As a result, many of Endemol Shine’s existing and potential customers are compelled to find new original formats and programs to deliver content to viewers over the internet. Endemol Shine expects this pressure to increase as digital platforms such as Netflix and Amazon Prime Video continue to grow, and expects to benefit from this customer diversification. Endemol Shine has historical relationships with many broadcasters and has already developed strong commercial relationships with digital platforms. OTT companies are also increasingly seeking out non-scripted content, a genre in which Endemol Shine has strong production know-how. In addition, Endemol Shine is increasingly focusing on formats or programs which, once produced for a local market, can be sold or licensed internationally to customers in other markets, such as broadcasters or digital platforms (including OTT platforms). Such increased diversification in customers and the resulting opportunities for distribution revenues has historically and will likely continue to impact Endemol Shine’s results of operations.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Endemol Shine’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Changes in Endemol Shine’s cost structure impact its results of operations from period to period. For example, scripted programs generally require a longer and more extensive development and production process, incurring higher costs and consequently generating lower margins than non-scripted programs. Endemol Shine is continuously focused on improving the cost efficiencies within the production process. To support this goal, Endemol Shine has implemented a flexible organization whereby shows are mainly produced by freelancers with minimal investments in fixed assets. Furthermore, Endemol Shine does not in principle start any production which is not fully funded and committed, thereby limiting its risks of not recovering production costs incurred. One of Endemol Shine’s key strategic priorities for managing its cost structure has been to improve its product mix of scripted and non-scripted programs. By selectively increasing its production of non-scripted programs with a constant focus on efficiency in the production of shows, Endemol Shine has decreased its overall production costs and simultaneously driven margins in its core production business. Endemol Shine believes these initiatives have contributed to EBITDA growth and increased operating cash flows during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, and contributed to its margin protection in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. 147 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Endemol Shine’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine typically recognizes revenues from the sale of a program to a broadcaster or digital platform at the time of the program’s delivery to that broadcaster, except where the transfer of performance obligations under the contract occurs before or after delivery. This creates a mismatch between the revenue amounts Endemol Shine actually receives in connection with such sale and the revenues recognized in its financial statements. For example, Endemol Shine receives production advances from broadcasters before production is complete and these advances are not recognized in its revenues until the final delivery of the program. As a result, Endemol Shine’s revenues from period to period may fluctuate.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Endemol Shine’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the broadcasting schedules of traditional television networks and the fact that broadcasters that typically premiere shows in the second half of the year, Endemol Shine generally has stronger sales in the third and fourth quarters of the year. To mitigate the seasonal impact of typical broadcasting schedules on its revenues, Endemol Shine also distributes its portfolio of television program titles to SVOD platforms, such as Amazon, Apple and Netflix, which provide Endemol Shine a fixed license fee for distribution of its titles to these platforms.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Endemol Shine’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine’s results of operations are impacted by several factors, including factors that influence the global television and digital content industry as a whole. Such factors primarily include the production and success of new formats and new programs, diversification of customers, distribution and secondary revenue generation and the general economic conditions in Endemol Shine’s markets. For a description of these factors, see the corresponding discussion of key factors influencing Banijay at “Banijay’s Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations.”_ Set forth below is a description of the other key factors that affected Endemol Shine’s results of operations during the periods presented.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Endemol Shine’s Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine has applied the following standards and amendments for the first time for their reporting period commencing January 1, 2019:

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Endemol Shine’s Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 16 replaced IAS 17 Leases and became effective on January 1, 2019. Under the new lease standard, assets leased by Endemol Shine are being recognized in the statement of financial position with a corresponding lease liability. Endemol Shine adopted IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach with the date of initial application of January 1, 2019, which impacts the comparability of its financial results between periods. The comparative figures were not required to be, and have not been, restated. Lease contracts that have an impact on Endemol Shine’s condensed consolidated interim financial statements relate to office buildings, car fleet, studios, production related leases and office equipment. The effect of the first application of IFRS 16 had no impact on Endemol Shine’s revenue, while operating result was positively impacted by €2.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This was caused by the operating lease expenses in the amount of €20.6 million being replaced by depreciation in the amount of €18.3 million and interest expenses amounting to €3.5 million, of which the latter is not recognized in operating result. In addition, the cash flow from operating activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, was positively impacted in an amount of €20.6 million, as the operating lease expenses are classified as cash outflow used in financing activities. Had we adopted IFRS 16 on January 1, 2018, we estimate that, based on our leases as of January 1, 2019, the implementation of IFRS 16 would have resulted in an increase of approximately €27 million in EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2018. This information may not be indicative of the impact of the first application of IFRS 16 on our right-of-use assets, lease liabilities and EBITDA for any past or future period. Endemol Shine recognized right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for those leases previously classified as operating leases, except for short-term leases and leases of low-value assets. Lease liabilities were recognized based on the present value of the remaining lease payments and discounted using the incremental borrowing rate at the date of initial application. The lease payments include (in-substance) fixed payments (less any lease incentives), variable lease payments that depend on an index or a rate, and amounts expected to be paid under residual value guarantees. The lease payments also include the exercise price of a purchase option reasonably certain to be exercised by Endemol Shine and payments of penalties for terminating a lease, if the lease term reflects Endemol Shine exercising the option to terminate. Endemol Shine recognizes right-of-use assets at the commencement date of the lease (i.e., the date the underlying asset is available for use). Right-of-use assets are measured at cost, less any accumulated depreciation and impairment losses, and adjusted for any remeasurement of lease liabilities. The cost of right-of-use assets includes the amount of lease liabilities recognized, initial direct costs incurred, and lease payments made at or before the commencement date less any lease incentives received. Unless Endemol Shine is reasonably certain to obtain ownership of the leased asset at the end of the lease term, the recognized right-of-use assets are depreciated on a straight-line basis over the shorter of its estimated useful life and the lease term. Right-of-use assets are subject to impairment under IAS 36. 148 ----- At the commencement date of the lease, Endemol Shine recognizes lease liabilities measured at the present value of lease payments to be made over the lease term. The lease payments include (in substance) fixed payments (less any lease incentives), variable lease payments that depend on an index or a rate, and amounts expected to be paid under residual value guarantees. The lease payments also include the exercise price of a purchase option reasonably certain to be exercised by Endemol Shine and payments of penalties for terminating a lease, if the lease term reflects Endemol Shine exercising the option to terminate. After the commencement date, the amount of lease liabilities is increased to reflect the accretion of interest and reduced for the lease payments made. In addition, the carrying amount of lease liabilities is remeasured if there is a modification, a change in the lease term, a change in the in-substance fixed lease payments or a change in the assessment to purchase the underlying asset. Endemol Shine applies the short-term lease recognition exemption to its short-term leases (i.e., those leases that have a lease term of twelve months or less from the commencement date and do not contain a purchase option). It also applies the lease of low-value assets recognition exemption to leases of office equipment that are considered of low value. Lease payments on short-term leases and leases of low-value assets are recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the lease term. Endemol Shine determines the lease term as the non-cancellable term of the lease, together with any periods covered by an option to extend the lease if it is reasonably certain to be exercised, or any periods covered by an option to terminate the lease, if it is reasonably certain not to be exercised. When determining the lease term, Endemol Shine considers all relevant facts and circumstances that create an economic incentive to exercise an extension option, or not to exercise a termination option. These circumstances include Endemol Shine’s strategic plans, the industrial footprint of Endemol Shine and the importance of the asset to Endemol Shine’s operations.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Endemol Shine’s Financial Statements
Subsubsection Title: IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine has adopted IFRS 15 from January 1, 2018, which resulted in changes in accounting policies and adjustments to the amounts recognized in the consolidated financial statements and thus impacts the comparability of its financial results between periods. The new accounting policies are set out in Note 2 to the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018 included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. In accordance with the transition provisions of IFRS 15, Endemol Shine has adopted the modified retrospective approach, as a result of which the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 15 is recorded as an adjustment to the opening balance as at January 1, 2018. As of January 1, 2018, the adjustment resulting from the transition to IFRS 15 on retained earnings was €6.7 million, an €8.0 million decrease in revenue and a €1.3 million increase in deferred tax liability. Endemol Shine applied the requirements of the new standard only to contracts that were not complete at January 1, 2018. Application of the new revenue recognition standard has no effect on the cash flows that Endemol Shine expects to receive. No other practical expedients were applied for the adoption of IFRS 15. The significant changes from IAS 18/IAS 11 to IFRS 15 are: - Production revenue is recognized on an output method (per program or milestone reached) rather than a percentage of completion method under IAS 11; and - Minimum guarantees are recognized at a point in time as opposed to over time under IAS 18.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Endemol Shine’s Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine has adopted IFRS 9 retrospectively, with an initial application as of January 1, 2018. The comparative figures were not required to be, and have not been, restated. Therefore, the cumulative impact of the adoption is recognized in retained earnings as of January 1, 2018. Under IFRS 9, the classification and measurement requirements have no material impact on Endemol Shine’s financial statements. Considering the nature of the financial instruments Endemol Shine currently holds (under assets and liabilities), there is no change to current valuations used (at amortized cost or at fair value) and Endemol Shine does not hold financial assets that require measurement at fair value with changes in fair value to be recorded through other comprehensive income under IFRS 9. 149 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Endemol Shine’s Financial Statements
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions, Joint Ventures, Divestments and Loss of Control
Subsubsection Text: _Acquisitions_ Endemol Shine completed a number of acquisitions of varying sizes during the periods presented, which impact the comparability of its financial results between periods. Since Endemol Shine consolidates the results of operations of each acquired business in its financial statements from the completion date of each acquisition, its historical financial periods are not directly comparable to one another. Following the closing date of an acquisition, the results of the acquired business are consolidated with the results of Endemol Shine, and are thereafter impacted by the revenues and expenses of the acquired business. In addition, Endemol Shine’s results are affected by other items such as its ability to realize synergies, including in sales and marketing, increases in profit margin due to its application of best practices and costs incurred to consolidate businesses. For example, in 2017, Endemol Shine acquired 100% of No Doubt Productions Inc. in the United States. No Doubt Productions Inc. owns post-production equipment facilities. This acquisition has been accounted for as a purchase of assets as of February 14, 2017. In 2016, Endemol Shine acquired 51% of Wild Mercury Limited in the United Kingdom. Wild Mercury is a scripted production company. In addition, in October 2016, Endemol Shine acquired the remaining 51% of Human Factor B.V., resulting in a 100% ownership in Human Factor B.V. Endemol Shine purchased the remaining shares (30%) in Kemna & Zonen B.V. during 2018 (subsequently renamed to Curtain Call Media B.V.), resulting in a 100% ownership. _Joint Ventures_ Endemol Shine completed a number of joint ventures of varying sizes during the periods presented, which impact the comparability of its financial results between periods. In 2017, Endemol Shine entered into an agreement with Boomdog, a leading independent production company in Mexico, to jointly develop opportunities both locally and in the fast-growing U.S. Spanish-language market. The transaction closed in January 2018. Endemol Shine contributed its Latino activities with an equity value of €2.5 million into the newly founded company Endemol Shine Boomdog LLC (“ES Boomdog Miami”). 49% of the shares in ES Boomdog Miami were sold to Boomdog US Inc., a 100% subsidiary of BDF Productions. In exchange BDF Productions gave up 51% in Endemol Shine Boomdog Holding S.A.P.I. de C.V. (“ES Boomdog Mexico”). ES Boomdog Mexico, a newly founded entity holds a 100% interest in Boomdog Films (now EndemolShine Boomdog S.A.P.I. de C.V.) and Boomdog Studios S.A.P.I. de C.V. The equity value of ES Boomdog Mexico, at the time of the transaction, was approximately zero, which resulted in the creation of goodwill amounting to €1.2 million. _Divestments_ Endemol Shine completed a number of selective divestments of varying sizes during the periods presented, which impact the comparability of its financial results between periods. In 2016, Endemol Shine sold its 90% interest in Endemol Shine Argentina and in Estudio Mayor in connection with refocusing its regional strategy. As of the closing date of a divestment, the results of operations and assets and liabilities attributable to the divested business are classified as discontinued operations, and Endemol Shine’s results are thereafter no longer impacted by the revenues and expenses of the divested business. Divestments may either allow Endemol Shine to generate profit therefrom, which would positively impact its cash position, or otherwise result in lower revenue, impairments of goodwill and a lower amount of total assets on Endemol Shine’s balance sheet. In 2017, Endemol Shine sold its 100% interest in Studios A/S Denmark and Studios AS Norway as part of refocusing its regional strategy and terminated its operations in Turkey and Chile. Endemol Shine also closed down its production activities in its non-core market of Singapore in 2018. Additionally, in 2018, Endemol Shine sold its 100% interest in Endemol Shine South Africa, to local management as part of refocusing on its key markets and its 51% share in Herr P in Germany to the original founder in exchange for an increase in the percentage of net income that Endemol Shine is entitled to receive in connection with its right to distribute for The Brain internationally. 150 ----- _Loss of Control of CORE Entertainment Inc._ On October 17, 2016, the Target completed bankruptcy proceedings with respect to CORE Entertainment Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries. See “Endemol Shine’s Business—Legal Proceedings—Core Media Group.” As a result, CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc.’s shares in CORE Entertainment Inc. were cancelled such that CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. no longer owns CORE Entertainment Inc. or any of its subsidiaries nor has the right to manage their businesses. The loss of control over these businesses triggered their immediate deconsolidation from the consolidated statement of financial position of the Target as of the date of loss of control, which was October 17, 2016. Therefore, the audited consolidated financial information of the Target as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016 includes the operations of CORE Entertainment Inc. and its subsidiaries from January 1, 2016 to October 17, 2016, such that the comparability of these financial statements with the financial statements of the Target as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, presented elsewhere in this offering memorandum, is limited.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Revenue (Including Revenue from Contracts with Customers)
Subsubsection Text: Revenue, since the application of IFRS 15, is recognized at the amount that Endemol Shine expects to be entitled to in exchange for goods or services transferred. This includes only those amounts to which Endemol Shine is entitled to under the present contract and excludes amounts collected on behalf of third parties. The commitment under a contract with a customer to produce a non-scripted or scripted show that consists of a certain number of episodes, including the commitment to grant a license, is considered to be a single performance obligation. When a contract has multiple performance obligations, the transaction price is allocated to each performance obligation based on stand-alone selling prices. This performance obligation will be satisfied over time, given that the customer gains control over the produced content at separate moments during the project, or the content produced does not have an alternative use and Endemol Shine has an enforceable right to payment while the produced content is being transferred. Endemol Shine measures the progress towards complete satisfaction of the performance obligation based on output measurement, which can either be the delivery of a program or the reaching of certain milestones specifically stated in the contract. Milestones are considered to be reached once the customer approval has been obtained. Distribution revenue is derived from contracts with customers including a license. Endemol Shine provides a right to use the format or program as they exist at the point in time at which the license is granted to the customer. This means that the customer can direct the use of and obtain substantially all of the remaining benefits from the license at the point in time at which the license transfers. Endemol Shine does not have any obligations towards improving or renewing the licensed format or program after the beginning of the license date. Therefore, distribution revenue is recognized at a certain point in time. If the transaction price for granting a license is based on usage-based royalties, Endemol Shine recognizes the revenue as the underlying usage occurs. Other revenue is ordinarily recognized in accordance with the substance of the underlying agreement. Revenue from commercial contracts is based on production of content and/or granting a license. Commercial, digital and other revenue is recognized, for example, on the basis of the number of calls or minutes spent on calls, the number of messages sent or received, the amounts of data traffic generated, the number of internet hits, the number of games sold and/or subscriptions sold in relation to the platforms provided. As a result of the application of IFRS 15, since January 1, 2018, the description of revenue in the consolidated statement of comprehensive income was replaced with revenue from contracts with customers. In this offering memorandum, we refer to revenue independent of whether we are referring to Endemol Shine’s revenue prior to, on or after January 1, 2018.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales consist primarily of production costs, net of grants and subsidies, consisting mainly of the following: - _Personnel expenses: all personnel expenses directly attributable to a program, format or genre relating to permanent and temporary employees on payroll and/or freelancers; 151 ----- - _Royalties: format fees, ancillary rights fees and ready-made fees paid to format owners; - _Technical services expenses: camera, editing, set and other technical production costs directly related to programs; - _Studio costs: direct rental and other studio costs obtained from third parties and attributed studio costs due to owned or long-term rented studios; - _Travel and entertainment expenses: car, travel, entertainment and representation costs related to productions; - _Housing expenses: rent, maintenance, service and insurance costs related to productions; - _Selling expenses: costs for publicity, meetings and presentations, agents and other selling expenses related to productions; - _Other expenses: other third party costs, such as costs that are specifically chargeable to the customer under the terms of the contract which may include some general administration costs and development costs for which reimbursement is specified in the terms of the contract. Personnel expenses, studio costs and technical services expenses are Endemol Shine’s most significant categories of cost of sales, and accounted for €421.1 million, €194.3 million and €138.8 million, respectively, in cost of sales for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine’s shows are mainly produced with freelancers requiring minimal investment in fixed assets, which is reflected in the variable nature of cost of Endemol Shine’s cost of sales. Endemol Shine also allocates the amortization of its format and program catalogue as well as the amortization of its brand value to cost of sales. The value of Endemol Shine’s format and program catalogue and brand value has been determined for purposes of the purchase price allocation at the inception of the joint venture structure of Endemol Shine created by Apollo and 21st Century Fox. See “Endemol Shine’s Business—History.” Based on management’s assessment, approximately 80% to 85% of Endemol Shine’s cost of sales is variable in nature.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Gross profit represents revenue less cost of sales.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Indirect Cost of Sales and Overhead
Subsubsection Text: Indirect cost of sales and overhead consists of costs relating to personnel, housing, travel and entertainment, as well as selling and general expenses which have not been attributed to direct costs of production. Indirect cost of sales relates to activities or services that are not specifically incurred or hired for one project or production but rather benefit more than one project. The precise benefit to a specific project is difficult to allocate. These costs can be fixed or variable and are scrutinized by management to ascertain that the cost structure is adjusted in line with the development of commissioning- and production volume. Overhead costs correspond to cost incurred for activities or services that are required to allow for continuation of the business, but not directly linked to the realization of productions. These costs are expected to be fixed in their vast majority and not subject to phasing through the year. Based on management’s assessment, approximately 75% to 85% of Endemol Shine’s indirect cost of sales and overhead is fixed in nature.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance income primarily comprises interest income on funds invested, fair value gains on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, gains on the re-measurement to fair value of any pre-existing interest in an acquiree in a business combination, gains on hedging instruments that are recognized in profit or loss and reclassifications of net gains previously recognized in other comprehensive income. 152 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Financial expense consists of interest expense on borrowings, unwinding of the discount on provisions and deferred consideration, fair value losses on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss and contingent consideration, impairment losses recognized on financial assets (other than trade receivables), losses on hedging instruments that are recognized in profit or loss and reclassifications of net losses previously recognized in other comprehensive income. Borrowing costs that are not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognized using the effective interest method. Foreign currency gains and losses on financial assets and financial liabilities are reported on a net basis as finance income or finance cost, depending on whether foreign currency movements result in a net gain or net loss position.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Share in Profit/(Loss) of Associates and Joint Ventures
Subsubsection Text: Investments in associates and joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method. They are recognized initially at cost, which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial statements include Endemol Shine’s share of the profit or loss and other comprehensive income of associates and joint ventures (after adjustments for alignment with Endemol Shine’s accounting policies), from the date that significant influence or joint control commences until the date that significant influence or joint control ceases. When Endemol Shine’s share of losses exceeds its interest in an associate or joint venture, the carrying amount is reduced to nil and recognition of further losses is discontinued except to the extent that Endemol Shine has incurred legal or constructive obligations or made payments on behalf of an associate. Unrealized gains arising from transactions with equity-accounted investees are eliminated against the investment to the extent of Endemol Shine’s interest in the investee. Unrealized losses are eliminated in the same way as unrealized gains, but only to the extent that there is no evidence of impairment.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Income tax benefit/(expense) has been calculated based on the taxable income for the period and includes current and deferred income taxes.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below is a brief description of the composition of the key line items of Endemol Shine’s income statement.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine reports its revenue and certain other financial data by genre. These categories consist of the following: - _Non-scripted, which include reality TV entertainment, game shows and talent shows in which the main events in the program are not pre-determined by writers and producers; - _Scripted, which include drama, comedy and soap operas for which writers pre-determine the script and structure; and - _Other, which includes primarily sports programming, online digital videos and commercial revenues.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine also reports its revenue by income category. These categories consist of the following: - _Production revenue (see “—Description of Key Income Statement Line Items—Revenues”); - _Distribution revenue (see “—Description of Key Income Statement Line Items—Revenues”); and - _Other revenues, which primarily include revenues from commercial contracts.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (a) Change in value and percentage change are unaudited and represent the absolute difference and percentage difference, respectively, between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, based on the appropriate mathematical formula. Accordingly, decreases in cost items are shown as positive changes in the change in value column, and negative changes in the percentage change (%) column, and increases in cost items are shown as negative changes in the change in value column, and positive changes in the percentage change (%) column. _Revenue_ Revenue decreased by €2.0 million, or 0.2%, from €1,131.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €1,129.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease of €18.2 million in distribution revenues from Endemol Shine International Limited in 2019 (due to formats such Troy which did not return in 2019), Endemol Shine France (with Guyane, Papa ou _Maman, The Bridge and The Island which were not renewed in 2019), the non-recommissioning of Big Brother_ in the United Kingdom and timing of delivery of certain programs in the Netherlands and India. This decrease was partly offset by higher revenues in Germany (due to delivery of the second season of Dark), the United States (due to the return of Deal or No Deal and the commissioning of Family Food Fight) and Australia (due to the new commissioning of, for example, Lego Masters, Changing Rooms and the scripted production Lambs of _God) as well as positive foreign exchange effects amounting to €14.1 million in 2019, following the_ strengthening of the U.S. Dollar. _Revenues by Genre_ The following table sets forth Endemol Shine’s revenues by genre for the periods presented.

Subsubsection Text: Except as otherwise stated in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Financial Information _Included in this Offering Memorandum—Endemol Shine Financial Statements,” the information presented below_ is extracted or derived from the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, and is compared to the year ended December 31, 2017.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (a) Change in value and percent change are unaudited. Change in value represents the mathematical difference between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, as set forth in the table above. Revenues from non-scripted programs increased by €13.1 million, or 1.5%, from €848.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €861.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This 154 ----- increase was primarily due to higher revenues in the United States (as a result of the return of Deal or No Deal and the commissioning of Family Food Fight), Australia (due to the new commissioning of, for example, Lego _Masters, Changing Rooms and the scripted production Lambs of God), Brazil and Mexico. This was offset by the_ timing of delivery of productions in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, and in particular, India, where the regional _Big Brother versions started later, as well as lower revenues in the United Kingdom (due to Big Brother not_ returning in 2019) and north and western Europe (particularly Germany). Revenues from scripted programs decreased by €7.9 million, or 3.3%, from €236.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €228.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower revenues in France and phasing of distribution revenues in Endemol Shine International Limited. This decrease was partially offset by the delivery of the second season of Dark in Germany, the introduction of Deep Water, the return of Grantchester and Peaky Blinders and higher revenue from Tin Star in the United Kingdom and revenue growth in Australia (with the delivery of Lambs of God in the first quarter). Revenues from other genres decreased by €7.2 million, or 15.8%, from €45.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €38.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower activity of OP Talent in the United Kingdom and the reallocation of revenues from certain music and secondary rights from other genres to non-scripted revenue. _Revenues by Income Category_ The following table sets forth Endemol Shine’s revenues by income category for the periods presented. (a) Change in value and percent change are unaudited. Change in value represents the mathematical difference between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, as set forth in the table above. Production revenues increased by €22.0 million, or 2.4%, from €904.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €926.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to revenue of €7.2 million generated from the scripted business (relating to, among others, the delivery of the second season of Dark in Germany) and a €13.7 million positive foreign exchange impact. The non-scripted production revenue remained stable, whereby the impact of Big Brother not being re-commissioned in the United Kingdom in 2019, lower revenues in France and the phasing of productions in Asia, Africa and the Middle East (the “Rest of the World”), were offset by increased revenues in the United States and Australia. Distribution and other revenues decreased by €18.2 million, or 12.2%, from €149.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €131.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the timing of delivery of certain programs more skewed towards the fourth quarter of 2019. Other (Commercial) revenues decreased by €5.8 million, or 7.5%, from €77.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €71.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the finalization of certain digital inventory and brand licensing contracts more skewed towards the fourth quarter of 2019 and the recognition in 2018 of certain minimum guarantees on gaming and brand licensing contracts. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales decreased by €0.4 million from €868.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €867.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the decrease in revenues and change in product mix, as well as production efficiency improvements and the lower amortization of Endemol Shine’s capitalized format rights and program catalogue. 155 ----- _Gross Profit_ Gross profit decreased by €1.5 million, or 0.6%, from €263.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €261.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower contribution from the United Kingdom, France and distribution activities. This decrease was partly offset by higher profitability in the United States, and Iberia and lower amortization of intangible assets. _Indirect Cost of Sales and Overhead_ Indirect cost of sales and overhead decreased by €16.9 million, or 6.7%, from €251.1 million, or 22.2% of revenue, for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €234.2 million, or 20.7% of revenue, for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to cost savings in connection with restructuring plans in France, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands as well as non-recurring transaction costs incurred in 2018 following the sales process of Endemol Shine and shareholder costs relating to legal fees and certain other shareholder expenses incurred in 2018. _Financial Income_ Financial income increased by €9.6 million, or 69.1%, from €13.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €23.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the fair market value revaluation of cross currency swaps following the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. _Financial Expense_ Financial expense increased by €13.5 million, or 8.5%, from €158.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €171.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher interest expenses on Endemol Shine’s first and second lien debt due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and the increase of the base LIBOR rate. _Share in Profit/(Loss) of Associates and Joint Ventures_ Share in profit/(loss) of associates and joint ventures increased by €3.8 million from €3.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €7.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to additional license fees received from Eredivisie Media & Marketing CV, which holds the Dutch soccer television rights. _Income Tax Benefit/(Expense)_ Income tax benefit decreased by €3.6 million, or 69.2%, from €5.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €1.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the receipt of prepaid state taxes in the United States relating to prior years. During the nine months ended September 30, 2019, Endemol Shine incurred higher taxes due to unrecognized tax losses and lower tax credits. _Profit/(Loss) for the Period_ Loss for the period decreased by €11.6 million, or 9.3%, from a loss of €124.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to a loss of €112.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. 156 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) The consolidated statement of profit or loss for the year ended December 31, 2017 has been restated due to the reclassification of certain expenses due to a change in presentation to classify expenses by function instead of by nature. This reclassification is unaudited and has no impact on operating results. The restated consolidated statement of profit or loss for the year ended December 31, 2017 presented in this offering memorandum includes a reclassification of €149.1 million between cost of sales and indirect cost of sales and overhead. This reclassification aims at fully presenting the impact of the functional allocation implemented for the first time in the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information— _Endemol Shine Financial Statements.”_ (2) Change in value and percentage change are unaudited and represent the absolute difference and percentage difference, respectively, between the results for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2017, based on the appropriate mathematical formula. Accordingly, decreases in cost items are shown as positive changes in the change in value column, and negative changes in the percentage change (%) column, and increases in cost items are shown as negative changes in the change in value column, and positive changes in the percentage change (%) column. _Revenue_ Revenue decreased by €68.1 million, or 3.7%, from €1,847.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €1,779.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to foreign exchange effects amounting to €47.1 million and the winding down of operations in Turkey (amounting to €8.3 million) and the disposal of Endemol Shine’s operations in South Africa (amounting to €7.4 million). The decrease in revenues was also due to a decrease in revenues in France with the termination of The Voice contract, non-recommissioning of The Wall and lower scripted revenues in Italy and Australia which was partly offset by an increase in revenues in the United States and the United Kingdom. The negative foreign exchange impact of €47.1 million was primarily a result of the weakening of the U.S. dollar (amounting to €17.4 million), the Australian dollar (amounting to €7.9 million), the British pound (amounting to €5.4 million), the Russian rubble (amounting to €3.6 million), the Swedish krona (amounting to €3.8 million) and the Indian rupee (amounting to €3.2 million). 157 ----- _Revenues by Genre_ The following table sets forth Endemol Shine’s revenues by genre for the periods presented.
