Subsubsection Text: Except as otherwise stated in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Financial Information _Included in this Offering Memorandum—Endemol Shine Financial Statements,” the information presented below_ is extracted or derived from the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017, and is compared to the year ended December 31, 2016.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (a) Change in value and percent change are unaudited. Change in value represents the mathematical difference between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, as set forth in the table above. Revenues from non-scripted programs decreased by €15.3 million, or 1.2%, from €1,279.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €1,264.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to negative foreign exchange effects amounting to €36.3 million in 2018 offset by the continued strong performance of Big Brother and MasterChef, and the growth of All Together Now. The Americas delivered a strong performance with higher volumes for MasterChef, Fear Factor, Ink Master and Real _Housewives. The United Kingdom also showed higher volumes for All Together Now and Pointless offsetting_ France’s loss of The Voice and non-commissioning of The Wall in 2018. Revenues from scripted programs decreased by €54.1 million, or 10.7%, from €506.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €452.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to negative foreign exchange impact amounting to €10.4 million and a number of shows not returning in Australia (Offspring, Sisters and Wake in Freight), Italy (La Profia and Le Tre Rose di Eva) and the Nordic Countries (Bron), as well as lower production volume in the Rest of the World (with the termination of Endemol Shine’s activities in Turkey in 2017). This was only partially offset by increased production revenues in the United Kingdom and the U.S. with the delivery of key programs including Curfew, Troy, Black Mirror, Humans and Utopia. Revenues from other genres increased by €1.3 million, or 2.1%, from €61.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €62.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to additional activities of OP Talent in the UK. _Revenues by income category_ The following table sets forth Endemol Shine’s revenues by income category for the periods presented. (a) Change in value and percent change are unaudited. Change in value represents the mathematical difference between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, as set forth in the table above. Production revenues decreased by €53.4 million, or 3.6%, from €1,487.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €1,434.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to a negative foreign exchange rate impact amounting to €41.8 million and lower scripted revenues and lower non-scripted revenues in France in 2018. Distribution revenues decreased by €13.9 million, or 5.6%, from €246.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €232.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower distribution revenues from 24 Hours and no profit share for the Steve Harvey Show, which ended in 2017. 158 ----- Other (Commercial) revenues remained stable at €112.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 from €112.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales decreased by €77.4 million, or 5.4%, from €1,432.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €1,355.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower revenues in 2018 reflective of the largely variable nature of Endemol Shine’s cost of sales combined with production efficiency improvements and better cost utilization across all segments and the lower amortization of Endemol Shine’s capitalized format rights and program catalogue. _Gross Profit_ Gross profit increased by €9.3 million, or 2.2%, from €414.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €424.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to lower amortization of intangible assets (€13.2 million) in 2018. _Indirect Cost of Sales and Overhead_ Indirect cost of sales and overhead decreased by €17.5 million, or 4.4%, from €400.1 million, or 21.7% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €382.6 million, or 21.5% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to cost savings in the United States, Mexico, Brazil, the United Kingdom and other European countries, as well as savings following the termination of production activities in favor of format sales in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, partly offset by the impairment losses on goodwill in France (amounting to €44.1 million) due to the loss of formats and non-commissioning of scripted titles combined with the ongoing challenging and competitive market in France, non-recurring transaction related costs following the sales process of the Endemol Shine and shareholder costs relating to legal fees and certain other shareholder expenses incurred, in each case, in 2018. _Financial Income_ Financial income decreased by €79.7 million, or 73.9%, from €107.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €28.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the euro in 2018 resulting in foreign exchange loss of €43.3 million, compared to a profit of €103.9 million in 2017. This decrease was partly offset by the positive fair market value revaluation of the cross currency swap following the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. _Financial Expense_ Financial expense increased by €17.5 million, or 8.6%, from €204.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €222.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to interest costs related to Endemol Shine’s first and second lien term loans and foreign currency exchange losses following the revaluation of the GBP and USD portion of Endemol Shine’s external loans. This was partly offset by the positive adjustment to the fair market value of the cross currency swap following the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. In 2017, the revaluation of the cross currency swap led to a loss of €42.0 million, while in 2018 the revaluation led to a profit of €16.5 million. _Share in Profit/(Loss) of Associates and Joint Ventures_ Share in profit/(loss) of associates and joint ventures increased by €3.8 million, from €2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €6.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the exclusion of the Reshet losses in 2018 following the full impairment of the investment in 2017 and better results of Endemol Shine’s investment in Eredivisie Media & Marketing CV, which holds the Dutch soccer television rights. _Income Tax Benefit/(Expense)_ Income tax benefit/(expense) decreased by €9.6 million, from an expense of €8.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to a benefit of €0.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was 159 ----- primarily due to an increase of the losses before tax in 2018, an adjustment to the total tax that affected the number of non-valued tax losses and credits, a decrease of the non-deductible expenses in 2018 compared to 2017 and the country mix where Endemol Shine realizes taxable profits leading to a lower tax expense and an increase of benefits of tax losses recognized. _Profit/(Loss) for the Period_ Loss for the period increased by €57.0 million, or 64.6%, from a loss of €88.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to a loss of €145.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the negative foreign exchange impact following the strengthening of the U.S. dollar, the impairment loss on goodwill relating to cash generating unit France (€44.1 million), non-recurring transaction related costs and a true up of shareholder costs in 2018. This decrease was partly offset by the increase in gross profit.

Subsubsection Text: (1) The consolidated statement of profit or loss for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2017 has been restated due to the reclassification of certain expenses due to a change in presentation to classify expenses by function instead of by nature. This reclassification is unaudited and has no impact on operating results. The restated consolidated statement of profit or loss for the year ended December 31, 2017 presented in this offering memorandum includes a reclassification of €149.1 million between cost of sales and indirect cost of sales and overhead. This reclassification aims at fully presenting the impact of the functional allocation implemented for the first time in the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018. See “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information—Endemol Shine Financial Statements.”_ (2) Change in value and percentage change are unaudited and represent the absolute difference and percentage difference, respectively, between the results for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016, based on the appropriate mathematical formula. Accordingly, decreases in cost items are shown as positive changes in the change in value column, and negative changes in the percentage change (%) column, and increases in cost items are shown as negative changes in the change in value column, and positive changes in the percentage change (%) column. _Revenue_ Revenue decreased by €44.5 million, or 2.4%, from €1,892.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €1,847.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to foreign exchange effects amounting to €42.3 million and €40.0 million of non-organic negative impact following divestitures in Denmark (amounting to €4.9 million), Norway (amounting to €0.4 million), Turkey (amounting to €18.0 million), Argentina (amounting to €9.1 million), Chile (amounting to €3.0 million) and the Middle East (amounting to €4.2 million), as well as the restructuring of operations in South East Asia in 2017. The decrease was partly offset by the strong performance of Endemol Shine’s programs such as Broadchurch, The Bridge and _Tin Star, reflecting a €34.5 million growth in the distribution business, excluding the impact of foreign exchange_ rates, and a €25.6 million growth in revenue in Iberia, driven by additional volume on both scripted (La Catedral 160 ----- _del Mar) and non-scripted (Your Face Sounds Familiar, Operación Triunfo and MasterChef) programs. The_ negative foreign exchange impact of €42.3 million was primarily due to the weakening of the British pound (amounting to €34.5 million) and the U.S. dollar (amounting to €6.3 million). _Revenues by Genre_ The following table sets forth Endemol Shine’s revenues by genre for the periods presented.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (a) Change in value and percent change are unaudited. Change in value represents the mathematical difference between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, as set forth in the table above. Revenues from non-scripted programs decreased by €24.8 million, or 1.9%, from €1,304.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €1,279.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to negative foreign exchange impact of €18.9 million in 2017 and lower revenues from Big Brother and The Steve Harvey Show in the United States, the cancellation of The Voice in Australia and non-commissioning of The Money Drop in France and the impact of the divested operations in Argentina, Chile and the Middle East, partly offset by the re-introduction of Fear Factor in the US and new shows like Hunted (the United States) and The Wall (Germany, France and Spain). Revenues from scripted programs decreased by €14.1 million, or 2.7%, from €520.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €506.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to negative foreign exchange impact amounting to €22.6 million in 2017 and lower production volumes in the United Kingdom due to non-returning formats (Humans, Guerilla) and in Turkey and Italy (with Sacrificio _D’Amore not returning). This decrease was partly offset by strong distribution performance (Humans, Tin Star)_ and UK and Iberia new commissions (Broadchurch, Tin Star and La Catedral del Mar). Revenues from other genres decreased by €5.6 million, or 8.4%, from €66.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €61.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily driven by a 2016 one-off Mariah Carey event in the United States. _Revenues by Income Category_ The following table sets forth Endemol Shine’s revenues by income category for the periods presented. (a) Change in value and percent change are unaudited. Change in value represents the mathematical difference between the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, as set forth in the table above. Production revenues decreased by €59.9 million, or 3.9%, from €1,547.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €1,487.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the negative foreign exchange impact amounting to €27.5 million in 2017 and lower scripted volumes following non-commissioning of The Money Drop in France, The Voice in Australia and Gran Hermano and The _Biggest Loser in the United States combined with various other scripted titles not being produced in 2017._ 161 ----- Distribution revenues increased by €21.7 million, or 9.6%, from €225.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €246.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to increased distribution revenues from scripted titles, predominantly coming from Humans 2, Broadchurch 2, Tin _Star and The Frankenstein Chronicles._ Other (Commercial) revenues decreased by €6.3 million, or 5.3%, from €119.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €112.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to negative foreign exchange effects. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales decreased by €75.5 million, or 5.0%, from €1,508.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €1,432.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to lower volumes, production efficiency improvements, better cost utilization across all segments, different product mix (higher contribution of distribution business, with relatively high margin) and the degressive amortization of Endemol Shine’s capitalized format rights and finished program catalogue. The value for the format rights and finished program catalogue originates from the purchase price allocation in 2014. _Gross Profit_ Gross profit increased by €31.0 million, or 8.1%, from €383.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €414.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to different product mix (higher contribution of distribution business, with relatively high margin) and the degressive amortization expense. _Indirect Cost of Sales and Overhead_ Indirect cost of sales and overhead decreased by €115.4 million, or 22.4%, from €515.5 million, or 27.2% of revenue, for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €400.1 million, or 21.7% of revenue, for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the impairment loss on goodwill in 2016 amounting to €114.0 million relating to the US (€75.4 million), Rest of the World (€16.6 million), relating to the exited countries and regions of Argentina, Chile, the Middle East, Kenya and South Africa, and an impairment on investments in associates and joint ventures in Brazil and Israel (€21.9 million). The impairment for 2017 amounted to (€23.8 million) relating to France (€18.6 million), Turkey (€5.2 million) and the investment in Reshet Media Ltd. (€5.9 million). This decrease in indirect cost of sales and overhead was further strengthened by cost saving plans materializing in the Americas, France and other European entities as well as savings following the sale of the studios in Denmark and Norway. _Financial Income_ Financial income increased by €90.4 million, from €17.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €107.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the weakening of the U.S. dollar (against the Euro) in 2017 leading to a foreign exchange income of €103.9 million for Endemol Shine, while in 2016 Endemol Shine incurred a loss of €53.0 million. The positive foreign exchange impact in 2017 of €103.9 million was partly offset by the negative fair market value revaluation of €42.0 million of the cross currency swap following the weakening of the U.S. dollar. _Financial Expense_ Financial expense decreased by €17.4 million, or 7.8%, from €221.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €204.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to foreign currency exchange profits in 2017 following the appreciation of the U.S. dollar portion of Endemol Shine’s external loans (2016 Endemol Shine incurred a loss). This was partly offset by the negative adjustment to the fair market value of the cross currency swap following the weakening of the U.S. dollar (in 2017 the revaluation of the cross currency swap lead to a loss of €42.0 million, while in 2016 the revaluation lead to a profit of €8.7 million). _Share in Profit/(Loss) of Associates and Joint Ventures_ Share in profit/(loss) of associates and joint ventures decreased by €0.7 million, or 20.6%, from €3.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was 162 ----- primarily due to increased losses in 2017 of Endemol Shine’s investment in Reshet Media Ltd., partly offset by better results of Endemol Shine’s investment in Eredivisie Media & Marketing CV, which holds the Dutch soccer television rights. _Income Tax Benefit/(Expense)_ Income tax expense decreased by €10.2 million, or 53.7%, from €19.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €8.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the tax effect of non-deductible expenses amounting to €45.7 million in 2016 (mainly the fair value adjustment to goodwill) and the tax on unrecognized tax losses. _Profit/(Loss) for the Period_ Loss for the period decreased by €26.2 million, or 22.9%, from a loss of €114.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to a loss of €88.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the higher impairment loss on goodwill in 2016 and cost efficiencies realized in 2017, which were fully offset by the negative foreign exchange impact following the strengthening of the U.S. dollar.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes, notably, the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flow to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including, but not limited to, working capital needs, capital expenditures, debt service obligations, contractual obligations and acquisitions. Endemol Shine’s principal sources of funds have been cash generated from its operating activities, access to a revolving credit facility (the “RCF”) of €125 million (of which €50.0 million was drawn as of September 30, 2019), which will be repaid and cancelled as part of the Refinancing, utilization of the $125 million Borrowing Base Facility to accelerate long-term distribution agreements receivables at a discounted value (of which €44.6 million (equivalent) was drawn as of September 30, 2019), and local bilateral facilities. Endemol Shine’s principal uses of cash are to fund working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions and debt service obligations. As of September 30, 2019, Endemol Shine had cash and cash equivalents of €43.6 million (including trapped cash in the amount of €9.0 million as of September 30, 2019, comprising, among others, trust account cash, country restricted cash, cash at jointly controlled ventures and cash backed bank guarantees). In connection with the Transactions, the RCF will be cancelled and repaid among other first and second lien debt and some small bilateral facilities.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow from operating activities decreased by €11.8 million, or 9.7%, from €121.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €110.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower cash generated through working capital changes, a net repayment on the Borrowing Base Facility and certain bilateral facilities of €32.3 million, compared to a net receipt in 2018 of €11.1 million, and the payment of €11.9 million for earn-out and put option liabilities. This decrease was primarily offset by the increase in operating result and the impact of IFRS 16 adoption (€20.6 million), as under the new standard, cash payments for the principal part of the lease liability are classified in the cash flow from financing activities instead of cash flow from operating activities. Net cash flow from operating activities increased by €38.7 million, or 25.5%, from €151.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €190.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the increase in operating results and limited earn-out and put option payments in 2018 (€0.2 million) compared to €26.4 million paid by Endemol Shine in 2017 for earn-out and put option liabilities. This increase was partly offset by lower cash generated through working capital changes. In addition, in 2018 Endemol Shine adjusted the classification for bilateral production financing from financial debt to production working capital, which resulted in a €25.5 million increase in cash flow from operating activities. Net cash flow from operating activities increased by €88.4 million, or 139.9%, from €63.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €151.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the increase in operating results and improved working capital management in 2017. This increase was partly offset by payments for earn-outs and put options amounting to €26.4 million in 2017.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow used in investing activities decreased by €6.6 million, or 88.0%, from €7.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €0.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the positive impact of higher dividends received from equity investments and, in the nine months ended September 30, 2019, higher cash inflow of €2.2 million relating to a profit share with a show host, which was prepaid in 2018. Net cash flow used in investing activities remained stable from €10.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €10.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to lower capital expenditures on property, plant and equipment offset by higher investments in writers’ rights and a cash outflow of €4.4 million relating to a pre-payment on a long term co-production agreement. Net cash flow used in investing activities decreased by €68.8 million, or 86.5%, from €79.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €10.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the termination of the operations of CORE Entertainment Inc. and its subsidiaries in April 2016, which led to a net cash outflow from investing activities of €63.1 million.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flow from (used in) Financing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow used in financing activities increased by €5.4 million, or 4.5%, from €120.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €125.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher interest payments on the first and second lien debt due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar, the increase in the base LIBOR rate and the impact of the IFRS 16 adoption (€20.6 million), as under the new standard, cash payments for the principal part of the lease liability are classified in the cash flow from financing activities instead of cash flow from operating activities, partly offset by a drawing of €25.0 million on Endemol Shine’s revolving credit facility, in each case, in 2019. Net cash flow used in financing activities increased by €58.5 million, or 38.6%, from €151.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €210.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to a repayment on Endemol Shine’s revolving credit facility (2018: €35.0 million; 2017: €19.8 million) and a net cash movement on the Borrowing Base Facility of €44.0 million (€20.2 million repayment in 2018 and €23.9 million drawings in 2017). 164 ----- Net cash flow used in financing activities increased by €120.3 million, or 384.3%, from €31.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €151.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to a higher repayment on the revolving credit facility (2017: €19.8 million repayment; 2016: €43.0 million drawing) and a net cash movement on the Borrowing Base Facility of €33.5 million (2017: €23.9 million drawing; 2016: €57.4 million drawing). In 2016 Endemol Shine entered into the Borrowing Base Facility under which $70 million was initially available, which was subsequently increased to $100 million and $125 million in 2017 and 2018, respectively.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine has incurred operating losses over the years leading to net operating losses which can benefit Endemol Shine by reducing taxable income in future tax years. Total net operating losses in 2018 amounted to €566 million and an amount of €128 million of interest carry forward has been identified at Endemol Shine. The total identified net operating losses mainly relate to positions in the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, the United States, and Australia and are mainly caused by the underlying operational results of the operations in these countries. As of December 31, 2018, €177 million of these total net operating losses were recoverable by Endemol Shine. As of December 31, 2018, no deferred tax asset was recognized for a total amount of €389 million of the net operating losses, as well as €128 million for the interest carry forward, following the assessment that these losses cannot be offset against deferred tax liabilities and there is a low probability that they can be offset with taxable profits in the next three years. From a tax cash perspective, the amounts paid within Endemol Shine mainly relate to payments made in Germany, Spain, India, Italy, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States. The total tax cash paid in 2017 and 2018 amounted to €8.6 million and €8.8 million, respectively.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: To support Endemol Shine’s business strategy and development plans and to further expand Endemol Shine’s business, Endemol Shine regularly incurs capital expenditures. Endemol Shine defines capital expenditure as purchases of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets. Overall, the capital expenditure levels are limited and mainly relate to maintenance and replacement investments. Capital expenditures increased by €0.4 million, or 4.4%, from €9.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, to €9.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to additional infrastructure investments in India. Capital expenditures decreased by €4.6 million, or 24.1%, from €19.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, to €14.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower investments in computer equipment and furniture and fixtures. Capital expenditures decreased by €6.7 million, or 26.0%, from €25.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €19.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to lower investments in leasehold improvements and furniture and fixtures.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Changes in working capital are impacted by the timing of production and program delivery and by the production of scripted and non-scripted programs. Because non-scripted programs are mainly produced in less than a year, working capital requirements related to Endemol Shine’s non-scripted business is mainly impacted by fluctuations in the number of non-scripted programs Endemol Shine produces. Endemol Shine may record cut-off impacts related to non-scripted activity at the end of each year if some large-scale programs are still under production. On the other hand, scripted productions have longer production cycles, and higher working capital requirements. Endemol Shine’s working capital related to scripted activity can be impacted significantly by cut-off issues at the end of the year. In addition, Endemol Shine sometimes finances a part of Endemol Shine’s scripted programs through tax credits or subsidies paid after the delivery of the program, which has an impact on Endemol Shine’s working capital for the year during which Endemol Shine produce the program but have not yet delivered it. Endemol Shine through Endemol Shine International Limited sometimes provides distribution advances for its production companies to secure deficit funding for these companies. The outstanding amount of these distribution advances is, on average, approximately €100 million, the majority of which represents advances paid to third-party owners for distribution rights. Net working capital improved over the years due to stricter collection efforts and the introduction of production financing through bilateral loans and the Borrowing Base Facility, which was entered into in 2016. Taxes receivable movements are mainly driven by timing of the receipt of production related tax credits and tax incentives. Receipt of these credits and incentives is subject to external tax audit finalization. Endemol Shine manages its production portfolio on a production-by-production basis, with detailed production budgets and monthly actual performance reviews. Every country has its own Production Working capital dynamics following local market and funding patterns. Endemol Shine’s working capital requirement for manageable working capital (excluding external production funding) ranges from 8% to 11% as a percentage of total revenue from the last twelve months. Under the Endemol Shine production cycle, Endemol Shine has a higher utilization of working capital and inventory in the first half of the year, which is mitigated with production funding. Endemol Shine’s revenues are typically largely concentrated in the second half of the year, mainly in the fourth quarter. Working capital relates to outstanding trade receivables and trade payables, unvoiced revenues, net distribution advances, accrued production cost and deferred revenues. 165 -----
