Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine is party to various customary off balance sheet arrangements. See note 27 to the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Due to Endemol Shine’s corporate and financing structure, access to cash remains a focus of attention for Endemol Shine, which has an objective to maintain a balance between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of bank overdrafts, bank loans, securitization facilities, factoring and the revolving credit facilities. Following the completion of the financial restructuring of the Target, Endemol Shine will operate with a levered capital structure with significant debt service obligations. Endemol Shine services its debt from cash flow generated from the operations. The nature of Endemol Shine’s operations across 20 countries offers diversification of these cash flows. In addition, during the periods presented, Endemol Shine utilized the Borrowing Base Facility for additional liquidity needs.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine has a number of important long-standing customers in its established markets. Any non-payment by such customer may have a significant financial impact. The financial capabilities of customers are monitored and any new business, including in new regions, is assessed before a customer is engaged. Endemol Shine trades only with recognized, creditworthy third parties. It is Endemol Shine’s policy that all customers who wish to trade on credit terms are subject to credit verification procedures. In addition, receivable balances are monitored on an ongoing basis with the result that Endemol Shine’s exposure to bad debts is not significant.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended December 31, 2018, 65% of Endemol Shine’s revenue was generated in currencies other than the euro, Endemol Shine’s reporting currency. Significant transactions and operations in foreign currency, that could materially impact Endemol Shine’s statement of financial position and profit and loss, occur mainly in USD and GBP. Since most of the costs related to producing shows and the administration of group companies are in euro, the transaction exposure resulting from non-euro business transactions is limited. In addition, Endemol Shine entered into a cross currency swap that converts Endemol Shine’s floating interest obligation in respect of 60% of the principal amount of the euro-denominated loans to a fixed rate. By means of natural hedging as well as foreign currency forward contracts, Endemol Shine minimizes exchange results on receivables, payables and expected future cash-flows denominated in currencies other than the functional currency.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine’s exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relates primarily to the debt obligations with floating interest rates.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk represents the risk that Endemol Shine’s income and expenses, future cash flow or fair value of financial instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market prices. Market risks affecting Endemol Shine include liquidity risk, credit risk, foreign currency risk and interest rate risk. Endemol Shine’s financial policy is aimed at minimizing the effects of fluctuations in currency exchange and interest rates on its results in the shortterm and following market rates in the long term.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Judgements, Assumptions and Estimation Uncertainties
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the consolidated financial statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, and income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and 167 ----- various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised, if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future periods, if the revision affects both current and future periods. The consolidated financial statements have been prepared on the basis that Endemol Shine is able to continue as a going concern.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of the Target and its subsidiaries. _Subsidiaries_ Subsidiaries are entities controlled by Endemol Shine, or when Endemol Shine is exposed to, or has rights to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the ability to affect those returns through its controlling influence over the entity. In assessing control, potential voting rights that presently are exercisable or convertible are taken into account. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are included in the consolidated financial statements from the date that control commences until the date that control ceases. _Non-controlling Interests_ Non-controlling interests are measured at fair value. Changes in Endemol Shine’s interest in subsidiaries that do not result in a loss of control are accounted for as equity transactions. _Loss of Control_ When Endemol Shine loses control over a subsidiary, it derecognizes the assets and liabilities of the subsidiary, and any non-controlling interests and other components of equity. Any resulting gain or loss is recognized in profit or loss. Any interest retained in the former subsidiary is measured at fair value when control is lost. _Intra-group Transactions_ Intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealized gains and losses or income and expenses arising from intra-group transactions, are eliminated.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Transactions_ Transactions in foreign currencies are translated to the respective functional currencies of Endemol Shine’s entities at exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate at the reporting date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognized in profit or loss. Non-monetary items that are measured based on historical cost in a foreign currency are not translated at the reporting date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair value are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate when the fair value was determined. _Foreign Operations_ The assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on acquisition, are translated into euro at exchange rates at the reporting date. Income and expenses of foreign 168 ----- operations are translated into euro at exchange rates prevailing at transaction date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognized in the translation reserve as part of equity, except to the extent that the translation difference is allocated to non-controlling interests. When a foreign operation is disposed of and control, significant influence or joint control is lost, the cumulative amount in the translation reserve related to that foreign operation is recycled to profit or loss as part of the gain or loss on disposal. If Endemol Shine disposes of only part of its interest in a subsidiary but retains control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is reclassified to non-controlling interests. When Endemol Shine disposes of only part of an associate or joint ventures while retaining significant influence or joint control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is recycled to profit or loss.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: A number of Endemol Shine’s accounting policies and disclosures require the measurement of fair values, for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities. Endemol Shine uses market observable data (to the extent practically possible) when measuring the fair value of an asset or a liability. Fair values are categorized into different fair value hierarchy levels based on the inputs used in the valuation techniques as follows: - Level 1: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities; - Level 2: inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (as prices) or indirectly (derived from prices); and - Level 3: inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs). If the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset or a liability might be categorized in different levels of the fair value hierarchy, then the fair value measurement is categorized in its entirety in the same level of the fair value hierarchy as the lowest level input that is significant to the entire measurement. Endemol Shine recognizes transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy at the end of the reporting period during which the change has occurred.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when control is transferred. The consideration transferred in the acquisition is generally measured at fair value, as are the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities at the date of acquisition. Goodwill is the difference between the consideration transferred and the fair value of net assets acquired and represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognized. Any gain on a bargain purchase (negative goodwill) is recognized in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs are expensed as incurred, except if related to the issue of debt or equity securities. Goodwill on acquisition of associates/joint ventures is included in investments in associates/joint ventures. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognized in profit or loss. Adjustments to the fair value of the consideration transferred and the provisional fair values of identifiable assets and liabilities in a business combination, identified within twelve months of the date of acquisition, are recognized retrospectively, provided that the new information relates to conditions that existed at the date of acquisition. In case the consideration transferred consists of (an) initial cash payment(s) and estimated future earn-out obligation based on (or related to) estimates of future results, any such obligations are only recognized as consideration if payments are not depending on future employment of the seller. An adjustment in the earn-out obligation recognized as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. As part of a business combination, Endemol Shine can grant an option to non-controlling interests (for example, a minority shareholder), to sell to Endemol Shine (part of) their remaining interest in the business 169 ----- acquired. If such a put option provides for settlement in cash, any such obligations are only recognized as consideration if payments are not dependent on future employment of the seller. Endemol Shine treats such a transaction as if the put option has been exercised at acquisition date (the so-called ‘anticipated-acquisition method’) when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to Endemol Shine. Accordingly, no non-controlling interest is recognized. An adjustment in the put option liability recognized as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. When a business combination is achieved in stages, the carrying value of the previously held equity interest is re- measured to fair value at acquisition date and the difference is recognized in profit or loss. If share-based payment awards (for example, replacement awards) are required to be exchanged for awards held by the acquiree’s employees (acquiree’s awards) and relate to past services, then all or a portion of the amount of the acquirer’s replacement awards is included in measuring the consideration transferred in the business combination. This determination is based on the market-based value of the replacement awards compared with the market-based value of the acquiree’s awards and the extent to which the replacement awards relate to pre-combination service.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Items of property, plant and equipment are stated at historical cost less accumulated depreciation (for definite useful life assets only) and impairment losses. Where parts of an item of property, plant and equipment have different useful lives, they are accounted for as separate components of property, plant and equipment. Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only when it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the item will flow to Endemol Shine and the cost of the item can be measured reliably. All other costs are recognized in the consolidated statement of comprehensive income as expense when incurred. Depreciation is expensed on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life of each part of an item of property, plant and equipment, taking into account the estimated residual value. Land is not depreciated. Depreciation methods, useful lives and residual values are reviewed and adjusted if necessary, annually. An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognized whenever Endemol Shine disposes of it, or when no more future benefits are expected by its use. Gain or loss from the derecognition of an item of property, plant and equipment is calculated as the difference between the net amount of the disposal and the book value of the asset. The gain or loss is recognized in Endemol Shine’s consolidated statement of comprehensive income in the period in which the derecognition occurs. Other property, plant and equipment relates to computer equipment, furniture and fixtures and other tangible assets.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Goodwill_ Goodwill represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognized. Goodwill recognized by Endemol Shine has arisen as a result of business combinations and is carried at cost less accumulated impairment losses. Note 2.10 of Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018, sets out the recognition and measurement principles for impairment. _Other Intangible Assets_ Other intangible assets are those assets which are identifiable and can be sold separately or which arise from legal rights and primarily consist of format rights, movie and TV movie rights, contracts with customers and brand names. These assets can either be purchased, acquired in a business combination or internally developed if certain criteria for capitalization are met. Purchased other intangible assets are stated at cost, which is the purchase price, less accumulated amortization and impairment losses. Note 2.10 of Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018 sets out the recognition and measurement principles for impairment. Amortization occurs over the period Endemol Shine is expected to benefit from the use of the intangible asset and commences when the assets are available for use. 170 ----- Format rights are amortized as from the time the format is taken into production and in proportion to the number of programs produced. TV movie rights are amortized using a declining balance method based on the expected consumption of economic benefits from these assets. Development expenditures on individual projects are only recognized as an intangible asset when the following can be demonstrated: - it is technically feasible to complete the project so that it will be available for either use or sale; - there is an intention to complete the project; - the completed project is able to be either used or sold; - the manner(s) in which the asset is expected to generate future economic benefits; - resources are available to complete the project; and - development expenditures can be measured reliably. The amount initially recognized for internally-generated intangible assets is the sum of the expenditure incurred from the date when the intangible asset first meets the recognition criteria. Where no internallygenerated intangible asset can be recognized, development expenditure is recognized in profit or loss in the period in which it is incurred. Amortization of development expenditure starts when the project is available for use. The amortization period and the amortization method for an intangible asset with a finite useful life is reviewed at least each reporting period-end. Changes in the expected useful life are accounted for by changing the amortization period or method, as appropriate, and are treated as changes in accounting estimates.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures
Subsubsection Text: _Associates_ Associates are those entities in which Endemol Shine has significant influence, but not control, over the financial and operating policies. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating decisions of the entity but is not control or joint control. _Joint Ventures_ A joint venture is a contractual arrangement whereby Endemol Shine and other parties undertake an economic activity that is subject to joint control and Endemol Shine has rights to the net assets of the arrangement, rather than rights to its assets and obligations for its liabilities. Joint control exists when decisions relating to the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Investments in associates and joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method. They are recognized initially at cost, which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial statements include Endemol Shine’s share of the profit or loss and other comprehensive income of associates and joint ventures (after adjustments for alignment with Endemol Shine’s accounting policies), from the date that significant influence or joint control commences until the date that significant influence or joint control ceases. When Endemol Shine’s share of losses exceeds its interest in an associate or joint venture, the carrying amount is reduced to nil and recognition of further losses is discontinued except to the extent that Endemol Shine has incurred legal or constructive obligations or made payments on behalf of an associate.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Transactions with Associates and Joint Ventures
Subsubsection Text: Unrealized gains arising from transactions with equity-accounted investees are eliminated against the investment to the extent of Endemol Shine’s interest in the investee. Unrealized losses are eliminated in the same way as unrealized gains, but only to the extent that there is no evidence of impairment.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In many of Endemol Shine’s business areas, Endemol Shine participates in pension and similar plans for its employees. A defined contribution plan is a post-employment benefit plan under which Endemol Shine pays 171 ----- fixed contributions into a separate entity and has no legal or constructive obligation to pay further amounts. Obligations for contributions to defined contribution plans are expensed as the related service is provided. Prepaid contributions are recognized as an asset to the extent that a cash refund or a reduction in future payments is available. For other long-term employee benefits, such as long-term service benefits, the net obligation is the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods. That benefit is discounted to determine its present value. Re-measurements are recognized in profit or loss in the period in which they arise. Short-term employee benefits are measured on an undiscounted basis and are expensed as the related service is provided. Endemol Shine recognizes a liability and an expense for bonuses and other current employee benefits on an accrual basis. Furthermore, a provision is recognized where contractually obliged or where there is a past practice that has created a constructive obligation. Termination benefits are expensed at the earlier of when Endemol Shine can no longer withdraw the offer of those benefits and when Endemol Shine recognizes costs for a restructuring. If benefits are not expected to be settled wholly within twelve months of the end of the reporting period, then they are discounted.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In general, a provision is recognized in the statement of financial position when: - there is a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of a past event; - it is probable that an outflow of economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation; and - a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. If the effect is material, provisions are determined by discounting the expected future cash flows at a pre-tax discount rate, that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and, where appropriate, the risks specific to the liability. Recoveries from third parties, which are likely to be realized, are recorded separately, and are not offset against the related liability. A provision for restructuring is recognized when: - there is an approved detailed and formal restructuring plan; and - the restructuring has either commenced or has been announced publicly. A provision for onerous contracts is recognized when the expected benefits to be derived from a contract are lower than the unavoidable cost of meeting its obligations under the contract and when such provision can be reasonably estimated.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue (under IFRS 15) is recognized at the amount that Endemol Shine expects to be entitled to in exchange for goods or services transferred. This includes only those amounts to which Endemol Shine is entitled to under the present contract and excludes amounts collected on behalf of third parties. The transaction price agreed upon in the contract can be a variable consideration, such as royalties, price concessions, rating bonuses and profit shares. Management estimates, and includes in the transaction price at contract inception, the amount of variable consideration to which it most likely expects to be entitled. The most likely amount is an appropriate estimate of the amount of variable consideration when the contract has only two possible outcomes. Only (part of) the variable consideration is included in the transaction price to the extent that it is highly probable that a significant reversal in the amount of cumulative revenue recognized will not occur when uncertainty associated with the variable consideration is subsequently resolved.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The promise in a contract with a customer to produce a non-scripted or scripted show that consist of a number of episodes including the promise to grant a license is considered to be one performance obligation. 172 ----- Where a contract has multiple performance obligations, the transaction price will be allocated to each performance obligation based on stand-alone selling prices. This performance obligation will be satisfied over time, since the customer gains control over the produced content at separate moments during the project; or the content produced does not have an alternative use and Endemol Shine has an enforceable right to payment while the produced content is being transferred. Endemol Shine measures the progress towards complete satisfaction of the performance obligation based on output methods. The output measurement can either be the delivery of a program or the reaching of milestones (if specifically stated in the contract). Milestones are considered to be reached once the customer approval has been obtained.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Distribution Revenues (From the Sale of Programs and Licensing Rights)
Subsubsection Text: Distribution revenue is derived from contracts with customers including a license. Endemol Shine promises a right to use the format/programs as they exist at the point in time at which the license is granted to the customer. This means that the customer can direct the use of and obtain substantially all of the remaining benefits from the license at the point in time at which the license transfers. Endemol Shine does not have any obligations towards improving or renewing the licensed format/program after start license date. Therefore, distribution revenue is recognized at a point in time. Contracts with customers can include a non-refundable minimum guarantee that effectively establishes a floor amount of consideration paid. Endemol Shine recognizes the revenue for non-refundable minimum guarantees at a point in time. In case the transaction price for granting a license is based on usage-based royalties, Endemol Shine recognizes the revenue as the underlying usage occurs.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Revenues from Other Rights and Services
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from commercial contracts is based on production of content and/or granting a license. The transaction price of a license is mostly dependent on usage-based royalties (number of views or number of clicks). Revenue will be recognized at a point in time, when such usage occurs. Where Endemol Shine has received consideration but has not transferred goods or services yet, Endemol Shine presents the contract as deferred revenue (contract liability). Where Endemol Shine has, partially or in full, satisfied the performance obligations but not yet billed the customer, Endemol Shine presents the contract as un-invoiced revenue (contract asset), excluding any amounts presented as a trade receivable. Endemol Shine capitalizes costs to fulfil a contract only when the costs relate directly to a contract or an anticipated contract that the entity can specifically identify; the costs generate or enhance resources of the entity that will be used in satisfying or continuing to satisfy performance obligations in the future; and the costs are expected to be recovered. These costs are presented as production cost assets and are actual costs incurred for the production. The asset is amortized in line with the satisfaction of the related performance obligation. For disclosure purposes, Endemol Shine nets per production the amounts related to un-invoiced revenue, deferred revenue and production cost assets and present them separately as “Other assets related to contracts from customers” or “Other liabilities related to contracts from customers.” Endemol Shine does not adjust the promised amount of consideration for the effects of a significant financing component where the period between when the customer receives the good or service and when the customer pays for that good or service will be one year or less.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine recognizes government grants initially as deferred income at fair value if there is reasonable assurance that they will be received, and Endemol Shine will comply with the conditions associated with the grant. Subsequently, grants are then recognized in profit or loss as other income on a systematic basis over the useful life of the asset. Grants that compensate Endemol Shine for expenses incurred are recognized in profit or loss on a systematic basis in the periods in which the expenses are recognized. 173 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: At the end of each reporting period it is assessed whether there is any indication that an asset may be impaired. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated. _Goodwill and Other Non-Current Intangible Assets with Infinite Lives_ Goodwill and other intangible assets with infinite lives are tested for impairment annually, or more frequently when there is an indication for impairment. Endemol Shine performed and completed annual impairment tests in the last quarter of the financial year. An impairment loss is recognized for the amount by which the asset’s carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less cost of disposal and its value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value, using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset. An impairment loss is recognized in the income statement and allocated first to reduce the carrying amount of the goodwill and then to the other assets of the cash generating unit pro-rata on the basis of the carrying amount of each asset in the unit. An impairment loss recognized for goodwill is not reversed in subsequent years. Except for goodwill, Endemol Shine assesses in subsequent years whether indications exist that impairment losses previously recognized for non-current assets may no longer exist or may have decreased. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of that asset (or cash generating unit) is recalculated and its carrying amount is increased to the revised recoverable amount. The increase is recognized in the income statement. A reversal is recognized only if it arises from a change in the assumptions used to calculate the recoverable amount. An impairment loss is reversed to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net amortization, if no impairment loss had been recognized. _Other Non-Current Assets with Finite Lives_ Other non-current assets with finite lives are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated using an approach similar to that applied for non-current assets with infinite lives. For an asset that does not generate independent cash inflows, the recoverable amount is determined for the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs. Impairment losses recognized in prior periods are assessed at each reporting date for any indications that the loss has decreased or no longer exists. An impairment loss is reversed if and to the extent there has been a change in the estimates used to determine the recoverable amount. The loss is reversed only to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortization, if no impairment loss had been recognized. Reversals of impairment are recognized in the income statement.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For equity-settled share-based payment awards granted to employees, the grant-date fair value is generally recognized as an expense, with a corresponding increase in equity, over the vesting period of the awards. The amount recognized as an expense is adjusted to reflect the number of awards for which the related service and non-market performance conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognized is based on the number of awards that meet the related service and non-market performance conditions at the vesting date. For share-based payment awards with market or non-vesting conditions, the grant-date fair value of the sharebased payment is measured to reflect such conditions and there is no true-up for differences between expected and actual outcomes. For cash-settled share-based payments, a liability is recognized for the goods or services acquired, measured initially at the fair value of the liability. The services received from employees are recognized as an expense over the vesting period of the awards, with recognition of a corresponding liability. At the end of each reporting period until the liability is settled, and at the date of settlement, the fair value of the liability is re-measured, with any changes in fair value recognized in profit or loss. 174 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Earn-out Payments / Put Option Rights in Favor of Minority Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: The liabilities with respect to acquisitions (earn-out obligations) are estimated on the basis of the expected future results of the respective companies (performance-related criteria). The majority of earn-out obligations are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. Earn-out obligations are calculated using management’s best estimate of the expected future cash flows and using the applicable historical interest rate including a mark-up reflecting the risks of the market in which Endemol Shine operates. Discount rates used vary around 10%. The main liabilities relate to the companies acquired in the UK. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. In a number of business combinations, Endemol Shine granted the seller/non-controlling shareholder a put option to sell in the future (part of) the remaining shares to Endemol Shine. These put options are regarded as a financial liability in Endemol Shine’s consolidated financial statements. The majority of put options are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the consideration to be paid upon exercise of the options. Discount rates used vary between 5% and 10%. Put option liabilities primarily relate to the companies acquired in the United States and the United Kingdom. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecast EBITDA, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. As the majority of the put options are payable within the coming year or are near the end of the option period, changes in EBITDA or discount rate will not have a material impact on the value of put option liabilities as per balance sheet date.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine defines EBITDA as profit for the period before depreciation, amortization, impairment, financial income, financial expense, share in profit of associates and income tax. EBITDA is not a measurement under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to (a) net profit, (b) cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities, or as a measure of Endemol Shine’s ability to meet cash needs, or (c) any other measures or performance under IFRS. EBITDA is not a direct measure of Endemol Shine’s liquidity, which is shown by Endemol Shine’s statement of cash flows and should be considered in the context of the financial commitments. EBITDA may not be indicative of Endemol Shine’s historical operating results and may not be predictive of Endemol Shine’s potential future results. Given that all companies do not calculate EBITDA identically, the presentation of EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly named measures of other companies. Exceptional items are excluded from management’s assessment of results because by their size, nature or incidence, they could distort Endemol Shine’s underlying quality of earnings. Such items are disclosed on the face of the consolidated statement of comprehensive income and separately in the notes to the financial statements. They are typically gains or losses arising from events that are not considered part of the core operations of the business (such as costs relating to capital transactions, including professional fees on acquisitions, one-off restructuring costs, shareholder management fees, earn-out and put option-related remuneration expense, long-term incentive plan expenses and gains and or losses on disposal of assets). These items are excluded to reflect performance in a consistent manner and are in line with how the business is managed and measured on a day-to-day basis.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Finance income primarily comprises interest income on funds invested, fair value gains on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, gains on the re-measurement to fair value of any pre-existing interest in an acquiree in a business combination, gains on hedging instruments that are recognized in profit or loss and reclassifications of net gains previously recognized in other comprehensive income. 175 ----- Interest income and expense is recognized as it accrues in profit or loss, using the effective interest method. Finance costs comprise interest expense on borrowings, unwinding of the discount on provisions and deferred consideration, fair value losses on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss and contingent consideration, impairment losses recognized on financial assets (other than trade receivables), losses on hedging instruments that are recognized in profit or loss and reclassifications of net losses previously recognized in other comprehensive income. Borrowing costs that are not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognized in profit or loss using the effective interest method. Foreign currency gains and losses on financial assets and financial liabilities are reported on a net basis as either finance income or finance cost depending on whether foreign currency movements are in a net gain or net loss position.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Current Tax_ The current tax payable is based on taxable profit for the period and includes adjustments to tax payable or receivable in respect of prior periods. Taxable profit differs from profit as reported in the income statement because of items of income or expense that are taxable or deductible in other periods and items that are never taxable or deductible. Endemol Shine’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. _Deferred Tax_ Deferred tax is recognized on temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the consolidated financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognized for all taxable temporary differences. Deferred tax assets are generally recognized for all deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which those deductible temporary differences can be utilized. Such deferred tax assets and liabilities are not recognized if the temporary difference arises from the initial recognition of goodwill or from the initial recognition (other than in a business combination) of other assets and liabilities in a transaction that affects neither the taxable profit nor the accounting profit. Deferred tax liabilities are recognized for taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries and associates, and interests in joint ventures, except where Endemol Shine is able to control the reversal of the temporary difference and it is probable that the temporary difference will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred tax assets arising from deductible temporary differences associated with such investments and interests are only recognized to the extent that it is probable that there will be sufficient taxable profits against which to utilize the benefits of the temporary differences and they are expected to reverse in the foreseeable future. A deferred tax asset is recognized for unused tax losses to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be utilized. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realized. Such reductions are reversed when the probability of future taxable profits improves. Unrecognized deferred tax assets are reassessed at each reporting date and recognized to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period in which the liability is settled or the asset realized, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner in which Endemol Shine expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and Endemol Shine intends to settle its current tax assets and liabilities on a net basis. 176 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: All financial instruments are initially recognized at fair value, plus or minus (in the case of a financial asset or financial liability not at fair value through profit or loss (“FVTPL”)) transaction costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition or issue of the financial instrument. Endemol Shine classifies and subsequently measures financial assets at either amortized cost or FVTPL. Financial assets measured at amortized cost include trade receivables, other financial receivables and cash and cash equivalents. Derivative such as purchased options, swaps and forward contracts are measured subsequently at FVTPL. There are no financial assets classified as fair value through other comprehensive income. Since January 1, 2018, Endemol Shine has applied the IFRS 9 simplified approach to measure expected credit losses which uses a lifetime expected loss allowance for all trade receivables and uninvoiced revenue (as defined in Note 2 to the Audited Endemol Shine Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018). For trade receivables or uninvoiced revenue that do not contain a significant financing component, the loss allowance should be measured at initial recognition and throughout its life at an amount equal to lifetime expected credit loss. Endemol Shine uses a provision matrix which is based on the historical credit loss experience over the life of the trade receivables. Endemol Shine subsequently measures financial liabilities at amortized cost, unless they are required to be measured at FVTPL. Financial liabilities measured at amortized cost include trade payables, other financial payables, cash and cash equivalents and loans and borrowings. Liabilities required to be measured at FVTPL include derivatives (such as foreign currency forwards or interest swaps), earn-out obligations and put-option liabilities. The amortized cost of a financial asset or financial liability is defined as the amount at which the financial asset or financial liability is measured at initial recognition minus the principal repayments, plus or minus the cumulative amortization using the effective interest method of any difference between that initial amount and the maturity amount and, for financial assets, adjusted for any loss allowance. Financial assets are derecognized when, and only when, the contractual rights to the cash flows from the financial asset expires or it transfers the financial asset and the transfer has qualified for derecognition. Endemol Shine derecognizes financial liabilities when, and only when, it is extinguished, such as when the obligation is discharged or cancelled or expires.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Distribution advances are advances paid for some productions to another company from which future revenue is expected to be derived. These advances are classified as current assets as they are expected to derive a short-term economic benefit for Endemol Shine. These advances are not expensed until the production is available for distribution or has been distributed. Up to that point, they are assessed annually for impairment through the reassessment of the future sales expected to be earned from that title.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Preparation of the Statement of Cash Flows
Subsubsection Text: The statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method. Changes in balance sheet items that have not resulted in cash flows (for example, translation differences, financial leases, fair value changes, conversions of debt to equity) have been eliminated for the purpose of preparing this statement. Dividends received are included in investing activities, whereas dividends paid to ordinary shareholders, interest received, and interest paid are included in financing activities. For the purposes of the cash flow statement, bank overdrafts that are an integral part of the company’s cash management are included as a component of cash and cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at the bank (both debit and credit) and (call) deposits.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following are certain of the key accounting policies applied in preparing Endemol Shine’s consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For information regarding recent and pending changes to Endemol Shine’s accounting policies, see “Factors _Affecting Comparability of Endemol Shine’s Financial Statements—Changes to Accounting Standards.”_ 177 -----

Section Title: ENDEMOL SHINE’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion of Endemol Shine’s financial condition and results of operations in the periods set forth below, based on data extracted or derived from the financial statements of the Target as discussed under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” You should read this discussion in conjunction with Endemol Shine’s consolidated financial statements included under “Selected Historical Financial Information,” and the Endemol Shine Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The following presentation and analysis contains forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that Endemol Shine consider reasonable, involve risks and uncertainties. For the reasons explained under “Disclosure Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this offering memorandum, Endemol Shine’s future results may differ materially from those expected or implied in these forward-looking statements._

Subsubsection Title: Global Television Market Size and Growth Potential
Subsubsection Text: The global television industry is large and growing, although this growth is expected to be somewhat slower in the coming years as new technology is fully absorbed by the market. Valued at approximately €386 billion in 2018, the global television industry is projected to continue growing at a CAGR of approximately 1.9% from 2019 to 2023, reaching a value of approximately €419 billion, which is slightly slower growth as compared with a CAGR of approximately 2.2% between 2014 and 2018. The television industry’s key revenue streams, pay TV subscriptions (approximately 45% of value in 2018) and advertising (approximately 36% of value in 2018), are both expected to continue growing from 2019 to 2023, albeit more slowly than in recent years in the case of subscriptions and license fees due in large part to increasing SVOD use. License fees (approximately 7% of value in 2018) are expected to remain stable with a growth at a CAGR of less than 1% from 2019 to 2023, which is somewhat slower growth as compared with the growth in license fees of approximately 1% in the period between 2014 and 2018. SVOD revenues (approximately 7% of value in 2018) are also expected to continue growing at a CAGR of approximately 14% from 2019 to 2023, which is slower growth as compared with the SVOD revenues CAGR of approximately 40% that was observed over the 2014 to 2018 period, primarily due to plateauing internet penetration. The graphic below shows the past and projected growth of global television market revenues and revenue sources over the 2014 to 2023 period.

We operate in the global television and digital content industry, which has traditionally had a value chain made up of five component groups: producers, distributors, broadcasters, channels and platforms, each of which traditionally committed to addressing a single vertical within the market. The production and distribution components have largely consolidated, with many broadcasters (such as BBC Worldwide), major studios (such as Disney, Warner Brothers and NBC Universal) and scaled studios (including independents) (such as Banijay) having both production and distribution in-house. There remain a large number of independent producers who tend to operate on a somewhat smaller scale and usually do not have distribution capabilities. Next in the value chain are broadcasters/channels, which may be public service broadcasters (such as PBS in the United States, France Télévisions in France, ARD in Germany, ABC in Australia and the BBC in the United Kingdom), commercial channels (such as ABC in the United States, ProSieben in Germany and TF1 in France), thematic pay TV channels (such as Canal Plus Group in France and HGTV in the United States) or premium pay TV channels (such as Sky in the United Kingdom, Canal Plus in France, Movistar in Spain and HBO in the United States). Platforms are also an important part of the global television value chain and may be cable (such as Virgin Media), satellite (such as Sky or DIRECTV), internet protocol television “IPTV” (such as BT), digital terrestrial television “DTT” (such as Freeview) or VOD. VOD platforms, which are recent market entrants and are driving change in our industry, may be AVOD (such as YouTube), subscription-funded “SVOD” (such as Amazon Prime Video, Netflix and Hulu) or transactional “TVOD” (such as iTunes Store and Google Play). Television viewing generally has two axes: traditional “linear” viewing, ordinarily on a TV set, and OTT viewing on a TV set, computer or mobile device (including VOD viewing), with some platforms, such as the BBC, offering both linear and VOD viewing options. In addition, a number of newer SVOD options have recently, or are expected to, come online, including Apple TV+ (offering exclusive television show and movies and launched in November 2019), Disney+ (aggregating content from Disney, Marvel, Pixar, Lucasfilm and Fox and launched in November 2019), HBO Max (offering original content from Warner Brothers, HBO and the CW and expected to launch in the first half of 2020) and Peacock (a streaming service from NBC Universal offering original programming, catalogue titles and reboots and expected to launch in April 2020). Over its almost 70-year history, the global television industry has grown consistently and is currently in a period of significant transition and development. At its advent, television was a relatively restricted local industry, with two to four broadcasters in most countries, public service broadcasters dominating and highly regulated commercial networks. From the late 1970s, the industry entered a period of liberalization in which pay TV channels emerged and expanded in an environment of regulatory relaxation and economies that boosted demand for advertising. In the late 1980s, satellite and cable offerings drove multi-channel offers in many markets, while premium sports and movie programming also expanded. Beginning around 2000, the “content revolution” saw formatted non-scripted content spread across the globe and become international brands, which was boosted by technological improvements such as digital television and broadband acceleration. The present period is characterized by another set of technological improvements and consumption shifts, with the rapid expansion of OTT viewing as well as internet-based television content aimed at the global market, the growth of the Asian and Latin American television markets and a shift in power along the value chain in favor of content and direct-to-consumer offerings. 178 -----

North America accounted for 44% of the global television industry in 2018, while North America accounted for only 28% of global GDP that same year. The graphic below shows the geographic split of global television market share in terms of revenues in 2018. 24% 44% 5% 25% 1% Europe Latin America Asia Pacific MEA North America Notably, the Asia Pacific (“APAC”) and the Middle East and Africa (“MEA”) regions, which have been the fastest growing television markets in recent years (5.4% and 8.3% CAGRs, respectively, between 2014 and 2018), still have shares of the global television market (approximately 25% and 1%, respectively, in 2018) that are significantly smaller than their share of global GDP (36% and 6%, respectively in 2018), indicating room for potential growth. Between 2019 and 2023, the APAC and the MEA markets are projected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 5% each and the Latin American market is projected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 4%. These emerging markets are thus expected to drive revenue growth over the next four years, while revenue growth in North America and Europe is expected to slow in the coming years. The graphic below shows the past and projected growth of global television market revenues by geographic region over the 2014 to 2023 period. bn 450 FORECAST 400350300 3531785[4] 3641888[4] 3762090[5] 3812091[5] 38621936 38922946 22966 23977 2499 10025 250 200 80 84 90 94 98 102 108 113 118 123 150 100 167 169 172 170 168 166 167 165 165 164 50 0 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 |3 27 06 3 258 01 3 268 16 3 15 473 3 146 84 5 85 88 90 91 93 80 84 90 94 98 167 169 172 170 168|3F 28 6O 29RECAST 3 29 6 29 4 270 34 4 21 7 42 4 21 7 59 94 96 97 99 100 102 108 113 118 123 166 167 165 165 164| |---|---| MEA Latin America Europe APAC North America The primary types of channels/platforms each rely on a different revenue mix and are exposed to different geographic and industry macro trends. In 2018, network television accounted for approximately €124 billion in revenues, thematic channels accounted for approximately €81 billion in revenues, premium services accounted for approximately €55 billion in revenues and SVOD accounted for approximately €26 billion in revenues. As regards revenue sources, network television is largely advertising-funded (approximately 71% of revenues in 2018) and is thus reliant on revenues that are highly sensitive to macroeconomic trends, as compared with premium services and SVOD, which rely on subscriptions (approximately 89% and 100%, respectively, of revenues in 2018). Premium service revenues are highly exposed to the “cord cutting” trend (whereby viewers abandon expensive pay and premium services in favor of less expensive OTT options) in the U.S., although subscription revenues have increased in other geographies. SVOD has proven to be an attractive complement and alternative to traditional pay TV models, particularly among younger populations. SVOD also has a potent ability to impact the wider market. For example, their comparatively high spending on original content is forcing other players to increase content spend, as further discussed below. Thematic channels, which are packaged by platforms as part of a basic pay TV offer, have the most diversified and balanced revenue mix, with advertising and carriage fees (fees paid by platforms to broadcasters to carry their channels) composing the majority of revenues, but their exposure to advertising revenues still remains high and the specialized nature of their content can make them less attractive to advertisers. As regards geographic revenue trends, the North American television market is characterized by higher advertising spend per capita and higher pay TV penetration as compared with the Rest of the World, while the two dominant European markets, Germany and the United Kingdom, are supported by comparatively high pay TV spend, as well as advertising and license fees. The graph below shows content spend in Western Europe, which has remained stable throughout the economic downturns, notably between 2007 and 2009 where total content spend, excluding sports rights content, grew 0.3% while aggregate television advertising revenues dropped by 14.2%. 35 30 25 20 15 10

_Market Size and Growth Potential_ The global content production industry is currently worth approximately €158 billion, representing approximately 41% of global television industry revenues (with approximately 20% of total global television industry revenues being spent on primary commissions/originations and approximately 22% being spent on news, sports rights and film and television rights acquisitions). The graphic below shows the global television industry’s content spend splits in 2018. 200 **ALL CONTENT 180 160 16 News 140 Sports 120 34 rights **PRIMARY COMMISSIONS 100 18 Filmrights TV rights (secondary & 80 158 15 international) 15 Drama 60 4 Comedy 16 Non-scripted already formatted 40 76 12 Non-scripted formattable 20 18 Other factual 11 Sports, children’s, current affairs etc 0 Content spend Primary commissions spend Content production revenues have grown in recent years and are projected to continue growing at a CAGR of approximately 4.7% from the period between 2020 to 2025, underpinned by the rise of (i) OTT platforms (particularly global SVOD players Netflix and Amazon Prime Video) that drive both supply and demand for content and increase levels of competition as well as total investment, (ii) competitive pressure on broadcasters that push them to increase their content investment in order to retain their audiences (particularly vis-à-vis OTT technology), (iii) the increasing influence of Asian content markets, particularly as large importers of content from Europe and North America and (iv) continued demand for high-budget drama content as a driver of audiences from one network/platform to another. _The Production Process Development and creation of new content: Content producers like the Combined Group create and develop_ new program concepts (known as “formats”) for television broadcasters and digital platforms, such as VOD platforms. Programs and formats may be either “non-scripted,” such as reality shows, entertainment shows, game shows or talk shows, or “scripted,” such as comedies or dramas that follow a written story and plot line. Content may either be produced by the producer who created the program/format or by a third party that acquires the rights to produce the content through a license agreement for a specific program/format and a specific geography. Content has traditionally been developed to cater to the viewer preferences of specific geographic markets but is increasingly being developed for wider audiences on a global scale, driven by the content offer of global VOD services. _Commissioning and sale of new content: Once a program/format has been developed, it is pitched to_ broadcasters and/or digital platforms. A pitch generally includes a detailed description of the program/format or, in certain instances, a full “pilot” is prepared by the production company, either at its own expense or with the financial support from the broadcaster or digital platform. The sales process for a format also generally includes the preparation of detailed production schedules and budgets for the broadcaster or digital platform to consider when deciding whether or not to commission a program/format. A program or format may either be originated (for example, a new program or format is commissioned by a broadcaster or digital platform), or it may be acquired (for example, the rights to an existing format are licensed for local adaptation by a broadcaster or digital platform). _Production and airing of new content: Once a broadcaster or digital platform has confirmed the_ commissioning or purchase of a program/format, the production process begins and programs based on the format are put into production. Production processes vary significantly depending on the type of format/program, but generally involve pre-filming preparatory work, filming, content editing and preparation of the program for 181 ----- delivery to the broadcaster or digital platform. Scripted programs generally require a more cost- and timeintensive development and production process, as compared with non-scripted programs. The commissioning broadcaster or digital platform generally has no obligation to air a program after its delivery.

Content distributors control the rights to the content developed as described above. Distributors enter into license agreements with licensees (mainly broadcasters and digital platforms), whereby such licensees may exercise certain rights to a given format/program, including the right to produce and/or air a format/program for a certain period of time and for a predetermined number of runs in a specific territory. Distribution of content allows production companies to increase their profits because costs associated with managing and selling a content library are relatively low, as compared to production costs. As a result, our industry has witnessed significant consolidation of production and distribution functions in recent years. Certain producers have pursued a vertically-integrated strategy, owning their own distribution business, as we do with our distribution companies. However, not all producers have their own distribution business and, as such, will grant licenses to distribution companies to distribute their formats/programs on their behalf, in exchange for a distribution commission. Historically, large international production groups such as Fremantle have been focused on maintaining exclusive intellectual property rights to their content catalogues within the territories in which they operate: this business model generates additional production value and distribution revenues from format fees paid by broadcasters. The royalties generated by the distribution business (the fees distributors receive from their licensees after deducting their commission) constitute important secondary revenues for the owners of the intellectual property rights to the format or program. As part of the commissioning and sale process, the broadcaster or digital platform may try to obtain ownership of the intellectual property rights to the program and/or the format itself. The owner of the intellectual property rights will generally control the future use of the program and/or format across jurisdictions and will, as a result, benefit from additional revenues generated, for example by exporting the format to additional markets and worldwide program sales. Depending on the market, broadcasters may retain all or part of such rights in the program and/or format. Otherwise, production companies, including the Combined Group, retain full intellectual property rights to the format and program. The ability to capitalize on formats or programs in forms other than the initial licensing to broadcasters and digital platforms varies from one format or program to another. The additional rights received by a producer from the content it has produced are known as “secondary rights.” In some cases, the producer has no secondary rights, and in other cases, it may only have the right to distribute the content in certain media and territories for a limited term, depending on the ownership of the format and the agreement with the relevant broadcaster or digital platform. Additional rights, or “ancillary rights,” related to a format or program may also be granted to licensees, such as for merchandising, music rights, DVD sales, digital services and mobile applications. These ancillary rights can drive further revenues.

Companies that are in the television and digital content production and distribution industry have historically operated a B2B business model, with broadcasters, channels and platforms as their primary customers. As a result, the dynamics affecting the production and distribution markets were for a long time closely tied to those that impacted the wider broadcasting and television industry. However, due to the emergence of new content buyers (such as VOD platforms) and even some vertically-integrated direct-to-consumer offerings (such as Netflix), this traditional approach is changing. Traditional industry players are increasing their investments in original content (both scripted and non-scripted) largely driven by the entry of new OTT players such as Netflix, Hulu and Amazon Prime Video, among others, which place independent content developers, producers and distributors such as the Combined Group in a favorable position. The key forces that are currently driving the global television and digital content industry are technological shifts caused by the rise of OTT services, shifting consumer behavior favoring increased content spend and competition-driven consolidation. _Tailwinds in OTT Viewership and Global Proliferation of Content_ The key technological force that is driving our market today is the rise of OTT services, on the back of the “broadband revolution” of the early 2000s. While OTT platforms currently represent a relatively small portion of the market, their rise is likely to be one of the greatest disruptive forces challenging traditional industry players in the years to come. 182 ----- The reach of OTT technology is significant and growing. By the end of 2018, Amazon Prime Video, Netflix and Hulu collectively accounted for almost half of the combined content spend of the ten largest global networks/ platforms. Netflix has approximately 158 million subscribers worldwide, while Amazon had over 100 million subscribers to its “Prime” service, which includes its streaming video offering. Another useful measure of the rise of OTT is the number of SVOD subscriptions per household. The number of SVOD subscriptions per household varies across geographies, but is generally on the rise. The number of SVOD subscriptions per household is currently highest in the United States (with an average of 1.4 SVOD subscriptions per household), where “cord cutting” is also most prevalent, due in large part to consumer willingness to replace expensive pay TV services with one or more relatively less expensive OTT offerings. Denmark trails the United States in terms of average SVOD subscriptions per household (0.8), followed by Sweden (0.6), the United Kingdom (0.6) and Australia (0.5). Even where the number of SVOD subscriptions per household is already relatively high, there may be room for further growth, as it is relatively common for users to subscribe to more than one SVOD provider. Multiple SVOD subscriptions are expected to become more common as niche services with lower price points become more common. On the other end of the spectrum are other European countries, including Germany, France, Spain, Italy and the Netherlands, where the average SVOD subscription per household is at or below 0.4, which may also represent a growth opportunity. Lower penetration of SVOD is primarily the result of slower broadband speed, lack of local content and late market entry of local players. The graphic below shows past and projected SVOD penetration (as measured by the number of SVOD subscriptions in each country) in certain of our key markets over the 2016 to 2020 period.
