90.0% FORECAST 80.0% 70.0% 60.0% 50.0% 40.0% 30.0% 20.0% 10.0% 0.0% Denmark Sweden UK France Spain Italy 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 |Number of SVOD subscriptions / population|Col2| |---|---| |FORECAST USA Denma Swede UK France Spain Italy|| ||| _Note:_ _Does not take into account those with multiple subscriptions; true penetration therefore lower in reality Source: OVUM, OECD, Oliver & Ohlbaum analysis_ The OTT environment is dominated by global players Amazon Prime Video and Netflix, who have primarily focused on high-budget drama, although there are also a number of strong local players (most of whom are broadcaster-led) who tend to put more focus on innovation and on local content and production in order to compete with global players. Both Amazon Prime Video and Netflix are increasing their budgets and demand for content significantly. Excluding spending on sports content, Netflix and Amazon Prime Video spent the highest amounts (approximately €10.2 billion and €5.3 billion, respectively) on content in 2018, representing an increase from 2017 (approximately €7.6 billion and €5.0 billion, respectively). This increased spending was made up of both commissions and acquisitions. Among VOD platforms, Netflix delivers the most original shows and has increased the overall demand for content. Netflix has added approximately 1,000 original titles, including commissions, to its catalogue since 2012 and spent approximately 85% of its total programming budget on originations in 2018. Other traditional players have recently launched or are expected to launch OTT platforms, such as Britbox (ITV/BBC), RTL Group, Pro7, Salto (TF1/France Télévisions / Groupe M6), Mediaset Espana, Disney+, Peacock (NBC Universal), Apple+, Warner and HBO Max. In addition to their increasing consumer base, OTT have an outsized influence on the content market, as trends that first manifest at the OTT-level, such as binge-watching of boxed set content, tend to migrate to traditional platforms. For example, networks now look for global reach with brands such as Planet Earth. 183 ----- _Shifting Consumer Behavior Favoring Increased Content Spend_ The rise of OTT services described above is driving changes to consumer behavior, first in regards to viewing patterns and second in regards to demand for content. Viewing patterns show shift toward on demand viewing Generally, while “linear” viewing on a television set remains the most common form of viewing, global viewing habits are moving towards more on demand viewing. On demand viewing may take many forms, from time-shifted viewing on traditional broadcast television channels to the various online and/or streaming VOD options. The graphics below show this shift away from linear viewing in the United States between 2011 and 2016 and the United Kingdom between 2012 and 2018 in terms of daily viewing.

The Combined Group operates across markets in 22 countries. Our largest geographic markets for television and digital content production include France, the Nordic Countries, the United States, Italy and the United Kingdom. While we expect that most of our key markets will generally continue to expand in the near future, growth will likely be slower than in previous years. Although macroeconomic conditions in our key markets are expected to continue to generally support accelerated GDP growth, the television industry is generally highly sensitive to macroeconomic conditions, particularly in sectors that rely on advertising revenues. Further, while the rise of OTT may challenge traditional broadcasters, channels and platforms, we believe their growth represents an opportunity for content producers, especially for players like the Combined Group, because they drive content demand and represent a growing segment of content consumers. Each of our key markets requires a tailored approach to produce and distribute content successfully. In particular, the balance between traditional platforms and emerging OTT services vary in popularity and penetration across our key markets. _France_ Television revenues in France remained broadly flat in recent years, shrinking slightly from approximately €9.0 billion in 2016 to approximately €8.7 billion in 2018. Revenues are fairly evenly spread between license fees, advertising and subscriptions. Content spend as a proportion of revenues in France has also been relatively stable, at approximately 70% in 2016 and approximately 74% in 2018, of which more than half were acquisitions, approximately 25% were external commissions and approximately 14% were in-house commissions in 2018. In 2018, the main pay TV player in the French market was SFR (since its merger with Numericable), followed by Canal Plus and Orange, while TF1 is the main broadcaster, followed by France Télévisions and M6. SVOD penetration is increasing in France, from approximately 4% in 2016 to approximately 12% in 2018 and projected growth to approximately 17% by 2020. Independent producers outnumber in-house broadcast production companies and are very active in the television production sector. The high number of independent producers in France is due in part to the fact that French law requires broadcasters to dedicate a certain percentage of their revenues to commissioning independent audiovisual works. The largest players in the French independent production sector, other than the Combined Group, are Fremantle, Lagardère Studios and Newen. _Nordic Countries (Denmark and Sweden)_ Television revenues in Denmark and Sweden remained relatively stable from approximately €1.8 billion in Denmark and €2.2 billion in Sweden in 2016 to €1.7 billion in Denmark and €2.2 billion in Sweden in 2018. Revenues in Denmark and Sweden are fairly evenly spread between license fees, advertising and subscriptions, with subscriptions representing the largest source of revenues. Content spend as a proportion of revenues in Denmark and Sweden has also been relatively stable, at approximately 55% in Denmark and approximately 49% in Sweden over the 2016 to 2018 period. The main pay TV players in Denmark are TDC and Boxer Denmark and in Sweden were Tele 2 and Canal Digital, while DR and TV 2 are the main broadcasters in Denmark and SVT, TV4 and NENT Group are the main broadcasters in Sweden. SVOD penetration is high and increasing in Denmark and Sweden, from approximately 37% and 35% respectively in 2016, to approximately 58% and 52% respectively in 2018 and projected growth to approximately 70% and 65%, respectively, in 2020. The major independent production players in Denmark, other than Banijay and Endemol Shine, are Fremantle, NICE Entertainment, Red Arrow Studios and Warner Brothers. The Swedish independent production industry is dominated by local independent producer NICE Entertainment, who competes with international production houses like the Combined Group, Fremantle and ITV Studios. _United States_ The United States is an important geographic market in terms of both production and consumption. Television revenues have declined in recent years, shrinking slightly from approximately €125 billion in 2016 to approximately €115 billion in 2018. Revenues are heavily skewed towards subscriptions, which accounted for approximately 64% of revenues in 2018. Content spend as a proportion of revenues in the United States has increased in recent years, from approximately 38% in 2016 to approximately 41% in 2018, of which almost half were acquisitions, approximately 39% were external commissions and approximately 10% were in-house commissions in 2018. The primary commercial networks are CBS, NBC, ABC and Fox and the primary pay TV market was fragmented, with many platforms (such as Charter, Comcast and AT&T) offering similar packages. SVOD penetration is high and increasing in the United States, from approximately 36% in 2016, to approximately 56% in 2018 and projected growth to approximately 78% in 2020. The major U.S. studios (including Disney and Warner Brothers, as well as independent players MGM and Lionsgate) dominate the production sector, but the independent production sector remains fragmented. 186 ----- _Italy_ Television revenues in Italy decreased slightly in recent years, from approximately €8.4 billion in 2016 to €8.0 billion in 2018. Revenues are spread between license fees, advertising and subscriptions, of which advertising has the largest share (over 40% in 2018). Content spend as a proportion of revenues in Italy has increased slightly, from approximately 59% in 2016 to approximately 61% in 2018, of which approximately 58% were acquisitions, approximately 18% were external commissions and approximately 15% were in-house commissions in 2018. The broadcast market in Italy is fairly consolidated, with four networks (RAI, Mediaset, Discovery and La7) dominating the market. In 2018, the main pay TV players were Sky, Mediaset and Telecom Italia. SVOD penetration is increasing in Italy, from approximately 1% in 2016 to approximately 3% in 2018 and projected growth to approximately 6% by 2020. The production industry in Italy has had success in altering global formats for an Italian audience and is led by, other than the Combined Group, independent production players such as Fremantle and MGM. _United Kingdom_ The United Kingdom is a leading geographic market for the creation and launch of formats because broadcasters demonstrate a willingness to experiment with new ideas and the legal framework protects producers’ rights to their programs. Television revenues in the United Kingdom have fluctuated in recent years, from approximately €17.1 billion in 2016, to approximately €16.8 billion in 2017 and approximately €16.1 billion in 2018. Revenues are spread between license fees, advertising and subscriptions. Content spend as a proportion of revenues in the United Kingdom has been increasing, from approximately 50% in 2016 to approximately 52% in 2018, of which approximately 58% were acquisitions, approximately 21% were external commissions and approximately 15% were in-house commissions in 2018. Competition is high among network broadcasters, as the broadcast market is highly fragmented, with BBC1 holding the single largest viewing share (approximately 21%) in 2018, followed by ITV1, BBC2, Channel 4 and 5, and with all other channels accounting for more than 47% of the viewing market. In 2018, the main pay TV players were Sky, Virgin Media, BT and Talk Talk. SVOD penetration is increasing in the United Kingdom, from approximately 19% in 2016 to approximately 29% in 2018 and projected growth to approximately 37% by 2020. The production industry in the United Kingdom is highly competitive and was valued at over £3 billion in 2018. The key independent production players in the United Kingdom are Endemol, All3Media, Avalon TV, Carnival, Fremantle and Left Bank.

Competition in the television and digital content production and distribution sectors remains fragmented: in many markets, a number of small, independent groups are important market participants. We have observed in recent years a trend towards significant consolidation within our industry, particularly through vertical consolidation and business combinations of market participants with one another. We believe that this consolidation is driven, in part, by market players’ desire to expand their content portfolios, thereby allowing them to further develop their capacity to successfully distribute their formats and programs. For example, most leading production groups also have established distribution businesses. This branch of activity allows them to market and sell their content and formats internationally to broadcasters and digital platforms. We have been an active and successful player in the consolidation of our industry and Banijay has been the only significant producer and distributor with worldwide operations that has managed to remain independent, as the majority of large European production houses are now controlled by established broadcasting groups. The Combined Group is the largest independent content producer based on revenues and content production hours for the year ended December 31, 2018. The Combined Group competes with other integrated production and distribution groups such as ITV Studios, Fremantle and All3Media, as well as smaller independent production companies, such as Tinopolis. Certain competitors, such as ITV Studios, have experienced significant growth through M&A activity in recent years. This is a reflection of the overall consolidation trend in the industry. There are four key types of players in the global content production and distribution industry: major studios (such as Warner Brothers and Disney), in-house content divisions (such as ITV Studios and BBC Worldwide), scaled studios (including independents) (such as Banijay) and smaller independents (such as Hat Trick and Beta), with local players, although locally significant, having a comparatively small global role. _Major studios: major studios, most of which are based in the U.S., such as Warner Brothers and Disney,_ tend to produce high-quality and expensive scripted content. Although we do produce scripted content and intend 187 ----- to focus more resources on scripted content in the future, we do not typically directly compete with major studios for content production contracts. Major studios tend to have integrated production and distribution businesses. _In-house content divisions: certain broadcasters, such as BBC or ITV in the United Kingdom, maintain their_ own in-house production departments. Some players have large in-house departments, as opposed to outsourcing their content production to third parties. Companies with in-house production capacities are integrated, as both production and distribution is done in-house. _Scaled studios (including independents): scaled studios (including independents) are often established_ through business combination transactions whereby independent producers in various markets are combined into one international group. In order to succeed and maximize market share, these groups typically maintain a presence in the United Kingdom and the United States in light of these markets’ importance for the overall industry. Scaled studios (including independents) are free to experiment with different content formats and pursue various production avenues. They are well-known for producing non-scripted formats which are popular with broadcasters as they tend to be low-risk opportunities as their production costs are significantly lower than scripted content. Scaled studios (including independents), including Banijay, tend to have integrated production and distribution businesses. _Smaller independents: independent companies are generally groups whose activities are limited to a specific_ domestic or specialist market. In general, small independents focus on a particular niche area or may even specialize in a specific show format and are known for producing creative content and are often on the cutting edge of innovation. Smaller independent companies include Elephant & Cie and Coyote in France, Hat Trick and Avalon in the United Kingdom and Ballandi in Italy and 7 y Accion and Zebra TV in Spain. Smaller independents tend not to, but may, have integrated production and distribution businesses. The major players in the global content distribution industry are largely the same as in the global content production industry, following the consolidation of many key producers with distributors in recent years. 188 -----

Minutes per person per day 300 250 200 150 100 50 0 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 CAGR 2012-2018 14.2% 22.1% 23.5% 1.5% -3.3% Linear TV DVR- Time shifted AVOD SVOD Online short-form Pay TV VOD Note: DVR-Time Shifted refers to digital video recording in which television program is digitally recorded for viewing after scheduled broadcasting. Viewer preferences and platform strategies are driving increasing content spend As a result of this shift toward online and on demand viewing, content supply is expected to increasingly reflect the demands of OTT audiences, which are currently characterized by viewer appetite for high-budget scripted content and more globalized viewer tastes. Content spend is expected to continue increasing, due in part to increased investment by VOD players and traditional players seeking to compete with VOD players, new sources of revenue from online offerings and innovation in content forms. At present, viewer demand is largely focused on high-budget scripted content, which is driving polarization of spend and schedule allocation. Global annual commission spending grew at a CAGR of approximately 2% between 2012 and 2018, within which drama content was the fastest growth area (approximately 7%), followed by formatted non-scripted entertainment (approximately 3%), sports, children’s and current affairs content (approximately 2%) and factual entertainment (approximately 2%). On one hand, increased spending on drama content has been driven in part by a shift in consumer habits to binge-watching of boxed set content and competition among cable channels for subscription fees, with the largest volume gains in the United States. On the other hand, spending on formatted non-scripted entertainment, which increased markedly (above 10%) between 1998 and 2008, has slowed as schedules have filled with established programs and formats. However, demand for non-scripted content, in which the Combined Group has particular experience and strength, continues to be high. For example, audience preferences in the APAC market, which is expected to drive total content spend and growth in the size of the global TV market, are skewed towards non-scripted formats such as game shows, quiz shows, talent shows and reality competitions. Additionally, as a counter to increased spending on high-budget drama, some spending has shifted to more cost-effective formats, including non-scripted and factual entertainment programs such as “lifestyle shows,” another trend that may benefit the Combined Group in the years to come. Content spend as proportion of revenues varies across business models: in 2018, premium services invested approximately 75% of revenues in content (after platform margins) followed closely by SVOD (72%), as compared with 64% by network television and 43% by thematic channels. High content spend by SVOD players 184 ----- is expected to decline once SVOD reaches scale, as these players begin to see higher margins. Content spend has been relatively resilient during downturns. During the dot-com crash in the early 2000s content spend continued to rise, even as advertising revenues fell, and during the 2008 financial crisis, content spend remained stable in Western Europe, even as advertising revenues dropped precipitously. Content spend is projected to expand at a CAGR of approximately 4.7% between 2020 and 2025 (compared to a CAGR of approximately 6% between 2017 and 2020), with growth expected across all service provider types (network television, thematic channels, premium services and SVOD) through 2025, as shown by the graphic below. CAGR CAGR 18–20 20–25 217 158 176 37 SVOD 19.0% 10.0% 18 24 35 24 28 Premium 8.3% 4.9% 53 36 40 Thematic 5.7% 6.2% 80 82 89 Network TV 1.5% 1.5% 2018 2020 2025 SVOD Premium Thematic Network TV **Total** **5.7%** **4.7% _Source: Olivier & Ohlbaum Analysis_ Content spend also varies widely among regions, both in terms of content spend as proportion of revenues and commissions spend as a proportion of revenues. Estimated content spend ratio is highest in Europe (60% of revenues in 2018, with 26% of revenues spent on commissions), as compared with 40% (with 18% of revenues spent on commissions) for North America and 45% (with 21% of revenues spent on commissions) for APAC. High spend on content in Europe is driven by the strength of public service broadcasters that tend to invest in local content and external producers. Within Europe in 2018, content spend as a proportion of revenues was highest in France and Spain, followed by Italy and Denmark. Content spend in North America, which has historically been comparatively lower than Europe and APAC, is expected to increase as major networks are pushed to invest more heavily in content to compete with VOD players as competition increases between VOD players. In addition, in most of the countries where the Combined Group operates, these content demand patterns tend to favor the growth of the independent sector in which the Combined Group operates. For example, in 2018, external productions accounted for over a third of all non-news commissions in the United Kingdom (58%), Germany (40%), France (64%), Italy (54%), Spain (64%), the Netherlands (38%), Sweden (73%) and Denmark (51%). _Consolidation Shifting the Dynamics Among Content Industry Players_ The global television and digital content production and distribution industries are in a period of consolidation, in which large integrated media companies are consolidating and undertaking M&A to strengthen their positions across the supply chain, scaled studios (including independents) like Banijay are acquiring smaller indies to maintain a fresh flow of intellectual property and platforms are acquiring channels and investing more in content production, as discussed above, as a result. Horizontal consolidation has led to the emergence of very large production groups and vertical consolidation has led to broadcasters and digital platforms increasingly owning their own content. VOD players, such as Netflix and Amazon, are also expanding their content businesses. We believe that this consolidation is driven, in part, by market players’ desire to expand their content portfolios, thereby allowing them to further develop their capacity to successfully distribute their formats and programs. For example, most leading production groups also have established distribution businesses. This branch of activity allows them to market and sell their content and formats internationally to broadcasters and digital platforms. The rise of OTT technology and shifting consumer behavior patterns described above have both increased competition in our industry, with the increasing popularity of OTT viewing putting pressure on traditional players and with evolving viewing habits creating room for different players to distinguish themselves from their competitors. Traditional linear broadcasters are expanding their reach in the VOD space to respond to the rise of the players such as Netflix and Amazon, both at a local/regional scale and a global scale, if their market position allows it. U.S. networks such as Disney, Warner Bros or NBC are currently taking back their content portfolios for their own global VOD offerings. For example, in August 2017, Disney announced its plans to end its distribution agreement with Netflix for subscription streaming of new releases in anticipation of its own Disney+ streaming service, and in June 2019, NBC Universal announced that it had secured the exclusive domestic streaming rights to The Office for its soon-to-be-launched streaming service, ending The Office’s successful run on Netflix. 185 |176|217|Col3| |---|---|---| |176 158 24 18 24 28 36 40 80 82|37|| ||35 53|| ||89|| -----

Unless otherwise stated, the source of all industry metrics, estimates and projections used in this offering memorandum is Oliver and Ohlbaum. Industry publications generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but some of the information may have been derived from estimates or subjective judgments or may have been subject to limited audit or validation. While Banijay believes such market data and other information are accurate and correct, Banijay has not independently verified them. Furthermore, such estimates or judgments, particularly as they relate to expectations about our market and industry, involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements” and elsewhere in this offering memorandum. These projections and other forward-looking statements in this section are not guarantees of future performance and actual events and circumstances could differ materially from current expectations. Numerous factors could cause or contribute to such differences. See “Industry and Market Information,” “Risk Factors” and “Disclosure Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.” All forecasts relating to CAGRs are based on value at nominal prices effective today. Unless otherwise indicated, references to “we,” “us” and “our” in this section are to the Combined Group._

We are the world’s leading independent producer of television programs based on revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018. We create, develop, sell, produce and distribute television formats and programs and digital content for a wide range of customers and operate across 16 countries. We produce both scripted and non-scripted content across all genres, including reality shows, entertainment and talk shows, game shows, factual entertainment and drama. We have produced successful long-running programs such as Survivor, _Temptation Island, Wife Swap, Keeping Up with the Kardashians, Beat the Star, 71 Degrees North, Don’t Forget The Lyrics!, Fort Boyard, The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds, Versailles, Solsidan and Occupied._ We generate revenues through the sale of the programs we create and produce and the distribution of formats and programs for which we retain intellectual property rights and/or rights to revenues generated by these formats and programs. We own intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of formats and programs with approximately 20,000 hours of television content. We distribute and license the content we own and control through our subsidiary Banijay Rights Limited to a customer base of approximately 290 traditional broadcasters and global digital platforms, including approximately 220 broadcasters in Europe and the United States, our main geographic markets as of December 31, 2018. These broadcasters include France Télévisions, TF1, the BBC, Channel 4 Television, Fox and MTV, and digital platforms such as Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Facebook Watch and Viaplay. We retain the intellectual property rights to most of our formats and programs which are assets that we distribute worldwide, when possible, to continue to generate revenues through various channels, in addition to initial sales to broadcasters and digital platforms. We employ creative talents in the countries in which we operate to develop original formats and produce television programs based on our analysis of trends in the industry and the demands of our customers.

The Group was established in 2007 by a team of experienced professionals led by Stéphane Courbit, the founder and former CEO of Endemol France. Mr. Courbit initially invested in Banijay Holding through his family holding company, LOV Group Invest S.A.S., and subsequently integrated other private investors such as the Agnelli Family through Exor N.V., the Drago and Boroli families through De Agostini S.p.A., Jean-Paul Bize through AMS Industries and Bernard Arnault through Groupe Arnault S.E. The Group is currently managed by Mr. Courbit, who serves as Chairman, and by Marco Bassetti, our Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Courbit created the Group in order to build it into a worldwide brand in the production of television and digital content, mostly through acquisitions of key local television and digital content producers. We have acquired several television production companies since 2007, attracting leading managers in the television and entertainment industries. 2016 was a turning point for the Group following the completion of the Banijay Zodiak Merger. The Banijay Zodiak Merger significantly reinforced our library in both non-scripted and scripted content. Zodiak also had a complementary customer base with us (for example in France, where they focused on scripted content, and in Italy) and a complementary geographical reach (for example with Zodiak’s presence in the United Kingdom). Upon the completion of the Banijay Zodiak Merger, Stéphane Courbit increased his shareholding in the Group and Vivendi acquired a strategic stake in the Group. 189 ----- We also established several joint ventures in the United Kingdom and the United States, the most active markets for international scripted shows. Over the past two years, we have developed our scripted activity with programs such as drama series Pine Gap (the first Netflix original program commissioned in Australia), the daily soap opera Familie in Belgium or Il Paradiso delle Signore in Italy and, more recently, with the commission of _Young Wallander by Netflix in the United Kingdom. The following timeline shows the main companies created_ and the acquisitions made during the development of our business: Creation of Vivendi Banijay becomes a Group shareholder **2007…2015** **2016** **2017** **2018** **2019** **2020** Several Strategic Acquisition acquisitions and merger completed creation of new completed on on Jul -17 Screen companies 23- Feb-2016 Media Created Acquired

We create, develop, sell, produce and distribute television formats and programs and digital content for a global market across the 16 countries in which we operate. We consider the operations of all of our subsidiaries to be similar and thus classify our operations into the following two main businesses: - _Production Business: Our production business consists in creating and developing original formats of television programs (scripted and non-scripted) through our production companies based on our analysis of trends in the industry and the needs of broadcasters, global OTT such as Netflix, Facebook Watch or Amazon Prime Video and other digital platforms. We benefit from the creativity and expertise of all our talents. These talents are necessary in order to maintain our policy to exclusively adapt our format catalogue through the Group’s local production companies in markets where we are present. In addition, we also acquire from time to time licenses for formats owned by third parties in order to produce and license the program based on such formats to a broadcaster or a digital platform. - _Distribution and Secondary Business: We generate revenues from the international distribution and licensing of intellectual property rights and merchandizing of successful formats and programs. Our distribution business consists of licensing and distributing our portfolio of formats and programs owned and/or controlled by the Group to traditional television channels, local producers and digital platforms. We operate our distribution business primarily through our subsidiary in the United Kingdom, Banijay Rights Limited. 190 ----- The following graphs show our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018 by (i) geography, (ii) business, comprising production, distribution and other revenues (excluding intercompany revenues between the production, distribution and secondary operating segments) and (iii) subgenre, as well as production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018 by genre, comprising scripted, non-scripted and other.

Subsection Title: Production Revenues by Genre** **Production Revenues by Subgenre
Subsubsection Text: We develop television programs both based on formats created in-house or by licensing formats from third parties in order to meet the demands of broadcasters. _Development of Formats_ The first step in our production process is to develop new concepts for television programming. Once these concepts are developed and formalized, we refer to them as “formats” and maintain intellectual property rights over such formats, when possible. A successful track record and creative reputation are key to continuing to develop original formats. From time to time, we also license the right to produce formats that are owned by third parties, rather than developed in-house, in order to address popular consumer trends and broadcasters’ needs. We either continue to develop these formats in-house or pitch them to broadcasters and digital platforms. We develop a wide variety of formats in order to limit our exposure to blockbusters and to keep a diversified portfolio of formats. We classify our formats in two main genres: non-scripted and scripted. Non-scripted content includes formats that do not follow a written story (for example, entertainment, game shows or reality shows), which are the majority of the formats we develop; while scripted content includes formats that follow a written scenario, mainly drama and comedy. We have historically focused on developing non-scripted formats, which is the core 191 ----- business implemented by our founder and Chairman, Stéphane Courbit. Non-scripted formats benefit from lower production costs, a shorter development period and more advantageous financing arrangements, because the broadcaster who purchases the non-scripted format typically funds the full production costs. Non-scripted formats can generate significant secondary revenues because they can be licensed and produced in several countries under different names. For example, a game show with a strong brand awareness can be developed in many countries, sometimes under different names but with an identical concept. Several large production groups, such as ITV Studios or Fremantle, have grown by exporting successful non-scripted formats in all countries where they maintain operations. For the year ended December 31, 2018, non-scripted contents generated in total €615.1 million, or 85.9%, of our production revenues. On the other hand, scripted formats require higher upfront development costs and often need to be co-produced by several parties. We have significantly expanded our scripted activity to meet our customers’ and the market’s increasing demand for scripted content. We currently have companies producing scripted programming in the majority of the 16 countries where we are present. Scripted programs can also generate significant secondary revenues, especially if such programs are in English because they can be sold worldwide to broadcasters and to local or global digital platforms. We develop new formats in each of our geographic markets. Our local subsidiaries have their own creative teams which work together with a central content team at the Group-level. Our central content team coordinates the local teams, keeps them informed of market trends outside their own territories and contributes to the creation of formats that address both local markets needs and global trends. If successful, these formats may be licensed and used in different markets and via different platforms. We develop original formats and programs in five principal genres: Non-scripted: - _Entertainment and Talk Shows: Entertainment and talk shows mainly encompass entertainment formats and programs that are studio-based. We believe our most successful entertainment programs include _Touche pas à mon poste! (internationally named It’s Only TV!), Go, Beat the Star, Versus, All Against 1, Fort Boyard, Big Class Reunion, The Best Singers and Child Support. Entertainment titles have_ significant potential for secondary format sales because they are easily adaptable to different local markets. For the year ended December 31, 2018, our entertainment content and talk shows generated €183.6 million in production revenues. - _Reality: Reality includes television programs in which ordinary people are continuously filmed outside their usual environment, designed to be entertaining rather than informative. We believe our most successful reality programs include: The Challenge, Real World, Paradise Hotel, Survivor, Temptation _Island, and Party Workers (called Les Marseillais and Les Ch’tis in France). For the year ended_ December 31, 2018, our reality content programs generated €179.8 million in production revenues. - _Factual_ _Entertainment:_ Factual entertainment is a combination of factual/documentary and entertainment programs, focusing on social experiments and popular topics. We believe our most successful factual entertainment programs include The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds, Location, Location, _Location, Revealed, Wife Swap, Keeping up with the Kardashians, Ball in the Family and Eat Well For Less. For the year ended December 31, 2018, our factual entertainment content programs generated_ €134.6 million in production revenues. - _Game Shows: Game shows are predominantly programs in which contestants compete for prizes during games of knowledge, physical challenges or by luck. We believe our most successful game shows include Don’t Forget the Lyrics!, Tipping Point, Killer Karaoke and The Legacy. Game shows have significant potential for secondary format sales because they are easily adaptable to different local markets. For the year ended December 31, 2018, our game show content programs generated €92.1 million in production revenues. For the year ended December 31, 2018, other genres of non-scripted content programs generated €25.0 million in production revenues. Scripted: _Scripted: Scripted includes drama, docu-drama and scripted comedy filmed in several programs following a_ written script. We believe our most successful drama programs include Versailles, Wallander, Occupied, _Millennium, Wolf Creek and Saint Tropez (Sous le soleil). Successful docu-drama brands include American_ 192 ----- _Playboy and Roman Empire. Formatted comedy series include Solsidan, Ladykracher and Pastewka. For the year_ ended December 31, 2018, our scripted content programs (excluding kid’s programming) generated €91.5 million in production revenues and other genres of programs (including kid’s programming) generated an additional €9.3 million in production revenues. Once a concept has been selected, our teams develop the format itself, through the creation of mechanics, game play, casting, set and music. Subsubsection Text: Our Group policy is to aim to retain intellectual property rights to our formats and programs. These formats and programs are assets that continue to generate secondary revenues through various channels, other than the initial sale to a broadcaster or digital platform. We own all or part of the intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of existing formats and programs, for which distribution rights are granted to Banijay Rights Limited. We distribute both formats and programs that we have produced and formats and programs in which we have acquired intellectual property rights but that have been produced by a third-party production company. Through our distribution business, we have, for example, distributed Versailles to 238 territories. Approximately 24% of the catalogue, in terms of hours of programs, of our distribution business consists of third-party programming from independent producers without their own distribution business and networks from around the globe. We distribute the content we own and license through Banijay Rights Limited to a traditional customer base of broadcasters and producers as well as VOD platforms. We license our portfolio of formats to producers, broadcasters and digital platforms, who can acquire from Banijay Rights Limited an option to pitch our formats to broadcasters. Once the format is commissioned by such broadcaster, such licensee acquires a license of the format through a format license agreement in order to produce a program based on such format and allow the broadcaster or digital platform to air the program as per the terms of the format license agreement. The licensees pay us an option fee to be granted the right to pitch the format and a format fee upon signing of the format license agreement once a commission is confirmed. In consideration of such format fee, they are allowed to produce a program based on our format and to air it in their local territory for a certain period of time. _Distribution of Programs to Broadcasters_ We distribute our portfolio of television programs directly to linear broadcasters, basic and premium cable networks, and international pay-television distributors. For the year ended December 31, 2018, sales of programs to broadcasters represented 61.6% of our distribution revenues. The broadcasters pay us a license fee in return for the right to air a program across a given period of time and for a given number of runs. Banijay Rights Limited receives a commission on that license fee for its distribution activity, and the remainder of the license fee is paid to the owner of the program (i.e., either our local production company owning the intellectual property rights or the third-party owner of the intellectual property rights). 194 ----- _Distribution of Programs to Digital Platforms_ We distribute our portfolio of television program titles to digital platforms, including SVOD providers such as Netflix or Amazon Prime Video and AVOD platforms such as Facebook Watch. For the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, 31.2% and 38.4%, respectively, of the gross revenues of our distribution business was generated through the revenues from the sales of our portfolio of programs licensed to VOD platforms such as Facebook Watch, Apple TV, Amazon Prime Video and Netflix and other revenues allocated to other digital platforms (mainly SVOD rights). In the United States and, to a lesser extent, Europe, consumers, particularly younger consumers, are viewing more content on more devices and through SVOD or AVOD platforms, such as Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime Video and Roku. SVOD requires consumers to enter into a subscription contract giving the consumer access to content, including exclusive content, from the digital platform. In the United States, SVOD services have increased the value of our catalogue series and movies due to increased viewership by consumers and the correlating demand and spending by digital platforms. Netflix, for example, reported that it had spent $12 billion in acquiring content in 2018. However, SVOD services specifically and the OTT model generally remain less widespread in Europe due to free-to-air offerings and the lower cost of pay-television bundles in Europe compared to the United States. As of December 31, 2018, we have license agreements with most of the main digital platforms and aim to further expand our agreements with them. These customers, such as Amazon Prime Video and Netflix, use our content on their platforms. These partnerships allow subscribers of the relevant networks to access our programs across a variety of devices. As of December 31, 2018, our content was available to approximately 260 million subscribers indirectly through our partnerships with Amazon Prime Video and Netflix. _Other Secondary Revenues_ Other secondary revenues include revenues from commercial activities related to our formats, such as merchandizing, DVD sales, music and events. Other secondary revenues complement revenues from the initial sale to broadcasters and digital platforms and our distribution revenues.

Subsection Title: Selected customers Number Countries Airing In 2018 Country of origin Total Number Of Territories since Launch Top 5 Shows Year Of Launch
Subsubsection Text: Temptation Island_ 2001 5 United 18 W9, USA (The Netherlands, Belgium, States Network Finland, Italy, Romania) Survivor_ 1997 14 Sweden 40 TF1, La (Italy, France, Czech Trois, CBS Republic, Sweden, New Zealand, Denmark, Belgium, United States, Spain, Greece, the Netherlands, Australia, Finland and Turkey) Fort Boyard_ 2002 4 France 30 France 2, (France, Sweden, Finland, Nickelodeon Germany) Wife Swap_ 2003 5 UK 27 Channel 4, (France, Russia, Poland, the TFX Netherlands, Germany) Versailles (scripted)_ 2015 France 238 Canal Plus, Netflix _Sales and Commissioning to Broadcasters_ Once we have developed original formats in-house or acquired option rights to third-party formats, we organize various presentations to pitch these formats to broadcasters and digital platforms. We usually approach broadcasters and digital platforms with a detailed presentation and/or a trailer for non-scripted formats, but when we present a scripted format, our pitch consists of a logline, a synopsis and a treatment. A logline is a onesentence description of the show. A “synopsis” is a brief summary of the show that includes information about the main characters and the theme of the show. A “treatment” is the more detailed, in that it includes detailed descriptions of the characters and the show’s plot. We also develop, in some instances, a trailer or a full pilot for a television show. We provide broadcasters with detailed project timelines and budget plans for production and negotiate with them to agree on the terms of their acquisition of rights to our programs, particularly with respect to pricing and retaining intellectual property rights that will enable us to generate secondary sales across various platforms and distribute the program in other regions. Key negotiation points include: (i) the duration of the license; (ii) the scope of rights granted to digital platforms and broadcasters, such as free VOD services (as discussed below) and ancillary rights; and (iii) holdbacks and options for renewal. We use our combined resources across other production projects and our expertise to propose competitive and lean production plans to broadcasters. _Production Process_ Once a format has been developed and sold to a broadcaster or digital platform, we begin the production process and produce a program based on such format. The process consists of producing and filming the show, editing the content as well as choosing and, when possible, publishing and producing the soundtrack. We operate a fully funded production model for the majority of our programs whereby broadcasters commit upfront to fund the full cost of the production in exchange for their right to use the program within the scope agreed with them. If broadcasters pay us after we incur production costs, we may fund this shortfall through financing arrangements 193 ----- or through our working capital. If we have longer cash flow shortfalls, in particular for scripted projects, we aim for broadcasters to cover our financing costs. Broadcasters also often receive a portion of the secondary revenues and, subject to market trends and our bargaining power, a portion of the intellectual property rights to the format or the program. We aim to keep intellectual property rights to our programs. Rights to a program are easier to protect than rights to a format, because a program is a finished product that has already aired, compared to a formalized concept. However, certain of our customers with an international footprint through distribution or broadcasting (such as large broadcasters or SVOD platforms) may ask to retain a portion or all of the intellectual property rights of our programs, depending on market practices. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business— _Customers may request to obtain intellectual property rights to the formats we create and programs we produce, which may have a negative impact on our revenues.”_ We have implemented cost-efficient, flexible and scalable production processes throughout our Group. For example, we use freelancers and lease production facilities in order to limit our investment in fixed assets. We have also implemented strict cost control, in order to deliver final programs on time and respect customers’ budgets. Cost control is especially important for scripted programs which require higher costs and longer production processes than non-scripted programs. _Internal Circulation of Our Formats_ As an independent production group, one of our major strengths is our network of producers who have exclusive access to our catalogue of formats in their respective geographic markets. This internal feed of formats is key for our local Group companies. We prioritize the production of successful formats in the markets in which we operate. Our central content team centralizes all the relevant information and material on new formats and upcoming, promising titles are circulated among our production companies. For example, Temptation Island, _Wife Swap, The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds, All Against 1, Eat Well for Less and Location, Location, Location are_ successful formats developed by one of our production companies in a given market and then produced by several of our production companies in their respective markets.

We are one of the largest independent television content producers in France. We generated 22.3% of our revenues in France for the year ended December 31, 2018. We had eight main operating subsidiaries in France as of September 30, 2019: - _Adventure Line Productions: Adventure Line Productions was founded in 1972. Adventure Line Productions produces original formats and programs based on formats owned by third parties for the main French broadcasters, cable and channels in a range of genres, including adventure, reality, light entertainment, factual entertainment, dramas and game shows. It is known for its long-standing production of the French version of Survivor (Koh Lanta) and Fort Boyard. It also produces factual entertainment series such as the French adaptation of Are You the One? and youth programming _Minikeums. The current president of Adventure Line Productions is Alexia Laroche-Joubert, a well-_ known French television personality. - _Banijay Production Media: Banijay Production Media (formerly Air Productions) was founded in 1993 by Nagui, one of France’s most popular television hosts. Banijay Production Media produces game shows, fiction and entertainment formats as well as French adaptations of third-party titles, mainly with Nagui as host. Nagui hosts game shows such as Don’t Forget the Lyrics! and Hold On to Your Seat as well as several entertainment prime-time shows. He is also the creator, host and producer of an iconic music show called Taratata which has been airing since 1993. - _Banijay Productions: Banijay Productions was founded in 2007 by two French producers, Alexia Laroche-Joubert and Lionel Vialaneix, both formerly at Endemol France. Banijay Productions 195 ----- produces a range of genres, but is most recognized for its long-running factual entertainment and reality franchises, Les Ch’tis/Les Marseillais, known internationally as Party Workers, which is now in its 19th season, as well as the more family-oriented Une Saison au Zoo, in its tenth season, both of which have numerous spin-offs. It also recently produced the local adaptation of our blockbuster _Temptation Island._ - _Banijay Studios France: Banijay Studios France was founded in 1999 by Christian Charret. Banijay Studios France produces, directly or indirectly through its subsidiaries, drama programming. These programs include Saint-Tropez (Sous le soleil) and Versailles, the most recent season of which has been sold internationally to more than 180 territories. Recent titles include Les Ombres Rouges and the French adaptation of the successful Amazon Prime Video scripted program Fleabag. - _H2O Productions: H2O Productions was founded by French media personality, Cyril Hanouna, and produces its own entertainment formats as well as third-party formats. H2O Productions’ flagship production is the daily live talk show hosted by Cyril Hanouna, Touche pas à mon poste! (known internationally as It’s Only TV), one of the main daily entertainment talk show in France in 2018 and simulcasted in Belgium. It has also been adapted in Lebanon and Italy. - _KM: KM was founded in 1994 by Renaud Le Van Kim. KM produces current affairs programming, documentaries and large-scale prestigious live events. Its productions include the annual opening and closing ceremonies of the Cannes Film Festival and the French national film awards, La Nuit des _Césars. It also produces the daily current affairs talk show 28 minutes and documentary series Revealed, as well as local adaptation of Group formats The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds and Eat Well for Less._ - _Non Stop People: Non Stop People was founded in 2012 as the first 24/7 news channel entirely focused on celebrity news, broadcasting only original content with approximately four hours of new content per day. Non Stop People employs journalists to cover international and local stars for television as well as for digital platforms, such as mobile devices, tablets. - _Terence Films: Terence Films was founded in 2005 by producer Bertrand Cohen and director Stéphane Meunier. It specializes in scripted programming and is responsible for the long-running daily soaps _Foudre, Cut and OPJ. The company also produced the adaptation of the format Les Innocents for TF1_ prime-time.

We are one of the key independent television content producer in the Nordic Countries. We generated 19.0% of our revenues in the Nordic Countries for the year ended December 31, 2018. We have 12 production subsidiaries in the Nordic Countries as of September 30, 2019: _Denmark_ - _Mastiff: Mastiff is one of the leading production companies in Denmark in many genres including reality, entertainment, lifestyle, factual entertainment, reportage, crime, kids and scripted genres. Mastiff produces both original and international formats, including Strictly Come Dancing, Paradise _Hotel and Versus._ - _Nordisk Film Television: Nordisk Film Television develops and produces more than 700 hours annually of premium content for major broadcasters across a range of genres and sub genres, including entertainment, reality television, factual entertainment, current affairs and talents shows, as well as across digital and new distribution channels. Its most well-known programs include the talk show franchise Go, All Against 1 and Sold and Broken. - _Pineapple Entertainment: Pineapple Entertainment produces comedy, talk shows and entertainment shows, both scripted and non-scripted, including, Night Shift and We Love Cars. - _Respirator: Respirator is the oldest comedy production company in Denmark. It produces satires, comedies and documentaries, including, Dybvaaaaad, which is in its seventh season, and Monte-Carlo. _Finland_ - _Banijay Finland: Banijay Finland produces prime-time shows for the main Finnish networks. Banijay Finland’s shows include The Best Singers, Temptation Island and Have I Got News For You, the last of which has been on the air since 1998. 196 ----- - _Zodiak Finland: Zodiak Finland produces television dramas and feature films including the successful children’s franchise Jill and Joy, which premiered in cinemas in January 2014 and led the company to produce three additional films. Its most well-known programs include Cuckoo’s Nest, Frozen Hearts, _Brothers and The Look of a Killer. Norway_ - _Mastiff Norway: Mastiff Norway is one of the main production companies in Norway. Mastiff Norway has produced a number of award-winning factual programs, factual entertainment and consumer shows, such as The Best Singers, Paradise Hotel and TV2 Helps You. - _Nordisk Film & Television: Nordisk Film & Television focuses on reality, drama and factual entertainment as well as, more recently, comedy. Its programs include 71 Degrees North, Psychic _Challenge and All Against 1. Sweden_ - _Jarowskij: Jarowskij is one of Sweden’s oldest production companies. Jarowskij produces many genres and sub-genres such as feature films, drama, current affairs, reality, entertainment and comedy. Jarowskij’s best-known program is Solsidan, which has been adapted in Finland and France. Jarowskij has also produced several dramas for the Swedish and international market including Black Lake and The Restaurant. The company has also won several national awards for its original work as well as an Emmy for Wild Kids. - _Mastiff Sweden: Mastiff Sweden is one of Sweden’s largest production companies, developing and producing its own entertainment formats, as well as international and third-party formats for the main channels in Sweden. Its programs include Wife Swap, Secret Millionaire, Survivor and Trash or _Treasure._ - _Nordisk Film Television Sweden: Nordisk Film Television Sweden produces many genres such as entertainment, factual entertainment, reality, children’s and branded entertainment, including programs such as The Unknown, Renovation Angels, The Rysberg Family and The Big Painting Challenge. - _Yellow Bird: Yellow Bird is a specialist in Scandi “noir” drama and has an international development slate with a range of television series and feature films, such as the Millennium Trilogy, Wallander and _Occupied._

We are a large independent television content producer in the United States, the world’s largest market for the consumption of television programs and digital entertainment content. We generated 16.1% of our revenues in the United States for the year ended December 31, 2018. We have four subsidiaries in the United States as of September 30, 2019: - _Bunim/Murray Productions: Bunim/Murray Productions was co-founded in 1987 by Mary Ellis Bunim, a soap opera producer, and Jonathan Murray, who built his career in news and documentaries. Together, they created a reality genre with mass appeal beginning with The Real World, initially aired on MTV for more than 30 seasons and now revived on Facebook Watch. Bunim/Murray Productions is also involved in editing music. Bunim/Murray Productions has continued to be a leader in producing factual entertainment and reality programming, currently producing long-running shows such as _Keeping Up with the Kardashians, The Challenge and Ball in the Family._ - _Banijay Studios North America: Banijay Studios North America is a joint venture founded in 2014 with David Goldberg. It creates original network, syndicated and cable programming. David Goldberg produced Big Brother in the United States, the two-time Emmy-winning series Extreme Makeover: _Home Edition, Deal or No Deal, Fear Factor, Wipeout and the Emmy-winning series Steve Harvey._ Banijay Studios North America has also produced two prime-time entertainment series for ABC network: Big Fan (with Jimmy Kimmel) and two seasons of Child Support (with Ricky Gervais) and also adapts Group catalogue hit titles such as Temptation Island and Wife Swap. It has also recently been commissioned by ABC to co-produce a new family game show with actor Ryan Reynolds called _Don’t._ - _Stephen David Entertainment: Stephen David Entertainment was founded in 2010 by Stephen David, who created a new form of hybrid documentary especially well-adapted to major historical events, 197 ----- combining storytelling with special effects not typically seen on television. Stephen David Entertainment specializes in non-scripted historical series and documentaries, as well as selected scripted series and docu-dramas. Stephen David Entertainment has received multiple awards, including Emmy awards, for its productions The Men Who Built America, The West (featuring Robert Redford), _American Playboy and Jonestown (featuring Leonardo DiCaprio)._ - _Yellow Bird US: We launched in 2018 a joint venture between Bunim/Murray Productions and Yellow Bird Sweden, the Scandinavian drama company well known for its crime “noir” series Millennium, _Wallander and lately Occupied. The Chief Creative Officer is Marianne Gray._

We are one of the main players in the independent television content producer in Italy. We generated 15.1% of our revenues in Italy for the year ended December 31, 2018. After giving effect to the acquisition of ITV Movie, we had seven production subsidiaries in Italy as of September 30, 2019: - _Aurora Television: Aurora Television produces television series. It currently produces the daily soap opera Il Paradiso delle Signore (Ladies’ Paradise) for leading broadcaster Rai Uno. - _Banijay Studios Italy: Banijay Studios Italy is a production company specialized in drama content. - _ITV Movie: ITV Movie is an independent producer of television content with attractive commercial relationships with broadcasters (mainly Discovery or La7), producing successful talk show programs such as Fratelli Di Crozza with Maurizio Crozza or Di Martedì with Giovanni Floris. - _L’Officina: L’Officina is a production company created with well-known talk show host Fabio Fazio. It produces the entertainment talk show Che tempo che fa, which has been on air since 2003, for pubcaster RAI Uno. - _Banijay Italia: Banijay Italia was formed on November 4, 2019, subsequent to the merger between Dry Media S.r.l. and Magnolia S.p.A. The former Magnolia branch produced original and third-party formats across factual entertainment, entertainment, reality, game shows, lifestyle, documentaries, talk shows, drama, comedy and kids’ shows. Its most well-known shows include Celebrity Survivor, Piazza _Pulita, Guess my Age, L’Eredita (The Legacy) and Peking Express. The former DRY Media branch_ focused on creating and producing original formats for Italian and international markets in broadcast television, pay-television, digital terrestrial television and digital television platforms, including Be my _Guest, Cuochi de Italia, My Restaurant Rocks and Hell’s Kitchen._ - _Nonpanic: Nonpanic develops and produces factual entertainment, entertainment and reality programs for satellite and digital terrestrial television channels as well as for new distribution channels, such as _Married at First Sight or It’s Only TV (Sbandati). In addition, Nonpanic creates and produces_ advertisement and branded content products for various platforms.

We are a key independent television content producer in the United Kingdom. We generated 7.8% of our revenues in the United Kingdom for the year ended December 31, 2018. The United Kingdom television and digital content market is large for the size of the country, partially due to the international premium on English-language content, which means that productions in the United Kingdom have greater export potential than many other countries. We have recently reinforced our scripted activity in the United Kingdom by setting up four companies around key producers: Blacklight, Neon Ink, Fearless Minds and Yellow Bird UK Productions. Our subsidiaries in the United Kingdom include several production companies and labels, such as RDF Television, RDF West, Fizz, IWC Media, Wonder and The Comedy Unit. - _Blacklight: Blacklight is an independent production company in the United Kingdom and was formed in 2017. Notable films and television drama include Ellen, Being Human, The Curse of Steptoe and _North Square._ - _Fearless Minds: Fearless Minds is another scripted joint venture launched in 2017 with the successful BAFTA-winning producer Jolyon Simmonds. Fearless Minds got commissioned in 2019 For Life, its first production, for the American broadcaster AMC. - _IWC Media: IWC Media produces a range of television programs across various genres and sub-genres. Notable television programs include Wild Things, Fake it, Science of Stupid, Most Historic _Town and Location, Location, Location, the latter of which won at BAFTA Scotland in 2014 and is_ now in its 33rd season. 198 ----- - _Neon Ink: Neon Ink is an independent production company in the United Kingdom and was formed in 2017 to produce bold mainstream drama for the United Kingdom and international audiences. - _RDF Television: RDF Television is an independent production company in the United Kingdom and produces formats in entertainment, factual entertainment, comedy and documentaries, including The _Crystal Maze, Wife Swap, The Secret Millionaire, The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds and Eat Well For Less. RDF’s entertainment label, Fizz, produces a daily daytime quiz show, Tipping Point, which has_ nine seasons aired to date. - _RDF West: RDF West is an independent regional production company based in Bristol that produces factual series for the United Kingdom’s principal broadcasters, including Eat Well For Less? and Shop _Well for Less? and long running Daytime shows such as Dickinson’s Real Deal._ - _The Comedy Unit: The Comedy Unit is a large comedy company in Scotland. Notable television programs include Chewin’ the Fat, Scot Squad, Burnistoun and Rab C Nesbitt. The Comedy Unit has won at BAFTA Scotland six times, in addition to winning multiple RTS Scotland awards and receiving several Rose D’Or nominations. - _The Natural Studios/Bear Grylls: The Natural Studios is a global production company focused on adventure TV and film production, across all platforms. Its programs include Planet (Nat Geo), _Eco-Challenge (Amazon), Running Wild with Bear Grylls (Nat Geo), Emmy-nominated You Vs Wild_ (Netflix) and BAFTA-winning series, The Island (Channel 4). - _Wonder: Wonder is a production company that we acquired in 2018, which is specialized in factual entertainment series. It produces, among others, Diabetes, The Fast Fix, Billy Connolly and the kids game show Do You Know? - _Yellow Bird UK: Yellow Bird UK is one of the scripted joint ventures launched in the United Kingdom in 2017 and based on the similarly-named Swedish drama company. The productions of Yellow Bird UK are part of the Group’s strategy aimed at increasing its activity in this genre. In November 2018, it announced its first commission from Netflix for Young Wallander.

We generated 16.6% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018 in the following other markets where we operate. - _Germany: We operate in Germany primarily through the Brainpool companies and Banijay Productions Germany. The Brainpool companies produce entertainment and comedy shows. Comedians such as Luke Mockridge or Bastian Pastewka are under contract with the Brainpool companies. We took control over the Brainpool companies following a change in management and therefore fully consolidate Brainpool since December 31, 2018. Banijay Productions Germany is responsible for adapting several hit shows from the Group catalogue in Germany, including Fort _Boyard, Survivor and Temptation Island._ - _Spain: After the Banijay Zodiak Merger, we created a central management team in Spain that coordinates the operations of our companies in Spain, including two production companies. Cuarzo Producciones creates programming within the entertainment, factual entertainment, talk shows and docu-reality genres on all major national networks, including, Viva la Vida, Madrid Directo and Te lo _vas a Comer? We also produce drama and comedy series within the fiction genre that air_ internationally as well as factual entertainment, reality and entertainment shows that include The Rest _is History and My Restaurant Rocks for several regional broadcasters. In 2018, we acquired PortoCabo,_ a Spanish independent production company specialized in producing scripted content for television. Based in Galicia, PortoCabo develops scripted projects for national channels like Movistar+, Telecinco, Antena 3, TVE as well as international co-production with a Latin American footprint. PortoCabo’s main genres are crime thrillers and comedy. - _Australia: We operate in Australia through Screentime Australia. Screentime Australia produces drama, documentaries, reality and factual entertainment formats, as well as corporate television, and is best known as the creator of Popstars, the world’s first music reality competition. Popstars is one of our most successful television franchises. Screentime’s catalogue boasts the successful drama franchises Underbelly and Wolf Creek. Screentime Australia received the first original commission from Netflix in Australia called Pine Gap. It also produced successful entertainment shows such as _Brush with Fame and Hughesy We Have A Problem as well as factual entertainment series Playing for Keeps._ 199 ----- - _New Zealand: We operate in New Zealand through Screentime New Zealand. Screentime New Zealand produces dramas, docu-dramas, documentaries and factual entertainment programs, including, How to _Murder Your Wife, Police Ten 7 and I am Innocent. It also produces international drama series such as Straight Forward (co-produced with Mastiff Denmark) and The Gulf. Screentime New Zealand has_ won national and international awards for its productions and has recently taken on a producing role for overseas productions that come to New Zealand to film. - _Belgium: We operate in Belgium through Zodiak Belgium. Zodiak Belgium produces factual entertainment, reality, entertainment, drama, comedy, scripted reality and feature films for the main Belgian channels. Its programs include entertainment series So You Think You Can Dance, scripted reality and feature film The Beat, game show The Legacy and factual entertainment series The Best _Singers. The company also took over the production of the long-running daily soap opera Familie._ Zodiak Belgium has also developed a business as a local producer for third-party producers interested in benefiting from Belgian tax incentives. - _The Netherlands: We operate in the Netherlands through Zodiak Nederland. Zodiak Nederland produces original programming for the main Dutch networks, both public and commercial. Zodiak Nederland focuses on the development and production of factual entertainment content aimed at large audiences, including entertainment and reality, such as The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds, The Big Help _Test, The Most Dangerous Roads and The Nation’s Brightest._ - _Russia: We operate in Russia through Mastiff Russia. Mastiff Russia produces entertainment, reality and comedy shows from our catalogues for the Russian market, including, Wild Things, Survivor, Fort _Boyard and Who Can Beat Them. The company also produces successful reality shows for local social_ network platforms. - _India: We operate in India through Sol and Banijay Asia, a joint venture we founded in 2018. Sol produces reality shows, talent shows, talk shows, kids’ programming, dramas and daily soap operas, as well as live televised events in India, including Just Dance and Koffee with Karan. Banijay Asia produces both scripted and non-scripted shows, including The Voice India, ARRived and the adaptation of the Israeli scripted format Hostages.

We derive revenues from our operations in 16 countries, including the United States, France, the four Nordic Countries, Italy, the United Kingdom, Germany, Spain, Australia, New Zealand, Belgium, the Netherlands, Russia and India. We manage our production companies in these countries through a decentralized structure. This structure incentivizes our local managers and partners to grow their respective brand in their respective markets.

Our businesses operate in highly competitive industries and different competitive factors apply in each segment of our operations. _Production_ The television program production market is fragmented both in Europe and in the United States. Production companies in the United States also have greater exposure to content production and licensing revenues. In the United States, independent producers are mainly contracted to provide non-scripted formats to broadcast networks, and increasingly also to cable networks, while drama series tend to be produced in-house by these networks and digital platforms, such as HBO. Recent acquisitions of independent producers by large media companies seeking vertical integration or by larger independent production groups illustrate the strategic importance of geographical presence and access to content. Acquisitions enable market players to increase their content library and distribution capabilities and expand to different countries and distribution channels. Ongoing market consolidation has led to the creation of a few large international television production and distribution groups, including our biggest competitors, Fremantle, BBC Worldwide and ITV Studios Group Entertainment, each of which provide their local production companies with exclusive access to their catalogues. Our competitive position is greatly affected by the quality of, and public response to, our content. We also compete with other production companies and studios for the services of creative talents, producers, directors, writers, actors and others and for the acquisition of intellectual property. _Distribution_ We also face competition for the licensing and distribution of our formats and programs. As a distributor of programs, we compete with other studios, television production groups and independent producers. 200 ----- New opportunities in the production and distribution business have emerged due to the growing demand for new programs. Audience fragmentation has increased due to digital platforms, both global, such as Netflix and Amazon Prime Video, and regional and local, such as Britbox in the United Kingdom and Hulu in the United States. The portfolio of potential customers is increasing as are the opportunities for distribution and for secondary rights revenue generation. We also compete for viewers’ time against other forms of entertainment, including other television networks, premium pay-television services, local over-the-air television stations, OTT services, motion pictures, home entertainment products and services, video games, print media, live events, radio broadcasts and other forms of news, information and entertainment, as well as pirated content.

Each of our subsidiaries develops its marketing and sales strategies independently to address the local needs of broadcasters. Our Group central team focuses on increasing the international appeal of our formats and programs and how to market programs in other countries in order to export successful formats into new markets. Local production teams work in close relationships with our central marketing team to provide all the material needed (for example, sales video trailers or presentations) to promote the show internationally. Our distribution business promotes our formats and programs in various international and regional markets at events such as MIPCOM, MIPTV, NATPE and DISCOP. Endemol Shine’s central resources (for example, Creative Networks, Group Marketing and Endemol Shine International Limited) support promoting the international appeal of Endemol Shine’s formats and programs in order to successful distribution into new markets. Local production teams are provided with sales materials (such as trailers, sizzles or presentations) for sales pitches, while priority formats and programs are promoted yearround in international trade media and at sales markets including MIPCOM, MipCancun, RealScreen and NATPE.

We work with a broad network of customers and partners, including broadcasters, television channels, producers and digital platforms active in the markets in which we operate as well as with licensees and retailers of consumer products from around the world. We produced content for approximately 290 broadcasters in most of the major markets in Europe and the United States and had over 350 customers in 2018, many of which purchase multiple formats from us. Our main customers for our production business include broadcasters, such as France Télévisions, TF1 Group, ITV, the BBC, Channel 4 Television, RTL Group, TV2 Denmark, NENT, DR Denmark, TV4 Sweden, SKY, Mediaset, Rai Uno, Canal Plus Group, ABC Network, Discovery, E! and MTV, and also global OTT players, such as Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, and platforms such as Snapchat and Facebook Watch. For the year ended December 31, 2018, the top ten broadcasters of our production business accounted for 53.3% of the production revenues of this business and no single broadcaster accounted for more than 10.1% of the production revenues of this business. Our main customers for our distribution business include Netflix, Foxtel, Discovery, the BBC and Amazon Prime Video. For the year ended December 31, 2018, the top ten customers of our distribution business accounted for 55.1% of the gross revenues of this business and no single customer generated more than 13.3% of the gross revenues of this business.

As of December 31, 2018, approximately 1,200 employees are working full time in the Group, compared to approximately 900 employees as of December 31, 2017.
