Subsubsection Text: We also use the services of a significant number of freelance production artists and technicians. This number varies from time to time depending, in part, on the level of television production activity in which we are engaged. 201 ----- In connection with the acquisition of production companies in various jurisdictions, we have entered into, and continue to enter into, earn-out or put option agreements with certain managers and creative talents of these companies in order to incentivize them to continue to work with us following the relevant acquisition. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Earn-outs.” In addition, our management has implemented a long-term incentive plan to ensure the commitment of local management teams by rewarding key personnel based on their respective contribution to the value creation of their entity and that of the Group. Many of our employees, including writers, producers and technical and production personnel, as well as some of our on-air and creative talents, are subject to collective bargaining agreements. As of December 31, 2018, approximately 17.5% of our full-time or part-time employees and 12.5% of our freelance employees were covered by collective bargaining agreements. In 2018, there were no active strikes or work stoppages, and we believe that our relations with our union and non-union employees are good. We contribute to pension plans and other post-employment benefits as required by local law or on a non-mandatory basis.

Our intellectual property assets principally include copyrights in our formats and programs, filmed entertainment and other content; trademarks and service marks in brand names; trade names and logos and domain names, as well as licenses to use other intellectual property rights and licenses of our intellectual property to others. Our proprietary content constitutes a significant part of the Group’s value, and the protection of our brands and content is important. To protect our intellectual property rights, we rely upon a combination of copyright, trademark, unfair competition, trade secret and domain name laws, as well as nondisclosure agreements. Approximately 58%, 56% and, including the impact of the Banijay Zodiak Merger for the full period, 55% of our production revenue for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2017 and 2016, respectively, come from our owned intellectual property. We seek to limit challenges to our intellectual property rights, especially with respect to rights to our formats which are more difficult to protect and which may lead to significant legal fees if a dispute becomes transnational. We monitor trademark registrations and relevant third-party productions to ensure that there is no copyright infringement of our proprietary content. By involving our Group legal team in all material intellectual property litigation across the Group, we are able to ensure consistency in our claims and defenses. Endemol Shine’s intellectual property assets principally include copyrights in their formats and programs, filmed entertainment and other content; trademarks and service marks in brand names; trade names and logos and domain names, as well as licenses to use other intellectual property rights and licenses of their intellectual property to others. Over 50% of Endemol Shine’s production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018 came from its owned intellectual property. The intellectual property assets or rights for a particular Endemol Shine format is owned by the Endemol Shine production company that originally created the format. Such Endemol Shine production company licenses the rights to such format to ESIP, which in turn may license out that format to other Endemol Shine production companies to produce the format in their respective local markets and to third parties in markets where Endemol Shine does not have production companies. Where Endemol Shine production companies produce an Endemol Shine format that was created by another Endemol Shine production company (making it the originating production company), such Endemol Shine production companies pay format fees to ESIP for the use of the 217 ----- format in their respective local markets, computed on the total production revenues. In such cases, ESIP in turn pays format royalties to the originating production company that created the format from the format fees it receives from the production companies producing the format in other markets. Endemol Shine’s proprietary content constitutes a significant part of its value, and the protection of its brands and content is important. To protect its intellectual property rights, Endemol Shine relies upon a combination of copyright, trademark, unfair competition, trade secret and domain name laws, as well as nondisclosure agreements. Endemol Shine seeks to limit challenges to its intellectual property rights, especially with respect to rights to its formats, which are more difficult to protect and which may lead to significant legal fees if a dispute becomes transnational. Endemol Shine monitors trademark registrations and relevant third-party productions to ensure that there is no copyright infringement of its proprietary content.

Our business depends on the successful operation of information systems and other standard technology. We have also developed Becom, an internal network where creative talents and managers of the entire Group can share ideas, discuss trends and broadcasters’ demands and access content created by all entities of the Group and competitors. Becom forms part of the entrepreneurial and independent culture of our Group. Endemol Shine’s business depends on the successful operation of information systems and it aims to leverage new technologies to optimize production workflows and internal processes. Management information systems include SAP, various real-time systems (such as Workday for HR, and Easytrack and Jaguar for Sales), and various workflows based on Mendix technology, among others. Endemol Shine also has a global asset management system, and the first application of this was the Hub 2.0, Endemol Shine’s internal news and ideasharing platform. An example of how Endemol Shine leverages new technology is the application of AI in speech-to-text transcription to quickly transcribe raw footage into transcripts plotted on a timeline.

We do not own any real estate. Instead, in order to limit our fixed costs, we lease properties and production facilities that we use for our production business. In certain countries, such as the United States and Germany, our subsidiaries own production equipment and lease it to other entities of the Group or third parties. Endemol Shine mainly leases properties and production facilities that it uses for its production business and its sales business. In addition, in Spain, Endemol Shine owns four properties, two that it uses as office space, one that it uses for parking and one that it uses as a recording studio. Further, Endemol Shine owns an apartment in Italy. In certain countries, such as Sweden, Endemol Shine owns production equipment and facilities that it may lease to third parties from time to time.

We maintain a stringent quality assurance program to ensure the quality of our formats and programs. To this end, we conduct regular training of our employees and we perform regular audits at each of our subsidiaries, employing several professionals active in auditing and improving the quality assurance of our operations. Endemol Shine maintains a stringent quality assurance program to ensure the quality of its formats and programs. To this end, Endemol Shine conducts regular training of its employees and performs regular audits at each of its subsidiaries, employing several professionals active in auditing and improving the quality assurance of its operations. Endemol Shine also has dedicated central resources, such as its Creative Networks team, to share and monitor best practices across Endemol Shine and ensure the quality of its productions. Endemol Shine’s code of conduct describes the operational and ethical standards that apply to all of Endemol Shine’s employees (who are required to sign the code of conduct upon employment) and supports Endemol Shine’s commitment to corporate governance, risk management and social responsibility. An external whistleblowing hotline is in place enabling employees to raise concerns on a confidential basis.

We have property, directors’ and officers’, key man, workers’ compensation and other specific production insurance coverage in place to the extent that we believe it to be appropriate for operating our business. We cannot guarantee, however, that we will not incur losses beyond the limits or outside the coverage of our insurance policies. In addition, longer interruptions of business at one or more of our studios can, even if insured, result in the loss of sales, profit, customers and market share. 202 ----- Endemol Shine has general liability, errors and omission, directors’ and officers’, crime and fraud, property and other specific production insurance coverage (including for our staff) in place to the extent that Endemol Shine believes it to be appropriate for operating its business. Endemol Shine cannot guarantee, however, that it will not incur losses beyond the limits or outside the coverage of its insurance policies. In addition, longer interruptions of business can, even if insured, result in the loss of sales, profit, customers and market share.

We seek to achieve and maintain compliance with all applicable environmental, health and safety laws and regulations, and believe that we are currently in compliance with all such applicable laws and regulations. Endemol Shine seeks to achieve and maintain compliance with all applicable environmental, health and safety laws and regulations, and believes that it is currently in compliance with all such applicable laws and regulations. 218 -----

From time to time, we are party to a variety of claims and legal proceedings that arise in the ordinary course of our business. We do not expect the final disposition of these matters to have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, cash flow or financial condition. We have insurance and reserves to cover self-insured retentions for any material adverse outcomes in most claims. For claims in which insurance coverage may not be available, we have established reserves deemed to cover possible adverse outcomes and related fees. While it is not feasible to predict the outcome of all pending suits and claims, the ultimate resolution of these matters or of future lawsuits could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial position or reputation. _Dropped Dropped is a format where two teams of athletes or former athletes are dropped in a remote location by_ helicopter and have to make their way back to civilization without a map or a compass as quickly as possible. We developed this format into a successful program in Sweden and Norway where it aired in 2014 and 2015. At the end of 2014, we began to develop the format for a program in France through our subsidiary, Adventure Line Productions, with Argentina chosen as the location for the first series. Adventure Line Productions had subcontracted the logistics of the show to a specialized company, SAX Logistica (“SAX”). On March 9, 2015, two helicopters took off from Villa Catelli (La Rioja province) in Argentina carrying three contestants (renowned yachtswoman Florence Arthaud, Olympic champion swimmer Camille Muffat and Olympic boxer Alexis Vastine) and five employees of Adventure Line Productions. The helicopters collided with each other shortly after takeoff causing the deaths of all the passengers onboard each helicopter and the two pilots. Following the crash, the Argentinean federal prosecutor initiated a criminal investigation. Argentina’s aviation investigations unit, JIAAC, concluded that the crash had occurred because the pilots, although both experienced, failed to realize how close the helicopters were to each other as they were flying. The Argentinean judge in charge of the investigation has requested the depositions of the director of aviation for the La Rioja province, the secretary for tourism for the province and two individuals representing SAX, each of whom have been indicted. The helicopters that SAX provided were owned by the La Rioja province and the two pilots were employed by the La Rioja province. In France, the Paris prosecutor received Adventure Line Productions as a supervised witness (témoin assisté), a process by which a witness is questioned by the court in the presence of an attorney. Adventure Line Productions has not been indicted as of the date of this offering memorandum. The criminal investigations in Argentina and France are ongoing. The families of the five deceased employees of Adventure Line Productions have initiated separate civil actions against Adventure Line Productions and are requesting aggregate damages of approximately €3.8 million. Hearing dates have not been set for two of these claims, while the three other claims have been deferred or suspended, either in the first instance or by a court of appeal, until completion of the criminal investigation. In addition, the families of two of the three athletes who died in the crash have filed civil claims against Adventure Line Productions for damages, with one claim amounting to €4.2 million and with the other family still estimating the damages incurred. Both cases have been deferred until the outcome of the criminal proceedings or until further actions from the plaintiffs. Our production risks insurer, Liberty Syndicates Management Ltd. (“LSM”), paid €2.1 million to Adventure Line Productions in connection with this event. LSM then filed a civil claim against SAX, which was rejected by the Commercial Court of Paris. LSM appealed this decision in July 2019. Separately, Adventure Line Productions has filed a lawsuit against AXA based on our professional liability insurance for any potential damages (subject to insurance limitations and exclusions) awarded to the families of the victims in connection with the pending civil actions. In September 2019, this case was deferred as the criminal proceedings are still ongoing. _Koh Lanta_ In 2013, a participant in Koh Lanta (the French version of Survivor), a reality program we produce in France through Adventure Line Productions, died as a result of a heart attack during the filming of the program. 203 ----- Following his death, a French court opened a criminal investigation into whether anyone had caused the involuntary manslaughter of the participant. It has since been established that the participant suffered from a pre-existing heart condition. While the family and heirs of the participant have not initiated any civil proceedings, the criminal investigation is still pending. We expect the court to drop the case but are not a party to the investigation and therefore do not have access to court documents. Based on the information received to date, we will continue to argue that the death of the participant was the result of natural causes and that our production company was not in any way responsible. _Zodiak Belgium_ In 2019, Zodiak Belgium N.V. (“Zodiak Belgium”) initiated criminal proceedings against, among others, its former CFO and former CEO and Managing Director, on the basis of unlawful practices within Zodiak Belgium. Such practices involved the creation of fraudulent invoices to companies owned by, or otherwise related to, the former CFO, cash withdrawals, cash payments to employees and certain third parties, fictitious expense notes and fictitious invoices to foreign companies, amounting to approximately €11 million over the course of eight years. In March 2019, Zodiak Belgium terminated its agreements with the former CFO and former CEO, which the CFO has challenged before a commercial court. The former CEO has repaid €140,000 as compensation for cash he received. Zodiak Belgium is also seeking, as part of its criminal claim, the reimbursement by its former CFO of all amounts improperly disbursed by him or certain related parties. Following the results of this investigation, we have also focused on improving our internal compliance and control mechanisms at our production companies. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Our success is dependent, in part, _upon the integrity of our management and employees, and our risk management and internal controls may not prevent or detect violations of law.”_ From time to time, Endemol Shine is party to a variety of claims and legal proceedings (including personnel and tax related claims) considered typical for its businesses. Endemol Shine has provisions to cover the potential losses likely to arise in respect of these matters. While it is not feasible to predict the outcome of all pending suits and claims, the ultimate resolution of these matters or of future lawsuits could have a material adverse effect on its business, results of operations, financial position or reputation. Endemol Shine has various processes in place to mitigate legal risks, including quarterly reporting of litigation to its group legal function, an authorization and delegation policy with guidelines for the subsidiaries which has been recently updated and the format registration procedure which is a process for review and registration of intellectual property developed by Endemol Shine. _Endemol Shine Turkey_ In 2017, external advisors of Endemol Shine concluded that Endemol Medya Produ¨ksiyon Tic. Ltd. S¸ti. (“Endemol Shine Turkey”) was insolvent as its liabilities exceeded its assets and it was no longer able to pay its debts as they fell due. It was also determined that management at Endemol Shine Turkey obtained unauthorized loans and issued several checks in contravention of Endemol Shine’s governance policies. In May and June of 2017, two members of the local management team implicated in the aforementioned mismanagement were dismissed. On June 30, 2017, the shareholders of Endemol Shine Turkey applied for bankruptcy. Various claims were filed against Endemol Shine Turkey due to unpaid debts and checks. At the hearing on January 9, 2020, the court announced the dismissal of the bankruptcy application of Endemol Shine Turkey. Such determination was subject to two expert financial reports produced by a panel of financial and sectoral experts delivered to the court in 2019. The court’s reasoning behind this decision is not yet known, as the court has not yet made its detailed written decision available. The court is expected to issue and notify the parties of its reasoned decision between two and four weeks after the hearing held on January 9, 2020. The decision of the court will become definite either (i) after an appellate review, if Endemol Shine Turkey or any of the creditors who are party to the bankruptcy case submit an appeal within two weeks of the issuance of the reasoned decision or (ii) once such two week period after the issuance of the reasoned decision lapses without Endemol Shine Turkey or any creditor who is party to the bankruptcy case appealing the decision. At the January 9, 2020 hearing, the court also decided that the court-appointed managing administrations who are authorized to carry out “urgent and financial” matters on behalf of Endemol Shine Turkey will remain in charge until the decision becomes definite. The managing administrators were originally appointed by the court back in October 2017 as “audit administrators” whose role was to independently audit any payments, expenses, money transfers and assignments made by Endemol Shine Turkey. At the hearing dated June 7, 2018, the court decided to extend the powers of the audit administrators to “managing” administrators, effectively giving them the power to make decisions in relation to Endemol Shine Turkey with regard only to “urgent and financial” matters. Further, Endemol Shine Turkey has entered into three settlement agreements with tax authorities: two for unpaid tax debts (taxes arising from two different laws) and one for the unpaid social security premium payments. There are no written agreements for these settlements, as the arrangements are made through the online system of the authorities. The implicated members of management have initiated labor lawsuits against Endemol Shine Turkey alleging wrongful termination of their employment contracts. These labor lawsuits are still pending. Endemol Shine has initiated separate criminal and civil proceedings against former management, which proceedings are continuing. In addition, a number of third-party criminal proceedings have been brought against Endemol Shine Turkey’s representatives in connection with post-dated checks issued by former managers during such former managers’ employment, all of which have been dismissed to date with one remaining subject to an appeal. _Core Media Group_ In April 2016, CORE Entertainment Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries (the “CORE Debtors”) filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”). In September 2016, the Bankruptcy Court approved the bankruptcy plan proposed by the CORE Debtors, which provides for a significant 219 ----- de-leveraging of the CORE Debtors. Under the bankruptcy plan, general unsecured creditors are entitled to share _pro rata in a distribution of cash (up to an aggregate amount of $2,375,000), as well as a certain distribution from_ a litigation trust (the “Litigation Trust”) that was created in connection with the bankruptcy, and holders of equity interests would not receive any distribution on account thereof. In December 2016, the Litigation Trust filed a lawsuit in the state courts of California against entities affiliated with Apollo, Twenty-First Century Fox and Endemol Shine. That case was ultimately stayed in California and refiled in the state courts of New York. The complaint alleged that the defendants intentionally interfered with loan agreements reached between the CORE Debtors and their lenders, and that certain of the defendants, including Endemol Shine, were liable for the breach of such loan agreements. Endemol Shine filed a motion to dismiss the lawsuit. In April 2018, the Litigation Trust filed two additional lawsuits in the Bankruptcy Court. The first lawsuit named various individuals and entities affiliated with Apollo and Endemol Shine as defendants, and brought claims for breach of fiduciary duties, aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duties and fraudulent transfer. That lawsuit did not assert any specific claim against Endemol Shine, and on August 23, 2018, the Litigation Trust filed a Notice of Dismissal which voluntarily dismissed Endemol Shine from this lawsuit without prejudice. The second lawsuit claimed that Endemol Shine was liable for actual and constructive fraudulent transfer of international distribution rights to The Wall, which complaint was later amended to allege conversion, breach of fiduciary duty, breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, unjust enrichment and imposition of a constructive trust. All parties to each of these lawsuits reached a settlement agreement in September 2019, pursuant to which the parties sought dismissal of the outstanding lawsuits with prejudice and the settlement amount was paid in October 2019. _Wipeout_ Two persons involved in the creation of Wipeout entered into a revenue participation agreement with Endemol USA Inc. In March 2018, following an audit of the account issued pursuant to the revenue participation agreement, counsel for these persons issued letters demanding payment in the sum of $8.0 million from Endemol USA Inc. These persons claimed that the audit indicated that the back-end participation payments paid during the period were less than what was required under the Revenue Participation Agreement. A mediation took place in November 2018 and did not result in a settlement as the parties were unable to agree on, among other things, a settlement amount. As the parties have not been able to agree a settlement, a sole arbitrator has been appointed with arbitration proceedings scheduled to commence in March 2020. _Endemol Shine Belgium_ Prior to 2011, Endemol Shine Belgium N.V. (“ESB”) produced call television shows under an agreement with the broadcaster VMMA/Medialaan N.V. (“Medialaan”) to be aired on its on channel VTM in Belgium. Viewers could participate in the shows through SMS or dialing a telephone number. For participation, an all-in price was charged to the participants through their telephone bill. VAT was included in that all-in price as it was regarded as a telephone cost. Following a cascade system, the telephone operators shared the revenues with ESB, Medialaan and the service provider Paratel. Following a January 2011 audit, the Belgian tax authorities issued a game and VAT tax assessment against Endemol Shine Belgium for the financial years 2008 to 2010 in the amount of €4,233,296.51 for game tax and VAT. The maximum possible assessment is €6.0 million (excluding interest and penalties). The claims are currently pending with the Supreme Court Counsel before a date is set for the final hearing. 220 -----

The main specific regulation applicable to our business in Europe is Directive 2010/13/EU (as amended by Directive 2018/1808/EU, the “Audiovisual Media Services Directive”), which requires that a certain portion of the programs broadcasters air (excluding sports, news, events, games, advertising, teletext services and teleshopping) are created in Europe and that at least 10% of their broadcasting time or 10% of their programming budget are for programs created in Europe by independent producers. Based on the definition of independent producer in each Relevant Member State, we are independent with respect to all major broadcasters worldwide except for Canal Plus in France. There are no similar regulations in the countries outside Europe in which we operate. Directive 2018/1808/EU extended the scope of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive with specific measures for video sharing platforms and social networks, as well as livestreaming platforms. The Audiovisual Media Services Directive also requires that 30% of the catalogues of audiovisual on demand media services are created in Europe and the application of Member States’ rules to financial contributions from broadcasters and OTT platforms. Member States have until September 19, 2020 to implement Directive 2018/1808/EU. In addition to the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, certain Member States such as the United Kingdom and France impose additional requirements on broadcasters in relation to the broadcasting of certain types of programs produced by independent producers. - In the United Kingdom, a new regulation introduced by the Communications Act 2003 set out two key provisions to develop independent production of television content. Public service broadcasters in the United Kingdom have to secure a minimum of 25% of their qualifying programming in each year for independent producers in order to receive a license to broadcast from the Office of Communications, the government-approved regulatory and competition authority for the broadcasting and telecommunications industries of the United Kingdom. In addition, certain broadcasters in the United Kingdom can only produce in-house content within a limited framework or, in some instances, not at all. For example, C4 is not permitted to produce any of its programs in-house. - In France, broadcasters are subject to (i) quotas of production whereby broadcasters must contribute to specific independent audiovisual works (called “oeuvres audiovisuelles” with a sub-quota for “oeuvres _patrimoniales”), with a certain percentage of the broadcasters’ revenues to be invested in such specific_ independent audiovisual works, and (ii) quotas of programs aired whereby broadcasters must air specific independent audiovisual works. These quotas vary from one broadcaster to another. The quotas for each broadcaster are negotiated with professional unions of independent producers. They are included in each broadcaster’s license agreement with governmental authority CSA. The other specific regulations applicable to our business are employment-related regulations, including regulations governing unions and guilds that can materially impact the production cost of programs and the 204 ----- secondary revenues generated by such programs (for example, minimum wages, limitations on number of working days/hours and payment of residuals). Specific regulations may also apply to certain productions (for example, children or animals participating in programs, health and safety rules, product placement rules and rules governing the use of monuments or art). 205 -----

On December 12, 2014, Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”) and Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”) formed Endemol Shine as part of a joint venture, in which Apollo and Fox would each beneficially own 50%. In connection with the joint venture, Fox contributed its interests in Shine Group and Apollo contributed its interests in Endemol Shine, which it had acquired in August 2014, and in the CORE Media Group, in each case, for the beneficial ownership of Endemol Shine. Endemol Shine, together with its subsidiaries, has become a global multi-platform content provider known as the Endemol Shine Group. Endemol N.V. was founded in 1994 by a merger of television production companies owned by Joop van den Ende and John de Mol. It had rapidly expanded through acquisitions and internally developed start-ups, to become a leading format creation and production company. Endemol N.V.’s indirect parent company, Endemol Holding N.V. was listed on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange in 1996. Telefónica made a public offer for all of the outstanding shares of Endemol Holding N.V. in 2000, pursuant to which it acquired 99.7% of such shares. Shine TV was founded in March 2001. It became Shine Group in 2006, following the acquisitions of Kudos Film and Television, Princess Productions and Dragonfly Film and Television Productions. Shine Group began as a UK production company and expanded in the international market, including by acquiring Metronome in the Nordic Countries and Reveille in the United States. Prior to the Endemol and Shine combination, Shine Group became a multi-genre company creating and producing popular, compelling and quality entertainment, features, factual, specialist factual and drama programming, including many United Kingdom and international hits. On March 20, 2019, The Walt Disney Company (“Disney”) acquired Fox, as well as the majority of Fox’s entertainment and international assets, including its 50% shareholding in Endemol Shine. With its head office in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Endemol Shine has subsidiaries and joint ventures with physical production presence in 20 countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Spain, Italy, Germany, France and the Netherlands, as well as in Mexico, Brazil, India and Australia.

Endemol Shine creates, develops, produces and distributes non-scripted and scripted content for multiplatform entertainment for a global market, with over 60 production labels across 20 countries. In 2018, Endemol Shine produced approximately 700 programs airing on more than 260 platforms and channels. In 2018, 44 Endemol Shine formats traveled to one or more new territories. In 2018, All Together Now was Endemol Shine’s fastest traveling new format, meaning it was sold to the largest number of territories in the shortest amount of time (eight territories in 2018, its year of launch) while third-party title The Wall was the top traveling format, adding eleven new territories in 2018. Endemol Shine classifies its operations into the following two main lines of business: - _Production Business: Endemol Shine creates, develops and produces non-scripted and scripted programs using both Endemol Shine-generated intellectual property and third party-owned intellectual property. Similar to Banijay, programs and formats are developed and commissioned based on current platform briefs and audience tastes, influenced by the latest industry trends. Clients include OTT platforms, streamers and an array of other digital platforms. See “Banijay’s Business.” Endemol Shine generated 80.6% of its total revenues from its production business in the year ended December 31, 2018. - _Sales Business: - _Distribution Sales: Endemol Shine also generates revenues from the international program distribution (referring to recordings of already aired programs) of both Endemol Shine-owned intellectual property and third party-owned intellectual property, and from the licensing of formats (including formats based on Endemol Shine’s intellectual property rights and those of third parties that are licensed to Endemol Shine). Similar to Banijay, Endemol Shine’s distribution business is platform-agnostic and caters to both traditional linear channels and OTT platforms, such as Netflix and Amazon Prime Video, among others. Endemol Shine generated 13.1% of its total revenues from its distribution business in the year ended December 31, 2018. 206 ----- - _Other (Commercial Exploitation): Endemol Shine also generates revenue from the commercial exploitation of successful formats and programs through brand licensing and merchandising, digital distribution, and gaming and gambling, among other channels. Endemol Shine generated 6.3% of its total revenues from these other commercial activities in the year ended December 31, 2018. Similar to Banijay, Endemol Shine classifies its formats in two main categories: non-scripted and scripted. Non-scripted formats represented 76.9% of Endemol Shine’s production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018. Scripted formats represented 21.3% of production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018. Other genres, including the sports activities of Eredivisie Media and Marketing C.V. in the Netherlands, represented the remaining 1.7% of production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2018. In 2018, Endemol Shine produced approximately 700 programs airing on more than 260 platforms and channels. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s production business generated direct gross profit margin (defined as direct gross profit divided by revenue) of 21.4%. Non-scripted: For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s non-scripted programs generated €1.1 billion in production revenues. - _Entertainment and Talk Shows: Entertainment and talk shows mainly encompass entertainment formats and programs that are studio-based. Endemol Shine’s most successful entertainment programs include _MasterChef, All Together Now, Your Face Sounds Familiar and Lego Masters. For the year ended_ 207 ----- December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s entertainment and talk shows generated €418.3 million in production revenues. - _Reality: Reality includes television programs in which participants are continuously filmed outside their usual environment and are designed to be entertaining rather than informative. Endemol Shine’s most successful reality programs include Big Brother and Big Brother VIP. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s reality programs generated €244.7 million in production revenues. - _Factual_ _Entertainment:_ Factual entertainment is a combination of factual/documentary and entertainment programs, focusing on social experiments and popular topics. Endemol Shine’s most successful factual entertainment programs include Real Housewives, Ink Master, Hunted, Heist, The _Island, Stripped, Ambulance and One Born Every Minute. For the year ended December 31, 2018,_ Endemol Shine’s factual entertainment programs generated €284.3 million in production revenues. - _Game Shows: Game shows are predominantly programs in which participants compete for prizes during games of knowledge, physical challenges or luck. Endemol Shine’s most successful game shows include Deal or No Deal, whose U.S. version has approximately four million views on YouTube as of January 2020, Pointless, The Money Drop and The Wall. Game shows have significant potential for secondary format sales because they are easily adaptable to different local markets. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s game show programs generated €156.4 million in production revenues. Scripted: Endemol Shine’s most successful drama series include BAFTA award-winning Peaky Blinders (a co-production with Caryn Mandabach Productions), the multi-Emmy award winning Black Mirror and The _Bridge (Bron), which by the end of 2018 had been adapted in seven additional territories, following the original_ production in Sweden and Denmark. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s scripted programs generated €305.9 million in production revenues. Endemol Shine aired more than 75 scripted titles across more than 50 platforms in more than 15 different territories in 2018, approximately half of which were new launches. Endemol Shine’s network of scripted producers work with local writers and directors to develop ideas and packages to pitch to local broadcasters. Given scripted shows generate the highest levels of investments from broadcasters, more time is spent on the quality of the writing in the first instance, and development lead times can often be lengthy. Producers then work with broadcasters to ensure that they attach the right cast for local and international audiences. Once a show is formally approved, it enters into pre-production and preparation begins. Once filming ends, the producer will work with the editor until the program is delivered to the broadcaster. Similar to Banijay, Endemol Shine aims to retain the intellectual property rights to its formats and programs because they are assets that continue to generate secondary revenues through various channels, after the initial sale to a client. Endemol Shine owns all or part of the intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of existing formats and programs. Endemol Shine’s sales business comprises its distribution sales business and commercial exploitation business, which are aligned to promote a 360 degree IP monetization strategy. 209 ----- The diagram below illustrates Endemol Shine’s sales business. Sales through OpCos or Group resources in certain territories (South East Asia, CEE, Middle East & Format Africa, LatAm) sales Support from Endemol Shine's creative networks ensures consistent quality across countries Linear distribution through ESI and digital syndication Local Finished Approximately 65,000 hours of catalogue OpCo lP tape Hubs in 7 countries with customers in over 180 territories Endemol 20 OpCos, Shine 360 High margin business Group Monetisation Licensing IP to build large games Gaming Invested in remote game server business ‘Playzido’ Other Endemol Shine OpCos MasterChef, Mr Bean, and Peaky Blinders are some of ESG’s key focus titles for L&M Licensing exploitation and Merch Merchandising, branded events / experiences (e.g. MasterChef Cruises) Long-tail monetisation and IP protection Digital Syndication at scale across all digital platforms _Distribution Sales:_ Endemol Shine distributes both its own formats and third party-owned formats and programs to a large traditional customer base of producers and broadcasters, as well as to a number of VOD platforms. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s distribution sales business generated direct gross profit margin of 47.2%. Endemol Shine has two distribution entities: Endemol Shine International Limited (“ESI”) and Endemol Shine IP B.V. (“ESIP”). - ESI is located in the United Kingdom and is mainly focused on the distribution of programs (although in some regions, such as South East Asia, for example, ESI may also act as format sales agent for the Group). ESI has grown its catalogue to approximately 65,000 hours of owned and third-party content across all genres. Approximately 21% of the ESI catalogue, in terms of programming hours, consists of third-party programs. Revenues generated by ESI in 2018 were supported by stronger program sales of multiple versions of Big Brother and MasterChef, as well as the addition of key scripted shows such as _Troy, Humans and Younger._ - ESIP is located in the Netherlands and is mainly focused on the licensing of Endemol Shine or thirdparty formats to third-party production companies for production outside of the territories where Endemol Shine has a physical production presence or operating companies. Endemol Shine’s distribution and format licensing business works as follows: - Formats: In countries where Endemol Shine has local production companies, typically formats are licensed as part of production commission arrangements by the local production companies. In countries where Endemol Shine has no local production company, typically ESIP licenses formats to third parties through format license agreements allowing the third parties to produce formats as per the terms of such format license agreements. - Programs: Programs based on Endemol Shine intellectual property are mostly distributed via ESI. ESI charges a distribution fee and recoups against its investment, if applicable. ESI shares the remaining distribution revenues with both the original format creator and Endemol Shine’s production company. In certain cases, where ESI does not see sufficient potential for recoupment and return on investment, or where third-party distributors have offered a minimum guarantee against an Endemol Shine 210 |Global sales|Distribution|Sales through OpCos or Group resources in certain territories (South East Asia, CEE, Middle East & Format Africa, LatAm) sales Support from Endemol Shine's creative networks ensures consistent quality across countries| |---|---|---| |||Linear distribution through ESI and digital syndication Finished Approximately 65,000 hours of catalogue tape Hubs in 7 countries with customers in over 180 territories| ||Commercial|High margin business Licensing IP to build large games Gaming Invested in remote game server business ‘Playzido’| |||MasterChef, Mr Bean, and Peaky Blinders are some of ESG’s key focus titles for L&M Licensing exploitation and Merch Merchandising, branded events / experiences (e.g. MasterChef Cruises)| |||Long-tail monetisation and IP protection Digital Syndication at scale across all digital platforms| ----- program, Endemol Shine intellectual property may be distributed by third-party distributors. Further, ESI distributes third-party owned programs. In such cases, ESI charges a distribution fee and shares the remaining distribution revenues with the original intellectual property creator. Where additional funding is needed beyond a broadcaster commitment and tax credits, ESI might make available an investment against the acquisition of the distribution rights, such as a distribution advance. Such decisions are made on a case-by-case basis and driven by ESI and Endemol Shine’s views on the commercial potential of the program. Endemol Shine is platform-agnostic and distributes content to both traditional linear channels and AVOD and SVOD platforms and has been increasing its commercial focus on the FAANG, as well as other global and regional streaming platforms. Endemol Shine has scheduled over ten launches over the next six months with distribution channels across the world on electronic sell-through or “EST” (iTunes, Google), TVOD (Vobile) and AVOD (TiVo, Vudu, Roku) models. For the year ended December 31, 2018, 19.1% of the gross revenues of Endemol Shine’s distribution business was generated through the revenues from the sales of their portfolio of programs licensed to VOD platforms such as Facebook Watch, Apple TV, Amazon Prime Video and Netflix as compared to 13.5% for the year ended December 31, 2017. Endemol Shine’s main customers for its distribution business include broadcasters and streaming platforms, such as Netflix, Globo, Discovery, Amazon, FOX and AMC. For the year ended December 31, 2018, the top ten customers of Endemol Shine’s distribution business accounted for 45.0% of its distribution revenues, while its single largest customer accounted for 13.8% of its distribution revenues. _Other (Commercial Exploitation):_ Endemol Shine generates commercial revenues from games and gaming, licensing and merchandising, and through Endemol Shine digital partnerships. - Games and gaming: Endemol Shine Gaming Limited exploits Endemol Shine intellectual property and third party intellectual property in the gaming and gambling space through licensing activities and selfpublishing on third party gaming platforms. Where the design or build of a game is complex and requires specific specialization, licenses may be granted to third-party producers. Endemol Shine games include Deal or No Deal and The Money Drop. - Licensing and merchandising: Endemol Shine licenses Endemol Shine-controlled intellectual property through the creation and management of contracts between Endemol Shine and third parties that want to use a particular brand in association with a product for an agreed period of time, within an agreed territory. MasterChef, Mr. Bean, and Peaky Blinders are some of Endemol Shine’s key focus titles for licensing and merchandising exploitation. - Digital exploitation: Endemol Shine’s digital business runs across three distinct pillars – digital commercial, sponsorship and digital inventory. - Digital inventory: the largest digital segment, encompasses primarily the monetization of Endemol Shine’s content through digital platforms like YouTube. Video views to official Endemol Shine online video content totaled approximately 15 billion for the period from January 2019 to November 2019, representing a 49% increase compared to the same period in 2018, fueled by the popularity of global properties, such as Mr. Bean, MasterChef, Big Brother and Wipeout. Mr. Bean was awarded the YouTube Diamond Play Button for surpassing ten million subscribers in October 2018. The official page has since grown to approximately 17 million subscribers. Mr. Bean remained the number one television entertainment brand on Facebook in 2019 (Mr. Bean’s live action page remains the eleventh most liked Facebook page), with over 90 million followers, including Mr. Bean’s animated Facebook page. In total, across Endemol Shine’s YouTube network, the total watch time of Endemol Shine content has increased to over 87 billion minutes in the first nine months of 2019, an increase of 17.0% from the same period in 2018. - Digital commercial: encompasses all revenue-generating in-program exploitation of digital technology and includes voting, polling, SMS and call TV. - Sponsorship: encompasses integrated sponsorship deals, both online and TV and on-air product placement on content Endemol Shine produces, selling brands a share of the content. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Endemol Shine’s other (commercial exploitation) business generated direct gross profit margin of 52.2%. 211 ----- Endemol Shine’s Sales Strategy: Endemol Shine’s sales business strategy is based on three pillars and covers both distribution sales and commercial exploitation. The first strategic pillar of the Endemol Shine sales business is continued access to Endemol Shine’s highquality multi-genre intellectual property, including both Endemol Shine-owned intellectual property and third party-owned intellectual property. This includes increasing the focus on non-English language scripted content to broaden the catalogue available. The second strategic pillar is to increase the sell-through rate of an existing catalogue, through selling to more platforms (including streaming and other digital platforms), monetization of unexploited parts of the existing catalogue and selling across all available rights channels. The third strategic pillar of the Endemol Shine sales business is to increase yield from the existing catalogue, including through improved channel management, increased bid density and implementation of a pricing strategy.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 21.8% of its revenues in North and South America for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine Americas delivers well-known content and compelling storytelling to multiple platforms in the U.S. and across the globe and is primarily focused on non-scripted programs. Endemol Shine Americas had the following six noteworthy TV production labels in North and South America as of September 30, 2019: - _Endemol Shine North America: Endemol Shine North America, based in Hollywood, produced hit series such as Big Brother, Biggest Loser, Extreme Makeover: Home Edition, Fear Factor, Wipe Out, _MasterChef and MasterChef Junior._ - _Truly Original: Truly Original creates a broad range of non-scripted programming for television and digital platforms. Truly Original is headquartered in New York. Emmy-winning producers Glenda Hersh and Steven Weinstock serve as Truly Original’s co-presidents and CEOs. Truly Original’s hit series include Real Housewives, Ink Master, Swamp People, Shahs of Sunset, Summer House and Deal _or No Deal._ - _51 Minds: 51 Mind, based in Hollywood, produces non-scripted content for a variety of clients with prominent titles such as Below Deck, Below Deck: Mediterranean, Truck Night in America, The Grand _Hustle and T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle._ - _Authentic Entertainment: Authentic Entertainment became part of Endemol Shine in 2010. Authentic Entertainment is an Emmy-winning production company based in North Hollywood, California. Authentic Entertainment produces popular TV shows such as Flipping Out, The Best Thing I Ever Ate, _Waterfront House Hunting, and Trading Spaces._ - _Endemol Shine Latino: Endemol Shine Latino, based in Miami, oversees all Spanish and Portuguese- language operations across Latin America, including the production operations undertaken through the Endemol Shine Brasil and Endemol Shine Boomdog labels, the latter of which produces original content for both the Mexican and U.S. Spanish-language markets. - _Endemol Shine Boomdog (U.S. and Mexico): Endemol Shine formed its joint venture with Alejandro Rincon’s Boomdog in 2018 to capitalize on the growing opportunities in the Mexican and U.S. Spanish-language TV markets and produces both non-scripted and scripted shows. Endemol Shine Boomdog shows include MasterChef Mexico, Nicky Jam El Ganador, Chumel con _Chumel Torres, Se busca comediante and Mira Quien Baila._ - _Endemol Shine Brasil: Endemol Shine Brasil, based in São Paulo, produces scripted and non-scripted formats mainly for the Brazilian market but also as a production hub for other territories. Endemol Shine Brasil’s top formats include Big Brother Brasil, MasterChef Brasil, All _Together Now and The Wall._ 212 -----

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Excluding the operations of Endemol Shine International Limited, Endemol Shine generated 17.1% of its revenues in the United Kingdom for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine UK Ltd. is a multi-genre producer of both scripted and non-scripted content behind a diverse range of hits including global entertainment formats, multi-award winning drama and innovative digital content. It is made up of over 15 core production companies and labels, producing over 1,000 hours of content a year for customers across platforms and geographies. Some of its more prominent production companies and labels include: - _Tiger Aspect: a prominent multi-genre content production company, with a long track record in drama, comedy and kids programs. Tiger Aspect produced the UK’s most famous comic creation, Mr. Bean, co-produced award-winning Peaky Blinders and produced recent hits Good Karma Hospital and Jack _Whitehall: Travels with my Father._ - _Kudos: an award winning scripted television production company. Its key titles include Tin Star, _Grantchester, Humans, Broadchurch, Deep Water, Utopia and upcoming projects Two Weeks to Live for Sky and Deadwater Fell for Channel 4._ - _Wild Mercury: Wild Mercury is a joint venture with Derek Wax to develop and produce bold, irreverent and imaginative stories for UK and U.S. broadcasters. Key titles include Troy: Fall of a City and Humans, and the business has a number of titles in development with broadcasters and streaming platforms. - _House of Tomorrow: produced multi-award winning Black Mirror and BAFTA award-winning Screen Wipe. - _Shine TV: creator of innovative popular factual content, behind global hits such as MasterChef, Hunted and The Island. - _Zeppotron: producer of high quality comedy and comedy-entertainment shows, including 8 out of 10 _Cats, Would I lie to you? and The Mash Report._ - _Remarkable: Remarkable specializes in quiz shows, entertainment, factual entertainment and popular factual formats including a large portfolio of long running hits such as Pointless, The £100 Drop, All _Together Now, Your Home Made Perfect and Deal or No Deal and Richard Osman’s House of Games._ Recent commissions also include hit gameshow The Wall and a reboot of the Nineties classic Ready _Steady Cook, both for BBC One._ - _Dragonfly: Dragonfly produces fearless factual television including global traveling hit One Born _Every Minute and Ambulance and Surgeons: At the Edge of Life._ - _Workerbee: Workerbee is a prominent UK producer of factual content, developing content for regional linear broadcasters in the UK, global platforms and streamers, including the United Kingdom’s first ever Quibi commission: Elba vs Block.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 8.4% of its revenues in Iberia for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine Iberia is primarily focused on non-scripted programming. Its production companies have a wide and diverse catalogue of successful productions, both in fiction and entertainment, including MasterChef, Big _Brother, Your Face Sounds Familiar, Operación Triunfo, Sewing Bee, Still Standing, Boom, Amar es para Siempre, Matadero, La Catedral del Mar and El Debate. Endemol Shine had the following key TV production_ labels in Iberia as of September 30, 2019: - _Gestmusic: Founded in 1985, Gestmusic produces entertainment shows such as Operación Triunfo and ES Iberia’s flagship Your Face Sounds Familiar as well as game shows such as Still Standing and _Boom!_ - _Zeppelin TV: Founded in 1989, Zeppelin TV is dedicated to the production of entertainment programs and fiction series, including Gran Hermano (Big Brother), Skam Virtual Hero, The Bridge and Fama. - _Shine Iberia: Founded in 2011, Shine Iberia produces television programs for Spain and Portugal, including originals and adaptations of both Endemol Shine and third-party formats. It is one of the main producers in Iberia with a wide and diverse catalogue of multi-award-winning programs in entertainment, factual and fiction. Its successful programs include MasterChef, MasterChef Celebrity, _MasterChef Junior, Hunted and Brim._ - _Diagonal TV: Diagonal TV is an independent production company and has primarily worked in fiction since its inception in 1997. Diagonal TV produces TV series and TV movies, as well as feature films. Notable titles include La Catedral del Mar, La Señora, The Bookshop and Amar para Siempre. 213 -----

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 7.6% of its revenues in Germany for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine had the following important TV production labels in Germany as of September 30, 2019: - _Endemol Shine Germany: Endemol Shine Germany is a prominent TV production and entertainment company headquartered in Cologne and primarily focused on non-scripted programming. Endemol Shine Germany was formed in May 2015 from the merger of two producers, Endemol Shine Deutschland GmbH and Shine Germany Film und Fernsehproduktion GmbH. Its shows include The _Masked Singer, Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, Big Brother, Big Bounce Battle, MasterChef, Bitte Melde Dich, Kitchen Heroes and Hot oder Schrott._ - _Wiedemann & Berg: Wiedemann & Berg (“W&B TV”) is an award winning independent drama company and was created in 2010 through a joint venture between Endemol Shine producers Max Wiedemann und Quirin Berg (Das Leben der Anderen). The company focuses on a combination of TV and made-for-TV movies, including Der Pass (the German adaptation of Endemol Shine format The _Bridge), 4 blocks, Tatort Weimar, Tatort Dresden, Feuer und Flamme and Dark for Netflix. In_ November 2019, Endemol Shine agreed to sell its 51% stake in W&B TV to KKR-backed German media group Leonine. Endemol Shine Germany also agreed to acquire 100% of the assets of W&B TV’s Berlin-based business to create a new scripted content production company in Germany. The sale of W&B TV closed on January 7, 2020 and the acquisition of W&B TV’s Berlin-based business closed on January 9, 2020. - _Jukers Media: Jukers Media was founded in 2017 by Endemol Shine Germany and Judith Rakers, one of the most renowned media personalities in Germany and the face of the most-watched German news program Tagesschau, as a talent vehicle to develop and produce Ms. Raker’s shows.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 5.6% of its revenues in the Nordic Countries for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine is primarily focused on non-scripted programming and had the following important TV production labels in the Nordic Countries as of September 30, 2019. _Denmark_ - _Metronome Productions: Metronome Productions is a prominent Danish label, creating content for TV for over 60 years. Its major shows include MasterChef, long running original series Luxury Trap, Ex on _the Beach and All Together Now. Finland_ - _Endemol Shine Finland: Endemol Shine Finland has been providing entertainment to Finnish TV viewers since 2000. Endemol Shine Finland produces content for a wide variety of TV channels and brands across popular entertainment, reality and factual entertainment. Its best known programs include _Big Brother, Gogglebox, Cosy Homes, Good Evening and Summerhouse. Norway_ - _Rubicon TV: Rubicon TV is a Norwegian producer of scripted and non-scripted content, producing content across a comprehensive array of entertainment, factual entertainment, reality and TV-drama. Its shows include Ex on the Beach, Luxury Trap, Eternal Glory, Maniac, Lilyhammer, The Councilman and Beforeigners, the first Nordic HBO original drama. _Sweden_ - _Filmlance: Founded in 1998, Filmlance is an award-winning scripted producer of audience and feature films, animated children’s films, TV movies, TV series and short movies. Filmlance is the producer of the TV series Bron/Broen, which has become a worldwide success, winning multiple awards. Several successful remakes have been made such as The Tunnel (France / UK), The Bridge (U.S. / Mexico) and _Der Pass (Germany / Austria), as well as local adaptations in Russia and Estonia, Singapore and_ Malaysia. Other successful returning series include Springtide, Beck and Sandhamn Murders. _Beartown for HBO Europe is currently in post-production for a scheduled 2020 air date._ 214 ----- - _Meter: Founded in 1990, Meter produced over 30 TV productions in 2018 and its shows are broadcasted on all major TV channels in Sweden. Its shows include Ex on the Beach, MasterChef, The _Biggest Loser, Luxury Trap, Eternal Glory and Emmy-winning Allt för Sverige (Culture Shock Sweden)._ - _Sto-Cph: Sto-Cph was founded in 2001 and became part of Endemol Shine in 2007. Sto-Cph produces content for TV and digital platforms and is behind some of Sweden’s largest television programs including GW’s Mord, Brottjournalen, Veckans Brott and premium crime documentaries such as _Kapten Klänning._

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Excluding the operations of Endemol Shine IP B.V., Endemol Shine generated 5.4% of its revenues in the Netherlands for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine had the following important TV production labels in the Netherlands as of September 30, 2019: - _Endemol Shine Nederland: Endemol Shine Nederland is a multi-genre major production house in the Netherlands. Its major shows include Good Times, Bad Times, Deal or No Deal, 1 Versus 100 and All _you Need is Love._ - _Simpel Media: Simpel Media is a specialist in factual entertainment shows. Its well-known titles include Hunted, Ik Depart and Johnny into the Wild. - _NL Film & TV: NL Film & TV is one of the most active, contemporary Dutch film producers with a large array of short and feature-length films, youth drama and television series. Its shows include _SpangaS, Floor Rules, Stone Cold Stanley, the 2018 NL Oscar submission The Body Collector and_ award winning The Resistance Banker. NL Film & TV also produces content for YouTube, such as web series House of No Limits. In June 2019, NL Film & TV announced an exclusive Dutch-language partnership with Wattpad with first-look rights to adapt Dutch-language stories from Wattpad. - _TVBV: TVBV produces talk shows, factual and current affairs. Its titles include 5 Jaar Later and Pauw. - _Human Factor: Human Factor is a non-scripted label focused on comedy/satire. It is a joint venture with Irene van den Brekel. Key titles include Sunday with Lubach, M and Easy Scoring. - _Totem Media: a non-scripted and scripted label focused on high-end factual entertainment. It is a joint venture with managing directors Isidoor Roebers and Kasper van Beek. Key titles include High _Cuisine._

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 5.4% of its revenues in Italy for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine Italy has been part of Endemol Shine since 1998 and has primarily focused on non-scripted programming. Endemol Shine Italy produces a wide range of entertainment programs for the main Italian networks, satellite platforms and interactive media. Its key titles include Big Brother, MasterChef, Identity, Boom and Still Standing. Notable scripted shows include Mentre ero Via and L’Allieva.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 5.0% of its revenues in Australia for the year ended December 31, 2018. - _Endemol Shine Australia: Endemol Shine Australia has a long track record in non-scripted content, generating a wide and diverse catalogue of successful productions; it was responsible for the “supersizing” of MasterChef, whose season two finale we believe remains one of the largest (non-sporting) audiences in Australia and became the international “template” for traveling versions. Led by industry veterans, Mark and Carl Fennessy, Endemol Shine Australia focuses primarily on non-scripted formats and has successfully adapted group formats such as MasterChef, All Together _Now, Ambulance and Pointless for the Australian market, as well as created original formats such as Family Food Fight (being adapted in the U.S.). Endemol Shine Australia is also a trusted producer of_ third party formats including Survivor, Ninja Warrior, Gogglebox and Married at First Sight. Endemol Shine Australia counts all major broadcasters in the Australian market as clients (such as 10, Nine and Seven Networks). Further, Endemol Shine Australia is working to build relationships with OTT platforms in order to expand its business to service OTT clients as well, with both scripted and non-scripted content. 215 ----- - _Endemol Shine Banks: Endemol Shine Banks is run by award winning producer Imogen Banks. Her recent hit Sisters is currently being adapted in the U.S. for Fox titled Almost Famous. Other recent commissions include RFD for Channel Seven and Endemol Shine Banks is actively developing its scripted business and its relationships with OTT clients.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 4.7% of its revenues in France for the year ended December 31, 2018. Endemol Shine France focuses predominantly on non-scripted content and operates several labels in France, which include Endemol Shine Production, Endemol Shine Fiction and Jereluc (a talent vehicle for Jean Luc Reichmann, the French radio and television host), whose main title is the show 12 Coups de Midi. Other notable Endemol Shine France TV shows include Children of TV, Pointless, Undercover Boss, Best Bakery, Guyane, Ce Soir La, Mental and Prodigies.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine generated 6.1% of its revenues (excluding Switzerland) for the year ended December 31, 2018 in all other markets where Endemol Shine operates, which include, among others: - _India: Endemol Shine India operates through Endemol India Private Limited as a majority-owned joint venture with CA Media and is led by CEO Abhishek Rege. It operates as a single label for both scripted and non-scripted content, and its top formats include multiple language versions of Big _Brother, as well as Fear Factor, The Wall, Ace of Space, Mission over Mars and, more recently, Thenmozhi._ - _Israel: Endemol Shine Israel operates through Endemol Israel Limited as a majority-owned joint venture with Elad Kuperman and is led by CEO Amir Ganor. Endemol Shine Israel operates as a single label for both scripted and non-scripted content, and its top formats include Big Brother, Game of _Chefs, The Voice, Nevsu, Harem, Queens, Just for one Day and Fifty. Endemol Shine also has a_ minority investment in Reshet Media Limited, a free to air commercial broadcaster in Israel. - _Russia: Endemol Shine operates in Russia through JSC WeiT Media, a joint venture in which Endemol Shine holds a controlling interest, alongside Wythside Holdings Ltd and its CEO, Yulia Semachova. WeiT Media is a multi-genre producer and operates as a single label for both scripted and non-scripted content. Its top formats include You Are Super, All Together Now, The Brain and That Side of Death, _Twins and Death._ - _Poland: Endemol Shine Polska operates through Endemol Shine Polska Sp. Z.o.o. and is led by Managing Director Ryszard Sibilski. It operates as a single label for both scripted and non-scripted content, and its top formats include The Wall, MasterChef, Your Face Sounds Familiar and Our _Century._ - _Switzerland: B&B Endemol Shine operates in Switzerland through B&B Endemol Shine A.G. as a 50:50 joint venture with FBM Group and operates as a single non-scripted label led by Managing Director Tommy Sturzenegger. B&B Endemol Shine is not consolidated in the financial results of Endemol Shine.

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine’s businesses operate in highly competitive industries and different competitive factors apply in each segment of its operations. _Production_ For a description of competition in the productions, licensing and distribution of Endemol Shine’s formats and programs, see “Banijay’s Business—Our Competition,” which describes the competitive trends that similarly impact Endemol Shine. _Distribution_ Endemol Shine also faces competition for the licensing and distribution of their formats and programs. As a distributor of programs, Endemol Shine competes with other studios, television production groups and independent producers. 216 -----

Subsection Title: Endemol Shine’s Markets and Production Companies
Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine has over 60 production labels, with physical production presence in 20 countries, including North and South America, the United Kingdom, Germany, Iberia, Australia, France, Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden, the Netherlands and Italy.

Endemol Shine works with a broad network of customers and partners, including broadcasters, television channels, producers and digital platforms active in the markets in which Endemol Shine operates as well as with licensees and retailers of consumer products from around the world. Endemol Shine licenses produced content in most of the major markets in Europe and the United States and had nearly 500 customers in 2018, many of which purchase multiple formats of Endemol Shine. Endemol Shine’s main customers for its production business include broadcasters, such as Fox, Sky, BBC, CBS, Bravo, Antena 3, TVE, Channel 5. For the year ended December 31, 2018, the top ten customers of Endemol Shine’s production business accounted for 38.2% of the production revenues, while its single largest customer accounted for 5.9% of the production revenues.

Subsection Title: Region Number of Employees Working Full Time at Endemol Shine

Subsubsection Text: Endemol Shine also uses the services of a significant number of freelance production artists and technicians. The number of freelancers as of December 31, 2018 was 1,100, having decreased from 1,279 as of December 31, 2017 and 1,801 as of December 31, 2016. This number varies from time to time depending, in part, on the level of television production activity in which Endemol Shine is engaged.

The Senior Notes Issuer is a société par actions simplifiée incorporated in France, with its registered office at 5, rue François 1er, 75008 Paris, France. It is registered with the registre du commerce et des sociétés de Paris under registration number 499 797 041. The President of the Senior Notes Issuer is LOV Group Invest S.A.S., a société par actions simplifiée incorporated in France. The sole legal representative (représentant légal) of the President is Stéphane Courbit. The following table sets forth the names, ages and positions of the representative of the Senior Notes Issuer.

LOV Group Invest S.A.S., represented by Stéphane Courbit 54 Sole Legal Representative _Stéphane Courbit. Mr. Courbit is the sole legal representative of LOV Group Invest S.A.S., the President of_ the Senior Notes Issuer. Mr. Courbit is the founder and chairman of LOV Group, the indirect majority shareholder of the Senior Notes Issuer, which he created in 2007. For a description of LOV Group, see “Shareholders.” Prior to founding LOV Group, Mr. Courbit was the CEO of Endemol France from 2001 to 2007. Endemol France was founded in 1998 and became in a few years, under Mr. Courbit’s leadership, a leading producer of television programs in France. On May 28, 2015, Mr. Courbit was fined €250,000 by the Court of Bordeaux for the offense resulting from the receipt by LOV Group of proceeds from an investment by Mrs. Liliane Bettencourt, which was decided by Mrs. Liliane Bettencourt’s authorized representatives, allegedly when Mrs. Bettencourt did not have the full capacity to make a reasoned decision. Mr. Courbit believed these allegations to be without merit, but he decided not to appeal the judgement. Financière LOV S.A.S., represented by Stéphane Courbit 54 Sole Legal Representative Stéphane Courbit 54 Chairman Marco Bassetti 62 Chief Executive Officer Sophie Kurinckx 41 Chief Financial Officer _Marco Bassetti. Mr. Bassetti has held the position of Chief Executive Officer of the Group since 2013._ Before joining the Group, Mr. Bassetti was the sole shareholder of the television production company Ambra Multimedia S.r.l., a company he founded in 2012. Prior to that, Mr. Bassetti was president of Endemol, prior to its merger into the Endemol Shine Group. Mr. Bassetti holds a degree in Economic and Social Sciences from Bocconi University in Milan and a degree in Political Sciences from Milan University. _Sophie Kurinckx. Ms. Kurinckx has held the position of Chief Financial Officer of the Group since 2013._ From 2011 to 2012, Ms. Kurinckx was the Head of Financial Control for the Group. Before joining the Group, Ms. Kurinckx was an auditor for KPMG and later the Deputy Head of Group Consolidation and Group IFRS Specialist for JCDecaux. Ms. Kurinckx holds a Masters of Science degree in Management from the ESSEC Business School in France. 221 -----

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a société par actions simplifiée incorporated in France, with its registered office at 5, rue François 1er, 75008 Paris, France. It is registered with the registre du commerce et des _sociétés de Paris under registration number 503 069 965. The President of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is_ Financière LOV S.A.S., a société par actions simplifiée incorporated in France. The sole legal representative (représentant légal) of the President is Stéphane Courbit. The following table sets forth the names, ages and positions of the representative of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer.

An executive management team manages the affairs of the Issuers, led by our Chairman, our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer. The following table sets forth the names, ages and positions of the current members of the executive management team.

Following the completion of the Transactions, we expect certain key managers, including our Chief Executive Officer, and other creative talents of the Group will indirectly own 7.8% of the shares in the Senior Notes Issuer, through wholly-owned or majority-owned intermediate holding companies. See “Certain _Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Earn-outs.” In addition, our Chairman, Stéphane Courbit,_ controls LOV Banijay, our majority shareholder. See “Shareholders.”

For the benefit of our directors and officers, we have entered into global directors and officers insurance policies with AIG and XL Catlin. The policies cover our present, former and future directors and officers, general managers, authorized officers and senior staff. These policies apply globally and provide for an insured limit of €20 million for each policy, per year. These insurance policies cover financial losses resulting from liability of our directors and officers and we believe the limitations of our coverage are in line with industry practice.

LOV Group Invest S.A.S., a company controlled by Stéphane Courbit, received €4.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2018, and between €1.6 million (in the year ended December 31, 2014) and €4.5 million (in the year ended December 31, 2017) per year for the previous five years for his services as representative of the President of the Senior Notes Issuer. In 2017, we put in place a long-term incentive plan for certain key employees of the Group. This plan consists of two allocations of phantom shares covering the period from 2016 to 2019 and from 2016 to 2023. This plan has been recorded as cash-settled share-based payments. Two employees of the Group will be granted free shares of the Senior Notes Issuer over the 2016-2026 period and their incentive plans have therefore been considered as equity-settled share-based payments. We may amend our long-term incentive plan following the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition. No loans have been granted to the members of the executive management team or to enterprises in which these individuals hold interests. The Issuers have assumed no guarantees or security arrangements for management members. 222 -----
Unless otherwise indicated, references to “we,” “us” and “our” in this section are to Banijay.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: We regularly enter into commercial contracts with customers affiliated with Vivendi or an affiliate of Vivendi, which owns a portion of the share capital of Banijay Group Holding, the parent company of the Senior Notes Issuer, such as commercial contracts with channels that are part of the Canal Plus Group in France, such as StudioCanal (Mouche) and C8 (Touche pas à mon poste!, produced by our subsidiary H2O Productions). In France, the channel Non Stop People is aired on CanalSat, a French subscription satellite, cable and IPTV service provider owned by Vivendi. In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer acquired from Marco Bassetti 100% of the shares in Ambra Multimedia Srl in two steps (in February 2014 and July 2016) for a purchase price of €9.4 million, €6 million of which were paid through a vendor loan made by Marco Bassetti to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. In the course of our ordinary business activities, we also regularly enter into agreements with companies controlled by our shareholders. These agreements relate to, among others, the provision of billing, IT and accounting services and the rendering of other intragroup services, such as business advisory, treasury and finance, marketing, human resources, legal and tax. For example, we organize from time to time seminars for our employees in hotels owned by LOV Hotel Collection, a company controlled by Stéphane Courbit, and Geca Italia Srl, a company controlled by Marco Bassetti, regularly provides industry consulting services for our production companies in Italy. LOV Group and Betclic Everest Group S.A.S., a company 50% of which is owned by Stéphane Courbit, have also entered into sublease agreements with the Senior Secured Notes Issuer.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: LOV Group Invest S.A.S., a company controlled by Stéphane Courbit, received €4.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2018, and between €1.6 million (in the year ended December 31, 2014) and €4.5 million (in the year ended December 31, 2017) per year for the previous five years for his services as representative of the President of the Senior Notes Issuer. 223 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this offering memorandum and after giving effect to the Transactions, the issued share capital of the Senior Notes Issuer consists of 103,451,358 ordinary shares with a par value of €1.0 per share and the issued share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, a direct majority-owned subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer, consists of 2,326,187 ordinary shares with a par value of €1.0 per share. Following the completion of the Transactions, Banijay Group Holding will directly hold 92.2% of the issued share capital of the Senior Notes Issuer, which will directly hold 100% of the issued share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. We expect the remaining 7.8% of the issued share capital of the Senior Notes Issuer will be held indirectly by certain key managers and creative talents of the Group through wholly-owned or majority-owned intermediate holding companies. Following the completion of the Transactions, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is expected to directly own all of the share capital of the Target. The Target was incorporated on November 5, 2014 with an authorized and issued share capital of €1, consisting of one ordinary share with a nominal value of €1. On December 12, 2014, 14,878,309 shares were issued against contributions by its shareholders. See “Summary—The Transactions—The _Endemol Shine Acquisition.”_ Following the completion of the Transactions, LOV Banijay will directly own the majority of the share capital of LDH, which in turn will own 67.1% of the share capital of Banijay Group Holding, the parent company of the Senior Notes Issuer.
