The carrying values of intangible assets are also reviewed for impairment where there has been a triggering event by assessing the present value of estimated future cash flows and net realisable value compared with net book value. The calculation of estimated future cash flows and residual values is based on the company’s best estimate of future prices, output and costs and is, therefore, subjective (Note 2.8) - Impairment of non-current assets, key assumptions underlying recoverable amounts (Note 2.10) - Other long-term employee benefits, estimating amounts payable for incentive plans (Note 2.11) - Earn-out liabilities, estimating fair value of consideration payable (Note 2.19) - Put option liabilities, estimating fair value of consideration payable (Note 2.19) - Revenue under IFRS 15—satisfying performance obligations (Note 2.13 a) - Revenue under IAS 18, determination of the stage of completion (Note 2.13 b) - Income taxes, recognition of deferred tax assets (Note 2.18) Information about assumptions and estimation uncertainties made in applying accounting policies that have a significant risk of resulting in a material adjustment in the consolidated financial statements in the subsequent financial year is included in the following notes: - Revenue, determination of the stage of completion (Note 2.18) - Intangible assets acquired in a business combination, determination of fair values (Note 2.6) F-283 ----- - Intangible assets estimated remaining useful lives are reviewed annually. The carrying values of intangible assets are also reviewed for impairment where there has been a triggering event by assessing the present value of estimated future cash flows and net realisable value compared with net book value. The calculation of estimated future cash flows and residual values is based on the Company’s best estimate of future prices, output and costs and is, therefore, subjective (Note 2.8) - Impairment of non-current assets, key assumptions underlying recoverable amounts (Note 2.10) - Other long-term employee benefits, estimating amounts payable for incentive plans (Note 2.13) - Earn-out liabilities, estimating fair value of consideration payable (Note 2.16) - Put option liabilities, estimating fair value of consideration payable (Note 2.17) - Income taxes, recognition of deferred tax assets (Note 2.23)

The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries. In accordance with section 402, Part 9 Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, the income statement in the Company financial statements is presented in condensed form. F-206 ----- The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries. In accordance with section 402, Part 9 Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, the income statement in the Company financial statements is presented in condensed form.

Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the Company, which is the case when the company is exposed to, or has rights to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the ability to affect those returns through its controlling influence over the entity. In assessing control, potential voting rights that presently are exercisable or convertible are taken into account. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are included in the consolidated financial statements from the date that control commences until the date that control ceases. Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the Company, which is the case when the Company is exposed to, or has rights to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the ability to affect those returns through its controlling influence over the entity. In assessing control, potential voting rights that presently are exercisable or convertible are taken into account. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are included in the consolidated financial statements from the date that control commences until the date that control ceases.

Non-controlling interests are measured at fair value. Changes in the company’s interest in subsidiaries that do not result in a loss of control are accounted for as equity transactions. Non-controlling interests are measured at fair value. Changes in the Company’s interest in subsidiaries that do not result in a loss of control are accounted for as equity transactions.

When the Company loses control over a subsidiary, it derecognises the assets and liabilities of the subsidiary, and any non-controlling interests and other components of equity. Any resulting gain or loss is recognised in profit or loss. Any interest retained in the former subsidiary is measured at fair value when control is lost. When the Company loses control over a subsidiary, it derecognises the assets and liabilities of the subsidiary, and any non-controlling interests and other components of equity. Any resulting gain or loss is recognised in profit or loss. Any interest retained in the former subsidiary is measured at fair value when control is lost.

Intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealised gains and losses or income and expenses arising from intra-group transactions, are eliminated. Intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealised gains and losses or income and expenses arising from intra-group transactions, are eliminated.

Transactions in foreign currencies are translated to the respective functional currencies of the company’s entities at exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate at the reporting date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognised in profit or loss. Non-monetary items that are measured based on historical cost in a foreign currency are not translated at the reporting date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair value are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate when the fair value was determined. Transactions in foreign currencies are translated to the respective functional currencies of JV Newco entities at exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate at the reporting date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognised in profit or loss. Non-monetary items that are measured based on historical cost in a foreign currency are not translated at the reporting date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair value are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate when the fair value was determined.

The assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on acquisition, are translated into Euro at exchange rates at the reporting date. Income and expenses of foreign operations are translated into Euro at exchange rates prevailing at transaction date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognised in the translation reserve as part of equity, except to the extent that the translation difference is allocated to non-controlling interests. When a foreign operation is disposed of and control, significant influence or joint control is lost, the cumulative amount in the translation reserve related to that foreign operation is recycled to profit or loss as part of the gain or loss on disposal. If the company disposes of only part of its interest in a subsidiary but retains control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is reclassified to non-controlling interests. When the company disposes of only part of an associate or joint venture while retaining significant influence or joint control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is recycled to profit or loss. The assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on acquisition, are translated into Euro at exchange rates at the reporting date. Income and expenses of foreign F-284 ----- operations are translated into Euro at exchange rates prevailing at transaction date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognised in the translation reserve as part of equity, except to the extent that the translation difference is allocated to non-controlling interests. When a foreign operation is disposed of and control, significant influence or joint control is lost, the cumulative amount in the translation reserve related to that foreign operation is recycled to profit or loss as part of the gain or loss on disposal. If the Company disposes of only part of its interest in a subsidiary but retains control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is reclassified to non-controlling interests. When the Company disposes of only part of an associate or joint venture while retaining significant influence or joint control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is recycled to profit or loss.

A number of the company’s accounting policies and disclosures require the measurement of fair values, for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities. The company uses market observable data (to the extent practically possible) when measuring the fair value of an asset or a liability. Fair values are categorised into different fair value hierarchy levels based on the inputs used in the valuation techniques as follows: - Level 1: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities; F-207 ----- - Level 2: inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (i.e. as prices) or indirectly (i.e. derived from prices); and - Level 3: inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs). If the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset or a liability might be categorised in different levels of the fair value hierarchy, then the fair value measurement is categorised in its entirety in the same level of the fair value hierarchy as the lowest level input that is significant to the entire measurement. The company recognises transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy at the end of the reporting period during which the change has occurred. Further information about the assumptions made in measuring fair values is included in the following notes: - Acquisitions (Note 3); - Goodwill and other intangibles assets (Note 11); - Earn-out obligations (Note 22); - Put option liabilities (Note 23); and - Financial instruments (Note 26). A number of JV Newco’s accounting policies and disclosures require the measurement of fair values, for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities. JV Newco uses market observable data (to the extent practically possible) when measuring the fair value of an asset or a liability. Fair values are categorised into different fair value hierarchy levels based on the inputs used in the valuation techniques as follows: - Level 1: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities; - Level 2: inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (i.e. as prices) or indirectly (i.e. derived from prices); and - Level 3: inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs). If the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset or a liability might be categorised in different levels of the fair value hierarchy, then the fair value measurement is categorised in its entirety in the same level of the fair value hierarchy as the lowest level input that is significant to the entire measurement. JV Newco recognises transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy at the end of the reporting period during which the change has occurred. Further information about the assumptions made in measuring fair values is included in the following notes: - Acquisitions (Note 3); - Goodwill and other intangibles assets (Note 11); - Earn-out obligations (Note 22); - Put option liabilities (Note 23); and - Financial instruments (Note 26).

The company accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when control is transferred. The consideration transferred in the acquisition is generally measured at fair value, as are the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities at the date of acquisition. Goodwill is the difference between the consideration transferred and the fair value of net assets acquired and represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognised. Any gain on a bargain purchase (negative goodwill) is recognised in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs are expensed as incurred, except if related to the issue of debt or equity securities. Goodwill on acquisition of associates/joint ventures is included in investments in associates/joint ventures. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognised in profit or loss. Adjustments to the fair value of the consideration transferred and the provisional fair values of identifiable assets and liabilities in a business combination, identified within 12 months of the date of acquisition, are recognised retrospectively, provided that the new information relates to conditions that existed at the date of acquisition. In case the consideration transferred consists of (an) initial cash payment(s) and estimated future earn-out obligation based on (or related to) estimates of future results, any such obligations are only recognised as consideration if payments are not depending on future employment of the seller. An adjustment in the earn-out obligation recognised as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. As part of a business combination, the company can grant an option to non-controlling interests (e.g. a minority shareholder), to sell to the company (part of) their remaining interest in the business acquired. If such a put option provides for settlement in cash, any such obligations are only recognised as consideration if payments are not dependent on future employment of the seller. The company treats such a transaction as if the put option has been exercised at acquisition date (the so-called ‘anticipated-acquisition method’) when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to the company. Accordingly, no non-controlling interest is recognised. An adjustment in the put option liability recognised as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. When a business combination is achieved in stages, the carrying value of the previously held equity interest is re-measured to fair value at acquisition date and the difference is recognised in profit or loss. If share-based payment awards (e.g. replacement awards) are required to be exchanged for awards held by the acquiree’s employees (acquiree’s awards) and relate to past services, then all or a portion of the amount of the acquirer’s replacement awards is included in measuring the consideration transferred in the business combination. This determination is based on the market-based value of the replacement awards compared with the market-based value of the acquiree’s awards and the extent to which the replacement awards relate to pre-combination service. F-208 ----- JV Newco accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when control is transferred to JV Newco. The consideration transferred in the acquisition is generally measured at fair value, as are the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities at the date of acquisition. Goodwill is the difference between the consideration transferred and the fair value of net assets acquired, and represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognised. Any gain on a bargain purchase (negative goodwill) is recognised in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs are expensed as incurred, except if related to the issue of debt or equity securities. Goodwill on acquisition of associates/joint ventures is included in investments in associates/joint ventures. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognised in profit or loss. Adjustments to the fair value of the consideration transferred and the provisional fair values of identifiable assets and liabilities in a business combination, identified within 12 months of the date of acquisition, are recognised retrospectively, provided that the new information relates to conditions that existed at the date of acquisition. In case the consideration transferred consists of (an) initial cash payment(s) and estimated future earn-out obligation based on (or related to) estimates of future results, any such obligations are only recognised as consideration if payments are not depending on future employment of the seller. An adjustment in the earn-out obligation recognised as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. F-285 ----- As part of a business combination, JV Newco can grant an option to non-controlling interests (e.g. a minority shareholder), to sell to JV Newco (part of) their remaining interest in the business acquired. If such a put option provides for settlement in cash, any such obligations are only recognised as consideration if payments are not dependent on future employment of the seller. JV Newco treats such a transaction as if the put option has been exercised at acquisition date (the so-called ‘anticipated-acquisition method’) when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to JV Newco. Accordingly no non-controlling interest is recognised. An adjustment in the put option liability recognised as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. When a business combination is achieved in stages, the carrying value of the previously held equity interest is remeasured to fair value at acquisition date and the difference is recognised in profit or loss. If share-based payment awards (e.g. replacement awards) are required to be exchanged for awards held by the acquiree’s employees (acquiree’s awards) and relate to past services, then all or a portion of the amount of the acquirer’s replacement awards is included in measuring the consideration transferred in the business combination. This determination is based on the market-based value of the replacement awards compared with the market-based value of the acquiree’s awards and the extent to which the replacement awards relate to pre-combination service.

Determining the fair value of intangible assets arising on acquisition requires judgment. Management makes estimates regarding the timing and amount of future cash flows derived from exploiting the assets being acquired. Management then estimates an appropriate discount rate to apply to the forecast cash flows. Such estimates are based on current budgets and forecasts, extrapolated for an appropriate period taking into account growth rates, expected changes in selling prices, operating costs and the expected useful lives of the assets. Management estimates the appropriate discount rate using pre-tax rates that reflect current market assessments of the time of money and the risks specific to the assets or business being acquired. The fair value of intangible assets acquired in a business combination is determined as follows: - Format library, (TV) movie rights, catalogue of finished programs and order backlog: multi-period excess earnings method; - Contractual arrangements and customer relationships: multi-period excess earnings method, taking into account the expected renewal of the contract; and - Brands: relief-from-royalty method. The multi-period excess earnings method (“MEEM”) measures the excess earnings generated by the intangible asset being valued after deducting contributory asset charges, whereas the relief-from-royalty method measures the after-tax royalties or license fees saved by owning the intangible asset. Determining the fair value of intangible assets arising on acquisition requires judgment. Management makes estimates regarding the timing and amount of future cash flows derived from exploiting the assets being acquired. Management then estimates an appropriate discount rate to apply to the forecast cash flows. Such estimates are based on current budgets and forecasts, extrapolated for an appropriate period taking into account growth rates, expected changes in selling prices, operating costs and the expected useful lives of the assets. Management estimates the appropriate discount rate using pre-tax rates that reflect current market assessments of the time of money and the risks specific to the assets or business being acquired. The fair value of intangible assets acquired in a business combination is determined as follows: - Format library, (TV) movie rights, catalogue of finished programs and order backlog: multi-period excess earnings method; - Contractual arrangements and customer relationships: multi-period excess earnings method, taking into account the expected renewal of the contract; and - Brands: relief-from-royalty method. The multi-period excess earnings method (“MEEM”) measures the excess earnings generated by the intangible asset being valued after deducting contributory asset charges, whereas the relief-from-royalty method measures the after-tax royalties or license fees saved by owning the intangible asset.

Items of property, plant and equipment are stated at historical cost less accumulated depreciation (for definite useful life assets only) and impairment losses. Where parts of an item of property, plant and equipment have different useful lives, they are accounted for as separate components of property, plant and equipment. Subsequent expenditure is capitalised only when it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the item will flow to Endemol Shine and the cost of the item can be measured reliably. All other costs are recognised in the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income as expense when incurred. Depreciation is expensed on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life of each part of an item of property, plant and equipment, taking into account the estimated residual value. Land is not depreciated. Depreciation methods, useful lives and residual values are reviewed and adjusted if necessary, annually. Based on the estimated useful life of the underlying assets, the following depreciation periods apply: - Land . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Indefinite - Buildings . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 13 – 33 years - Plant and equipment . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8 – 13 years - Other . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 – 5 years An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognised whenever The company disposes of it, or when no more future benefits are expected by its use. Gain or loss from the derecognition of an item of property, plant and equipment is calculated as the difference between the net amount of the disposal and the book value of the asset. The gain or loss is recognised in the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income in the period in which the derecognition occurs. Other property, plant and equipment relates to computer equipment, furniture and fixtures and other tangible assets Items of property, plant and equipment are stated at historical cost less accumulated depreciation (for definite useful life assets only) and impairment losses. Where parts of an item of property, plant and equipment have different useful lives, they are accounted for as separate components of property, plant and equipment. Subsequent expenditure is capitalised only when it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the item will flow to Endemol Shine and the cost of the item can be measured reliably. All other costs are recognised in the income statement as expense when incurred. Depreciation is charged to the income statement on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life of each part of an item of property, plant and equipment, taking into account the estimated residual value. Land is not depreciated. Depreciation methods, useful lives and residual values are reviewed and adjusted if necessary, annually. Based on the estimated useful life of the underlying assets, the following depreciation periods apply: - Land Indefinite - Buildings 13 – 33 years - Plant and equipment 8 – 13 years - Other 3 – 5 years Leased property, plant and equipment, for which JV Newco substantially assumes all of the benefits and risks of ownership, are classified as finance leases. Determining whether a lease is a finance lease requires judgment as to whether substantially all of the risks and benefits of ownership have been transferred to F-286 ----- JV Newco. Finance leases are capitalised at their fair value of the leased asset or at the estimated net present value of the underlying minimum lease payments, whichever is the lower. The corresponding current and non-current rental obligations, net of finance charges, are included in the statement of financial position as current and non-current payables, respectively. Finance costs are charged to the income statement over the life of each respective lease. Payments made under operating leases, net of lease incentives received, are charged to the income statement in equal instalments over the life of the leases, except where an alternative method is more representative of the time pattern from which benefits are derived. An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognised whenever JV Newco disposes of it, or when no more future benefits are expected by its use. Profit or loss from the de-recognition of an item of property, plant and equipment is calculated as the difference between the net amount of the disposal and the book value of the asset. The profit or loss is recognised in the income statement in the period in which the de-recognition occurs. When assets are sold in a sale-and-lease-back transaction, and the lease-back results in a finance lease, then any gain on the sale is deferred and recognised as income over the lease term. If the leaseback is classified as an operating lease, the associated gain is in principle recognised in profit or loss, unless the transaction is clearly not at fair value, in which case it is accounted for in accordance with the substance of the agreement.

Goodwill represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognised. Goodwill recognised by has arisen as a result of business combinations and is carried at cost less accumulated impairment losses. Note 2.10 sets out the recognition and measurement principles for impairment. F-209 ----- Goodwill represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognised. Goodwill recognised by JV Newco has arisen as a result of business combinations and is carried at cost less accumulated impairment losses.

Other intangible assets are those assets which are identifiable and can be sold separately or which arise from legal rights and primarily consist of format rights, (TV) movie rights, contracts with customers and brand names. These assets can either be purchased, acquired in a business combination or internally developed if certain criteria for capitalisation are met. Purchased other intangible assets are stated at cost, which is the purchase price, less accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Note 2.10 sets out the recognition and measurement principles for impairment. Amortisation occurs over the period the company is expected to benefit from the use of the intangible asset and commences when the assets are available for use. Format rights are amortised as from the time the format is taken into production and in proportion to the number of episodes produced. (TV) movie rights are amortised using a declining balance method based on the expected consumption of economic benefits from these assets. Development expenditures on individual projects are only recognised as an intangible asset when the following can be demonstrated: - it is technically feasible to complete the project so that it will be available for either use or sale; - there is an intention to complete the project; - the completed project is able to be either used or sold; - the manner(s) in which the asset is expected to generate future economic benefits; - resources are available to complete the project; and - development expenditures can be measured reliably. The amount initially recognised for internally-generated intangible assets is the sum of the expenditure incurred from the date when the intangible asset first meets the recognition criteria. Where no internally-generated intangible asset can be recognised, development expenditure is recognised in profit or loss in the period in which it is incurred. Amortisation of development expenditure starts when the project is available for use. Based on the estimated useful life of the underlying assets, the following amortisation periods apply: - Format rights . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8 – 15 years - (TV) movie rights . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8 – 20 years - Contracts . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8 – 12 years - Brand names . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 – 20 years - Other . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 – 5 years The amortisation period and the amortisation method for an intangible asset with a finite useful life is reviewed at least each reporting period-end. Changes in the expected useful life are accounted for by changing the amortisation period or method, as appropriate, and are treated as changes in accounting estimates. Other intangible assets are those assets which are identifiable and can be sold separately or which arise from legal rights and primarily consist of format rights, (TV) movie rights, contracts with customers and brand names. These assets can either be purchased, acquired in a business combination or internally developed if certain criteria for capitalisation are met. Purchased other intangible assets are stated at cost, which is the purchase price, less accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Amortisation occurs over the period JV Newco is expected to benefit from the use of the intangible asset and commences when the assets are available for use. Format rights are amortised as from the time the format is taken into production and in proportion to the number of episodes produced. (TV) movie rights are amortised using a declining balance method based on the expected consumption of economic benefits from these assets. Development expenditures on individual projects are only recognised as an intangible asset when the following can be demonstrated: - it is technically feasible to complete the project so that it will be available for either use or sale; - there is an intention to complete the project; - the completed project is able to be either used or sold; - the manner(s) in which the asset is expected to generate future economic benefits; - resources are available to complete the project; and - development expenditures can be measured reliably. The amount initially recognised for internally-generated intangible assets is the sum of the expenditure incurred from the date when the intangible asset first meets the recognition criteria. Where no internally-generated intangible asset can be recognised, development expenditure is recognised in profit or loss in the period in which it is incurred. Amortisation of development expenditure starts when the project is available for use. Based on the estimated useful life of the underlying assets, the following amortisation periods apply: - Format rights 8 – 15 years - (TV) movie rights 8 – 20 years - Contracts 8 – 12 years - Brand names 3 - 20 years - Other 3 – 5 years F-287 ----- The amortisation period and the amortisation method for an intangible asset with a finite useful life is reviewed at least each reporting period-end. Changes in the expected useful life are accounted for by changing the amortisation period or method, as appropriate, and are treated as changes in accounting estimates. Format catalogue includes television and (TV) movie rights and finished program catalogue consists of the finished programs of both Endemol Shine and third party formats. The annual impairment test, as described under goodwill, did not result in an impairment of intangible assets as of 31 December 2017. In Rest of the World, JV Newco is refocusing its regional strategy in a number of markets. This has led to an impairment of brands and other intangibles of EUR 0.6 million (EUR 0.5 million including FX). No expenditures for (creative) development or other internally generated intangible fixed assets were capitalised in 2017 or in previous years. Development expenditure recognised as an expense amounted to EUR 16.2 million (2016: EUR 12.0 million). Development expenditure mainly consists of personnel expenses. Intangible assets of the Company are included in security arrangements for Loans and borrowings as disclosed in Note 19.

Subsection Title: 2.9 Investments in associates and joint-ventures Associates
Subsubsection Text: Associates are those entities in which the company has significant influence, but not control, over the financial and operating policies. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating decisions of the entity but is not control or joint control. Associates are those entities in which JV Newco has significant influence, but not control, over the financial and operating policies. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating decisions of the entity but is not control or joint control.

A joint venture is a contractual arrangement whereby the company and other parties undertake an economic activity that is subject to joint control and the company has rights to the net assets of the arrangement, rather than rights to its assets and obligations for its liabilities. Joint control exists when decisions relating to the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Investments in associates and joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method. They are recognised initially at cost, which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial F-210 ----- statements include the company’s share of the profit or loss and other comprehensive income of associates and joint ventures (after adjustments for alignment with the company’s accounting policies), from the date that significant influence or joint control commences until the date that significant influence or joint control ceases. When The company’s share of losses exceeds its interest in an associate or joint venture, the carrying amount is reduced to nil and recognition of further losses is discontinued except to the extent that the company has incurred legal or constructive obligations or made payments on behalf of an associate. A joint venture is a contractual arrangement whereby JV Newco and other parties undertake an economic activity that is subject to joint control and JV Newco has rights to the net assets of the arrangement, rather than rights to its assets and obligations for its liabilities. Joint control exists when decisions relating to the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Investments in associates and joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method. They are recognised initially at cost, which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial statements includes JV Newco’s share of the profit or loss and other comprehensive income of associates and joint ventures (after adjustments for alignment with JV Newco’s accounting policies), from the date that significant influence or joint control commences until the date that significant influence or joint control ceases. When JV Newco’s share of losses exceeds its interest in an associate or joint venture, the carrying amount is reduced to nil and recognition of further losses is discontinued except to the extent that JV Newco has incurred legal or constructive obligations or made payments on behalf of an associate.

Subsection Title: Transactions with associates and joint ventures
Subsubsection Text: Unrealised gains arising from transactions with equity-accounted investees are eliminated against the investment to the extent of the company’s interest in the investee. Unrealised losses are eliminated in the same way as unrealised gains, but only to the extent that there is no evidence of impairment. Unrealised gains arising from transactions with equity-accounted investees are eliminated against the investment to the extent of JV Newco’s interest in the investee. Unrealised losses are eliminated in the same way as unrealised gains, but only to the extent that there is no evidence of impairment.

At the end of each reporting period it is assessed whether there is any indication that an asset may be impaired. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated. At the end of each reporting period it is assessed whether there is any indication that an asset may be impaired. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated.

Subsection Title: Goodwill and other non-current intangible assets with infinite lives
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and other intangible assets with infinite lives are tested for impairment annually, or more frequently when there is an indication for impairment. The company performed and completed annual impairment tests in the last quarter of the financial year. An impairment loss is recognised for the amount by which the asset’s carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less cost of disposal and its value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value, using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset. An impairment loss is recognised in the income statement and allocated first to reduce the carrying amount of the goodwill and then to the other assets of the cash generating unit pro-rata on the basis of the carrying amount of each asset in the unit. An impairment loss recognised for goodwill is not reversed in subsequent years. Except for goodwill, the company assesses in subsequent years whether indications exist that impairment losses previously recognised for non-current assets may no longer exist or may have decreased. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of that asset (or cash generating unit) is recalculated and its carrying amount is increased to the revised recoverable amount. The increase is recognised in the income statement. A reversal is recognised only if it arises from a change in the assumptions used to calculate the recoverable amount. An impairment loss is reversed to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net amortisation, if no impairment loss had been recognised.

Subsection Title: Other non-current assets with finite lives
Subsubsection Text: Other non-current assets with finite lives are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated using an approach similar to that applied for non-current assets with infinite lives. For an asset that does not generate independent cash inflows, the recoverable amount is determined for the cash- generating unit to which the asset belongs. Impairment losses recognized in prior periods are assessed at each reporting date for any indications that the loss has decreased or no longer exists. An impairment loss is reversed if and to the extent there has been a change in the estimates used to determine the recoverable amount. The loss is reversed only to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortization, if no impairment loss had been recognized. Reversals of impairment are recognized in the income statement. The carrying amounts of JV Newco’s non-current assets with finite lives are reviewed annually to determine whether there is an indication for impairment. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated using an approach similar to that applied for non-current assets with infinite lives. For an asset that does not generate independent cash inflows, the recoverable amount is determined for the cashgenerating unit to which the asset belongs.

In many of Endemol Shine’s business areas, the company participates in pension and similar plans for its employees. A defined contribution plan is a post-employment benefit plan under which the Company pays fixed F-211 ----- contributions into a separate entity and has no legal or constructive obligation to pay further amounts. Obligations for contributions to defined contribution plans are expensed as the related service is provided. Prepaid contributions are recognised as an asset to the extent that a cash refund or a reduction in future payments is available. For other long-term employee benefits, such as long-term service benefits, the net obligation is the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods. That benefit is discounted to determine its present value. Re-measurements are recognised in profit or loss in the period in which they arise. Short-term employee benefits are measured on an undiscounted basis and are expensed as the related service is provided. The company recognises a liability and an expense for bonuses and other current employee benefits on an accrual basis. Furthermore, a provision is recognized where contractually obliged or where there is a past practice that has created a constructive obligation. Termination benefits are expensed at the earlier of when Endemol Shine Group can no longer withdraw the offer of those benefits and when Endemol Shine Group recognises costs for a restructuring. If benefits are not expected to be settled wholly within 12 months of the end of the reporting period, then they are discounted.

In general, a provision is recognised in the statement of financial position when: - there is a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of a past event; - it is probable that an outflow of economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation; and - a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. If the effect is material, provisions are determined by discounting the expected future cash flows at a pre-tax discount rate, that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and, where appropriate, the risks specific to the liability. Recoveries from third parties, which are likely to be realised, are recorded separately, and are not offset against the related liability. A provision for restructuring is recognised when: - there is an approved detailed and formal restructuring plan; and - the restructuring has either commenced or has been announced publicly. A provision for onerous contracts is recognised when the expected benefits to be derived from a contract are lower than the unavoidable cost of meeting its obligations under the contract and when such provision can be reasonably estimated.

Revenue is recognized at the amount that the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for goods or services transferred. This includes only those amounts to which the Company is entitled to under the present contract and excludes amounts collected on behalf of third parties. The transaction price agreed upon in the contract can be a variable consideration, such as royalties, price concessions, rating bonuses and profit shares. Management estimates, and includes in the transaction price at contract inception, the amount of variable consideration to which it most likely expects to be entitled. The most likely amount is an appropriate estimate of the amount of variable consideration when the contract has only two possible outcomes. Only (part of) the variable consideration is included in the transaction price to the extent that it is highly probable that a significant reversal in the amount of cumulative revenue recognized will not occur when uncertainty associated with the variable consideration is subsequently resolved.

The promise in a contract with a customer to produce a non-scripted or scripted show that consist of x number of episodes including the promise to grant a license is considered to be one performance obligation. Where a F-212 ----- contract has multiple performance obligations, the transaction price will be allocated to each performance obligation based on stand-alone selling prices. This performance obligation will be satisfied over time, since the customer gains control over the produced content at separate moments during the project; or the content produced does not have an alternative use and the Company has an enforceable right to payment while the produced content is being transferred. The Company measures the progress towards complete satisfaction of the performance obligation based on output methods. The output measurement can either be the delivery of an episode or the reaching of milestones (if specifically stated in the contract). Milestones are considered to be reached once the customer approval has been obtained. If the outcome of a production contract can be estimated reliably, revenue associated with the production are recognised by reference to the stage of completion. This is the case when: - persuasive evidence of the sale of a production with the customer exists; F-213 ----- - the amount of revenue can be measured reliably; - it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the production will flow to the entity; - the stage of completion of the production at the end of the reporting period can be measured reliably; and - the production costs incurred and the costs to complete the production can be measured reliably. The stage of completion is ordinarily determined with reference to either: - the proportion of finished episodes (to date) to total episodes to be produced under the contract (measurement of stage of completion may be done on the basis of delivery if this is a better measurement); or - the proportion of production days spent (to date) to total production days expected to be made under the contract (mainly applicable for scripted productions like telenovela’s and movies) If the outcome of a production contract cannot be estimated reliably, revenue is recognised only to the extent it is probable that expenses incurred are recoverable. Contract costs are recognised in profit or loss as incurred unless they create an asset related to future contract activity. An expected loss on a contract is recognised in profit or loss immediately. Production revenue includes the initial amount agreed in the contract plus any variations in production work, claims and incentive payments, to the extent that it is probable that these will result in revenue and they can be measured reliably.

Subsection Title: Distribution revenue—finished program sales and sale of licensing rights
Subsubsection Text: Distribution revenue is derived from contracts with customers including a license. The Company promises a right to use the format/ finished programs as they exist at the point in time at which the license is granted to the customer. This means that the customer can direct the use of and obtain substantially all of the remaining benefits from the license at the point in time at which the license transfers. The Company does not have any obligations towards improving or renewing the licensed format/finished program after start license date. Therefore, distribution revenue is recognized at a point in time. Contracts with customers can include a non-refundable minimum guarantee that effectively establishes a floor amount of consideration paid. The Company recognizes the revenue for non-refundable minimum guarantees at a point in time. In case the transaction price for granting a license is based on usage-based royalties, the Company recognizes the revenue as the underlying usage occurs.

Revenue from commercial contracts is based on production of content and/or granting a license. The transaction price of a license is mostly dependent on usage-based royalties (number of views or number of clicks). Revenue will be recognized at a point in time, when such usage occurs. Where the Company has received consideration but has not transferred goods or services yet, the Company presents the contract as deferred revenue (contract liability). Where the Company has, partially or in full, satisfied the performance obligations but not yet billed the customer, the Company presents the contract as un-invoiced revenue (contract asset), excluding any amounts presented as a trade receivable. The Company capitalizes costs to fulfil a contract only when the costs relate directly to a contract or an anticipated contract that the entity can specifically identify; the costs generate or enhance resources of the entity that will be used in satisfying or continuing to satisfy performance obligations in the future; and the costs are expected to be recovered. These costs are presented as production cost assets and are actual costs incurred for the production. The asset is amortised in line with the satisfaction of the related performance obligation. For the disclosure purposes, the Company nets per production the amounts related to un-invoiced revenue, deferred revenue and production cost assets and present them separately as “Other assets related to contracts from customers” or “Other liabilities related to contracts from customers”. The Company does not adjust the promised amount of consideration for the effects of a significant financing component where the period between when the customer receives the good or service and when the customer pays for that good or service will be one year or less. Other revenue is ordinarily recognised in accordance with the substance of the underlying agreement. Commercial, digital and other revenue is recognised e.g. on the basis of the number of calls or minutes spent on calls, the number of messages sent or received, the amounts of data traffic generated, the number of internet hits, the number of games sold and/or subscriptions sold in relation to the platforms provided. Services rendered in exchange for dissimilar goods or services are regarded as transactions that generate revenue. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the goods or services received, adjusted by the amount of cash or cash equivalents transferred. When the fair value of the goods or services received cannot be measured reliably, revenue is measured at the fair value of the goods or services given up, adjusted by the amount of cash or cash equivalents transferred.
The policy for revenue under IAS 18 was applied in the comparative statements of this financial statements.

Subsection Title: Distribution—finished program sales and sale of licensing rights
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from the sale of finished programs and licensing rights on intellectual property formats is recognised when it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the sale will flow to Endemol Shine and the amount of revenue can be estimated reliably. Any such revenues shall be recognised on an accrual basis, and only to the extent there is no continuing involvement. Revenues cannot be recognised until the start of the broadcasting/ license period. When there is continuing involvement of the company, revenue is recognised over the term of the contract.

The company recognises government grants initially as deferred income at fair value if there is reasonable assurance that they will be received, and the company will comply with the conditions associated with the grant. Subsequently, grants are then recognised in profit or loss as other income on a systematic basis over the useful life of the asset. Grants that compensate the company for expenses incurred are recognised in profit or loss on a systematic basis in the periods in which the expenses are recognised.

For equity-settled share-based payment awards granted to employees, the grant-date fair value is generally recognised as an expense, with a corresponding increase in equity, over the vesting period of the awards. The F-214 ----- amount recognised as an expense is adjusted to reflect the number of awards for which the related service and non-market performance conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognised is based on the number of awards that meet the related service and non-market performance conditions at the vesting date. For share-based payment awards with market or non-vesting conditions, the grant-date fair value of the sharebased payment is measured to reflect such conditions and there is no true-up for differences between expected and actual outcomes. For cash-settled share-based payments, a liability is recognised for the goods or services acquired, measured initially at the fair value of the liability. The services received from employees are recognised as an expense over the vesting period of the awards, with recognition of a corresponding liability. At the end of each reporting period until the liability is settled, and at the date of settlement, the fair value of the liability is re-measured, with any changes in fair value recognised in profit or loss.

The company uses the EBITDA heading in the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income. The company defines EBITDA as profit for the period before depreciation, amortisation, impairment, financial income, financial expense, share in profit of associates and income tax. EBITDA is not a measurement under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to (a) net profit, (b) cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities, or as a measure of the company’s ability to meet cash needs, or (c) any other measures or performance under IFRS. EBITDA is not a direct measure of the company’s liquidity, which is shown by The Company’s Statement of cash flows and should be considered in the context of the financial commitments. EBITDA may not be indicative of Endemol Shine’s historical operating results and may not be predictive of the company’s potential future results. Because not all companies calculate EBITDA identically, the presentation of EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly named measures of other companies. To enhance the insight into the financial results of the company’s activities, the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income shows EBITDA before (operating) exceptional items. Exceptional items are excluded from management’s assessment of results because by their size, nature or incidence they could distort the company’s underlying quality of earnings. Such items are disclosed on the face of the consolidated statement of comprehensive income and separately in the notes to the financial statements. They are typically gains or losses arising from events that are not considered part of the core operations of the business (e.g. costs relating to capital transactions, such as professional fees on acquisitions, one-off restructuring costs, shareholder management fees, earn-out and put option related remuneration expense, LTIP expenses and gains and or losses on disposal of assets). These items are excluded to reflect performance in a consistent manner and are in line with how the business is managed and measured on a day-to-day basis.

Finance income primarily comprises interest income on funds invested, fair value gains on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, gains on the re-measurement to fair value of any pre-existing interest in an acquiree in a business combination, gains on hedging instruments that are recognised in profit or loss and reclassifications of net gains previously recognised in other comprehensive income. Interest income and expense is recognised as it accrues in profit or loss, using the effective interest method. Finance costs comprise interest expense on borrowings, unwinding of the discount on provisions and deferred consideration, fair value losses on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss and contingent consideration, impairment losses recognised on financial assets (other than trade receivables), losses on hedging instruments that are recognised in profit or loss and reclassifications of net losses previously recognised in other comprehensive income. Borrowing costs that are not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognised in profit or loss using the effective interest method. Foreign currency gains and losses on financial assets and financial liabilities are reported on a net basis as either finance income or finance cost depending on whether foreign currency movements are in a net gain or net loss position. F-215 -----

The current tax payable is based on taxable profit for the period and includes adjustments to tax payable or receivable in respect of prior periods. Taxable profit differs from profit as reported in the income statement because of items of income or expense that are taxable or deductible in other periods and items that are never taxable or deductible. The company’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period.

Deferred tax is recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the consolidated financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognised for all taxable temporary differences. Deferred tax assets are generally recognised for all deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which those deductible temporary differences can be utilised. Such deferred tax assets and liabilities are not recognised if the temporary difference arises from the initial recognition of goodwill or from the initial recognition (other than in a business combination) of other assets and liabilities in a transaction that affects neither the taxable profit nor the accounting profit. Deferred tax liabilities are recognised for taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries and associates, and interests in joint ventures, except where the company is able to control the reversal of the temporary difference and it is probable that the temporary difference will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred tax assets arising from deductible temporary differences associated with such investments and interests are only recognised to the extent that it is probable that there will be sufficient taxable profits against which to utilise the benefits of the temporary differences and they are expected to reverse in the foreseeable future. A deferred tax asset is recognised for unused tax losses to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be utilised. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realised. Such reductions are reversed when the probability of future taxable profits improves. Unrecognised deferred tax assets are reassessed at each reporting date and recognised to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period in which the liability is settled or the asset realised, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner, in which the company expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and the company intends to settle its current tax assets and liabilities on a net basis. Deferred tax is recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the consolidated financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognised for all taxable temporary differences. Deferred tax assets are generally recognised for all deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which those deductible temporary differences can be utilised. Such deferred tax assets and liabilities are not recognised if the temporary difference arises from the initial recognition of goodwill or from the initial recognition (other than in a business combination) of other assets and liabilities in a transaction that affects neither the taxable profit nor the accounting profit. Deferred tax liabilities are recognised for taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries and associates, and interests in joint ventures, except where JV Newco is able to control the reversal of the temporary difference and it is probable that the temporary difference will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred tax assets arising from deductible temporary differences associated with such investments and interests are only recognised to the extent that it is probable that there will be sufficient taxable profits against which to utilise the benefits of the temporary differences and they are expected to reverse in the foreseeable future. A deferred tax asset is recognised for unused tax losses to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be utilised. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realised. Such reductions are reversed when the probability of future taxable profits improves. Unrecognised deferred tax assets are reassessed at each reporting date and recognised to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period in which the liability is settled or the asset realised, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner, in which JV Newco expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and JV Newco intends to settle its current tax assets and liabilities on a net basis. F-293 -----

All financial instruments are initially recognised at fair value, plus or minus (in the case of a financial asset or financial liability not at fair value through profit or loss (‘FVTPL’)) transaction costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition or issue of the financial instrument. The Company classifies and subsequently measures financial assets at either amortised cost or FVTPL. Financial assets measured at amortised cost include trade receivables, other financial receivables and cash and cash equivalents. Derivative such as purchased options, swaps and forward contracts are measured subsequently at FVTPL. There are no financial assets classified as fair value through other comprehensive income. From 1 January 2018, the Company applies the IFRS 9 simplified approach to measure expected credit losses which uses a lifetime expected loss allowance for all trade receivables and uninvoiced revenue (as defined in Note 2.13a). For trade receivables or uninvoiced revenue that do not contain a significant financing component, the loss allowance should be measured at initial recognition and throughout its life at an amount equal to lifetime expected credit loss (‘ECL’). The Company uses a provision matrix which is based on the historical credit loss experience over the life of the trade receivables. F-216 ----- The Company subsequently measures financial liabilities at amortised cost, unless they are required to be measured at FVTPL. Financial liabilities measured at amortised cost include trade payables, other financial payables, cash and cash equivalents and loans and borrowings. Liabilities required to be measured at FVTPL include derivatives (such as foreign currency forwards or interest swaps), earn-out obligations and put-option liabilities. The amortised cost of a financial asset or financial liability is defined as the amount at which the financial asset or financial liability is measured at initial recognition minus the principal repayments, plus or minus the cumulative amortisation using the effective interest method of any difference between that initial amount and the maturity amount and, for financial assets, adjusted for any loss allowance. Financial assets are derecognised when, and only when, the contractual rights to the cash flows from the financial asset expires or it transfers the financial asset and the transfer has qualified for derecognition. The Company derecognises financial liabilities when, and only when, it is extinguished i.e. when the obligation is discharged or cancelled or expires.

The proceeds of issued shares in excess of the nominal value of the shares are recognised as share premium, after deducting the incremental costs directly attributable to the share issue, net of tax. The proceeds of issued shares in excess of the nominal value of the shares are recognised as share premium, after deducting the incremental costs directly attributable to the share issue, net of tax. Redeemable preference shares are classified as financial liabilities when they bear non-discretionary dividends and are redeemable in cash by the holders. Non-discretionary dividends thereon are recognised as interest expense in profit or loss as accrued. Non-redeemable preference shares are classified as equity, because they bear discretionary dividends, do not contain any obligations to deliver cash or other financial assets and do not require settlement in a variable number of the Group’s equity instruments. Discretionary dividends thereon are recognised as equity distributions on approval by the Company’s shareholders. When shares recognised as equity are purchased by the Group, the consideration paid, including directly attributable costs, net of any tax effects, is recognised as a deduction from other reserves within equity. When such shares are sold or reissued subsequently, the amount received is recognised as an increase in other reserves within equity. When purchased shares are withdrawn, the nominal value of the shares and the related share premium is deducted from share capital and share premium, and added to the other reserves.

The company uses derivative financial instruments principally to manage its foreign currency risks. All derivative financial instruments are accounted for at the trade date and classified as current or non-current assets or liabilities based on the maturity date or the early termination date. The company measures all derivative financial instruments at fair value derived from market prices of the instruments or calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable interest yield curves, basis spread, credit spreads and foreign exchange rates, or from option pricing models, as appropriate. Gains or losses arising from changes in fair value of derivatives are recognized in the statement of comprehensive income. Effective 8 January 2015, the Company entered into a EUR 350.0 million for USD 412 million Cross Currency Swap (CCS), at spot rate USD/EUR 1.177. The CCS partly off sets the mismatch between the currency mix of the external loans and borrowings and the currency mix of EBITDA and cash flow and in addition converts the company’s floating interest obligation in respect of 60% of the principal amount of the EUR-denominated loans to a fixed rate. Inputs used by the financial institution in measuring the fair value transferred from Level 2 to Level 3 because of a lack of observable market data, resulting from a decrease in the credit rating of JV Newco from B to CCC. Since JV Newco did not designate a hedge, the change in fair value of the derivative financial instrument is recorded in the income statement. In 2017 the fair value changed from an asset into a liability (included in Note 24 ‘Other non-current liabilities’). Reference is made to the disclosure in Note 13 ‘Other financial assets’.

Trade receivables are initially recognised at fair value, and subsequently carried at amortised cost, which is usually the nominal value, less impairment losses. Prior to 1 January 2018, allowances for bad debts are recorded when there is objective evidence that collection of the receivable is no longer probable. From 1 January 2018, the Company applies the IFRS 9 simplified approach to measure expected credit losses which uses a lifetime expected loss allowance for all trade receivables and contract assets.

Cash and cash equivalents include all cash on hand balances, short-term highly liquid cash investments and time deposits with original maturities of three months or less. Cash and cash equivalents are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently at amortised cost, which is usually the nominal value. Positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with one bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously.

Interest-bearing borrowings are recognised initially at fair value less directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, interest-bearing borrowings are stated at amortised cost with any difference between cost and redemption value being recognised in the income statement over the period of the borrowings based on the effective interest method.

When part of the purchase price consideration of a business combination depends on future results, an earn-out obligation is initially calculated at fair value. F-217 ----- The calculation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario (performance-related criteria). Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation.

A put option liability is calculated in case the company granted a minority shareholder an option to sell to Endemol Shine its remaining interest. Put option liabilities are re-measured to fair value at least annually based on the expected future results of the respective company, or earlier when indicators warrant recalculation. This is considered to be an obligation as the company acquires its own equity, even if the exercise is contingent and conditional, when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to The company, as such no non-controlling interest is recognised. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. To the extent dividend payments to minority shareholders reduce the redemption amount, they are recognised against the put option liability. Otherwise dividend payments to minority shareholders are recognised as financial expense in profit or loss upon profit distribution.

Distribution advances are advances paid for some productions to another company from which future revenue is expected to be derived. These advances are classified as current assets as they are expected to derive a short-term economic benefit for the Company. These advances are not expensed until the production is available for distribution or has been distributed. Up to that point, they are assessed annually for impairment through the reassessment of the future sales expected to be earned from that title.

Subsection Title: 2.21 Preparation of the Statement of cash flows
Subsubsection Text: The statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method. Changes in balance sheet items that have not resulted in cash flows (e.g. translation differences, financial leases, fair value changes, conversions of debt to equity) have been eliminated for the purpose of preparing this statement. Dividends received are included in investing activities, whereas dividends paid to ordinary shareholders, interest received, and interest paid are included in financing activities. For the purposes of the cash flow statement, bank overdrafts that are an integral part of the company’s cash management are included as a component of cash and cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at the bank (both debit and credit) and (call) deposits.

Subsection Title: 2.22 New, revised and amended standards and interpretations not yet applied
Subsubsection Text: The following new, revised and amended IFRSs may be relevant to JV Newco, and are not yet applied by JV Newco: _IFRS 16—The standard sets out principles for recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure_ requirements for leases. The changes mainly affect lessee accounting and generally require lessees to recognize contractual rights and obligations on the lessee’s balance sheet. The standard replaces the straight-line recognition of operating lease expense for those leases applying IAS 17 with the recognition of depreciation expenses for the right-of-use asset and interest expenses on the lease liability (included within the financial result). In addition, IFRS 16 requires more extensive disclosures in the notes for lessees. The standard must be adopted for periods beginning on, or after, 1 January 2019. F-218 ----- The Company will apply the low value and short-term recognition exemptions. The Company will also apply the practical expedient to not separate non-lease components from lease components for all classes of leases. The Company will apply the standard from its adoption date on 1 January 2019 and will apply the modified retrospective approach therefore the Company will not restate comparative amounts prior to the first year of adoption. The right-of-use asset will be measured at the amount of the lease liability on adoption. The Company will apply the following practical expedients: for leases ending within 12 months of adoption of IFRS 16 to be treated as short term; exclude initial direct costs from the measurement of the right-of-use asset; and use hindsight, such as in determining the lease term if the contract contains options to extend or terminate the lease. The Company identified the operating leases which are expected to have an impact, and these relate to office buildings, car & truck lease, studio’s, production related leases and office equipment. As at the reporting date, the Company has non-cancellable lease commitments of EUR 176 million (Note 27 Commitments, litigation and other matters). Of these commitments, approximately EUR 2.6 million relates to short-term leases and low value leases which will be recognized on a straight-line basis as expense in profit or loss. Lease agreements entered into do not contain contingent rent payables, significant renewal/purchase/escalation options/restrictions. For the remaining lease commitments, after the impact of discounting, the Company expects to recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities of EUR 151 million on 1 January 2019. The Company expects that EBITDA will increase, as operating lease payments were included in EBITDA, but the depreciation of right-of-use assets and interest on the lease liability are excluded from this measure. The Company’s activities as a lessor are not material and hence the Company does not expect any significant impact on the financial statements.

In 2017, the Company entered into an agreement to join activities with Boomdog, a leading independent production company in Mexico, to jointly develop opportunities both locally and in the fast-growing U.S. Hispanic market. The transaction closed in January 2018. The Company contributed its Latino activities with an equity value of EUR 2.5m into the newly founded company Endemol Shine Boomdog LLC (“ES Boomdog Miami”). 49% of the shares in ES Boomdog Miami were sold to Boomdog US Inc., a 100% subsidiary of BDF Productions. In exchange BDF Productions gave up 51% in Endemol Shine Boomdog Holding S.A.P.I. de C.V. (“ES Boomdog Mexico”). ES Boomdog Mexico, a newly formed entity, holds a 100% interest in Boomdog Films (now Endemol Shine Boomdog S.A.P.I. de C.V.) and Boomdog Studios S.A.P.I. de C.V.. The equity value of ES Boomdog Mexico, at the moment of the transaction, was approximately zero. This resulted in the creation of Goodwill amounting to EUR 1.2m. The Company purchased the remaining shares (30%) in Kemna & Zonen B.V. during 2018 (post acquisition renamed to Curtain Call Media B.V).
