In 2018, the Company sold its 100% interest in EndemolShine South Africa to local management as part of refocusing on its key markets and its 51% share in Herr P in Germany to the original founder in exchange for an increase in the percentage of net income that we are entitled to receive in connection with our right to distribute the Brain internationally.

In 2017, the Company did not acquire stakes in companies that have been accounted for as business combinations. F-219 ----- Per 14 February 2017 the Company acquired 100% of No Doubt Productions Inc in the United States of America. No Doubt Productions Inc. owns post production equipment facilities. This transaction has been accounted for as purchase of assets.

In 2017, the Company sold its 100% interest in Studios A/S Denmark and Studios AS Norway as part of refocusing its regional strategy for a consideration of EUR 5.3 million. In 2017, the Company sold its 100% interest in Studios A/S Denmark and Studios AS Norway as part of refocusing its regional strategy for a consideration of EUR 5.3 million.

In 2016, at the derecognition of CORE Media Group as described in Note 3, the Company derecognized the non-valuated losses and tax credits pertaining to CORE Media Group. In business combinations in 2014 the Company recognised deferred tax liabilities pertaining to identified assets at book values as previously carried by the contributing shareholder where the tax base was not affected by the business combination. The Company subsequently recognized tax benefits in respect of tax losses of the fiscal unity in certain jurisdictions to the extent it can be set off against deferred tax liabilities arising from the business combinations that relate to the fiscal unity of that particular jurisdiction. To the extent tax losses cannot be set off against deferred tax liabilities, valuation (if any) of tax losses is based on forecasts of future results and assessment of probability of its realisation.

As per 2018, the Company performed its annual goodwill impairment test as of October 1. This will also be the measurement date going forward. In 2017, the goodwill test was performed at 31 December 2017. The Company considers the development of the WACCs, peer group information and the realisation of the operating results of its CGUs versus budgeted amounts and market multiples as key factors when reviewing for indicators of impairment. The recoverable amounts of CGUs have been determined based on fair value less costs of disposal calculations. The financial projections cover a period of five years. The key assumptions used for the fair value less cost of disposal calculations relate to discount rate and terminal value growth rate, revenue growth and EBITDA margin. The financial projections are derived from the 2019 Budget and 2020 business plan and forward-looking statements as approved by management taken into account various downside adjustments. The projections include estimates for the cost savings that have been realized and are to be realized from several cost and procurement saving initiatives. By their nature, forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties as they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. Accordingly, actual results of operations, financial condition and liquidity may differ from those assumed in the forward-looking statements. This impairment test is considered to be a level 3 assessment. The post-tax discount rates, applied to the cash flow projections, vary between 6.4% and 11.7% (December 2017: 6.6% and 11.5%). These rates have been calculated using the weighted average cost of capital methodology. The main parameters are the targeted debt-to-equity ratio, the risk-free interest rate based on government bonds and a risk premium. The terminal value growth rate is based on the risk-free rate for all Euro denominated CGU’s or the risk-free rate plus inflation differential for other CGU’s. The revenue growth rates and EBITDA margins used to estimate future performance are based on past performance and the Company’s expectations for growth rates and EBITDA margins achievable in the markets the Company is active in. Consolidated for the Company, the average annual compounded revenue growth rate applied for the forecast period financial year 2019-2023 is 2.5%. The average annual compounded revenue growth rate applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 0.0% and 8.4%. Consolidated for the Company the terminal value year EBITDA margin applied is 9.0%. The terminal value year EBITDA margins applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 7.4% and 20.3%. Consolidated for the Company the terminal value growth rate applied is 0.5%. The terminal value growth rate applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 0.4% and 1.3%. The impairment test led to the conclusion that there was an impairment required for the CGU France following the market deterioration and subsequently revision of the forecast for the year 2019-2022 in May 2019. The impairment for CGU France of EUR 44.1 million, which was not recorded in the consolidated financial statements of MediArena Acquisition BV, is mainly driven by significantly lower than anticipated performance in the year 2019 mainly for the non-scripted business. The impairment charge of EUR 44.1 million has been reported in the statement of comprehensive income. The recoverable amount of the CGU France is EUR 38.9 million as per 31 December 2018. In addition to the forecast used in the impairment test, a sensitivity analysis has been prepared. In the scenario of using a 50 bps higher discount rate, this would lead to recognizing a total additional impairment charge of F-228 ----- EUR (25) million for the CGU International & Distribution. A 5% lower terminal value EBITDA growth level would lead to recognizing a total additional impairment of EUR (10) million for the CGU International & Distribution. The following table illustrates for the CGUs with limited headroom the sensitivity to changes in the terminal value EBITDA which would result in a recoverable amount equal to the carrying amount and the headroom based on current projections:

Allocation of goodwill to cash generating units
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill has been allocated to cash-generating units (“CGUs”) as disclosed in the table below for 31 December 2018 and 31 December 2017. The goodwill allocated at the measurement date was € 1,131 million (Dec 2017: € 1,180 million). The movement of the goodwill amount between measurement date and 31 December 2018 was due to foreign exchange differences and the impairment recognized for CGU France. There were no changes to the methodology of goodwill allocation to CGUs except for the goodwill of Belgium (€ 8 million) which is now part of the CGU Netherlands instead of the CGU Northern Europe. The transfer of the CGU Belgium to the CGU The Netherlands is due to a change in management structure. In 2018, a CEO has been appointed to manage both the Netherlands and Belgium business and as a result the Belgium activities have been integrated in activities in the Netherlands including key account management. The CGU structure has been set-up on the basis of materiality of the operating companies and in order to align with the reporting and responsibility structure. Subsubsection Text: During the financial period 2017, the Company assessed the recoverable amount of goodwill and other intangible assets, based on a detailed forecast per CGU taking into account various downside adjustments to the detailed business plans. This level 3 assessment led to the conclusion that an impairment was required for an amount of EUR (19.8) million, for the CGU France. An additional impairment charge was incurred for the CGU Rest of World in the amount of EUR (5.8) million, EUR (5.2) million including FX. An impairment charge of EUR (25.6) million was reported in the statement of comprehensive income. The impairment for CGU France was mainly driven by lower performance in the year and lower forward projections in especially the non-scripted business. In Rest of the World, the company refocused its regional strategy in some markets. As part of that refocus, the decision was made to unwind the operations in Turkey and to liquidate the local operating company in Turkey. F-230 -----

Subsubsection Text: Effective 8 January 2015, the Company entered into a EUR 350.0 million for USD 412 million Cross Currency Swap (CCS), at spot rate USD/EUR 1.177. The CCS partly off sets the mismatch between the currency mix of F-232 ----- the external loans and borrowings and the currency mix of EBITDA and cash flow and in addition converts the company’s floating interest obligation in respect of 60% of the principal amount of the EUR-denominated loans to a fixed rate. Inputs used by the financial institution in measuring the fair value transferred from Level 2 to Level 3 because of a lack of observable market data, resulting from a decrease in the credit rating of Endemol Shine Group from B to CCC. Since JV Newco did not designate a hedge, the change in fair value of the derivative financial instrument is recorded in the income statement. In 2017, the fair value changed from an asset into a liability (included in Note 24 ‘Other non-current liabilities’).

Services rendered in exchange for dissimilar goods or services are regarded as transactions that generate revenue. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the goods or services received, adjusted by the amount of cash or cash equivalents transferred. When the fair value of the goods or services received cannot be measured reliably, revenue is measured at the fair value of the goods or services given up, adjusted by the amount of cash or cash equivalents transferred. Subsection Title: Total cash and cash equivalents . . . . . . . . .** **278,762** **191,131 Notional cash pool
Subsubsection Text: Positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with one bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. Notional cash pools form an integral part of the company’s cash management. Based on the above JV Newco is required to report the cash balances and the bank overdrafts on a gross basis. Bank overdrafts as included in current part of Loans and borrowings (‘Other bank debt’) are EUR (276.5) million (2017: EUR (132.2) million) of which EUR (224.8) million (2017: EUR (106.8 million) relates to the cash pool effect. All cash is at the free disposal of the company, except for trapped cash in the amount of EUR 14 million (2017: EUR 25.8 million). Trapped cash consists amongst others of trust account cash, country restricted cash, cash at jointly controlled ventures and cash backed bank guarantees.

Short-term deposits in the amount of EUR 0.9 million (2017: EUR 3.3 million) were placed for periods less than one month. Short-term deposits in the amount of EUR 3.3 million (2016: EUR 3.3 million) were placed for periods less than one month.

On 13 August 2014, MediArena Acquisition B.V. (formerly known as AP NMT Acquisition B.V.), as borrower, MediArena Newco B.V. (formerly AP NMT Newco B.V.), the borrower’s direct parent company, and certain financial institutions entered into a First Lien Credit Agreement and a Second Lien Credit Agreement. On 12 December 2014, to finance the Shine transaction, MediArena Acquisition B.V. also entered into an Incremental Assumption Agreement. Together these provide for: a EUR 125 million First Lien multi-currency revolving credit facility (“RCF”), which also facilitates a letter of credit sub-facility and a EUR 30 million swing line loan sub-facility. On 22 December 2017, the maturity date of the RCF was extended to 13 August 2020 (previously 13 August 2019). In May 2019, management extended the maturity of the RCF to May 2021. As per 31 December 2018, total drawings under the RCF amounting to EUR 25.0 million were outstanding (2017: EUR 60.0 million); a First Lien Term Loan B facility maturing on 13 August 2021, comprised of a USD 885 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans, a EUR 235 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans and a GBP 50 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans; and a USD 457 million Second Lien Term Loan B facility maturing on 13 August 2022. On 22 April 2015, MediArena Acquisition B.V. entered into an Incremental Assumption Agreement providing for: an additional USD 25 million First Lien Term Loan B loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, which also matures on 13 August 2021; and an additional EUR 25 million First Lien Term Loan B loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, which also matures on 13 August 2021. The loans incurred on 12 December 2014 and 22 April 2015 have the same terms as the loans of the same currency incurred under the First Lien Credit Agreement on 13 August 2014. In addition, the Group may request one or more incremental term loan facilities and/or increase commitments under its First Lien Credit Agreement and request one or more incremental term loan facilities under its Second Lien Agreement in an aggregate amount of up to the sum of EUR 100 million plus such additional amount as long as, (i) in the case of loans under additional credit facilities that rank equally to the liens on the collateral securing the Term B Loans and the Initial Revolving Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, its consolidated net first lien leverage ratio would be no greater than 3.40 to 1.00 and (ii) in the case of loans under additional credit facilities that rank junior to the liens on the collateral securing the Term B Loans and the Initial Revolving Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement and equally and without preference with, or junior to, the liens on the collateral securing the Term Loans under the Second Lien Credit Agreement, its consolidated net secured leverage ratio would be no greater than 5.20 to 1.00, subject to certain conditions and receipt of commitments by existing or additional lenders. F-237 ----- All borrowings under the Group’s revolving credit facility under the First Lien Credit Agreement are subject to the satisfaction of customary conditions, including the absence of a default and the accuracy of representations and warranties. Prior to the maturity date of 13 August 2021, the First Lien Term B Loans require scheduled quarterly amortization payments in an amount equal to 0.25% of the original principal amount of the term loans, the first payment of which was due on 31 December 2014, with the balance due at maturity. In 2018, amortization payments of EUR 10.9 million were made (2017: EUR 11.1 million). Amortization payments due in 2019 amount to EUR 11.1 million. Within the context of the financing agreements, guarantees and securities have been provided by several of Endemol Shine’s entities established in the Security Jurisdictions (United States, England and Wales, the Netherlands, Germany, France, Spain and Australia) and guarantees have been provided by certain Endemol Shine entities established in Italy, Norway, Sweden and Denmark. Borrowings of term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement and Second Lien Credit Agreement with a base rate equal to the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) are subject to a 1.00% floor. The First Lien Credit Agreement includes customary mandatory prepayment requirements based on certain events, such as asset sales, certain debt issuances and defined levels of excess cash flow. The Second Lien Credit Agreement includes customary mandatory prepayment requirements based on certain events, such as asset sales, certain debt issuances and defined levels of excess cash flow. The Company may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement at any time, without prepayment premium or penalty and subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to LIBOR rate loans. The Company may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the Second Lien Credit Agreement at any time. All prepayments will be subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to LIBOR loans. The Revolving Facility requires that the financial maintenance covenant be tested as of the last day of any quarter if as of such time any revolving facility loans, swingline loans or letters of credit are outstanding (excluding letters of credit other than letters of credit supporting debt for borrowed money). With respect to the Revolving Facility only, the covenant requires the consolidated net first lien leverage ratio not to exceed 5.50 to 1.00; provided that, solely to the extent that conditions relating to available capacity under certain Indebtedness, lien, investment and restricted payment baskets (the so-called financial covenant stepdown conditions) are not satisfied at any time when the Revolving Facility may be drawn, the net first lien leverage ratio would be reduced from a ratio equal to 5.50 to 1.00 to a ratio equal to 3.00 to 1.00. As of 31 December 2018, borrowings were outstanding under the revolving credit facility; therefore, the covenant was in effect. The First Lien Credit Agreement and Second Lien Credit Agreement also contain customary affirmative covenants and events of default, and the negative covenants limit the Group’s ability to, among other things: incur additional debt or issue certain preferred shares; create liens on assets; make certain loans or investments (including acquisitions); pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of its capital stock or make other restricted payments; consolidate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of its assets; enter into certain transactions with its affiliates; enter into sale-leaseback transactions; change its lines of business; restrict dividends from its subsidiaries or restrict liens; change its fiscal year; and modify the terms of certain debt or organizational agreements.

On 24 March 2016, Endemol Shine OpCo Holding SPV B.V. entered into a USD 70 million revolving receivable securitisation facility (the “Facility”) with Bank of America, N.A., as administrative agent. On 23 December 2016, the revolving receivable securitisation facility was increased to USD 100 million. On 29 September 2017, the revolving receivable securitisation facility was increased to USD 125 million. The Facility is structured as a permitted securitisation under the Company’s First Lien Credit Agreement and second lien credit agreement. Under the Facility, interest and certain principal amounts are paid on a monthly basis or, in the case of loans bearing interest based on LIBOR, on the last day of each applicable interest period. The interest rates under the Facility are based on either LIBOR, the prime rate published by Bank of America, N.A., or the federal funds rate, plus, in each case, an agreed upon margin. The Facility is classified as a held to maturity instrument. F-238 ----- The loan parties under the Facility are special purpose entities that are structured as bankruptcy-remote from the rest of Endemol Shine Group. The Facility is secured by the receivables that are transferred to the loan parties by members of Endemol Shine Group from time to time, which assets also comprise of liquidity buffers under the Facility. The Facility is not guaranteed by other members of Endemol Shine Group that are not parties to the Facility. As per 31 December 2018, an amount of EUR 55.9 million was drawn under the facility (2017: EUR 74 million), of which EUR 31.7 million matures within a year (2017: EUR 46 million). On 24 March 2016, Endemol Shine OpCo Holding SPV B.V. entered into a USD 70 million revolving receivable securitisation facility (the “Facility”) with Bank of America, N.A., as administrative agent. On 23 December 2016, the revolving receivable securitisation facility was increased to USD 100 million. On 29 September 2017, the revolving receivable securitisation facility was increased to USD 125 million. The Facility is structured as a permitted securitisation under the Company’s first lien credit agreement and second lien credit agreement. Under the Facility, interest and certain principal amounts are paid on a monthly basis or, in the case of loans bearing interest based on LIBOR, on the last day of each applicable interest period. The interest rates under the Facility are based on either LIBOR, the prime rate published by Bank of America, N.A., or the federal funds rate, plus, in each case, an agreed upon margin. The Facility is classified as a held to maturity instrument. The loan parties under the Facility are special purpose entities that are structured as bankruptcy-remote from the greater Endemol Shine Group. The Facility is secured by the receivables that are transferred to the loan parties by members of Endemol Shine Group from time to time, which assets also comprise of liquidity buffers under the Facility. The Facility is not guaranteed by other members of Endemol Shine Group that are not parties to the Facility. As per 31 December 2017, an amount of EUR 74.0 million was drawn under the facility (2016: EUR 57.4 million), of which EUR 46.0 million matures within a year (2016: EUR 21.1 million).

As per 29 December 2016 the Company received a short-term loan from related parties in the amount of USD 30 million. The short-term loan had an original maturity date of 29 March 2017, which has been extended from time to time. The principal was increased to USD 33 million as per 15 December 2017. The loan has a maturity date of 14 June 2019.The loan bears an interest rate of 10% per annum, payable at maturity. On 4 June 2019, the maturity of the shareholders’ loan was extended to 13 December 2019. Reference is made to the disclosure in Note 19 ‘Loans and borrowings’. Notional cash pools form an integral part of the company’s cash management. Based on the above, the company is required to report the cash balances and the bank overdrafts on a gross basis. Subsection Title: Total employee benefit obligations . . . . . .** **19,177** **12,288 Post-employment benefits
Subsubsection Text: Except for the Dutch group companies, Endemol Shine’s employees are covered by several defined contribution plans. In the Netherlands, Endemol participates in a defined benefit plan for nearly all employees at Stichting Bedrijfstakpensioenfonds voor de Media PNO (“PNO Media”). This plan is a multi-employer defined benefit pension plan, which is accounted for as a defined contribution plan because sufficient information for defined F-240 ----- benefit accounting is not available. PNO Media is a multi-employer pension fund and PNO Media is not able to provide Endemol with sufficient information on the present value of the benefit obligations, the fair value of plan assets and the funded status of Endemol. As of 31 December 2018, PNO Media had a policy funding ratio (“beleiddekkingsgraad”) of 106% (2017: 102%), which is below the required ratio by De Nederlandsche Bank (DNB) of approximately 123%. As long as the policy funding ratio (“beleiddekkingsgraad”) is below the required coverage ratio, the recovery plan will be updated by PNO Media annually. The estimated contributions are likely to remain the same for 2019. In Italy, employees are covered by a severance plan (post-employment benefit plan) provided for in accordance with local legislation. Severance pay is considered normal remuneration that has been deferred and approximates one month’s pay for each year of service, valued each year on a basis linked to cost-of-living indices. The severance liability as of 31 December 2018 of EUR 0.6 million (2017: EUR 0.7 million), represents the accumulated amount due to employees upon termination based on service to date. In other countries, the total unfunded retirement indemnity for employees is provided for, amounting to EUR 0.1 million as of 31 December 2018 (2017: EUR 0.1 million).

Subsection Title: Other employee benefits: group incentive plan
Subsubsection Text: In 2018 the Company changed the long-term incentive plans (“LTIPs”) to one Group Incentive Plans (“GIP”) to further align the interest of local executives with the interest of the stakeholders in the Group and stimulate further value creation. Additionally, the number of participants in the GIP has been reduced. The value creation is measured by the growth in consolidated group trading EBITDA -/- cash Exceptional charges, measured over the Plan period. The GIP period covers the period 2018 – 2020. The GIP will payout in March 2021 (50%) and the remaining 50% in March 2022, to only participants who are still employed at the moment of the respective payments. If there is no or limited growth of earnings over the GIP period, the GIP is out of the money. The GIP amount is calculated as a percentage of the participant salaries, with a maximum expected payout of EUR 18.8 million. The GIP has a so called “lock-in mechanism” for 2018, which means that the 2018 achievement is locked-in if the 2018 target is achieved. The 2018 results are above the hurdles set in the GIP plan and therefore executives participating in the GIP are eligible for payout of the 2018 participation value in 2021 and 2022. As per the end of 2018 only the LTIP for the UK is still active and therefore these executives have not moved to the GIP yet. Selected executives will be moving to the GIP in 2019, as the LTIP is finalized in 2018. All other LTIPs were settled in 2018. The GIP is in substance considered a profit-sharing arrangement and are accounted for as an employee benefit in accordance with IAS 19. The expenses in connection with such plans are attributed to the period in which the services that give rise to the obligation are rendered. Therefore 50% is attributed to the period January 2018 – March 2021 and 50% is attributed to the period January 2018 – March 2022. In terms of the GIP, the Company only accounts for GIP expenses in any given period if it is management’s best estimate as of the end of that period that the plan will be “in the money” and the bonus payable can be estimated reliably. The “in the money” assessment is primarily made with reference to whether or not a certain targeted earnings measure has been achieved during the respective financial period.

In 2018 the Long-Term Incentive Option Plan was modified into a new Equity Incentive Plan (EIP) designed to provide long-term incentives for eligible senior executives to deliver long-term shareholder returns. Participation in the plan has been limited to a smaller group, being the group executive team. Under the plan, participants are granted Restricted Stock Units (RSU) which is a right to receive the value of the shares (1 RSU = 1 Share) at no costs, in the capital of AP NMT JV Newco BV (“JV Newco”). 25% of the granted RSU’s will vest rateably over four years (service based vesting tranche), and 75% of the granted RSU’s will vest only at the occurrence of a realization event (performance based vesting tranches): - 37.5% will vest if the share price is at least $85 but only when Fox and/or Apollo sell at least 60% of their shares in the Parent (exit event); - 37.5% will vest if the share price is at least $105 but only when Fox and/or Apollo sell at least 60% of their shares in the Parent (exit event); F-241 ----- A “exit event” means the occurrence of certain sales of JV Newco shares by JV Newco shareholders, certain transfers of JV Newco assets or a liquidation of JV Newco. As the awards granted under the plan are equity-settled share-based payment awards, the grant date fair value is recognised as an expense over the vesting period with a corresponding increase in equity. The new RSU plan has been applied retrospectively starting January 1, 2017. The total value of the time based RSU amounts to USD 5 million and the performance based RSU amount to USD 18 thousand. The fair value of the old option plan as per January 1, 2017 amounted to USD 9 thousand, resulting in recognition of the delta in value of the 2 plans to be recognized over the period till January 1, 2021. For the valuation of RSU’s granted during the year 2018, the main assumptions are: - Valuation date: 1 May 2018 - Vesting date: January 1 - expected option life: 0.67 years / 1.67 years - share price at grant date: USD 35.46 - expected share price volatility of the company’s shares: 26.3% / 25.3% - risk-free interest rate: 2.06% (0.67 year US government bond) / 2.45% (1.67 year US government bond) - expected dividends: 0% Set out below is a summary of the grant dates of the new RSU plan: Number of RSU As of 31 December 2017 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . **— Granted 2018 RSU’s . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 565,000 Forfeited during the year . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . — The Equity Incentive Plan is designed to provide long-term incentives for eligible management to deliver long-term shareholder returns. Participation in the plan is at the board’s discretion. Under the plan, participants are granted options to purchase shares of common stock of JV Newco. 25% of the granted options will vest ratably over five years (service based vesting tranche), and 75% of the granted options will vest only at the occurrence of a realization event (Performance based vesting tranches): - 25% will vest only on the occurrence of a realization event, but only if JV Newco shareholders receive cash proceeds of at least two times (2.0x) their aggregate investment in JV Newco - 25% will vest only on the occurrence of a realization event, but only if the “JV Newco” shareholders receive cash proceeds of at least two and a half times (2.5x) their aggregate investment in JV Newco - 25% will vest only on the occurrence of a realization event, but only if JV Newco shareholders receive cash proceeds of at least three times (3.0x) their aggregate investment in JV Newco. The option grant has a 10 year term with an exercise period of 5 years after the final vesting date for the service based tranche. A “realization event” means the occurrence of certain sales of JV Newco shares by JV Newco shareholders, certain transfers of JV Newco assets or a liquidation of JV Newco. Options are granted under the plan for no consideration and carry no dividend or voting rights. When exercisable, each option is convertible into one ordinary share. The exercise price of options is based on the initial price paid by the shareholders for their shares in JV Newco. As the awards granted under the plan are equity-settled share-based payment awards, the grant date fair value is recognised as an expense over the vesting period with a corresponding increase in equity. The liabilities with respect to acquisitions (earn-out obligations) are estimated on the basis of the expected future results of the respective companies (performance-related criteria). The majority of earn-out obligations are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. Earn-out obligations are calculated using management’s best estimate of the expected future cash flows and using the applicable historical interest rate including a mark-up reflecting the risks of the market in which JV Newco operates. Discount rates used vary around 10%. The main liabilities relate to the companies acquired in the UK. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. Valuation models used are in level 3 in the three-tier hierarchy. In a number of business combinations, the company granted the seller/non-controlling shareholder a put option to sell in the future (part of) the remaining shares to the company. These put options are regarded as a financial liability in the company’s consolidated financial statements. The majority of put options are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the consideration to be paid upon exercise of the options. Discount rates used vary between 5% and 10.0%. Put option liabilities primarily relate to the companies acquired in North America and United Kingdom. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecast EBITDA, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. As the majority of the put options is payable within the coming year or are near the end of the option period, changes in EBITDA or discount rate will not have a material impact on the value of put option liabilities as per balance sheet date. Valuation models used are in level 3 in the three-tier hierarchy. Risk management and control procedures are integrated in the operation of the business. This includes monitoring of progress in the company’s areas for improvement, through the introduction of an effective structure for the maintenance and evaluation of internal controls. The aim of risk management within JV Newco is to provide reasonable assurance that JV Newco understands the risks associated with achieving its business objectives, and that JV Newco is responding appropriately to these risks at all levels within the organisation. This will be achieved by ensuring that the following five action points are carried out at all times: - risks are properly identified, managed and reported; - ownership is taken for risks and communicated to others; - resources are effectively and efficiently allocated to manage risks; - risks that could significantly affect employees, Endemol Shine, suppliers or clients are suitably managed; and - Endemol Shine is compliant with regulatory and legal requirements. To which category of IFRS 9 a financial instrument belongs has been indicated in Note 2 ‘Significant accounting policies’. For the Company relevant classes of financial instruments have been indicated in the respective disclosure notes to the items included in the ‘Consolidated statement of financial positions’.

The primary objective of JV Newco is to ensure that it maintains healthy capital ratios in order to support its business and maximise shareholder value. JV Newco manages its capital structure, and makes adjustments to it, in light of changes in economic conditions. The primary objective of JV Newco is to ensure that it maintains healthy capital ratios in order to support its business and maximise shareholder value. JV Newco manages its capital structure and makes adjustments to it, in light of changes in economic conditions.

JV Newco’s activities expose it to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including foreign currency risk and interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. JV Newco’s overall risk management programme focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on JV Newco’s financial performance. Derivative financial instruments can be used to hedge exposure to fluctuations in interest rates. Risk management is carried out by a central treasury department under policies approved by the JV Newco Management Board. Treasury identifies, evaluates, mitigates and transfers/hedges financial risks. The Management Board provides written principles for overall risk management, as well as written policies covering specific areas, such as foreign exchange risk, interest rate risk, credit risk, use of derivative financial instruments, and investment of excess liquidity. Policies for each of these risks are summarised below. F-245 ----- JV Newco’s activities expose it to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including foreign currency risk and interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. JV Newco’s overall risk management programme focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on JV Newco’s financial performance. Derivative financial instruments can be used to hedge exposure to fluctuations in interest rates. Risk management is carried out by a central treasury department under policies approved by the JV Newco Management Board. Treasury identifies, evaluates, mitigates and transfers/hedges financial risks. The Management Board provides written principles for overall risk management, as well as written policies covering specific areas, such as foreign exchange risk, interest rate risk, credit risk, use of derivative financial instruments, and investment of excess liquidity. Policies for each of these risks are summarised below.

JV Newco assesses foreign currency risk by identifying and monitoring changes in exchange rate exposures that may adversely impact the income statement, cash flow and equity. JV Newco maintains risk management control systems to monitor foreign currency risk attributable to both outstanding foreign currency positions and commitments, as well as offsetting hedge positions. The risk management control systems involve the centralisation of JV Newco’s foreign currency exposure management, the netting and offsetting exposures from different group companies and the use of analytical techniques, including sensitivity analysis, to estimate the expected impact of changes in foreign currency rates. JV Newco group companies enter into transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the group company concerned. Significant transactions and operations in foreign currency, that could materially impact JV Newco’s statement of financial position and profit and loss, occur mainly in USD and GBP. These transactions expose JV Newco to foreign currency results. By means of natural hedging as well as foreign currency forward contracts JV Newco minimises exchange results on receivables, payables and expected future cash-flows denominated in currencies other than the functional currency. Financial derivatives can be used to economically hedge the net exchange results due to changes in foreign currency rates. Effective 8 January 2015, the Company entered into a EUR 350.0 million for USD 412 million Cross Currency Swap (CCS), at spot rate USD/EUR 1.177. The CCS partly offsets the mismatch between the currency mix of the external loans and borrowings and the currency mix of EBITDA and cash flow and in addition converts the company’s floating interest obligation in respect of 60% of the principal amount of the EUR-denominated loans to a fixed rate. Changes in the fair value of foreign currency forward contracts are reported in the income statement as fair value adjustments on derivative financial instruments and (partially) offset the exchange results recognised as foreign exchange results on the assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies. It is JV Newco’s policy to settle foreign currency forward contracts within the reporting period. The following table demonstrates the sensitivity to a reasonably possible change in the US dollar and British pound exchange rate, with all variables held constant, of JV Newco’s equity and result before tax. The calculations are based on current year’s results and year end positions in USD and GBP. Subsection Title: Effect on result before tax** **Effect on equity

Subsubsection Text: JV Newco trades only with recognised, creditworthy third parties. It is JV Newco’s policy that all customers who wish to trade on credit terms are subject to credit verification procedures. In addition, receivable balances are monitored on an on-going basis with the result that JV Newco’s exposure to bad debts is not significant. The maximum exposure is the carrying amount as disclosed in Note 14 ‘Trade and other receivables’. JV Newco’s objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of bank overdrafts, bank loans, securitisation facilities, factoring and the revolving credit facilities. JV Newco monitors its risk of shortage of funds using a recurring Cash flow management tool. The Cash flow management tool includes robust forecasts, weekly actual cash flow reporting and variance analysis reporting to the Management Board, continuous identification and problem solving, monitoring and delivery of cash generation and preservation initiatives. Due to the applied accounting policies the Consolidated statement of financial position includes certain financial liabilities for which the carrying amount is different from the expected related future cash flows. Subsection Title: Interest rate risk / interest rate swaps

Subsection Title: Core Media Group—petition for relief under Chapter 11 US bankruptcy code
Subsubsection Text: On 28 April 2016, CORE Entertainment, Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries (the “CORE Debtors”) filed voluntary petitions for relief under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”). On 23 September 2016, the Bankruptcy Court confirmed (i.e., approved) the bankruptcy plan proposed by the CORE Debtors. The plan provides for a significant de-leveraging of the CORE Debtors pursuant to which, among other things, holders of equity interests in the CORE Debtors (including CORE Entertainment Holdings’ equity interest in CORE Entertainment, Inc.) did not receive any distribution on account thereof. Under the CORE Debtors’ bankruptcy plan, unsecured creditors are entitled to share pro rata in a distribution of cash (up to USD 2,375,000 in the aggregate and not to exceed 10% of its unsecured claim) and certain residual rights in respect of actions brought against parties not released from claims under the plan. On December 12, 2016, a litigation trust (the “Litigation Trust”) that was created in connection with the bankruptcy of CORE Media, Inc. and several of its affiliates (collectively, “Core”) filed a lawsuit in the State Courts in California in the United States, against certain Apollo companies, 21CF companies and JV Newco entities. As part of the Core’s plan of reorganization, the Litigation Trust was assigned the legal claims previously belonging to various entities which loaned money to Core. In 2017, the court in California ruled in favour of a motion filed by the Company to stay the Core Litigation in California to force it to be refiled in New York. Accordingly, later in 2017, the Litigation Trust filed a new lawsuit in the State Courts in New York. The complaint alleges that the defendants, including the Company, intentionally interfered with loan agreements reached between Core and its lenders. The lawsuit also claims that certain defendants, including AP NMT JV Newco B.V. but not including the Company, are liable for Core’s breach of its loan agreements by virtue of the alter ego doctrine and/or the de facto merger doctrine. Litigation Trust is seeking both compensatory and punitive damage in an undetermined amount against each of the 21 defendants it has named in the litigation, including MediArena Holding B.V., Reveille, LLC, AP NMT JV Newco B.V., Endemol USA, Inc., and Endemol USA Holding, Inc. The Company has indicated that it intends to vigorously defend its rights. The Company and each of the Endemol Shine entities named in the lawsuit have filed a Motion to Dismiss the lawsuit. Those Motions were argued in May 2018 and are awaiting decision. A new Judge has been appointed and the motion may need to be heard again. Based on management’s current consideration of the facts and circumstances, no provision has been recorded. On April 27, 2018, the Litigation Trust filed two lawsuits in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”), both of which identified certain JV Newco entities as defendants. The first lawsuit in the Bankruptcy Court names as defendants certain Apollo entities and individuals, Core Entertainment Holdings, Inc., and AP NMT JV Newco B.V. That lawsuit makes claims against various entities for breach of fiduciary duties, aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duties, and fraudulent transfer. On August 23, 2018, the Litigation Trust filed a Notice of Dismissal which voluntarily dismissed AP NMT JV Newco B.V. from this lawsuit without prejudice. The case remains ongoing against the remaining defendants, none of which are JV Newco entities. The second lawsuit in the Bankruptcy Court names Endemol USA Holding, Inc. and Endemol USA, Inc. as defendants. The complaint sought to avoid the transfer of international distribution rights to The Wall to Endemol and brought claims for actual and constructive fraudulent transfer. The Litigation Trust seeks compensatory damages in an unspecified amount. Defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss on July 13, 2018. The F-249 ----- Court granted that Motion on November 13, 2018, but granted the Litigation Trust thirty days to amend its complaint. The Litigation Trust filed an Amended Complaint on December 13, 2018, asserting causes of action for conversion, breach of fiduciary duty, breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, unjust enrichment, and imposition of a constructive trust. Defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss on January 25, 2019, and briefing related to that Motion is ongoing. The JV Newco entities named in the lawsuit have indicated that they intend to vigorously defend their rights. Motions were argued in May, 2018 and are awaiting decision.

In 2017 the Company was refocusing its regional strategy in some markets, including Turkey. As part of that refocus, the decision was made to unwind the operations in Turkey and to liquidate the local operating company in Turkey because of the situation set out below. In May 2017 group management of Endemol Shine discovered serious issues around the local management of Endemol Shine Turkey. Group management has undertaken a comprehensive analysis of the business in Istanbul which included an investigation by a local law firm and assistance and advice from independent financial consultants. These investigations revealed EUR 18.2 million of local project-related write-downs and EUR 2.2 million of other local expenses which are all included in the exceptional items. Group management concluded, following the investigation by the law firm, that local management in Turkey did not comply with governance requirements and while every effort was made to find an alternative solution, the only viable option was to file for insolvency of Endemol Shine Turkey. The first hearing in the bankruptcy process took place in 2017 and several hearings have been held since. As of the end of 2017 Audit Administrators were appointed to review and approve all envisaged payments by Endemol Shine Turkey and this panel of Administrators was converted by the court during the hearing of 7 June 2018 to a panel of so-called Management Administrators. The Management Administrators are authorised the represent the company with regard to urgent and financial matters. The Court and the appointed Administrators have made decisions on disbursement of distribution income from exploitation of titles owned by Endemol Shine Turkey, which will reduce outstanding liabilities over time. Financial experts were appointed during the hearing that took place in February 2018 to consider the bankruptcy imminently. The most recent hearing in the bankruptcy process was on 18 July 2019 and the next hearing is scheduled to take place on 5 December 2019. In 2017 the Company was refocusing its regional strategy in some markets, including Turkey. As part of that refocus, the decision was made to unwind the operations in Turkey and to liquidate the local operating company in Turkey because of the situation set out below. In May 2017 group management discovered serious issues around the local management of Endemol Shine Turkey. Group management has undertaken a comprehensive analysis of the business in Istanbul which included an investigation by a local law firm and assistance and advice from independent financial consultants. These investigations revealed EUR 18.2 million of local project-related write-downs and EUR 2.2 million of other local expenses which are all included in the exceptional items of 2017 (EUR 9.4 million) and 2016 (EUR 11.0 million). Group management concluded, following the investigation by the law firm, that local management in Turkey did not comply with governance requirements and while every effort was made to find an alternative solution, the only viable option was to file for insolvency of Endemol Shine Turkey. The first hearing in the bankruptcy process took place last year and at the end of last year Audit Administrators were appointed to approve all payments made by Endemol Shine Turkey. The Court has made decisions on disbursement of distribution income from exploitation of titles owned by Endemol Shine Turkey, which will reduce outstanding liabilities over time. The most recent hearing in the bankruptcy process was on 25 January 2018. We expect that financial experts will be appointed to consider the bankruptcy imminently. Following the decision to liquidate, further asset impairments (goodwill and other intangible assets), amounting to EUR 5.6 million, have been recorded in the 2017 Consolidated statement of comprehensive income under ‘Impairment loss’.

Subsection Title: 28 Related parties and transactions with related parties (Ultimate) parent company
Subsubsection Text: AP NMT JV Newco B.V. is a limited liability company incorporated in The Netherlands (“JV Newco”). JV Newco is jointly owned by an affiliate of Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”) and funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”), with each owning 50%. As further discussed below in Note 29 (Subsequent Events), The Walt Disney Company has acquired the majority of Fox’s entertainment and international assets including the 50% shareholding in the Endemol Shine Group.

Subsection Title: Notes to the company financial statements 1** **General
Subsubsection Text: The company financial statements of AP NMT JV Newco B.V. (the “Company”) and the consolidated financial statements together constitute the statutory financial statements of the Company. AP NMT JV Newco B.V. is registered at the Chamber of Commerce under number 61823147. The company financial statements are presented in Euro, the Company’s functional and reporting currency, rounded to the nearest thousand. The Company is jointly owned by an affiliate of Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”) and funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”), with each owning 50%. As discussed in Note 29 (Subsequent Events), The Walt Disney Company has acquired the majority of Fox’s entertainment and international assets including the 50% shareholding in the Endemol Shine Group.

The company financial statements have been prepared in accordance with Part 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The Company uses the option of Section 362.8 of Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code, which means that that the principles for the recognition and measurement of assets and liabilities and determination of the result in the company financial statements are the same as the principles applied in the consolidated financial statements. Those principles are described in note 2 to the consolidated financial statements. The Company has applied RJ uiting 2017/7 with regards to the exemption on use of expected credit loss on standalone accounts for intercompany balances.

Investments in subsidiaries are valued at equity value, but not lower than nil. This equity value is based on the same accounting principles as applied by the Company in the consolidated financial statements. Investments in subsidiaries with a negative equity value are valued at nil. If the Company fully or partly guarantees the liabilities of the subsidiaries concerned, or has the effective obligation respectively, to enable the subsidiaries to pay its (share of the) liabilities, a provision is formed. Upon determining this provision, provisions for doubtful debts already deducted from receivables from the subsidiaries are taken into account. Investments in subsidiaries are valued at equity value, but not lower than nil. This equity value is based on the same accounting principles as applied by the Company in the consolidated financial statements. Investments in subsidiaries with a negative equity value are valued at nil. If the Company fully or partly guarantees the liabilities of the subsidiaries concerned, or has the effective obligation respectively, to enable the subsidiaries to pay its (share of the) liabilities, a provision is formed. Upon determining this provision, provisions for doubtful debts already deducted from receivables from the subsidiaries are taken into account.

Financial fixed assets consist of investments in subsidiaries. Movements in shareholders’ equity are disclosed in the consolidated statement of changes in equity on a consolidated and a company-only basis. Legal reserves for the purposes of the Company’s shareholders’ equity are the same as the reserves disclosed in the consolidated statement of changes in equity and Note 17 ‘Equity’ to the consolidated financial statements. Until derecognition of CORE Media Group per 17 October 2016 as explained in Note 3 ‘Acquisitions and divestments’ to the consolidated financial statements, the difference between the equity according to the company accounts and the consolidated accounts was explained by the fact that the subsidiary CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc, as included in the consolidation, had a negative net asset value but was valuated in the company balance sheet at zero. AP NMT JV Newco B.V. has not issued a declaration of liability or guarantee for these companies.

AP NMT JV Newco B.V. was incorporated on 5 November 2014 with an authorised and issued share capital of EUR 1 consisting of 1 ordinary share with a nominal value of EUR 1. After incorporation shareholders made contributions in kind against 14,878,309 issued shares with a nominal value of EUR 1. All shares are fully paid (in cash or other consideration). Fully paid ordinary shares carry one vote per share and carry a right to dividends. Subsection Title: Other information Allocation of results as laid down in the articles of association Article 21
Subsubsection Text: The general meeting is authorized to appropriate the profits which have been determined by adopting the annual accounts, and to determine distributions, to the extent the equity of the company exceeds the reserves which must be maintained under Dutch law. A resolution to make a distribution has no effect until the management board has granted approval for such resolution. The management board shall refuse this approval only if it knows or should reasonably foresee that the company will be unable to continue to pay its short-term debts after the distribution. In calculating each distribution, the shares held by the company in its own capital shall be disregarded. In calculating the amount that will be distributed on each share, only the amount of the mandatory payment on the nominal amount of the shares is eligible. Deviation from the preceding sentence is possible with the consent of all shareholders. The right to receive a distribution shall expire five years from the day on which such a distribution became payable. No dividends were declared in 2018.
Subsequent events are disclosed in Note 29 of the consolidated financial statements.
