Subsection Title: Notes to the consolidated financial statements 1** **General information 1.1 Company overview
Subsubsection Text: AP NMT JV Newco B.V. (“the Company” or “JV Newco”) owns (a) all of the ordinary shares in the capital of MediArena Holding B.V. (together with its subsidiaries, “Endemol Shine”) and (b) substantially all of the common stock of CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. (until 17 October 2016 together with its subsidiaries “CORE Media”). Endemol Shine is a global creator, producer and distributor of multiplatform entertainment. Endemol Shine incorporates creative operations with a diverse portfolio of formats across scripted and non-scripted genres; coupled with digital, gaming, and distribution operations. With companies in 28 territories worldwide, Endemol Shine is positioned to benefit from the scale of an international company, whilst having local presence and focus relevant for clients and audiences, including local broadcasters. Other than its ownership of such equity securities and control of such subsidiaries, JV Newco conducts no other business operations. The Company is a limited liability company incorporated in the Netherlands. AP NMT Coöperatief U.A., an affiliate of funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”), owns 50% of the issued and outstanding shares of the Company. 21CF Empire Holdco Coöperatief U.A., an affiliate of Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”), owns the remaining 50% of the issued and outstanding shares of the Company. The address of the Company’s registered office is MediArena 1, 1114 BC Amsterdam-Duivendrecht, the Netherlands.

Subsection Title: Non-scripted programmes comprise reality TV entertainment, game shows and talent shows in which the
Subsubsection Text: main events within the programme are not pre-determined by writers and producers but are the result of actual events happening during the show.

Subsection Title: Scripted programmes are programmes such as drama, comedy and soap operas for which writers
Subsubsection Text: pre-determine the script and structure.

Subsection Title: Other genres mainly comprise sports programmes, online digital video and commercial revenues. 2** **Significant accounting policies 2.1 Basis of preparation of the consolidated financial statements Statement of compliance
Subsubsection Text: These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (“IFRS”) as adopted by the European Union (“EU-IFRS”) and in accordance with Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code. The consolidated financial statements and the company financial statements together constitute the statutory financial statements of the Company. The financial statements have been prepared by the Management Board of the Company and have been authorised for issue on 22 May 2018. The accounting policies set out below have been applied consistently by Group entities and in the consolidated financial statements.

Subsection Title: Goodwill and other non-current assets with infinite lives
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and other intangible assets with infinite lives are tested for impairment annually, or more frequently when there is an indication for impairment. For impairment testing, goodwill is allocated to the smallest identifiable cash-generating unit. A cash-generating unit is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets. An impairment loss is recognised for the amount by which the asset’s carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less cost to sell and its value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value, using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset. An impairment loss is recognised in the income statement and allocated first to reduce the carrying amount of the goodwill and then to the other assets of the cash generating unit pro-rata on the basis of the carrying amount of each asset in the unit. An impairment loss recognised for goodwill is not reversed in subsequent years. Except for goodwill, JV Newco assesses in subsequent years whether indications exist that impairment losses previously recognised for non-current assets may no longer exist or may have decreased. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of that asset (or cash generating unit) is recalculated and its carrying amount is increased to the revised recoverable amount. The increase is recognised in the income F-288 ----- statement. A reversal is recognised only if it arises from a change in the assumptions used to calculate the recoverable amount. An impairment loss is reversed to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortisation, if no impairment loss had been recognised.

Trade receivables are initially recognised at fair value, and subsequently carried at amortised cost, which is usually the nominal value, less impairment losses. Allowances for bad debts are recorded when there is objective evidence that collection of the receivable is no longer probable. Productions in progress represents the gross unbilled amount expected to be collected from customers for production work performed to date. It is measured at costs incurred plus profits recognised to date less progress billings, advances received and recognised losses. Productions in progress are presented as part of trade receivables in the statement of financial position for all productions in which costs incurred plus recognised profits exceed progress billings, advances received from customers and recognised losses. For all productions where progress billings, advances received from customers and recognised losses exceed costs incurred plus recognised profits, the balance is presented as productions in progress as part of trade and other payables.

Cash and cash equivalents include all cash on hand balances, short-term highly liquid cash investments and time deposits with original maturities of three months or less. Cash and cash equivalents are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently at amortised cost, which is usually the nominal value. Positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with one bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously.

In many of JV Newco’s business areas it participates in pension and similar plans for its employees. A defined contribution plan is a post-employment benefit plan under which JV Newco pays fixed contributions into a separate entity and has no legal or constructive obligation to pay further amounts. Obligations for contributions to defined contribution plans are expensed as the related service is provided. Prepaid contributions are recognised as an asset to the extent that a cash refund or a reduction in future payments is available. A defined benefit plan is a post-employment benefit plan other than a defined contribution plan. JV Newco’s net obligation in respect of defined benefit plans is calculated separately for each plan by estimating the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in the current and prior periods, discounting that amount and deducting the fair value of any plan assets. The calculation of defined benefit obligations is performed annually by a qualified actuary using the projected unit credit method. When the calculation results in a potential asset for JV Newco, the recognised asset is limited to the present value of economic benefits available in the form of any future refunds from the plan or reductions in future contributions to the plan. To calculate the present value of economic benefits, consideration is given to any applicable minimum funding requirements. Re-measurements of the net defined benefit liability, which comprise actuarial gains and losses, the return on plan assets (excluding interest) and the effect of the asset ceiling (if any, excluding interest), are recognised immediately in other comprehensive income. JV Newco determines the net interest expense F-289 ----- (income) on the net defined benefit liability (asset) for the period by applying the discount rate used to measure the defined benefit obligation at the beginning of the annual period to the then-net defined benefit liability (asset), taking into account any changes in the net defined benefit liability (asset) during the period as a result of contributions and benefit payments. Net interest expense and other expenses related to defined benefit plans are recognised in profit or loss. When the benefits of a plan are changed or when a plan is curtailed, the resulting change in benefit that relates to past service or the gain or loss on curtailment is recognised immediately in profit or loss. JV Newco recognises gains and losses on the settlement of a defined benefit plan when the settlement occurs. For other long-term employee benefits, such as long-term service benefits, the net obligation is the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods. That benefit is discounted to determine its present value. Re-measurements are recognised in profit or loss in the period in which they arise. Termination benefits are expensed at the earlier of when JV Newco can no longer withdraw the offer of those benefits and when JV Newco recognises costs for a restructuring. If benefits are not expected to be settled wholly within 12 months of the end of the reporting period, then they are discounted.

In general, a provision is recognised in the statement of financial position when: - there is a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of a past event; - it is probable that an outflow of economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation; and - a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. If the effect is material, provisions are determined by discounting the expected future cash flows at a pre-tax discount rate, that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and, where appropriate, the risks specific to the liability. Recoveries from third parties, which are likely to be realised, are recorded separately, and are not offset against the related liability. A provision for restructuring is recognised when: - there is an approved detailed and formal restructuring plan; and - the restructuring has either commenced or has been announced publicly. A provision for onerous contracts is recognised when the expected benefits to be derived from a contract are lower than the unavoidable cost of meeting its obligations under the contract and when such provision can be reasonably estimated.

Interest-bearing borrowings are recognised initially at fair value less directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, interest-bearing borrowings are stated at amortised cost with any difference between cost and redemption value being recognised in profit or loss over the period of the borrowings based on the effective interest method.

When part of the purchase price consideration of a business combination depends on future results, an earn-out obligation is initially calculated at fair value. The calculation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario (performance-related criteria). Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation.

A put option liability is calculated in case JV Newco granted a minority shareholder an option to sell to JV Newco its remaining interest. F-290 ----- Put option liabilities are re-measured to fair value at least annually based on the expected future results of the respective company, or earlier when indicators warrant recalculation. This is considered to be an obligation as JV Newco acquires its own equity, even if the exercise is contingent and conditional, when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to JV Newco, as such no non-controlling interest is recognised. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. To the extent dividend payments to minority shareholders reduce the redemption amount, they are recognised against the put option liability. Otherwise dividend payments to minority shareholders are recognised as financial expense in profit or loss upon profit distribution.

If the outcome of a production contract can be estimated reliably, revenue associated with the production are recognised by reference to the stage of completion. This is the case when: - persuasive evidence of the sale of a production with the customer exists; - the amount of revenue can be measured reliably; - it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the production will flow to the entity; - the stage of completion of the production at the end of the reporting period can be measured reliably; and - the production costs incurred and the costs to complete the production can be measured reliably. The stage of completion is ordinarily determined with reference to either: - the proportion of finished episodes (to date) to total episodes to be produced under the contract (measurement of stage of completion may be done on the basis of delivery if this is a better measurement); or - the proportion of production days spent (to date) to total production days expected to be made under the contract (mainly applicable for scripted productions like telenovela’s and movies) If the outcome of a production contract cannot be estimated reliably, revenue is recognised only to the extent it is probable that expenses incurred are recoverable. Contract costs are recognised in profit or loss as incurred unless they create an asset related to future contract activity. An expected loss on a contract is recognised in profit or loss immediately. Production revenue includes the initial amount agreed in the contract plus any variations in production work, claims and incentive payments, to the extent that it is probable that these will result in revenue and they can be measured reliably. If JV Newco acts as an agent rather than as a principal under a production agreement, no revenue is recognised, except to the extent commissions are earned.

Subsection Title: Distribution – finished program sales and sale of licensing rights
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from the sale of finished programs and licensing rights on intellectual property formats is recognised when it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the sale will flow to Endemol Shine and the amount of revenue can be estimated reliably. Any such revenues shall be recognised on an accrual basis, and only to the extent there is no continuing involvement. Revenues cannot be recognised until the start of the broadcasting/ license period. When there is continuing involvement of JV Newco, revenue is recognised over the term of the contract.

JV Newco recognises government grants initially as deferred income at fair value if there is reasonable assurance that they will be received and JV Newco will comply with the conditions associated with the grant. Subsequently, grants are then recognised in profit or loss as other income on a systematic basis over the useful life of the asset. Grants that compensate JV Newco for expenses incurred are recognised in profit or loss on a systematic basis in the periods in which the expenses are recognised.

For equity-settled share-based payment awards granted to employees, the grant-date fair value is generally recognised as an expense, with a corresponding increase in equity, over the vesting period of the awards. The amount recognised as an expense is adjusted to reflect the number of awards for which the related service and non-market performance conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognised is based on the number of awards that meet the related service and non-market performance conditions at the vesting date. For share-based payment awards with market or non-vesting conditions, the grant-date fair value of the share-based payment is measured to reflect such conditions and there is no true-up for differences between expected and actual outcomes. For cash-settled share-based payments, a liability is recognised for the goods or services acquired, measured initially at the fair value of the liability. The services received from employees are recognised as an expense over the vesting period of the awards, with recognition of a corresponding liability. At the end of each reporting period until the liability is settled, and at the date of settlement, the fair value of the liability is re-measured, with any changes in fair value recognised in profit or loss.

JV Newco uses the EBITDA heading in the income statement. Endemol Shine defines EBITDA as profit for the period before depreciation, amortisation, impairment, financial income, financial expense, share in profit of associates and income tax. EBITDA is not a measurement under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to (a) net profit, (b) cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities, or as a measure of our ability to meet cash needs, or (c) any other measures or performance under IFRS. EBITDA is not a direct measure of our liquidity, which is shown by JV Newco’s cash flow statement and should be considered in the context of our financial commitments. EBITDA may not be indicative of our historical operating results, and may not be predictive of our potential future results. Because not all companies calculate EBITDA identically, the presentation of EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly named measures of other companies. To enhance the insight into the financial results of the Company’s activities, the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income shows EBITDA before (operating) exceptional items. Exceptional items are excluded from management’s assessment of results because by their size, nature or incidence they could distort the Company’s underlying quality of earnings. Such items are disclosed on the face of the consolidated income statement and separately in the notes to the financial statements. They are typically gains or losses arising from events that are not considered part of the core operations of the business (e.g. costs relating to capital transactions, such as professional fees on acquisitions, one-off restructuring costs, shareholder management fees, earn-out and put option related remuneration expense, LTIP expenses and gains and or losses on disposal of assets). These items are excluded to reflect performance in a consistent manner and are in line with how the business is managed and measured on a day-to-day basis. F-292 -----

Finance income primarily comprises interest income on funds invested, fair value gains on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, gains on the re-measurement to fair value of any pre-existing interest in an acquiree in a business combination, gains on hedging instruments that are recognised in profit or loss and reclassifications of net gains previously recognised in other comprehensive income. Interest income and expense is recognised as it accrues in profit or loss, using the effective interest method. Finance costs comprise interest expense on borrowings, unwinding of the discount on provisions and deferred consideration, fair value losses on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss and contingent consideration, impairment losses recognised on financial assets (other than trade receivables), losses on hedging instruments that are recognised in profit or loss and reclassifications of net losses previously recognised in other comprehensive income. Borrowing costs that are not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognised in profit or loss using the effective interest method. Foreign currency gains and losses on financial assets and financial liabilities are reported on a net basis as either finance income or finance cost depending on whether foreign currency movements are in a net gain or net loss position.

The current tax payable is based on taxable profit for the period and includes adjustments to tax payable or receivable in respect of prior periods. Taxable profit differs from profit as reported in the income statement because of items of income or expense that are taxable or deductible in other periods and items that are never taxable or deductible. JV Newco’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period.

JV Newco initially recognises loans and receivables and deposits on the date that they are originated at fair value. Subsequent measurement is at amortised cost. All other financial assets are recognised initially on the trade date at which JV Newco becomes a party to the contractual provisions of the instrument. JV Newco derecognises a financial asset when the contractual rights to the cash flows from the asset expire, or it transfers the rights to receive the contractual cash flows on the financial asset in a transaction in which substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the financial asset are transferred. Any interest in transferred financial assets that is created or retained by JV Newco is recognised as a separate asset or liability. Financial assets and liabilities are offset and the net amount presented in the statement of financial position when, and only when, JV Newco has a legal right to offset the amounts and intends either to settle on a net basis or to realise the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. Non-derivative financial assets include held-to-maturity financial assets (debt securities), loans and receivables (including cash and cash equivalents, and trade and other receivables) and available for sale financial assets (equity securities and debt securities).

JV Newco initially recognises debt securities issued and subordinated liabilities on the date that they are originated. All other financial liabilities are recognised initially on the trade date, which is the date that the Group becomes a party to the contractual provisions of the instrument. JV Newco derecognises a financial liability when its contractual obligations are discharged, cancelled or expired. JV Newco classifies non-derivative financial liabilities into the other financial liabilities category. Such financial liabilities are recognised initially at fair value less any directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, these financial liabilities are measured at amortised cost using the effective interest method except for earn out obligations which are measured at fair value. Other financial liabilities comprise loans and borrowings, debt securities issued (including certain preference shares), bank overdrafts, and trade and other payables.

Subsection Title: Derivative financial instruments and hedging activities
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco uses derivative financial instruments principally in the management of its foreign currency and interest rate risks. JV Newco measures all derivative financial instruments based on fair values, derived from market prices or a valuation model. Derivatives are initially recognised at fair value on the date a derivative contract is entered into and are subsequently remeasured at their fair value at each reporting date. The method of recognising the resulting gain or loss depends on whether the derivative is designated as a hedging instrument, and if so, the nature of the item being hedged. JV Newco designates certain derivatives as hedges of a particular risk associated with a recognised asset or liability or a highly probable forecast transaction (cash flow hedge). JV Newco F-294 ----- documents at the inception of the transaction the relationship between hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategy for undertaking various hedging transactions. JV Newco also documents its assessment, both at hedge inception and on an ongoing basis, of whether the derivatives that are used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in fair values or cash flows of hedged items. The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivatives that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedges is recognised in equity. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognised immediately in the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. Amounts accumulated in equity are recycled in the income statement in the periods when the hedged item affects profit or loss. The gain or loss relating to the effective portion of interest rate swaps hedging variable rate borrowings is recognised in the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognised in the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. However, when the forecast transaction that is hedged results in the recognition of a non-financial asset the gains and losses previously deferred in equity are transferred from equity and included in the initial measurement of the cost of the asset. When a hedging instrument expires, or is sold, or when a hedge no longer meets the criteria for hedge accounting, any cumulative gain or loss existing in equity at that time remains in equity and is recognised when the forecast transaction is ultimately recognised in the income statement. In 2017 and 2016, no hedge accounting has been applied. When a forecast transaction is no longer expected to occur, the cumulative gain or loss that was reported in equity is immediately transferred to the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. If JV Newco does not designate a derivative as hedge of a particular risk associated with a recognised asset or liability or a highly probable forecast transaction (cash flow hedge), movements in the fair value of the instrument are recognised in the income statement.

Subsection Title: Call and put options relating to acquisition contracts
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco has entered into various call and put options in connection with some of its acquisitions. Call options are valued at fair value and recognised in the statement of financial position when the option exercise price is lower than the underlying fair value of the potential future investee. Granted put options to joint venture partners and shareholders of entities where JV Newco does not have control are valued at fair value and recognised when the option exercise price is higher than the underlying fair value of the entity involved. The fair value of the options is re-measured at each reporting date. All changes in fair values are accounted for in the income statement, as financial income or expense.

Subsection Title: 2.25 Preparation of the statement of cash flows
Subsubsection Text: The statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method. Changes in balance sheet items that have not resulted in cash flows (e.g. translation differences, financial leases, fair value changes, conversions of debt to equity) have been eliminated for the purpose of preparing this statement. Dividends received are included in investing activities, whereas dividends paid to ordinary shareholders, interest received and interest paid are included in financing activities. For the purposes of the cash flow statement, bank overdrafts that are an integral part of JV Newco’s cash management are included as a component of cash and cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at the bank (both debit and credit) and (call) deposits. Starting 2017 JV Newco excludes the change in the drawn First Lien Revolving Credit Facility from the cash balances and presents the change as part of the financing activities (Proceeds from loans and borrowings).

Subsection Title: 2.26 New, revised and amended standards and interpretations not yet applied
Subsubsection Text: The following new, revised and amended IFRSs (not yet adopted by the European Union) may be relevant to Endemol Shine, and are not yet applied by JV Newco: IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers (effective 2018) IFRS 9 (Revised) Financial instruments (effective 2018) IFRS 16 Leases (effective 2019) IFRIC 22 Foreign Currency Transactions and Advance Consideration (effective 2018) F-295 ----- IFRS 15 – The new standard is based on the principle that revenue is recognised when control of a good or service transfers to the customer, so the notion of control replaces the existing notion of risks and rewards. A new five step approach must be applied before revenue can be recognised: - Identify contracts with customers; - Identify the separate performance obligations; - Determine the transaction price of the contract; - Allocate the transaction price to each of the separate performance obligations; and - Recognise the revenue as each performance obligation is satisfied. The effects of applying the new standard on the Company’s financial statements has been assessed. An impact has been identified for the revenue recognition of contracts with customers containing a performance obligation to produce content. Revenue will be recognised when control has been transferred to the customer. Revenue from production services will be recognised over time based on clearly stated milestones, being milestones as stated in the contract with the customer or delivery of an episode rather than a variance of milestones. The Company has not identified revenue recognition changes from revenue of other income categories. The Company identified contracts with a revenue amounting to EUR 47 million and EBITDA of EUR 8 million in 2017 that will phase into 2018. The Company expects a similar effect from 2018 to 2019. As a result, the impact on the 2018 EBITDA is expected to be limited. IFRS 15 will be applied for the first time in the financial year 2018. The Company intends to adopt the standard using the modified retrospective approach, which means that the cumulative impact of the adoption will be recognised in retained earnings as of 1 January 2018 and that comparatives will not be restated. IFRS 9 – The final version of IFRS 9 contains revised regulations for the classifications and measurement of financial assets, new requirements for impairment of financial instruments and new requirements for hedge accounting. The Company performed a high level assessment of the impact of IFRS 9 in comparison with IAS 39. Considering the nature of the financial instruments the Company currently holds (under assets and liabilities), we expect no significant change to current valuations used (at amortized cost or at fair value). The Company does not hold financial assets that require measurement at fair value with changes in fair value to be recorded through other comprehensive income under IFRS 9. The required accounting of expected credit losses (ECL) on financial assets under IFRS 9 mainly pertains to trade receivables and contract assets as per IFRS 15. The Company intends to implement a simplified approach as permitted under IFRS 9 to calculate the lifetime ECL of these financial assets from initial recognition onwards. The provision matrix will be based on the Company’s historical default rates, adjusted for forward looking estimates. IFRS 9 will be applied for the first time in the financial year 2018. The impact on the allowance for impairment losses per 1 January 2018 has been calculated at EUR 1.8 million (increase). The Company intends to adopt the standard using the modified retrospective approach, which means that the cumulative impact of the adoption will be recognised in retained earnings as of 1 January 2018 and that comparatives will not be restated. IFRS 16 – The new standard sets out principles for recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure requirements for leases. The changes mainly affect lessee accounting and generally require lessees to recognize contractual rights and obligations on the lessee’s balance sheet. The standard replaces the straightline recognition of operating lease expense for those leases applying IAS 17 with the recognition of depreciation expenses for the right-of-use asset and interest expenses on the lease liability (included within the financial result). In addition, IFRS 16 includes more extensive disclosures in the notes for lessees. The new standard will have a significant impact on the financial statements of the Company. As at the reporting date, the Company has non-cancellable operating lease commitments of EUR 148.5 million, see note 27. The Company estimates that less than 10% of these relate to payments for short-term and low value leases which will be recognised on a straight-line basis as an expense in profit or loss. However, the Company has not yet assessed what other adjustments, if any, are necessary for example because of the change in the definition of the lease term and the different treatment of variable lease payments and of extension and termination options. It is therefore not yet possible to estimate the amount of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities that will have to be recognised on adoption of the new standard and how this may affect the group’s profit or loss and classification of cash flows going forward. F-296 ----- Examples of leases where the new standard will have an impact are leases for the rental of buildings and studio’s. The standard will be applied for the first time in the financial year 2019. An assessment of the impact on the financial statements of the Company will be made in 2018. IFRIC 22 – The interpretation clarifies how to determine the date of transaction for the exchange rate to be used on initial recognition of a related asset, expense or income where an entity pays or receives consideration in advance for foreign currency-denominated contracts. For a single payment or receipt, the date of the transaction should be the date on which the entity initially recognises the non-monetary asset or liability arising from the advance consideration (the prepayment or deferred income/contract liability). If there are multiple payments or receipts for one item, a date of transaction should be determined as above for each payment or receipt. Entities can choose to apply the interpretation: - retrospectively for each period presented; - prospectively to items in scope that are initially recognised on or after the beginning of the reporting period in which the interpretation is first applied, or; - prospectively from the beginning of a prior reporting period presented as comparative information. The Company intends to apply the second option.

In 2017, the Company did not acquire stakes in companies that have been accounted for as business combinations. Per 14 February 2017 the Company acquired 100% of No Doubt Productions Inc in the United States of America. No Doubt Productions Inc. owns post production equipment facilities. This transaction has been accounted for as purchase of assets.

In 2016, the Company acquired a stake in a number of companies complementary to our business strategy. The Company acquired 51% of Wild Mercury Limited in the United Kingdom. Wild Mercury is a scripted production company. Per 19 October 2016 51% of Human Factor B.V. was acquired by the Netherlands, resulting in a 100% ownership in Human Factor B.V. This acquisition is treated as a step acquisition. The condensed balance sheets of all acquisitions, immediately before and after the acquisition is as follows:

Subsection Title: Accounting for business combinations Fair value assets and liabilities acquired

Subsubsection Text: Other intangible assets . . . . . . . . . — — **— Property, plant and equipment . . . 111 — **111 Current assets and liabilities . . . . 191 — **191 Cash . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 198 — **198 Minority interest . . . . . . . . . . . . . — — **—

Fair value approximates the carrying amounts acquired. No intangible assets have been identified. The total consideration amounted to EUR 0.6 million paid in cash. Acquisition related costs that were recognized in other operating expense amounted to EUR 0.8 million. Goodwill amounts to EUR 0.6 million, being the total consideration of EUR 0.6 million plus fair value of the 49% previously owned EUR 0.5 million of minority interests minus the fair value of the acquired assets and liabilities of EUR 0.5 million. A gain has been recognized on remeasuring the equity interest held before acquisition to fair value of EUR 0.1 million. The goodwill is mainly related to the creative potential within the acquired companies. The goodwill is not tax deductible. F-297 ----- After acquisition, the acquired companies contributed revenues of EUR 0.4 million to the 2016 income statement of the Company. Revenue before acquisition date amounts to EUR 0.9 million. Cash and cash equivalents acquired in business combinations amounted to EUR 0.2 million.

On 28 April 2016, CORE Entertainment, Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries (the “CORE Debtors”) filed voluntary petitions for relief under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”). On 23 September 2016, the Bankruptcy Court confirmed (i.e., approved) the bankruptcy plan proposed by the CORE Debtors. The plan provided for a significant de-leveraging of the CORE Debtors pursuant to which, among other things, holders of equity interests in the CORE Debtors (including CORE Entertainment Holdings’ equity interest in CORE Entertainment, Inc.) did not receive any distribution on account thereof. As such, JV Newco’s indirect equity interest in CORE Media Group was cancelled for no consideration. Under the CORE Debtors’ bankruptcy plan, unsecured creditors were entitled to share pro rata in a distribution of cash (up to USD 2,375,000 in the aggregate and not to exceed 10% of its unsecured claim) and certain residual rights in respect of actions brought against parties not released from claims under the plan. As a legal matter, JV Newco remained the controlling stockholder of CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. with the authority to appoint a majority of the board of directors. However, upon the CORE Debtors’ emergence from bankruptcy on 17 October 2016, CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc.’s shares in CORE Entertainment Inc. were cancelled such that CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. no longer owns CORE Entertainment Inc. or any of its subsidiaries nor has the right to manage CORE’s business. This resulted in a loss of control over CORE’s business and triggered an immediate deconsolidation from the consolidated balance sheet of JV Newco per date of loss of control. Since CORE’s business was a separate cash generating unit within JV Newco’s operations, the disposal of CORE Media Group has been accounted for and presented as discontinued operations.

Subsection Title: Financial performance and cash flow information of discontinued operations
Subsubsection Text: The financial performance and cash flow information presented are for the period 1 January – 16 October 2016. Subsection Title: 11** **Goodwill and other intangible assets Movement Schedule 2017
Subsubsection Text: EUR 1,000_ **Goodwill

During the financial period 2017, the Company assessed the recoverable amount of goodwill and other intangible assets, based on a detailed forecast per CGU taking into account various downside adjustments to the detailed business plans. This level 3 assessment leads to the conclusion that an impairment was required for an amount of EUR (18.6) million, for the CGU France. An additional impairment charge was incurred for the CGU Rest of World in the amount of EUR (5.8) million, EUR (5.2) million including FX. An impairment charge of EUR (24.4) million has been reported in the statement of comprehensive income. Impairment CGU France is mainly driven by lower performance in the year and lower forward projections in especially the non-scripted business. In Rest of the World, JV Newco is refocusing its regional strategy in some markets. As part of that refocus, the decision was made to unwind the operations in Turkey and to liquidate the local operating company in Turkey. Goodwill of the cash generating units has been tested for impairment at year-end 2017 based on the latest short- and long-term business forecasts. The recoverable amounts of the cash generating units have been determined based on a fair value less cost of disposal approach. To determine the fair value less cost of disposal, cash flow projections are based on financial budgets and forward-looking statements, approved by senior management, for the underlying operations of a cash generating unit. These projections include estimates for the cost savings that have been realized and are to be realized from several cost savings initiatives. F-306 ----- By their nature, forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties as they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. Accordingly, actual results of operations, financial condition and liquidity may differ from those assumed in the forward-looking statements. The key assumptions used for the fair value less cost of disposal calculations relate to discount rate and terminal value growth rate, revenue growth and EBITDA margin. The post-tax discount rates, applied to the cash flow projections, vary between 6.6% and 11.5%. These rates have been calculated using the weighted average cost of capital methodology. The main parameters are the targeted debt-to-equity ratio, the risk-free interest rate based on government bonds and a risk premium. The terminal value growth rate is based on the lower of i) the risk-free rate for all Euro denominated CGU’s or the risk free rate plus inflation differential for other CGU’s, and ii) the estimated local long-term inflation expectation. The revenue growth rates and EBITDA margins used to estimate future performance are based on past performance and our expectations for growth rates and EBITDA margins achievable in the markets the Company is active in. Consolidated for the Company the average annual compounded revenue growth rate applied in the projected periods is 2.4%. The average annual compounded revenue growth rate applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 1.1% and 6.9%. Consolidated for the Company the terminal value year EBITDA margin applied is 9.65%. The terminal value year EBITDA margins applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 6.4% and 24.2%. Consolidated for the Company the terminal value growth rate applied is 1.04%. The terminal value growth rate applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 0.6% and 1.4%. In addition to the forecast used in the impairment test, a sensitivity analysis has been prepared. In the scenario of using a 50 bps higher discount rate, this would lead to recognizing a total impairment charge of EUR (58) million, of which EUR (28) million would relate to the CGU France and EUR (30) million would relate to the CGU International & Distribution. A 5% lower terminal value EBITDA level would lead to recognizing a total impairment of EUR (44) million, of which EUR (25) million would relate to the CGU France and EUR (19) million would relate to the CGU International & Distribution. The following table illustrates for the CGUs with limited headroom the sensitivity to changes in the terminal value EBITDA which would result in a recoverable amount equal to the carrying amount and the headroom based on current projections:

Subsubsection Text: Positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with one bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. Notional cash pools form an integral part of JV Newco’s cash management. Based on the above JV Newco is required to report the cash balances and the bank overdrafts on a gross basis. Bank overdrafts as included in current part of Loans and borrowings (‘Other bank debt’) is EUR (132.2) million (2016: EUR (113.1) million) of which EUR (106.8) million (2016: EUR (86.4 million) relates to the cash pool effect. All cash is at the free disposal of JV Newco, except for trapped cash in the amount of EUR 25.8 million (2016: EUR 37.5 million). Trapped cash consists amongst others of trust account cash, country restricted cash, cash at jointly controlled ventures and cash backed bank guarantees.

Subsection Title: Adjustment to comparative numbers 2016 of shareholders’ equity
Subsubsection Text: Until the date of loss of control over CORE Media (17 October 2016), the consolidated balance sheet carried a different amount of shareholders’ equity than the company balance sheet, originating from the contribution of CORE Media by shareholder Apollo on 12 December 2014, and was reflected in share premium. Since deconsolidation of CORE Media from the consolidated balance sheet of JV Newco, there is no difference between total shareholders’ equity on the consolidated balance sheet and total shareholders’ equity on the company balance sheet. In the comparative numbers of equity per 31 December 2016 on the consolidated balance sheet, an adjustment of EUR 164,522 has been made between ‘Share premium’ and Accumulated deficit’ to reconcile the equity on the consolidated balance sheet with the split on the company balance sheet.

The non-controlling interest “(NCI”) consists of the third-party ownership share in a number of JV Newco’s consolidated subsidiaries, as well as the minority share recognized upon the Endemol and Shine acquisition transaction in 2014. The full goodwill method was applied to the transaction and the related NCI accounts for around 80% of the total NCI. An amount of EUR 31.2 million of the total minority interest pertains to the goodwill and other intangible assets recognized upon the Endemol and Shine acquisition transaction in 2014 (2016: EUR 34.7 million). Subsection Title: First and second lien loans and borrowings
Subsubsection Text: On 13 August 2014, MediArena Acquisition B.V. (formerly known as AP NMT Acquisition B.V.), as borrower, MediArena Newco B.V. (formerly AP NMT Newco B.V.), the borrower’s direct parent company, and certain financial institutions entered into a First Lien Credit Agreement and a Second Lien Credit Agreement. On 12 December 2014, to finance the Shine transaction, MediArena Acquisition B.V. also entered into an Incremental Assumption Agreement. Together providing for: - a EUR 125 million First Lien multi-currency revolving credit facility (“RCF”), which also facilitates a letter of credit sub-facility and a EUR 30 million swing line loan sub-facility. On 22 December 2017, the maturity date of the RCF was extended to 13 August 2020 (previously 13 August 2019). As per 31 December 2017, total drawings under the RCF amounting to EUR 60.0 million were outstanding (2016: EUR 80.0 million); - a First Lien Term Loan B facility maturing on 13 August 2021, comprised of a USD 885 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans, a EUR 235 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans and a GBP 50 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans; and - a USD 457 million Second Lien Term Loan B facility maturing on 13 August 2022. On 22 April 2015, MediArena Acquisition B.V. entered into an Incremental Assumption Agreement providing for: - an additional USD 25 million First Lien Term Loan B loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, which also matures on 13 August 2021; and - an additional EUR 25 million First Lien Term Loan B loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, which also matures on 13 August 2021. The loans incurred on 12 December 2014 and 22 April 2015 have the same terms as the loans of the same currency incurred under the First Lien Credit Agreement on 13 August 2014. In addition, the Group may request one or more incremental term loan facilities and/or increase commitments under its First Lien Credit Agreement and request one or more incremental term loan facilities under its Second Lien Agreement in an aggregate amount of up to the sum of EUR 100 million plus such additional amount as long as, (i) in the case of loans under additional credit facilities that rank equally to the liens on the collateral securing the Term B Loans and the Initial Revolving Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, its consolidated net first lien leverage ratio would be no greater than 3.40 to 1.00 and (ii) in the case of loans under additional credit facilities that rank junior to the liens on the collateral securing the Term B Loans and the Initial Revolving Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement and equally and without preference with, or junior to, the liens on the collateral securing the Term Loans under the Second Lien Credit Agreement, its consolidated net secured leverage ratio would be no greater than 5.20 to 1.00, subject to certain conditions and receipt of commitments by existing or additional lenders. All borrowings under the Group’s revolving credit facility under the First Lien Credit Agreement are subject to the satisfaction of customary conditions, including the absence of a default and the accuracy of representations and warranties. Prior to the maturity date of 13 August 2021, the First Lien Term B Loans require scheduled quarterly amortization payments in an amount equal to 0.25% of the original principal amount of the term loans, the first payment of which was due on 31 December 2014, with the balance due at maturity. In 2017, amortization payments of EUR 11.1 million were made (2016: EUR 11.5 million). Amortization payments due in 2018 amount to EUR 10.7 million. Within the context of the financing agreements, guarantees and securities have been provided by several of Endemol Shine’s entities established in the Security Jurisdictions (United States, England and Wales, the Netherlands, Germany, France, Spain and Australia) and guarantees have been provided by certain Endemol Shine Group entities established in Italy, Norway, Sweden and Denmark. Borrowings of term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement and Second Lien Credit Agreement at a base rate equal to the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) are subject to a 1.00% floor. The First Lien Credit Agreement includes customary mandatory prepayment requirements based on certain events, such as asset sales, certain debt issuances and defined levels of excess cash flow. The Second Lien Credit Agreement includes customary mandatory prepayment requirements based on certain events, such as asset sales and certain debt issuances. F-315 ----- The Company may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement at any time, without prepayment premium or penalty and subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to LIBOR rate loans. The Company may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the Second Lien Credit Agreement at any time. All prepayments will be subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to LIBOR loans. Initially the revolving credit facility under the First Lien Credit Agreement included a springing financial maintenance covenant that required the consolidated net first lien leverage ratio not to exceed 5.50 to 1.00. The covenant would be tested quarterly when the revolving credit facility was more than 30% drawn (excluding outstanding letters of credit other than letters of credit supporting debt for borrowed money). As of 31 December 2016, the borrowings under the revolving credit facility were more than 30% of the outstanding commitments; therefore, the covenant was in effect. The amendment of the Revolving Facility requires that the covenant be tested quarterly at any time if as of such time any revolving facility loans, swingline loans or letters of credit are outstanding. With respect to the Revolving Facility only, the covenant requires the consolidated net first lien leverage ratio not to exceed 5.50 to 1.00; provided that, solely to the extent that certain financial covenant stepdown conditions are not satisfied at any time when the revolver may be drawn, the net first lien leverage ratio shall be reduced from a ratio equal to 5.50 to 1.00 to a ratio equal to 3.00 to 1.00. As of 31 December 2017, borrowings were made under the revolving credit facility; therefore, the covenant was in effect. The First Lien Credit Agreement and Second Lien Credit Agreement also contain customary affirmative covenants and events of default, and the negative covenants limit the Group’s ability to, among other things: incur additional debt or issue certain preferred shares; create liens on assets; make certain loans or investments (including acquisitions); pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of its capital stock or make other restricted payments; consolidate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of its assets; enter into certain transactions with its affiliates; enter into sale-leaseback transactions; change its lines of business; restrict dividends from its subsidiaries or restrict liens; change its fiscal year; and modify the terms of certain debt or organizational agreements.

Subsection Title: Loans and borrowings CORE Media Group First and second lien loans and borrowings
Subsubsection Text: On 9 December 2011, CORE Media Group and certain financial institutions entered into a First Lien Term Loan and a Second Lien Term Loan (collectively: the ‘Term Loans’). The First Lien Term had an aggregate principal amount of USD 200 million. The Second Lien Term Loan had an aggregate principal amount of USD 160 million. Per 17 October 2016 JV Newco lost control over the CORE Media activities subject to a financial restructuring as described in Note 3 and JV Newco derecognized all assets and liabilities pertaining to the CORE Media Group. The First Lien Term was scheduled to mature on 21 June 2017 and bore interest at a rate of 9.0% per annum or 11% per annum when in default. The First Lien Term Loan was collatarized by a first priority security interest in the material assets of CORE Media Group and its guarantor subsidiaries with a number of exclusions, the most significant of which were cash and contracts that could not be assigned. On the date of derecognition of the liability (17 October 2017), interest accrued under the First Lien including Default Rate interest was USD 8.5 million (31 December 2015: USD 1.2 million). The Second Lien Term Loan was scheduled to mature on 18 June 2018 and bore interest at a rate of 13.5% per annum or 15.5% per annum when in default. The Second Lien Term Loan was collatarized by a second priority security interest in the same assets as the First Lien Term Loan. On the date of derecognition of the liability (17 October 2017), interest accrued under the Second Lien including Default Rate interest was USD 28.8 million (31 December 2015: USD 19.6 million).

Subsection Title: Total employee benefit obligations . . . . . .** **12,288** **5,924 Post-employment benefits
Subsubsection Text: Except for the Dutch group companies, all of JV Newco’s employees are covered by several defined contribution plans. In the Netherlands, Endemol participates in a defined benefit plan for nearly all employees in the Netherlands at Stichting Bedrijfstakpensioenfonds voor de Media PNO (“PNO Media”). This plan is a multi-employer defined benefit pension plan, which is accounted for as a defined contribution plan because sufficient information for defined benefit accounting is not available. PNO Media is a multiemployer pension fund and PNO Media is not able to provide Endemol with sufficient information on the present value of the benefit obligations, the fair value of plan assets and the funded status of Endemol. As of 31 December 2017, PNO Media had a coverage ratio of 102.0% (2016: 91.3%), which is below the required ratio by De Nederlandsche Bank (DNB) of 122.0%. In March 2017 PNO Media submitted its latest updated of a recovery plan at the Dutch National Bank, including the measures to be taken in order to get the coverage ratio at the required level within the next 10 years. As long as the actual coverage ratio is below the required coverage ratio, the recovery plan will be updated by PNO Media annually. In Italy, employees are covered by a severance plan (post-employment benefit plan) provided for in accordance with local legislation. Severance pay is considered normal remuneration that has been deferred and approximates one month’s pay for each year of service, valued each year on a basis linked to cost-of-living indices. The severance liability as of 31 December 2017 of EUR 0.7 million (2016: EUR 0.3 million), represents the accumulated amount due to employees upon termination based on service to date. F-318 ----- In other countries, the total unfunded retirement indemnity for employees is provided for, amounting to EUR 0.1 million as of 31 December 2017 (2016: EUR 0.3 million).

Subsection Title: Other employee benefits: employee incentive plans
Subsubsection Text: In a previous year JV Newco introduced within Endemol Shine certain long-term incentive plans (“LTIPs”) targeted at incentivizing the Group’s most senior executives. For the key executives within certain local operations a local LTIP was introduced running for a 4 to 5-year period. All bonus payments under the LTIPs (if any) will be made in cash. The LTIPs are aimed to align the interests of the stakeholders with the participating executives by virtue of sharing part of the value created of the relevant Group entities. The value creation is predominantly driven by a growth in applicable earnings measured over the relevant LTIP period. If there is no or limited growth of earnings over the LTIP period, the LTIPs are not in the money. The LTIP plans provide for an advance payment of 30% of the estimated total cash bonus payable at the end of the LTIP period (if any) to each participant in the course of 3rd year of the 5-year plan period. The remainder (if any) will be paid upon settlement of the LTIPs. For the local LTIPs effective at 31 December 2017, the total cash bonus payments over the LTIP period are capped at EUR 75 million (2016: capped at EUR 77 million). In 2018 new LTIP-arrangements will become effective, triggering settlement in 2018 of some of the LTIPobligations as accrued per 31 December 2017 under the initial LTIP-arrangements (included in current part). The LTIPs are in substance considered profit-sharing arrangements and are accounted for as an employee benefit in accordance with IAS 19. The expenses in connection with such plans are attributed to the period in which the services that give rise to the obligation are rendered. In terms of the LTIP, the Company only accounts for LTIP expenses in any given period if it is management’s best estimate as of the end of that period that the plan will be “in the money” and the bonus payable can be estimated reliably. The “in the money” assessment is primarily made with reference to whether or not a certain targeted earnings measure has been achieved during the respective financial period.

The fair value at grant date of the service based vesting tranche is independently determined using the Black Scholes Model. The weighted average fair value at grant date 2016 in relation to the options granted before 2016 was USD 13.45 per option. The fair value at grant date of the Performance based vesting tranches are independently determined using a Monte Carlo simulation model that takes into account the exercise price, the term of the option, the share price at grant date and expected price volatility of the underlying share, the risk free interest rate for the term of the option and the correlations and volatilities of the peer group companies. For the option valuation of options granted during the year 2016, the main assumptions are: - grant date varying between January and October 2016 - expected option life: 5 years - share price at grant date: USD 46 - exercise price at grant date: USD 100 - expected share price volatility of the company’s shares: 29.5% - risk-free interest rate: 1.3% (5 year US government bond) - expected dividends: 0% For the option valuation of options granted during the year 2015 main assumptions are: - grant date: 9 March 2015 - expected option life: 5 years - share price at grant date: USD 100 - exercise price at grant date: USD 100 - expected share price volatility of the company’s shares: 27.4% - risk-free interest rate: 1.65% (5 year US government bond) - expected dividends: 0% F-320 ----- As part of the Group long-term incentive plan, Restricted Stock Option Units (“RSU’s”) have been granted in the course of 2016. The liabilities with respect to acquisitions (earn-out obligations) are estimated on the basis of the expected future results of the respective companies (performance-related criteria). The majority of earn-out obligations are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. Earn-out obligations are calculated using management’s best estimate of the expected future cash flows and using the applicable historical interest rate including a mark-up reflecting the risks of the market in which JV Newco operates. Discount rates used vary around 10%. The main liabilities relate to the companies acquired in the UK. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. Valuation models used are in level 3 in the three-tier hierarchy. In a number of business combinations, JV Newco granted the seller/non-controlling shareholder a put option to sell in the future (part of) the remaining shares to JV Newco. These put options are regarded as a financial liability in JV Newco’s consolidated financial statements. The majority of put options are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the consideration to be paid upon exercise of the options. Discount rates used vary between 5% and 10.0%. Put option liabilities primarily relate to the companies acquired in France, North America and United Kingdom. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecast EBITDA, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. As the majority of the put options is payable within the coming year or are near the end of the option period, changes in EBITDA or discount rate will not have a material impact on the value of put option liabilities as per balance sheet date. Valuation models used are in level 3 in the three-tier hierarchy. Risk management and control procedures are integrated in the operation of the business. This includes monitoring of progress in our areas for improvement, through the introduction of an effective structure for the maintenance and evaluation of internal controls. The aim of risk management within JV Newco is to provide reasonable assurance that JV Newco understands the risks associated with achieving its business objectives, and that JV Newco is responding appropriately to these risks at all levels within the organisation. This will be achieved by ensuring that the following five action points are carried out at all times: - risks are properly identified, managed and reported; - ownership is taken for risks and communicated to others; - resources are effectively and efficiently allocated to manage risks; - risks that could significantly affect employees, Endemol Shine, suppliers or clients are suitably managed; and - Endemol Shine is compliant with regulatory and legal requirements. To which category of IAS39 a financial instrument belongs has been indicated in Note 2 ‘Significant accounting policies’. For the Company relevant classes of financial instruments have been indicated in the respective disclosure notes to the items included in the ‘Consolidated statement of financial positions’.

Subsection Title: Core Media Group - petition for relief under Chapter 11 US bankruptcy code
Subsubsection Text: On 28 April 2016, CORE Entertainment, Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries (the “CORE Debtors”) filed voluntary petitions for relief under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”). On 23 September 2016, the Bankruptcy Court confirmed (i.e., approved) the bankruptcy plan proposed by the CORE Debtors. The F-327 ----- plan provides for a significant de-leveraging of the CORE Debtors pursuant to which, among other things, holders of equity interests in the CORE Debtors (including CORE Entertainment Holdings’ equity interest in CORE Entertainment, Inc.) did not receive any distribution on account thereof. Under the CORE Debtors’ bankruptcy plan, unsecured creditors are entitled to share pro rata in a distribution of cash (up to USD 2,375,000 in the aggregate and not to exceed 10% of its unsecured claim) and certain residual rights in respect of actions brought against parties not released from claims under the plan. On December 12, 2016, a litigation trust (the “Litigation Trust”) that was created in connection with the bankruptcy of CORE Media, Inc. and several of its affiliates (collectively, “Core”) filed a lawsuit in the State Courts in California in the United States, against certain Apollo companies, 21CF companies and JV Newco entities. As part of the Core’s plan of reorganization, the Litigation Trust was assigned the legal claims previously belonging to various entities which loaned money to Core. In 2017, the court in California ruled in favour of a motion filed by the Company to stay the Core Litigation in California to force it to be refiled in New York. Accordingly, later in 2017, the Litigation Trust filed a new lawsuit in the State Courts in New York. The complaint alleges that the defendants, including the Company, intentionally interfered with loan agreements reached between Core and its lenders. The lawsuit also claims that certain defendants, including AP NMT JV Newco B.V., are liable for Core’s breach of its loan agreements by virtue of the alter ego doctrine and/or the de facto merger doctrine. Litigation Trust is seeking both compensatory and punitive damage in an undetermined amount against each of the 21 defendants it has named in the litigation, including MediArena Holding B.V., Reveille, LLC, AP NMT JV Newco B.V., Endemol USA, Inc., and Endemol USA Holding, Inc. The Company has indicated that it intends to vigorously defend its rights. The Company and each of the JV Newco entities named in the lawsuit have filed a Motions to Dismiss the lawsuit, which are currently pending. Based on management’s current consideration of the facts and circumstances, no provision has been recorded.

Subsection Title: Notes to the company financial statements 1 General
Subsubsection Text: The company financial statements of AP NMT JV Newco B.V. (the “Company”) and the consolidated financial statements together constitute the statutory financial statements of the Company. AP NMT JV Newco B.V. is registered at the Chamber of Commerce under number 61823147. The company financial statements are presented in Euro, the Company’s functional and reporting currency, rounded to the nearest thousand. The Company is jointly owned by an affiliate of Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”) and funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”), with each owning 50%.

Subsection Title: 2 Significant accounting policies Basis of preparation
Subsubsection Text: The company financial statements have been prepared in accordance with Part 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The Company uses the option of Section 362.8 of Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code, which means that that the principles for the recognition and measurement of assets and liabilities and determination of the result in the company financial statements are the same as the principles applied in the consolidated financial statements. Those principles are described in note 2 to the consolidated financial statements.

Financial fixed assets consist of investments in subsidiaries. Movements in shareholders’ equity are disclosed in separate statements of changes in equity on a consolidated and a company-only basis. Legal reserves for the purposes of the Company’s shareholders’ equity are the same as the reserves disclosed in the consolidated statement of changes in equity and Note 17 ‘Equity’ to the consolidated financial statements. Until derecognition of CORE Media Group per 17 October 2016 as explained in Note 3 ‘Acquisitions and divestments’ to the consolidated financial statements, the difference between the equity according to the company accounts and the consolidated accounts was explained by the fact that the subsidiary CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc, as included in the consolidation, had a negative net asset value but was valuated in the company balance sheet at zero. AP NMT JV Newco B.V. has not issued a declaration of liability or guarantee for these companies.

Subsection Title: Allocation of results as laid down in the articles of association Article 21
Subsubsection Text: The general meeting is authorized to appropriate the profits which have been determined by adopting the annual accounts, and to determine distributions, to the extent the equity of the company exceeds the reserves which must be maintained under Dutch law. A resolution to make a distribution has no effect until the management board has granted approval for such resolution. The management board shall refuse this approval only if it knows or should reasonably foresee that the company will be unable to continue to pay its short-term debts after the distribution. In calculating each distribution, the shares held by the company in its own capital shall be disregarded. In calculating the amount that will be distributed on each share, only the amount of the mandatory payment on the nominal amount of the shares is eligible. Deviation from the preceding sentence is possible with the consent of all shareholders. The right to receive a distribution shall expire five years from the day on which such a distribution became payable. No dividends were declared in 2017. F-343 -----
As of 31 December 2017 and 31 December 2016 the Company had no outstanding guarantees.

The average number of employees of AP NMT JV Newco B.V. during 2017 amounted to zero (2016: zero). The remuneration of the Company’s Management Board for 2017 amounted to EUR nil (2016: nil). The Company does not have any Supervisory Directors. The Company has not provided loans, guarantees or advances to members of the Company’s Management Board.
The Company and its Dutch subsidiaries are part of a Dutch fiscal unity headed by AP NMT JV Newco B.V. Within the Dutch fiscal unity profits and losses of the group companies are offset.
Subsequent events are disclosed in Note 29 of the consolidated financial statements.
