Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Notes to the consolidated financial statements 1 General information 1.1 Company overview
Subsubsection Text: AP NMT JV Newco B.V. (“the Company” or “JV Newco”) owns (a) all of the ordinary shares in the capital of MediArena Holding B.V. (together with its subsidiaries, “Endemol Shine”) and (b) substantially all of the common stock of CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. (until 17 October 2016 together with its subsidiaries “CORE Media”). Endemol Shine is a global creator, producer and distributor of multiplatform entertainment. Endemol Shine incorporates creative operations with a diverse portfolio of formats across scripted and non-scripted genres; coupled with digital, gaming, and distribution operations. With companies in 28 territories worldwide, Endemol Shine is positioned to benefit from the scale of an international company, whilst having local presence and focus relevant for clients and audiences, including local broadcasters. Other than its ownership of such equity securities and control of such subsidiaries, JV Newco conducts no other business operations. The Company is a limited liability company incorporated in the Netherlands. AP NMT Coöperatief U.A., an affiliate of funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”), owns 50% of the issued and outstanding shares of the Company. 21CF Empire Holdco Coöperatief U.A., an affiliate of Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”), owns the remaining 50% of the issued and outstanding shares of the Company. The address of the Company’s registered office is MediArena 1, 1114 BC Amsterdam-Duivendrecht, the Netherlands.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The content the Company creates comprises non-scripted, scripted and other genres:

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Non-scripted programmes comprise reality TV entertainment, game shows and talent shows in which the main
Subsubsection Text: events within the programme are not pre-determined by writers and producers but are the result of actual events happening during the show.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Scripted programmes are programmes such as drama, comedy and soap operas for which writers pre-determine
Subsubsection Text: the script and structure.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Other genres mainly comprise sports programmes, online digital video and commercial revenues. 2 Significant accounting policies 2.1 Basis of preparation of the consolidated financial statements Statement of compliance
Subsubsection Text: These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (“IFRS”) as adopted by the European Union (“EU-IFRS”) and in accordance with Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code. The consolidated financial statements and the company financial statements together constitute the statutory financial statements of the Company. The financial statements have been prepared by the Management Board of the Company and have been authorised for issue on 4 January 2018. The accounting policies set out below have been applied consistently by Group entities and in the consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Historical cost is used as the measurement basis, except for acquisitions through business combinations, derivative financial instruments, earn-out obligations and put option liabilities which are measured at fair value. Policies for the measurement of fair values are discussed in section 2.5. F-357 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements are presented in Euro, the Company’s functional and reporting currency, rounded to the nearest thousand.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: New and amended standards adopted by the group
Subsubsection Text: The Company has applied the following standards and amendments for the first time for their annual reporting period commencing 1 January 2016: – Accounting for acquisitions of interests in joint operations – Amendments to IFRS 11 – Clarification of acceptable methods of depreciation and amortisation - Amendments to IAS 16 and IAS 38 – Annual improvements to IFRSs 2012 – 2014 cycle, and – Disclosure initiative – amendments to IAS 1. IAS 38 Intangible Assets now includes a rebuttable presumption that the amortisation of intangible assets based on revenue is inappropriate. The Company amortises intangible assets using a declining balance method based on the expected consumption of economic benefits from these assets. Therefore, the amendment of IAS 38 has no impact on the amortisation method of the Company’s intangible assets. The adoption of these amendments did not have an impact on the current period or prior period and is not likely to affect future periods. Note 2.26 discloses the impact of new, revised and amended standards and interpretations not yet applied.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 2.2 Critical accounting judgements, assumptions and estimation uncertainties
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the consolidated financial statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, and income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgements about carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognised in the period in which the estimate is revised, if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future periods, if the revision affects both current and future periods. The consolidated financial statements have been prepared on the basis that the Company is able to continue as a going concern.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Information about judgements made in applying accounting policies that have the most significant effect on the amounts recognised in the consolidated financial statements is included in the following notes: – Business combinations (Note 2.6) – The long-term loans are valued at amortised cost. The long-term loan agreements include specific early redemption clauses. As part of the initial measurement of the amortised costs value of the loans it is assumed that the loans will be held to maturity. If an early redemption of all or part of the loans is expected, the liability will be re-measured based on the original effective interest rate. The difference between the liability, excluding a change in assumed early redemption and the liability, including a change in assumed early redemption, will go through profit and loss (Note 2.15) – Earn-out obligations and put option liabilities, evaluation of contract conditions (Note 2.16 and 2.17) – Financial instruments (Note 2.24) F-358 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Information about assumptions and estimation uncertainties made in applying accounting policies that have a significant risk of resulting in a material adjustment in the consolidated financial statements in the subsequent financial year is included in the following notes: – Revenue, determination of the stage of completion (Note 2.18) – Contributions at the formation of the joint venture, measured at book values as previously carried by the contributing shareholder (Note 2.6) – Intangible assets acquired in a business combination, determination of fair values (Note 2.6) – Intangible assets estimated remaining useful lives are reviewed annually. The carrying values of intangible assets are also reviewed for impairment where there has been a triggering event by assessing the present value of estimated future cash flows and net realisable value compared with net book value. The calculation of estimated future cash flows and residual values is based on the Company’s best estimate of future prices, output and costs and is, therefore, subjective (Note 2.8) – Impairment of non-current assets, key assumptions underlying recoverable amounts (Note 2.10) – Other long-term employee benefits, estimating amounts payable for incentive plans (Note 2.13) – Earn-out liabilities, estimating fair value of consideration payable (Note 2.16) – Put option liabilities, estimating fair value of consideration payable (Note 2.17) – Income taxes, recognition of deferred tax assets (Note 2.23)

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries. In accordance with section 402, Part 9 Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, the income statement in the Company financial statements is presented in condensed form.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the Company, which is the case when the Company is exposed to, or has rights to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the ability to affect those returns through its controlling influence over the entity. In assessing control, potential voting rights that presently are exercisable or convertible are taken into account. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are included in the consolidated financial statements from the date that control commences until the date that control ceases.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Non-controlling interests are measured at fair value. Changes in the Company’s interest in subsidiaries that do not result in a loss of control are accounted for as equity transactions.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: When the Company loses control over a subsidiary, it derecognises the assets and liabilities of the subsidiary, and any non-controlling interests and other components of equity. Any resulting gain or loss is recognised in profit or loss. Any interest retained in the former subsidiary is measured at fair value when control is lost. If the operational activities of derecognized subsidiaries form a separate major line of business and cash generating unit, they constitute discontinued operations as identified in IFRS 5. Results from discontinued operations from the current year and the comparative previous year are shown as a one-line item on the consolidated statement of comprehensive income, with a breakdown in disclosure Note 3 Acquisitions and divestments.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealised gains and losses or income and expenses arising from intra-group transactions, are eliminated. F-359 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Transactions in foreign currencies are translated to the respective functional currencies of JV Newco entities at exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate at the reporting date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognised in profit or loss. Non-monetary items that are measured based on historical cost in a foreign currency are not translated at the reporting date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair value are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate when the fair value was determined.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on acquisition, are translated into Euro at exchange rates at the reporting date. Income and expenses of foreign operations are translated into Euro at exchange rates prevailing at transaction date. The resulting foreign currency differences are recognised in the translation reserve as part of equity, except to the extent that the translation difference is allocated to non-controlling interests. When a foreign operation is disposed of and control, significant influence or joint control is lost, the cumulative amount in the translation reserve related to that foreign operation is recycled to profit or loss as part of the gain or loss on disposal. If the Company disposes of only part of its interest in a subsidiary but retains control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is reclassified to non-controlling interests. When the Company disposes of only part of an associate or joint venture, while retaining significant influence or joint control, then the relevant proportion of the cumulative amount is recycled to profit or loss.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: A number of JV Newco’s accounting policies and disclosures require the measurement of fair values, for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities. JV Newco uses market observable data (to the extent practically possible) when measuring the fair value of an asset or a liability. Fair values are categorised into different fair value hierarchy levels based on the inputs used in the valuation techniques as follows: – Level 1: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities; – Level 2: inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (i.e. as prices) or indirectly (i.e. derived from prices); and – Level 3: inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs). If the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset or a liability might be categorised in different levels of the fair value hierarchy, then the fair value measurement is categorised in its entirety in the same level of the fair value hierarchy as the lowest level input that is significant to the entire measurement. JV Newco recognises transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy at the end of the reporting period during which the change has occurred. Further information about the assumptions made in measuring fair values is included in the following notes: – Acquisitions (Note 3); – Goodwill and other intangibles assets (Note 11); – Earn-out obligations (Note 22); – Put option liabilities (Note 23); and – Financial instruments (Note 26). F-360 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The contributions at formation of the joint-venture have been measured at the book values as previously carried by the contributing shareholder. At their initial recognition, some of the book values carried by the previous shareholder were subject to conversion from local accounting principles as applied by the contributing shareholder to IFRS as applied by JV Newco. Recognized book value carrying amounts for goodwill and non-current assets are based on the fair value accounting applied at initial acquisition by the venturers prior to their contributions to JV Newco. Contributed book values of goodwill and non-current assets have been allocated to cash-generating units as identified within the joint operations of JV Newco. After formation of the joint venture JV Newco accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when control is transferred to JV Newco. The consideration transferred in the acquisition is generally measured at fair value, as are the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities at the date of acquisition. Goodwill is the difference between the consideration transferred and the fair value of net assets acquired, and represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognised. Any gain on a bargain purchase (negative goodwill) is recognised in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs are expensed as incurred, except if related to the issue of debt or equity securities. Goodwill on acquisition of associates/joint ventures is included in investments in associates/joint ventures. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognised in profit or loss. Adjustments to the fair value of the consideration transferred and the provisional fair values of identifiable assets and liabilities in a business combination, identified within 12 months of the date of acquisition, are recognised retrospectively, provided that the new information relates to conditions that existed at the date of acquisition. In case the consideration transferred consists of (an) initial cash payment(s) and estimated future earn-out obligation based on (or related to) estimates of future results, any such obligations are only recognised as consideration if payments are not depending on future employment of the seller. An adjustment in the earn-out obligation recognised as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. As part of a business combination, JV Newco can grant an option to non-controlling interests (e.g. a minority shareholder), to sell to JV Newco (part of) their remaining interest in the business acquired. If such a put option provides for settlement in cash, any such obligations are only recognised as consideration if payments are not dependent on future employment of the seller. JV Newco treats such a transaction as if the put option has been exercised at acquisition date (the so-called ‘anticipated-acquisition method’) when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to JV Newco. Accordingly no non-controlling interest is recognised. An adjustment in the put option liability recognised as consideration is accounted for in profit or loss. When a business combination is achieved in stages, the carrying value of the previously held equity interest is remeasured to fair value at acquisition date and the difference is recognised in profit or loss. If share-based payment awards (e.g. replacement awards) are required to be exchanged for awards held by the acquiree’s employees (acquiree’s awards) and relate to past services, then all or a portion of the amount of the acquirer’s replacement awards is included in measuring the consideration transferred in the business combination. This determination is based on the market-based value of the replacement awards compared with the market-based value of the acquiree’s awards and the extent to which the replacement awards relate to pre-combination service.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Determining the fair value of intangible assets arising on acquisition requires judgment. Management makes estimates regarding the timing and amount of future cash flows derived from exploiting the assets being acquired. Management then estimates an appropriate discount rate to apply to the forecast cash flows. Such estimates are based on current budgets and forecasts, extrapolated for an appropriate period taking into account growth rates, expected changes in selling prices, operating costs and the expected useful lives of the assets. Management estimates the appropriate discount rate using pre-tax rates that reflect current market assessments of the time of money and the risks specific to the assets or business being acquired. F-361 ----- The fair value of intangible assets acquired in a business combination is determined as follows: – Format library, (TV) movie rights, catalogue of finished programs and order backlog: multi-period excess earnings method; – Contractual arrangements and customer relationships: multi-period excess earnings method, taking into account the expected renewal of the contract; and – Brands: relief-from-royalty method. The multi-period excess earnings method (“MEEM”) measures the excess earnings generated by the intangible asset being valued after deducting contributory asset charges, whereas the relief-from-royalty method measures the after-tax royalties or license fees saved by owning the intangible asset.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Items of property, plant and equipment are stated at historical cost less accumulated depreciation (for definite useful life assets only) and impairment losses. Where parts of an item of property, plant and equipment have different useful lives, they are accounted for as separate components of property, plant and equipment. Subsequent expenditure is capitalised only when it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the item will flow to JV Newco and the cost of the item can be measured reliably. All other costs are recognised in the income statement as expense when incurred. Depreciation is charged to the income statement on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life of each part of an item of property, plant and equipment, taking into account the estimated residual value. Land is not depreciated. Depreciation methods, useful lives and residual values are reviewed and adjusted if necessary, annually. Based on the estimated useful life of the underlying assets, the following depreciation periods apply: - Land Indefinite - Buildings 13 – 33 years - Plant and equipment 8 – 13 years - Other 3 – 5 years Leased property, plant and equipment, for which JV Newco substantially assumes all of the benefits and risks of ownership, are classified as finance leases. Determining whether a lease is a finance lease requires judgment as to whether substantially all of the risks and benefits of ownership have been transferred to JV Newco. Finance leases are capitalised at their fair value of the leased asset or at the estimated net present value of the underlying minimum lease payments, whichever is the lower. The corresponding current and non-current rental obligations, net of finance charges, are included in the statement of financial position as current and non-current payables, respectively. Finance costs are charged to the income statement over the life of each respective lease. Payments made under operating leases, net of lease incentives received, are charged to the income statement in equal instalments over the life of the leases, except where an alternative method is more representative of the time pattern from which benefits are derived. An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognised whenever JV Newco disposes of it, or when no more future benefits are expected by its use. Profit or loss from the de-recognition of an item of property, plant and equipment is calculated as the difference between the net amount of the disposal and the book value of the asset. The profit or loss is recognised in the income statement in the period in which the de-recognition occurs. When assets are sold in a sale-and-lease-back transaction, and the lease-back results in a finance lease, then any gain on the sale is deferred and recognised as income over the lease term. If the leaseback is classified as an operating lease, the associated gain is in principle recognised in profit or loss, unless the transaction is clearly not at fair value, in which case it is accounted for in accordance with the substance of the agreement.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill represents the future economic benefits that arise from assets that are not capable of being individually identified and separately recognised. Goodwill recognised by JV Newco has arisen as a result of business combinations and is carried at cost less accumulated impairment losses. F-362 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Other intangible assets are those assets which are identifiable and can be sold separately or which arise from legal rights and primarily consist of format rights, (TV) movie rights, contracts with customers and brand names. These assets can either be purchased, acquired in a business combination or internally developed if certain criteria for capitalisation are met. Purchased other intangible assets are stated at cost, which is the purchase price, less accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Amortisation occurs over the period JV Newco is expected to benefit from the use of the intangible asset and commences when the assets are available for use. Format rights are amortised as from the time the format is taken into production and in proportion to the number of episodes produced. (TV) movie rights are amortised using a declining balance method based on the expected consumption of economic benefits from these assets. Development expenditures on individual projects are only recognised as an intangible asset when the following can be demonstrated: – it is technically feasible to complete the project so that it will be available for either use or sale; – there is an intention to complete the project; – the completed project is able to be either used or sold; – the manner(s) in which the asset is expected to generate future economic benefits; – resources are available to complete the project; and – development expenditures can be measured reliably. The amount initially recognised for internally-generated intangible assets is the sum of the expenditure incurred from the date when the intangible asset first meets the recognition criteria. Where no internally-generated intangible asset can be recognised, development expenditure is recognised in profit or loss in the period in which it is incurred. Amortisation of development expenditure starts when the project is available for use. Based on the estimated useful life of the underlying assets, the following amortisation periods apply: - Format rights 8 – 15 years - (TV) movie rights 8 – 20 years - Contracts 8 – 12 years - Brand names 3 – 20 years - Other 3 – 5 years The amortisation period and the amortisation method for an intangible asset with a finite useful life is reviewed at least each reporting period-end. Changes in the expected useful life are accounted for by changing the amortisation period or method, as appropriate, and are treated as changes in accounting estimates.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 2.9 Investments in associates and joint-ventures Associates
Subsubsection Text: Associates are those entities in which JV Newco has significant influence, but not control, over the financial and operating policies. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating decisions of the entity but is not control or joint control.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: A joint venture is a contractual arrangement whereby JV Newco and other parties undertake an economic activity that is subject to joint control and JV Newco has rights to the net assets of the arrangement, rather than rights to its assets and obligations for its liabilities. Joint control exists when decisions relating to the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Investments in associates and joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method. They are recognised initially at cost, which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial F-363 ----- statements includes JV Newco’s share of the profit or loss and other comprehensive income of associates and joint ventures (after adjustments for alignment with JV Newco’s accounting policies), from the date that significant influence or joint control commences until the date that significant influence or joint control ceases. When JV Newco’s share of losses exceeds its interest in an associate or joint venture, the carrying amount is reduced to nil and recognition of further losses is discontinued except to the extent that JV Newco has incurred legal or constructive obligations or made payments on behalf of an associate.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Transactions with associates and joint ventures
Subsubsection Text: Unrealised gains arising from transactions with equity-accounted investees are eliminated against the investment to the extent of JV Newco’s interest in the investee. Unrealised losses are eliminated in the same way as unrealised gains, but only to the extent that there is no evidence of impairment.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: At the end of each reporting period it is assessed whether there is any indication that an asset may be impaired. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Goodwill and other non-current assets with infinite lives
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and other intangible assets with infinite lives are tested for impairment annually, or more frequently when there is an indication for impairment. For impairment testing, goodwill is allocated to the smallest identifiable cash-generating unit. A cash-generating unit is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets. An impairment loss is recognised for the amount by which the asset’s carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less cost to sell and its value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value, using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset. An impairment loss is recognised in the income statement and allocated first to reduce the carrying amount of the goodwill and then to the other assets of the cash generating unit pro-rata on the basis of the carrying amount of each asset in the unit. An impairment loss recognised for goodwill is not reversed in subsequent years. Except for goodwill, JV Newco assesses in subsequent years whether indications exist that impairment losses previously recognised for non-current assets may no longer exist or may have decreased. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of that asset (or cash generating unit) is recalculated and its carrying amount is increased to the revised recoverable amount. The increase is recognised in the income statement. A reversal is recognised only if it arises from a change in the assumptions used to calculate the recoverable amount. An impairment loss is reversed to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortisation, if no impairment loss had been recognised.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Other non-current assets with finite lives
Subsubsection Text: The carrying amounts of JV Newco’s non-current assets with finite lives are reviewed annually to determine whether there is an indication for impairment. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated using an approach similar to that applied for non-current assets with infinite lives. For an asset that does not generate independent cash inflows, the recoverable amount is determined for the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Trade receivables are initially recognised at fair value, and subsequently carried at amortised cost, which is usually the nominal value, less impairment losses. Allowances for bad debts are recorded when there is objective evidence that collection of the receivable is no longer probable. Productions in progress represents the gross unbilled amount expected to be collected from customers for production work performed to date. It is measured at costs incurred plus profits recognised to date less progress billings, advances received and recognised losses. F-364 ----- Productions in progress are presented as part of trade receivables in the statement of financial position for all productions in which costs incurred plus recognised profits exceed progress billings, advances received from customers and recognised losses. For all productions where progress billings, advances received from customers and recognised losses exceed costs incurred plus recognised profits, the balance is presented as productions in progress as part of trade and other payables.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents include all cash on hand balances, short-term highly liquid cash investments and time deposits with original maturities of three months or less. Cash and cash equivalents are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently at amortised cost, which is usually the nominal value. Positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with one bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In many of JV Newco’s business areas it participates in pension and similar plans for its employees. A defined contribution plan is a post-employment benefit plan under which JV Newco pays fixed contributions into a separate entity and has no legal or constructive obligation to pay further amounts. Obligations for contributions to defined contribution plans are expensed as the related service is provided. Prepaid contributions are recognised as an asset to the extent that a cash refund or a reduction in future payments is available. A defined benefit plan is a post-employment benefit plan other than a defined contribution plan. JV Newco’s net obligation in respect of defined benefit plans is calculated separately for each plan by estimating the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in the current and prior periods, discounting that amount and deducting the fair value of any plan assets. The calculation of defined benefit obligations is performed annually by a qualified actuary using the projected unit credit method. When the calculation results in a potential asset for JV Newco, the recognised asset is limited to the present value of economic benefits available in the form of any future refunds from the plan or reductions in future contributions to the plan. To calculate the present value of economic benefits, consideration is given to any applicable minimum funding requirements. Re-measurements of the net defined benefit liability, which comprise actuarial gains and losses, the return on plan assets (excluding interest) and the effect of the asset ceiling (if any, excluding interest), are recognised immediately in other comprehensive income. JV Newco determines the net interest expense (income) on the net defined benefit liability (asset) for the period by applying the discount rate used to measure the defined benefit obligation at the beginning of the annual period to the then-net defined benefit liability (asset), taking into account any changes in the net defined benefit liability (asset) during the period as a result of contributions and benefit payments. Net interest expense and other expenses related to defined benefit plans are recognised in profit or loss. When the benefits of a plan are changed or when a plan is curtailed, the resulting change in benefit that relates to past service or the gain or loss on curtailment is recognised immediately in profit or loss. JV Newco recognises gains and losses on the settlement of a defined benefit plan when the settlement occurs. For other long-term employee benefits, such as long-term service benefits, the net obligation is the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods. That benefit is discounted to determine its present value. Re-measurements are recognised in profit or loss in the period in which they arise. Termination benefits are expensed at the earlier of when JV Newco can no longer withdraw the offer of those benefits and when JV Newco recognises costs for a restructuring. If benefits are not expected to be settled wholly within 12 months of the end of the reporting period, then they are discounted. F-365 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In general, a provision is recognised in the statement of financial position when: – there is a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of a past event; – it is probable that an outflow of economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation; and – a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. If the effect is material, provisions are determined by discounting the expected future cash flows at a pre-tax discount rate, that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and, where appropriate, the risks specific to the liability. Recoveries from third parties, which are likely to be realised, are recorded separately, and are not offset against the related liability. A provision for restructuring is recognised when: – there is an approved detailed and formal restructuring plan; and – the restructuring has either commenced or has been announced publicly. A provision for onerous contracts is recognised when the expected benefits to be derived from a contract are lower than the unavoidable cost of meeting its obligations under the contract and when such provision can be reasonably estimated.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Interest-bearing borrowings are recognised initially at fair value less directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, interest-bearing borrowings are stated at amortised cost with any difference between cost and redemption value being recognised in profit or loss over the period of the borrowings based on the effective interest method.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: When part of the purchase price consideration of a business combination depends on future results, an earn-out obligation is initially calculated at fair value. The calculation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario (performance-related criteria). Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: A put option liability is calculated in case JV Newco granted a minority shareholder an option to sell to JV Newco its remaining interest. Put option liabilities are re-measured to fair value at least annually based on the expected future results of the respective company, or earlier when indicators warrant recalculation. This is considered to be an obligation as JV Newco acquires its own equity, even if the exercise is contingent and conditional, when analysis confirms all significant risks and rewards of the non-controlling interest have been transferred to JV Newco, as such no non-controlling interest is recognised. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. To the extent dividend payments to minority shareholders reduce the redemption amount, they are recognised against the put option liability. Otherwise dividend payments to minority shareholders are recognised as financial expense in profit or loss upon profit distribution. F-366 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: If the outcome of a production contract can be estimated reliably, revenue associated with the production are recognised by reference to the stage of completion. This is the case when: – persuasive evidence of the sale of a production with the customer exists; – the amount of revenue can be measured reliably; – it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the production will flow to the entity; – the stage of completion of the production at the end of the reporting period can be measured reliably; and – the production costs incurred and the costs to complete the production can be measured reliably. The stage of completion is ordinarily determined with reference to either: – the proportion of finished episodes (to date) to total episodes to be produced under the contract (measurement of stage of completion may be done on the basis of delivery if this is a better measurement); or – the proportion of production days spent (to date) to total production days expected to be made under the contract (mainly applicable for scripted productions like telenovela’s and movies) If the outcome of a production contract cannot be estimated reliably, revenue is recognised only to the extent it is probable that expenses incurred are recoverable. Contract costs are recognised in profit or loss as incurred unless they create an asset related to future contract activity. An expected loss on a contract is recognised in profit or loss immediately. Production revenue includes the initial amount agreed in the contract plus any variations in production work, claims and incentive payments, to the extent that it is probable that these will result in revenue and they can be measured reliably. If JV Newco acts as an agent rather than as a principal under a production agreement, no revenue is recognised, except to the extent commissions are earned.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Distribution – finished program sales and sale of licensing rights
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from the sale of finished programs and licensing rights on intellectual property formats is recognised when it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the sale will flow to JV Newco and the amount of revenue can be estimated reliably. Any such revenues shall be recognised on an accrual basis, and only to the extent there is no continuing involvement. Revenues cannot be recognised until the start of the broadcasting/ license period. When there is continuing involvement of JV Newco, revenue is recognised over the term of the contract.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Other revenue is ordinarily recognised in accordance with the substance of the underlying agreement. Commercial, digital and other revenue is recognised e.g. on the basis of the number of calls or minutes spent on calls, the number of messages sent or received, the amounts of data traffic generated, the number of internet hits, the number of games sold and/or subscriptions sold in relation to the platforms provided. Services rendered in exchange for dissimilar goods or services are regarded as transactions that generate revenue. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the goods or services received, adjusted by the amount of cash or cash equivalents transferred. When the fair value of the goods or services received cannot be measured reliably, revenue is measured at the fair value of the goods or services given up, adjusted by the amount of cash or cash equivalents transferred. Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco recognises government grants initially as deferred income at fair value if there is reasonable assurance that they will be received and JV Newco will comply with the conditions associated with the grant. Subsequently, grants are then recognised in profit or loss as other income on a systematic basis over the useful life of the asset. F-367 ----- Grants that compensate JV Newco for expenses incurred are recognised in profit or loss on a systematic basis in the periods in which the expenses are recognised.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: For equity-settled share-based payment awards granted to employees, the grant-date fair value is generally recognised as an expense, with a corresponding increase in equity, over the vesting period of the awards. The amount recognised as an expense is adjusted to reflect the number of awards for which the related service and non-market performance conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognised is based on the number of awards that meet the related service and non-market performance conditions at the vesting date. For share-based payment awards with market or non-vesting conditions, the grant-date fair value of the sharebased payment is measured to reflect such conditions and there is no true-up for differences between expected and actual outcomes. For cash-settled share-based payments, a liability is recognised for the goods or services acquired, measured initially at the fair value of the liability. The services received from employees are recognised as an expense over the vesting period of the awards, with recognition of a corresponding liability. At the end of each reporting period until the liability is settled, and at the date of settlement, the fair value of the liability is re-measured, with any changes in fair value recognised in profit or loss.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco uses the EBITDA heading in the income statement. JV Newco defines EBITDA as profit for the period before depreciation, amortisation, impairment, financial income, financial expense, share in profit of associates and income tax. EBITDA is not a measurement under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to (a) net profit, (b) cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities, or as a measure of our ability to meet cash needs, or (c) any other measures or performance under IFRS. EBITDA is not a direct measure of our liquidity, which is shown by JV Newco’s cash flow statement and should be considered in the context of our financial commitments. EBITDA may not be indicative of our historical operating results, and may not be predictive of our potential future results. Because not all companies calculate EBITDA identically, the presentation of EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly named measures of other companies. To enhance the insight into the financial results of the Company’s activities, the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income shows EBITDA before (operating) exceptional items. Exceptional items are excluded from management’s assessment of results because by their size, nature or incidence they could distort the Company’s underlying quality of earnings. Such items are disclosed on the face of the consolidated income statement and separately in the notes to the financial statements. They are typically gains or losses arising from events that are not considered part of the core operations of the business (e.g. costs relating to capital transactions, such as professional fees on acquisitions, one-off restructuring costs, shareholder management fees, earn-out and put option related remuneration expense, LTIP expenses and gains and or losses on disposal of assets). These items are excluded to reflect performance in a consistent manner and are in line with how the business is managed and measured on a day-to-day basis.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Finance income primarily comprises interest income on funds invested, fair value gains on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, gains on the re-measurement to fair value of any pre-existing interest in an acquiree in a business combination, gains on hedging instruments that are recognised in profit or loss and reclassifications of net gains previously recognised in other comprehensive income. Interest income and expense is recognised as it accrues in profit or loss, using the effective interest method. Finance costs comprise interest expense on borrowings, unwinding of the discount on provisions and deferred consideration, fair value losses on financial assets at fair value through profit or loss and contingent consideration, impairment losses recognised on financial assets (other than trade receivables), losses on hedging instruments that are recognised in profit or loss and reclassifications of net losses previously recognised in other comprehensive income. Borrowing costs that are not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognised in profit or loss using the effective interest method. F-368 ----- Foreign currency gains and losses on financial assets and financial liabilities are reported on a net basis as either finance income or finance cost depending on whether foreign currency movements are in a net gain or net loss position.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The current tax payable is based on taxable profit for the period and includes adjustments to tax payable or receivable in respect of prior periods. Taxable profit differs from profit as reported in the income statement because of items of income or expense that are taxable or deductible in other periods and items that are never taxable or deductible. JV Newco’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax is recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the consolidated financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognised for all taxable temporary differences. Deferred tax assets are generally recognised for all deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which those deductible temporary differences can be utilised. Such deferred tax assets and liabilities are not recognised if the temporary difference arises from the initial recognition of goodwill or from the initial recognition (other than in a business combination) of other assets and liabilities in a transaction that affects neither the taxable profit nor the accounting profit. Deferred tax liabilities are recognised for taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries and associates, and interests in joint ventures, except where JV Newco is able to control the reversal of the temporary difference and it is probable that the temporary difference will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred tax assets arising from deductible temporary differences associated with such investments and interests are only recognised to the extent that it is probable that there will be sufficient taxable profits against which to utilise the benefits of the temporary differences and they are expected to reverse in the foreseeable future. A deferred tax asset is recognised for unused tax losses to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be utilised. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realised. Such reductions are reversed when the probability of future taxable profits improves. Unrecognised deferred tax assets are reassessed at each reporting date and recognised to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period in which the liability is settled or the asset realised, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner, in which JV Newco expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and JV Newco intends to settle its current tax assets and liabilities on a net basis.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco initially recognises loans and receivables and deposits on the date that they are originated at fair value. Subsequent measurement is at amortised cost. All other financial assets are recognised initially on the trade date at which JV Newco becomes a party to the contractual provisions of the instrument. JV Newco derecognises a financial asset when the contractual rights to the cash flows from the asset expire, or it transfers the rights to receive the contractual cash flows on the financial asset in a transaction in which substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the financial asset are transferred. Any interest in transferred financial assets that is created or retained by JV Newco is recognised as a separate asset or liability. F-369 ----- Financial assets and liabilities are offset and the net amount presented in the statement of financial position when, and only when, JV Newco has a legal right to offset the amounts and intends either to settle on a net basis or to realise the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. Non-derivative financial assets include held-to-maturity financial assets (debt securities), loans and receivables (including cash and cash equivalents, and trade and other receivables) and available for sale financial assets (equity securities and debt securities).

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The proceeds of issued shares in excess of the nominal value of the shares are recognised as share premium, after deducting the incremental costs directly attributable to the share issue, net of tax. Redeemable preference shares are classified as financial liabilities when they bear non-discretionary dividends and are redeemable in cash by the holders. Non-discretionary dividends thereon are recognised as interest expense in profit or loss as accrued. Non-redeemable preference shares are classified as equity, because they bear discretionary dividends, do not contain any obligations to deliver cash or other financial assets and do not require settlement in a variable number of the Group’s equity instruments. Discretionary dividends thereon are recognised as equity distributions on approval by the Company’s shareholders. When shares recognised as equity are purchased by the Group, the consideration paid, including directly attributable costs, net of any tax effects, is recognised as a deduction from other reserves within equity. When such shares are sold or reissued subsequently, the amount received is recognised as an increase in other reserves within equity. When purchased shares are withdrawn, the nominal value of the shares and the related share premium is deducted from share capital and share premium, and added to the other reserves.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco initially recognises debt securities issued and subordinated liabilities on the date that they are originated. All other financial liabilities are recognised initially on the trade date, which is the date that the Group becomes a party to the contractual provisions of the instrument. JV Newco derecognises a financial liability when its contractual obligations are discharged, cancelled or expired. JV Newco classifies non-derivative financial liabilities into the other financial liabilities category. Such financial liabilities are recognised initially at fair value less any directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, these financial liabilities are measured at amortised cost using the effective interest method except for earn out obligations which are measured at fair value. Other financial liabilities comprise loans and borrowings, debt securities issued (including certain preference shares), bank overdrafts, and trade and other payables.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Derivative financial instruments and hedging activities
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco uses derivative financial instruments principally in the management of its foreign currency and interest rate risks. JV Newco measures all derivative financial instruments based on fair values, derived from market prices or a valuation model. Derivatives are initially recognised at fair value on the date a derivative contract is entered into and are subsequently remeasured at their fair value at each reporting date. The method of recognising the resulting gain or loss depends on whether the derivative is designated as a hedging instrument, and if so, the nature of the item being hedged. JV Newco designates certain derivatives as hedges of a particular risk associated with a recognised asset or liability or a highly probable forecast transaction (cash flow hedge). JV Newco documents at the inception of the transaction the relationship between hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategy for undertaking various hedging transactions. JV Newco also documents its assessment, both at hedge inception and on an ongoing basis, of whether the derivatives that are used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in fair values or cash flows of hedged items. F-370 ----- The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivatives that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedges is recognised in equity. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognised immediately in the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. Amounts accumulated in equity are recycled in the income statement in the periods when the hedged item affects profit or loss. The gain or loss relating to the effective portion of interest rate swaps hedging variable rate borrowings is recognised in the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognised in the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. However, when the forecast transaction that is hedged results in the recognition of a non-financial asset the gains and losses previously deferred in equity are transferred from equity and included in the initial measurement of the cost of the asset. When a hedging instrument expires, or is sold, or when a hedge no longer meets the criteria for hedge accounting, any cumulative gain or loss existing in equity at that time remains in equity and is recognised when the forecast transaction is ultimately recognised in the income statement. In 2016, no hedge accounting has been applied. When a forecast transaction is no longer expected to occur, the cumulative gain or loss that was reported in equity is immediately transferred to the income statement within ‘Net financial income (expense)’. If JV Newco does not designate a derivative as hedge of a particular risk associated with a recognised asset or liability or a highly probable forecast transaction (cash flow hedge), movements in the fair value of the instrument are recognised in the income statement.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Call and put options relating to acquisition contracts
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco has entered into various call and put options in connection with some of its acquisitions. Call options are valued at fair value and recognised in the statement of financial position when the option exercise price is lower than the underlying fair value of the potential future investee. Granted put options to joint venture partners and shareholders of entities where JV Newco does not have control are valued at fair value and recognised when the option exercise price is higher than the underlying fair value of the entity involved. The fair value of the options is re-measured at each reporting date. All changes in fair values are accounted for in the income statement, as financial income or expense.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 2.25 Preparation of the statement of cash flows
Subsubsection Text: The statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method. Changes in balance sheet items that have not resulted in cash flows (e.g. translation differences, financial leases, fair value changes, conversions of debt to equity) have been eliminated for the purpose of preparing this statement. Dividends received are included in investing activities, whereas dividends paid to ordinary shareholders, interest received and interest paid are included in financing activities. For the purposes of the cash flow statement, bank overdrafts that are an integral part of JV Newco’s cash management are included as a component of cash and cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at the bank (both debit and credit) and (call) deposits.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 2.26 New, revised and amended standards and interpretations not yet applied
Subsubsection Text: The following new, revised and amended IFRSs (not yet adopted by the European Union) may be relevant to JV Newco, and are not yet applied by JV Newco: IAS 7 (Amendment) (issued 2016) Statement of Cash Flows (effective 2017) (Disclosure Initiative) IAS 12 (Amendment) (issued 2016) Recognition of Deferred Tax (effective 2017) Assets for Unrealised Losses IFRS 9 (Revised) Financial instruments (effective 2018) IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with (effective 2018) Customers IFRS 16 (issued 2016) Leases (effective 2019) IAS 7 – The amendments to IAS 7 Statement of Cash Flows require a disclosure of changes in liabilities arising from financing activities, including changes arising from cash flows and non-cash changes. According to the Company’s initial assessment, the disclosure initiative of IAS 7 will not have a material impact on the financial statements. A further assessment will be done in 2017. F-371 ----- IAS 12 – Amendments made to IAS 12 clarify the accounting for deferred tax where an asset is measured at fair value and that fair value is below the asset’s tax base. This amendment has no impact on the Company’s financial statements. IFRS 15 – The new standard is based on the principle that revenue is recognised when control of a good or service transfers to the customer, so the notion of control replaces the existing notion of risks and rewards. A new five step approach must be applied before revenue can be recognised: – Identify contracts with customers; – Identify the separate performance obligations; – Determine the transaction price of the contract; – Allocate the transaction price to each of the separate performance obligations; and – Recognise the revenue as each performance obligation is satisfied. Considering the Company’s current revenue recognition policy, the Company’s first assessment shows no material impact from applying the new IFRS 15 standard. A further assessment will be performed in 2017. IFRS 15 will be applied for the first time in the financial year 2018. IFRS 9 – The final version of IFRS 9 contains revised regulations for the classifications and measurement of financial assets, new requirements for impairment of financial instruments and new requirements for hedge accounting. The impact of the application of the revised standard on the Company’s financial statements has not been assessed yet. IFRS 9 will be applied for the first time in the financial year 2018. IFRS 16 – The new standard sets out principles for recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure requirements for leases. The changes mainly affect lessee accounting and generally require lessees to recognize contractual rights and obligations on the lessee’s balance sheet. The standard replaces the straight-line recognition of operating lease expense for those leases applying IAS 17 with the recognition of depreciation expenses for the right-of-use asset and interest expenses on the lease liability (included within the financial result). In addition, IFRS 16 includes more extensive disclosures in the notes for lessees. The new standard will have an impact on the financial statements of the Company. Examples of leases where the new standard will have an impact are leases for the rental of buildings and studio’s. An initial assessment will be performed in 2017. The standard will be applied for the first time in the financial year 2019.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On 28 April 2016, CORE Entertainment, Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries (the “CORE Debtors”) filed voluntary petitions for relief under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”). On 23 September 2016, the Bankruptcy Court confirmed (i.e., approved) the bankruptcy plan proposed by the CORE Debtors. The plan provided for a significant de-leveraging of the CORE Debtors pursuant to which, among other things, holders of equity interests in the CORE Debtors (including CORE Entertainment Holdings’ equity interest in CORE Entertainment, Inc.) did not receive any distribution on account thereof. As such, JV Newco’s indirect equity interest in CORE Media Group was cancelled for no consideration. Under the CORE Debtors’ bankruptcy plan, unsecured creditors were entitled to share pro rata in a distribution of cash (up to USD 2,375,000 in the aggregate and not to exceed 10% of its unsecured claim) and certain residual rights in respect of actions brought against parties not released from claims under the plan. As a legal matter, JV Newco remained the controlling stockholder of CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. with the authority to appoint a majority of the board of directors. However, upon the CORE Debtors’ emergence from bankruptcy on 17 October 2016, CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc.’s shares in CORE Entertainment Inc. were cancelled such that CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc. no longer owns CORE Entertainment Inc. or any of its subsidiaries nor has the right to manage CORE’s business. This resulted in a loss of control over CORE’s business and triggered an immediate deconsolidation from the consolidated balance sheet of JV Newco per date of loss of control. Since CORE’s business was a separate cash generating unit within JV Newco’s operations, the disposal of CORE Media Group has been accounted for and presented as discontinued operations.

Subsubsection Text: The gain on derecognized carrying amounts of assets and liabilities includes EUR 24.6 million profit from derecognition of other non-current liabilities “Series A” and “Series B” Convertible Preferred Stock of the remaining (empty) holding company Core Entertainment Holdings Inc. (reference is also made to Note 24). After loss of control of the CORE Media Group, Core Entertainment Holdings Inc. is no longer holding any assets or any other liabilities and is envisaged to be liquidated. At liquidation there will be no cash available for distribution to the holders of the preferred stock. To fully reflect the economic substance and financial impact of the loss of control of the CORE Media Group activities, the “Series A” and “Series B” Convertible Preferred Stock liabilities have been derecognized at the loss of control.

Within the Dutch fiscal unity profits and losses of the group companies are offset. Over the 2016 and 2015 reporting periods the Dutch fiscal unity was in a tax loss position. At the derecognition of CORE Media Group as described in Note 3, the Company derecognized the non-valuated losses and tax credits pertaining to CORE Media Group. In business combinations in 2014 the Company recognised deferred tax liabilities pertaining to identified assets at book values as previously carried by the contributing shareholder where the tax base was not affected by the business combination. The Company subsequently recognized tax benefits in respect of fiscal losses of the fiscal unity in certain jurisdictions to the extent it can be set off against deferred tax liabilities arising from the business combinations that relate to the fiscal unity of that particular jurisdiction. To the extent losses cannot be set off against deferred tax liabilities, valuation (if any) of fiscal losses is based on forecasts of future results and assessment of probability of its realisation. Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: During the financial period 2016, the Company assessed the recoverable amount of goodwill and other intangible assets, based on a detailed forecast per CGU taking into account various downside adjustments to the detailed business plans. This level 3 assessment leads to the conclusion that an impairment was required for an amount of EUR (75.4) million, EUR (79.6) million including FX, for the CGU US. An additional impairment charge was incurred for the CGU Rest of World in the amount of EUR (16.6) million, EUR (17.5) million including FX. An impairment charge of EUR (92.0) million has been reported in the statement of comprehensive income. Impairment US is mainly driven by lower plan projections and refocused scripted approach. In Rest of the World, Endemol Shine is refocusing its regional strategy in some markets. Goodwill of the cash generating units has been tested for impairment at year-end 2016 based on the latest shortand long-term business forecasts. The recoverable amounts of the cash generating units have been determined based on a fair value less cost of disposal approach. To determine the fair value less cost of disposal, cash flow projections are based on financial budgets and forward-looking statements, approved by senior management, for the underlying operations of a cash generating unit. These projections include estimates for the cost savings that have been realized and are to be realized from several cost savings initiatives. By their nature, forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties as they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. Accordingly, actual results of operations, financial condition and liquidity may differ from those assumed in the forward-looking statements. The key assumptions used for the fair value less cost of disposal calculations relate to discount rate and terminal value growth rate, revenue growth and EBITDA margin. The post-tax discount rates, applied to the cash flow projections, vary between 7.0% and 14.7%. These rates have been calculated using the weighted average cost of capital methodology. The main parameters are the targeted debt-to-equity ratio, the risk-free interest rate based on government bonds and a risk premium. The terminal value growth rate is based on the lower of i) the risk-free rate for all Euro denominated CGU’s or the risk free rate plus inflation differential for other CGU, and ii) the estimated local long-term inflation expectation. The revenue growth rates and EBITDA margins used to estimate future performance are based on past performance and our expectations for growth rates and EBITDA margins achievable in the markets the Company is active in. Consolidated for the Company the average annual compounded revenue growth rate applied in the projected periods is 5.2%. The average annual compounded revenue growth rate applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 1.4% and 10.6%. Consolidated for the Company the terminal value year EBITDA margin applied is 9.5%. The terminal value year EBITDA margins applied for the main CGU’s ranged between 6.2% and 21.3%. Consolidated for the Company the terminal value growth rate applied is 1.5%. The terminal value growth rate applied for the CGU’s ranged between 0.9% and 1.9%. F-383 ----- In addition to the forecast used in the impairment test, a sensitivity analysis has been prepared. In the scenario of using a 50 bps higher discount rate, this would lead to recognizing a total impairment charge of EUR (131) million, of which EUR (97) million would relate to the CGU US, the remaining impairment charge would relate to the CGUs France, Rest of World and International & Distribution. A 5% lower terminal value EBITDA level would lead to recognizing a total impairment of EUR (104) million, of which EUR (90) million would relate to the CGU US. The remaining impairment charge would relate to the CGUs France, Rest of World and International & Distribution. The following table illustrates for the CGUs with limited headroom the sensitivity to changes in the terminal value EBITDA which would result in a recoverable amount equal to the carrying amount and the headroom based on current projections:

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Effective 8 January 2015, the Company entered into a EUR 350.0 million for USD 412 million Cross Currency Swap (CCS), at spot rate USD/EUR 1.177. The CCS partly off sets the mismatch between the currency mix of the external loans and borrowings and the currency mix of EBITDA and cash flow and in addition converts the company’s floating interest obligation in respect of 60% of the principal amount of the EUR-denominated loans to a fixed rate. Inputs used by the financial institution in measuring the fair value are at level 2 in the three-tier hierarchy, using observable inputs other than quoted prices in active markets. Since JV Newco did not designate a hedge, the change in fair value of the derivative financial instrument is recorded in the income statement. F-387 -----

Subsubsection Text: Trade receivables as of 31 December 2016 amounted to EUR 233.6 million (2015: EUR 280.6 million). Allowances for impairment losses as of 31 December 2016 are deducted from trade receivables and amounted to EUR 12.8 million (2015: EUR 6.7 million), resulting in a net receivable of EUR 220.8 million (2015: EUR 273.9 million). Trade receivables are non-interest bearing and generally on 30 – 90 day’s payment term. Allowances for impairment losses bad debts are recorded when there is objective evidence that collection of the receivable is no longer probable. Balances past due but not impaired relate to customers with good track records. The Company does not hold any collateral in relation to trade or other receivables.

Subsection Title: Total cash and cash equivalents . . . . . . . . .** **218,092** **445,139 Notional cash pool
Subsubsection Text: Positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with one bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. Notional cash pools form an integral part of JV Newco’s cash management. Based on the above JV Newco is required to report the cash balances and the bank overdrafts on a gross basis. Credit institutions balance is EUR (193.0) million (2015: EUR (338.5) million) of which EUR (57.2) million (2015: EUR (262.4) million) relates to the Dutch cash pool effect. All cash is at the free disposal of JV Newco, except for trapped cash in the amount of EUR 37.5 million (2015: EUR 22.8 million). Trapped cash consists amongst others of trust account cash, country restricted cash, cash at jointly controlled ventures and cash backed bank guarantees.

Subsubsection Text: AP NMT JV Newco B.V. was incorporated on 5 November 2014 with an authorised and issued share capital of EUR 1 consisting of 1 ordinary shares with a nominal value of EUR 1. Subsubsection Text: The share premium is the amount paid to the Company by shareholders, in cash or other consideration, over and above the nominal value of shares.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The legal reserves comprise of: – Translation reserve: The translation reserve comprises of all foreign exchange differences arising from the translation of the financial statements of foreign operations; and – Reserve for participating interests: Pursuant to Dutch law certain limitations exist relating to the distribution of shareholders’ equity. The reserve for participating interests was formed for the retained profits from investments in joint ventures and associates, which were not paid in the form of dividends and payment of which cannot be realized by JV Newco itself.
