Subsection Title: Total interest-bearing loans and borrowings . . . . . .** **1,772,151** **2,128,580 Capital structures within JV Newco
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the joint venture, Fox contributed its interests in the Shine Group to JV Newco and Apollo contributed its interests in the Endemol Group and the CORE Media Group to JV Newco. Subsequent to these contributions the Shine Group has been contributed to the Endemol Group in anticipation of further legal and operational integration. Per 17 October 2016 JV Newco lost control over the CORE Media activities subject to a financial restructuring as described in Note 3, and JV Newco derecognized all assets and liabilities pertaining to the CORE Media Group. Endemol Shine and CORE Media maintained separate capital structures within JV Newco’s operations. The financing arrangements of the Endemol Shine Group (combined) and CORE Media Group are therefore disclosed separately.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Loans and borrowings Endemol Shine Group First and second lien loans and borrowings
Subsubsection Text: On 13 August 2014, MediArena Acquisition B.V. (formerly known as AP NMT Acquisition B.V.), as borrower, MediArena Newco B.V. (formerly AP NMT Newco B.V.), the borrower’s direct parent company, and certain financial institutions entered into a First Lien Credit Agreement and a Second Lien Credit Agreement. On 12 December 2014, to finance the Shine transaction, MediArena Acquisition B.V. also entered into an Incremental Assumption Agreement. Together providing for: – a EUR 125 million First Lien multi-currency revolving credit facility (“RCF”) maturing on 13 August 2019, which includes a letter of credit sub-facility and a EUR 30 million swing line loan sub-facility; – a First Lien Term Loan B facility maturing on 13 August 2021, comprised of a USD 885 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans, a EUR 235 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans and a GBP 50 million tranche of First Lien Term B loans; and – a USD 457 million Second Lien Term Loan B facility maturing on 13 August 2022. On 22 April 2015, MediArena Acquisition B.V. entered into an Incremental Assumption Agreement providing for: – an additional USD 25 million First Lien Term Loan B loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, which also matures on 13 August 2021; and – an additional EUR 25 million First Lien Term Loan B loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, which also matures on 13 August 2021. F-391 ----- The loans incurred on 12 December 2014 and 22 April 2015 have the same terms as the loans of the same currency incurred under the First Lien Credit Agreement on 13 August 2014. As per 31 December 2016, total drawings under the RCF amounting to EUR 80.0 million were outstanding (2015: EUR 37.0 million). In addition, the Group may request one or more incremental term loan facilities and/or increase commitments under its First Lien Credit Agreement and request one or more incremental term loan facilities under its Second Lien Agreement in an aggregate amount of up to the sum of EUR 200 million plus such additional amount as long as, (i) in the case of loans under additional credit facilities that rank equally to the liens on the collateral securing the Term B Loans and the Initial Revolving Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement, its consolidated net first lien leverage ratio would be no greater than 3.40 to 1.00 and (ii) in the case of loans under additional credit facilities that rank junior to the liens on the collateral securing the Term B Loans and the Initial Revolving Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement and equally and without preference with, or junior to, the liens on the collateral securing the Term Loans under the Second Lien Credit Agreement, its consolidated net secured leverage ratio would be no greater than 5.20 to 1.00, subject to certain conditions and receipt of commitments by existing or additional lenders. All borrowings under the Group’s revolving credit facility under the First Lien Credit Agreement are subject to the satisfaction of customary conditions, including the absence of a default and the accuracy of representations and warranties. Prior to the maturity date of 13 August 2021, the First Lien Term B Loans require scheduled quarterly amortization payments in an amount equal to 0.25% of the original principal amount of the term loans, the first payment of which was due on 31 December 2014, with the balance due at maturity. In 2016, amortization payments of EUR 11.5 million were made (2015: EUR 11.5 million). Amortization payments due in 2017 amount to EUR 11.3 million. Within the context of the financing agreements, guarantees and securities have been provided by several of Endemol Shine’s entities established in the Security Jurisdictions (United States, England and Wales, the Netherlands, Germany, France, Spain and Australia) and guarantees have been provided by certain Endemol Shine entities established in Italy, Norway, Sweden and Denmark. Borrowings of term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement and Second Lien Credit Agreement at a rate equal to the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) are subject to a 1.00% floor. The First Lien Credit Agreement includes customary mandatory prepayment requirements based on certain events, such as asset sales, certain debt issuances and defined levels of excess cash flow. The Second Lien Credit Agreement includes customary mandatory prepayment requirements based on certain events, such as asset sales and certain debt issuances. The Company may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement at any time, without prepayment premium or penalty and subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to LIBOR rate loans. The Company may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the Second Lien Credit Agreement at any time. In the event of any prepayment before 13 August 2017, such prepayment will be accompanied by a 1.00% prepayment premium. All prepayments will be subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to LIBOR loans. The revolving credit facility under the First Lien Credit Agreement includes a springing financial maintenance covenant that requires the consolidated net first lien leverage ratio not to exceed 5.50 to 1.00. The covenant will be tested quarterly when the revolving credit facility is more than 30% drawn (excluding outstanding letters of credit other than letters of credit supporting debt for borrowed money). As of 31 December 2016, the borrowings under the revolving credit facility were more than 30% of the outstanding commitments; therefore, the covenant was in effect (2015: borrowings less than 30% of the outstanding commitments and the covenant was not in effect). As of 31 December 2016, the consolidated net first lien leverage ratio did not exceed the maximum of 5.5. F-392 ----- The First Lien Credit Agreement and Second Lien Credit Agreement also contain customary affirmative covenants and events of default, and the negative covenants limit the Group’s ability to, among other things: incur additional debt or issue certain preferred shares; create liens on certain assets; make certain loans or investments (including acquisitions); pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of its capital stock or make other restricted payments; consolidate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of its assets; sell assets; enter into certain transactions with its affiliates; enter into sale-leaseback transactions; change its lines of business; restrict dividends from its subsidiaries or restrict liens; change its fiscal year; and modify the terms of certain debt or organizational agreements.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On 24 March 2016, Endemol Shine, entered into a USD 70 million revolving receivable securitisation facility (the “Facility”) with Bank of America, N.A., as administrative agent. On 23 December 2016, the revolving receivable securitisation facility was increased to USD 100 million. The Facility is structured as a permitted securitisation under the Company’s first lien credit agreement and second lien credit agreement. Under the Facility, interest and principal are paid on a monthly basis or, in the case of loans bearing interest based on LIBOR, on the last day of each applicable interest period. The interest rates under the Facility are based on either LIBOR, the prime rate published by Bank of America, N.A., or the federal funds rate, plus, in each case, an agreed upon margin. The Facility is classified as a held to maturity instrument. The loan parties under the Facility are special purpose entities that are structured as bankruptcy-remote from the greater Endemol Shine Group. The Facility is secured by the assets that are transferred to the loan parties by members of Endemol Shine Group from time to time, which assets also comprise the borrowing base under the Facility. The Facility is not guaranteed by other members of Endemol Shine Group. As per 31 December 2016, an amount of EUR 57.4 million was drawn under the facility, of which EUR 21.1 million matures within the year.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: As per 29 December 2016 the company received a short-term loan from related parties in the amount of USD 30 million. The short-term loan had an original maturity date of 29 March 2017, which has been extended from time to time. The principal was increased to USD 33 million as per December 2017 and the loan has a maturity date of 15 June 2018. The loan bears an interest rate of 10% per annum, payable at maturity.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Other current bank debt Endemol Shine Group
Subsubsection Text: Based on IAS 32.42, positive and negative bank balances of a legal entity with a bank are not offset, even though these balances are part of a notional cash pool, unless there is a legally enforceable right to offset the recognised amounts and the entity intends either to settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. Notional cash pools form an integral part of Endemol Shine’s cash management. Based on the above, Endemol Shine is required to report the cash balances and the bank overdrafts on a gross basis. For interest calculation purposes these amounts are netted. As per 31 December 2016, total drawings under the RCF amounting to EUR 80 million were outstanding (2015: EUR 37 million), leaving an undrawn amount of EUR 45 million (2015: EUR 88 million undrawn). Remaining other bank debt is EUR 113.1 million (2015: EUR 301.5 million) of which EUR 57.2 million relates to the Dutch cash pool effect (2015: EUR 262.4 million). Endemol Shine maintains a number of bilateral and production financing facilities in UK, France, Brazil, Germany, Italy, Israel, Russia and Turkey subject to other interest rates than the above-mentioned facilities. For some of the bilateral facilities (Brazil and Israel), a bank guarantee has been issued by the Company to secure the local credit exposure of the local banks. No parental and/or bank guarantees have been provided in respect of the other facilities. The undrawn amount against the bilateral facilities as per 31 December 2016 was EUR 23.4 million (2015: EUR 14.9 million). F-393 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Loans and borrowings CORE Media Group First and second lien loans and borrowings
Subsubsection Text: On 9 December 2011, CORE Media Group and certain financial institutions entered into a First Lien Term Loan and a Second Lien Term Loan (collectively: the ‘Term Loans’). The First Lien Term has an aggregate principal amount of USD 200 million. The Second Lien Term Loan has an aggregate principal amount of USD 160 million. Starting 11 June 2015, CORE Media Group elected not to make the scheduled quarterly interest payments on the USD 160 million Second Lien Term Loan, giving the Second Lien holders the right to default interest and to accelerate the maturity of the debt. On 26 July 2015 CORE Media Group has entered into forbearance agreements with its lenders holding the majority of the debt outstanding under each of the First and Second Lien Term Loans. The forbearance agreements placed certain restrictions on CORE Media Group during the forbearance period including certain payments to affiliates and payment of interest on the Second Lien Term Loan. The forbearance agreements further required CORE Media Group to continue negotiations with the respective lender groups during the forbearance period. Due to certain cross default provisions in the loan agreement which would be triggered if the Second Lien holders exercise their rights to accelerate their debt, both the First Lien Term Loan and the Second Lien Term Loan were classified as current as of 31 December 2015. Per 17 October 2016 JV Newco lost control over the CORE Media activities subject to a financial restructuring as described in Note 3 and JV Newco derecognized all assets and liabilities pertaining to the CORE Media Group. The First Lien Term was scheduled to mature on 21 June 2017 and bore interest at a rate of 9.0% per annum or 11% per annum when in default. The First Lien Term Loan was collatarized by a first priority security interest in the material assets of CORE Media Group and its guarantor subsidiaries with a number of exclusions, the most significant of which were cash and contracts that could not be assigned. On the date of derecognition of the liability (17 October 2017), interest accrued under the First Lien including Default Rate interest was USD 8.5 million (31 December 2015: USD 1.2 million). F-394 ----- The Second Lien Term Loan was scheduled to mature on 18 June 2018 and bore interest at a rate of 13.5% per annum or 15.5% per annum when in default. The Second Lien Term Loan was collatarized by a second priority security interest in the same assets as the First Lien Term Loan. On the date of derecognition of the liability (17 October 2017), interest accrued under the Second Lien including Default Rate interest was USD 28.8 million (31 December 2015: USD 19.6 million).

Subsection Title: Total employee benefit obligations . . . . . .** **5,924** **8,654 Post-employment benefits
Subsubsection Text: Except for the Dutch group companies, all of JV Newco’s employees are covered by several defined contribution plans. In the Netherlands, Endemol participates in a defined benefit plan for nearly all employees in the Netherlands at Stichting Bedrijfstakpensioenfonds voor de Media PNO (“PNO Media”). This plan is a multiemployer defined benefit pension plan, which is accounted for as a defined contribution plan because sufficient information for defined benefit accounting is not available. PNO Media is a multi-employer pension fund and PNO Media is not able to provide Endemol with sufficient information on the present value of the benefit obligations, the fair value of plan assets and the funded status of Endemol. As of 31 December 2016, PNO Media had a coverage ratio of 91.3% (2015: 97.3%), which is below the required ratio by De Nederlandsche Bank (DNB). On 29 June 2015 PNO Media submitted a recovery plan at the Dutch National Bank including the measures to be taken in order to get the coverage ratio at the required level within the next 12 years. As long as the actual coverage ratio is below the required coverage ratio, the recovery plan will be updated by PNO Media annually. In Italy, employees are covered by a severance plan (post-employment benefit plan) provided for in accordance with local legislation. Severance pay is considered normal remuneration that has been deferred and approximates one month’s pay for each year of service, valued each year on a basis linked to cost-of-living indices. The severance liability as of 31 December 2016 of EUR 0.3 million (2015: EUR 0.3 million), represents the accumulated amount due to employees upon termination based on service to date. F-395 ----- In other countries, the total unfunded retirement indemnity for employees is provided for, amounting to EUR 0.3 million as of 31 December 2016 (2015: EUR 0.2 million). CORE Media Group maintained an employee savings plan to provide for defined contributions which covered substantially all its employees. CORE Media Group’s contributions to its savings plan provided a dollar-for-dollar matching contribution up to four percent of salary deferrals. In 2016 employer contributions amounted to EUR 0.0 million (2015: EUR 0.1 million).

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Other employee benefits: employee incentive plans
Subsubsection Text: Over the past year JV Newco introduced within Endemol Shine certain long-term incentive plans (“LTIPs”) targeted at incentivizing the Group’s most senior executives. For the key executives within certain local operations a local LTIP was introduced running for a 4 to 5-year period. All bonus payments under the LTIPs (if any) will be made in cash. The LTIPs are aimed to align the interests of the stakeholders with the participating executives by virtue of sharing part of the value created of the relevant Group entities. The value creation is predominantly driven by a growth in applicable earnings measured over the relevant LTIP period. If there is no or limited growth of earnings over the LTIP period, the LTIPs are not in the money. The LTIP plans provide for an advance payment of 30% of the estimated total cash bonus payable at the end of the LTIP period (if any) to each participant in the course of 3rd year of the 5-year plan period. The remainder (if any) will be paid upon settlement of the LTIPs. For the local LTIPs effective at 31 December 2016, the total cash bonus payments over the LTIP period are capped at EUR 77 million (2015: capped at EUR 93 million). The LTIPs are in substance considered profit-sharing arrangements and are accounted for as an employee benefit in accordance with IAS 19. The expenses in connection with such plans are attributed to the period in which the services that give rise to the obligation are rendered. In terms of the LTIP, the Company only accounts for LTIP expenses in any given period if it is management’s best estimate as of the end of that period that the plan will be “in the money” and the bonus payable can be estimated reliably. The “in the money” assessment is primarily made with reference to whether or not a certain targeted earnings measure has been achieved during the respective financial period.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The completion of the sale on 13 August by Endemol B.V. of the shares in Endemol Holding B.V. to MediArena B.V. is deemed a sale under the Group LTIP plan rules. In accordance with the plan rules, each participant is eligible to a cash bonus. The LTIP bonus amount has been set by reference to the enterprise value of Endemol Group and amounts to EUR 15.0 million (EUR 16.5 million including social security charges). The LTIP bonus amounts was payable in 2 installments, 50% upon completion of the sale and 50% per 31 December 2015. The latter payment was conditional on continued employment of the participant until 31 December 2015. The decision to terminate and settle the plan was made prior to the completion of the sale and therefore the 50% payable upon closing has been accounted for in Endemol Holding B.V. prior to the completion of the sale. The 50% that became payable as per 31 December 2015 payment was conditional upon continued employment and was therefore considered a retention payment that is accrued over the period of the retention (i.e. over the period during which continued services are rendered by the participants). Based on the above accounting treatment and assessments, EUR 6.2 million has been expensed during the period ended 31 December 2015. The majority of this amount was paid before year-end 2015.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Equity Incentive Plan is designed to provide long-term incentives for eligible management to deliver longterm shareholder returns. Participation in the plan is at the board’s discretion. Under the plan, participants are granted options to purchase shares of common stock of JV Newco. 25% of the granted options will vest ratably over five years (service based vesting tranche), and 75% of the granted options will vest only at the occurrence of a realization event (Performance based vesting tranches): – 25% will vest only on the occurrence of a realization event, but only if JV Newco shareholders receive cash proceeds of at least two times (2.0x) their aggregate investment in JV Newco F-396 ----- – 25% will vest only on the occurrence of a realization event, but only if the “JV Newco” shareholders receive cash proceeds of at least two and a half times (2.5x) their aggregate investment in JV Newco – 25% will vest only on the occurrence of a realization event, but only if JV Newco shareholders receive cash proceeds of at least three times (3.0x) their aggregate investment in JV Newco. The option grant has a 10 year term with an exercise period of 5 years after the final vesting date for the service based tranche. A “realization event” means the occurrence of certain sales of JV Newco shares by JV Newco shareholders, certain transfers of JV Newco assets or a liquidation of JV Newco. Options are granted under the plan for no consideration and carry no dividend or voting rights. When exercisable, each option is convertible into one ordinary share. The exercise price of options is based on the initial price paid by the shareholders for their shares in JV Newco. As the awards granted under the plan are equity-settled share-based payment awards, the grant date fair value is recognised as an expense over the vesting period with a corresponding increase in equity. Subsubsection Text: Weighted average remaining contractual life of options outstanding at end of 2016 is 8.6 years (2015: 9.3 years). The weighted average fair value in relation to the options granted before 2016 was USD 13.45 per option (2015: USD 15.66 per option). For the options granted during 2016 the fair value was USD 0.89. The fair value at grant date of the service based vesting tranche is independently determined using the Black Scholes Model. The fair value at grant date of the Performance based vesting tranches are independently determined using a Monte Carlo simulation model that takes into account the exercise price, the term of the option, the share price at grant date and expected price volatility of the underlying share, the risk free interest rate for the term of the option and the correlations and volatilities of the peer group companies. For the option valuation of options granted during the year 2016, the main assumptions are: – grant date varying between January and October 2016 – expected option life: 5 years – share price at grant date: USD 46 – exercise price at grant date: USD 100 – expected share price volatility of the company’s shares: 29.5% – risk-free interest rate: 1.3% (5 year US government bond) – expected dividends: 0% F-397 ----- For the option valuation of options granted during the year 2015 main assumptions are: – grant date: 9 March 2015 – expected option life: 5 years – share price at grant date: USD 100 – exercise price at grant date: USD 100 – expected share price volatility of the company’s shares: 27.4% – risk-free interest rate: 1.65% (5 year US government bond) – expected dividends: 0% As part of the Group long-term incentive plan, Restricted Stock Option Units (“RSU’s”) have been granted in the course of 2016. Per the end of 2016 the outstanding RSU’s amount to 30.000. The granted RSU’s will vest ratably over four years (service based vesting). The RSU’s are valued at USD 46, based on the following assumptions: – number of RSU’s outstanding: 30,000 – grant date: 15 October 2016 – vesting period: 4 years The total expense recognized in the income statement for the Long-term incentive plan amounts to EUR 1.7 million in 2016 (2015: EUR 1.9 million). Total liability in equity amounts to EUR 3.6 million.

The provision for restructurings is made based on defined and communicated restructuring plans in place for several territories and for those countries where the Company is refocusing its regional strategy.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Following completion of a merger by CORE Media Group in 2011, two former stockholders, who were the beneficial owners of 13,728,196 shares of common stock of CORE Media Group Inc., demanded appraisal of such shares and filed a petition for appraisal in the Delaware Court of Chancery. On 31 October 2013, the Court F-398 ----- issued an opinion in the matter finding that the USD 5.50 Merger price is the most relevant exemplar of valuation available, but providing the parties the opportunity to submit additional arguments that a portion of the Merger price represented synergy value. Following submission of such additional arguments, the Court issued an opinion on 19 May 2014, confirming that the USD 5.50 Merger price is the best indicator of fair value. The former stockholders appealed the Court’s final judgement and the CORE Media Group filed a cross-appeal. The Company had accrued USD 16.9 million of interest as of 31 December 2014. On 12 February 2015 the Supreme Court of Delaware affirmed the decision of the Court of Chancery and the Company paid USD 92.3 million in March 2015. The payment consisted of USD 76.1 million merger consideration (accrued under ‘Other provisions’) and USD 16.2 million interest.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The liabilities with respect to acquisitions (earn-out obligations) are estimated on the basis of the expected future results of the respective companies (performance-related criteria). The majority of earn-out obligations are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the future obligation. Earn-out obligations are calculated using management’s best estimate of the expected future cash flows and using the applicable historical interest rate including a mark-up reflecting the risks of the market in which JV Newco operates. Discount rates used vary around 10%. The main liabilities relate to the companies acquired in the UK. The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecasted result, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. Subsubsection Text: In a number of business combinations, JV Newco granted the seller/non-controlling shareholder a put option to sell in the future (part of) the remaining shares to JV Newco. These put options are regarded as a financial liability in JV Newco’s consolidated financial statements. The majority of put options are dependent on the seller remaining with the business as an employee. Where contingent consideration payable in the future is employment linked, it is treated as an employee benefit expense in the income statement over the period of required employment. The liability is stated at the net present value of the accrued part of the consideration to be paid upon exercise of the options. Discount rates used vary between 5% and 10.0%. Put option liabilities primarily relate to the companies acquired in France, North America and United Kingdom. F-399 ----- The valuation model considers the present value of expected payments, discounted using a risk-adjusted discount rate. The expected payment is determined by considering the possible scenarios of forecast EBITDA, the amount to be paid under each scenario and the probability of each scenario. As the majority of the put options is payable within the coming year or are near the end of the option period, changes in EBITDA or discount rate will not have a material impact on the value of put option liabilities as per balance sheet date. Subsubsection Text: The other non-current liabilities consist for an amount of EUR 7.0 million of contractual incentives received, mainly for building premises in the Netherlands (2015: EUR 9.0 million). These incentives are amortized over the expected lifetime of the related contracts. As described in Note 3 under “Discontinued operations’ JV Newco released the other non-current liabilities which pertained to the Series A and Series B Preferred Stock of CORE Media Group. F-400 ----- The other non-current liabilities consisted for an amount of EUR 16.9 million (2015: EUR 17.1 million) of CORE Media Group’s Series A Convertible Preferred Stock (“Series A”) and for an amount of EUR 8.0 million (2015: EUR 6.6 million) of CORE Media Group’s Series B Convertible Preferred Stock (“Series B”). Series A, which was issued in connection with a merger on 21 June 2011, was convertible to common shares of the issuer at the option of the holder at any time and at the option of the issuer in connection with certain public offerings on the issuer on or after 21 June 2015. The Series A was redeemable at the option of the issuer between 21 June 2015 and 21 June 2016 or in connection with a public offering on the issuer at any time on or after 21 June 2015. On 10 December 2015 CORE Media Group repurchased 65,000 shares of the Series A at the cash price of USD 0.03 (three cents) per share. CORE Media Group subsequently exercised its right to retire all of the repurchased shares and recorded the offset in the income statement. The Series A required the issuer to pay quarterly dividend on the stated value (USD 76.50 per share) of the Series A, calculated at a rate of 9.0% per annum. Series B, which was issued in connection with an acquisition on 17 July 2012, was convertible to common shares of the issuer at the option of the holder after the eighth anniversary of issuance and under certain circumstances. The Series B was also redeemable at the option of the issuer under certain circumstances, including if the holder ceased to be employed by the acquired company. The Series B paid an annual dividend until the Series B was converted or redeemed. The future dividend was tied to the future results of the acquired business. Due to the contingent employment features of the Series B, the Series B was accounted for as a liability separate from the business combination in 2012 and treated as compensation. The estimated fair value of the series B (in total USD 16.6 million) was recognized as non-cash compensation expense ratably over eight years, the implied service period of the arrangement. In 2016 JV Newco recognized an expense of EUR 1.5 million (2015: EUR 1.8 million).

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Risk management and control procedures are integrated in the operation of the business. This includes monitoring of progress in our areas for improvement, through the introduction of an effective structure for the maintenance and evaluation of internal controls. The aim of risk management within JV Newco is to provide reasonable assurance that JV Newco understands the risks associated with achieving its business objectives, and that JV Newco is responding appropriately to these risks at all levels within the organisation. This will be achieved by ensuring that the following five action points are carried out at all times: – risks are properly identified, managed and reported; F-401 ----- – ownership is taken for risks and communicated to others; – resources are effectively and efficiently allocated to manage risks; – risks that could significantly affect employees, Endemol Shine, suppliers or clients are suitably managed; and – JV Newco is compliant with regulatory and legal requirements.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The primary objective of JV Newco is to ensure that it maintains healthy capital ratios in order to support its business and maximise shareholder value. JV Newco manages its capital structure and makes adjustments to it, in light of changes in economic conditions.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco’s activities expose it to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including foreign currency risk and interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. JV Newco’s overall risk management programme focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on JV Newco’s financial performance. Derivative financial instruments can be used to hedge exposure to fluctuations in interest rates. Risk management is carried out by a central treasury department under policies approved by the JV Newco Management Board. Treasury identifies, evaluates, mitigates and transfers/hedges financial risks. The Management Board provides written principles for overall risk management, as well as written policies covering specific areas, such as foreign exchange risk, interest rate risk, credit risk, use of derivative financial instruments, and investment of excess liquidity. Policies for each of these risks are summarised below.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: JV Newco assesses foreign currency risk by identifying and monitoring changes in exchange rate exposures that may adversely impact the income statement, cash flow and equity. JV Newco maintains risk management control systems to monitor foreign currency risk attributable to both outstanding foreign currency positions and commitments, as well as offsetting hedge positions. The risk management control systems involve the centralisation of JV Newco’s foreign currency exposure management, the netting and offsetting exposures from different group companies and the use of analytical techniques, including sensitivity analysis, to estimate the expected impact of changes in foreign currency rates. JV Newco group companies enter into transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the group company concerned. Significant transactions and operations in foreign currency, that could materially impact JV Newco’s statement of financial position and profit and loss, occur mainly in USD and GBP. These transactions expose JV Newco to foreign currency results. By means of natural hedging as well as foreign currency forward contracts JV Newco minimises exchange results on receivables, payables and expected future cash-flows denominated in currencies other than the functional currency. Financial derivatives can be used to economically hedge the net exchange results due to changes in foreign currency rates. Effective 8 January 2015, the Company entered into a EUR 350.0 million for USD 412 million Cross Currency Swap (CCS), at spot rate USD/EUR 1.177. The CCS partly off sets the mismatch between the currency mix of the external loans and borrowings and the currency mix of EBITDA and cash flow and in addition converts the company’s floating interest obligation in respect of 60% of the principal amount of the EUR-denominated loans to a fixed rate. Changes in the fair value of foreign currency forward contracts are reported in the income statement as fair value adjustments on derivative financial instruments and (partially) offset the exchange results recognised as foreign exchange results on the assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies. It is Endemol Shine’s policy to settle foreign currency forward contracts within the reporting period. JV Newco monitors its risk of shortage of funds using a recurring Cash flow management tool. The Cash flow management tool includes robust forecasts, weekly actual cash flow reporting and variance analysis reporting to the Management Board, continuous identification and problem solving, monitoring and delivery of cash generation and preservation initiatives. Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: CORE Media Group - petition for relief under Chapter 11 US bankruptcy code
Subsubsection Text: On 28 April 2016, CORE Entertainment, Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries (the “CORE Debtors”) filed voluntary petitions for relief under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Bankruptcy Court”). On 23 September 2016, the Bankruptcy Court confirmed (i.e., approved) the bankruptcy plan proposed by the CORE Debtors. The plan provides for a significant de-leveraging of the CORE Debtors pursuant to which, among other things, holders of equity interests in the CORE Debtors (including CORE Entertainment Holdings’ equity interest in CORE Entertainment, Inc.) did not receive any distribution on account thereof. Under the CORE Debtors’ bankruptcy plan, unsecured creditors are entitled to share pro rata in a distribution of cash (up to USD 2,375,000 in the aggregate and not to exceed 10% of its unsecured claim) and certain residual rights in respect of actions brought against parties not released from claims under the plan. On December 12, 2016, a litigation trust (the “Litigation Trust”) that was created in connection with the bankruptcy of CORE Media, Inc. and several of its affiliates (collectively, “Core”) filed a lawsuit in the State Courts in California in the United States, against certain Apollo companies, 21CF companies and Endemol Shine entities. As part of the Core’s plan of reorganization, the Litigation Trust was assigned the legal claims previously belonging to various entities which loaned money to Core. The complaint alleges that the defendants induced a breach of such loan agreements or intentionally interfered with such loan agreements. The Litigation Trust is seeking both compensatory and punitive damage in an undetermined amount against each of the 21 defendants it has named in the litigation, including MediArena Holding B.V. and Endemol USA Holding, Inc. The Company has indicated that it intends to vigorously defend its rights. In 2017 the court in California ruled in favour of a motion filed by the Company to dismiss the Core Litigation in California to force it to be refiled in New York. Based on management’s current consideration of the facts and circumstances, no provision has been recorded.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 29 Subsequent events Unwinding operations in Turkey
Subsubsection Text: In 2017 the Company was refocusing its regional strategy in some markets, including Turkey. As part of that refocus, the decision was made to unwind the operations in Turkey and to liquidate the local operating company in Turkey because of the situation set out below. In relation to this decision the Company will incur restructuring and exceptional costs in 2017. In May 2017 group management of Endemol Shine discovered serious issues around the local management of Endemol Shine Turkey. Group management has undertaken a comprehensive analysis of the business in Istanbul which included an investigation by a local law firm and assistance and advice from independent financial consultants. These investigations revealed certain project-related write-downs of which EUR 11 million was accounted for in 2016 and included in the exceptional items. Group management concluded, following the investigation by the law firm, that local management in Turkey did not comply with governance requirements and while every effort was made to find an alternative solution, the only viable option was to file for insolvency of Endemol Shine Turkey. The first hearing in the bankruptcy process took place last year and at the end of last year Audit Administrators were appointed to approve all payments made by Endemol Shine Turkey. The next hearing in the bankruptcy process is on 25 January 2018 and we expect that an expert will be appointed to consider the bankruptcy imminently. The Court has made decisions on disbursement of distribution income from exploitation of titles owned by Endemol Shine Turkey, which will reduce outstanding liabilities over time. Following the decision to liquidate, further assets impairments, amounting to EUR 17 million, will be recorded in the 2017 financial statements.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The following are JV Newco’s significant subsidiaries, associates and joint ventures as of 31 December 2016. Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Notes to the company financial statements 1 General
Subsubsection Text: The company financial statements of AP NMT JV Newco B.V. (the “Company”) and the consolidated financial statements together constitute the statutory financial statements of the Company. AP NMT JV Newco B.V. is registered at the Chamber of Commerce under number 61823147. The company financial statements are presented in Euro, the Company’s functional and reporting currency, rounded to the nearest thousand. The Company is jointly owned by an affiliate of Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (“Fox”) and funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, LLC (“Apollo”), with each owning 50%.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 2 Significant accounting policies Basis of preparation
Subsubsection Text: The company financial statements have been prepared in accordance with Part 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The Company uses the option of Section 362.8 of Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code, which means that that the principles for the recognition and measurement of assets and liabilities and determination of the result in the company financial statements are the same as the principles applied in the consolidated financial statements. Those principles are described in note 2 to the consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Investments in subsidiaries are valued at equity value, but not lower than nil. This equity value is based on the same accounting principles as applied by the Company in the consolidated financial statements. Investments in subsidiaries with a negative equity value are valued at nil. If the Company fully or partly guarantees the liabilities of the subsidiaries concerned, or has the effective obligation respectively, to enable the subsidiaries to pay its (share of the) liabilities, a provision is formed. Upon determining this provision, provisions for doubtful debts already deducted from receivables from the subsidiaries are taken into account.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Movements in shareholders’ equity are disclosed in separate statements of changes in equity on a consolidated and a company-only basis. Legal reserves for the purposes of the Company’s shareholders’ equity are the same as the reserves disclosed in the consolidated statement of changes in equity and Note 17 ‘Equity’ to the consolidated financial statements. Until derecognition of CORE Media Group per 17 October 2016 as explained in Note 3 ‘Acquisitions and divestments’ to the consolidated financial statements, the difference between the equity according to the company accounts and the consolidated accounts was explained by the fact that the subsidiary CORE Entertainment Holdings Inc, as included in the consolidation, had a negative net asset value but was valuated in the company balance sheet at zero. AP NMT JV Newco B.V. has not issued a declaration of liability or guarantee for these companies.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: AP NMT JV Newco B.V. was incorporated on 5 November 2014 with an authorised and issued share capital of EUR 1 consisting of 1 ordinary share with a nominal value of EUR 1. After incorporation shareholders made contributions in kind against 14,878,309 issued shares with a nominal value of EUR 1. All shares are fully paid (in cash or other consideration). Fully paid ordinary shares carry one vote per share and carry a right to dividends.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The share premium is the amount paid to the Company by shareholders, in cash or other consideration, over and above the nominal value of the shares.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The legal reserves comprise of: – Translation reserve: The translation reserve comprises of all foreign exchange differences arising from the translation of the financial statements of foreign operations; and – Reserve for participating interests: Pursuant to Dutch law certain limitations exist relating to the distribution of shareholders’ equity. The reserve for participating interests was formed for the retained profits from investments in joint ventures and associates, which were not paid in the form of dividends and payment of which cannot be realized by the Company itself.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Allocation of results as laid down in the articles of association Article 21
Subsubsection Text: The general meeting is authorized to appropriate the profits which have been determined by adopting the annual accounts, and to determine distributions, to the extent the equity of the company exceeds the reserves which must be maintained under Dutch law. A resolution to make a distribution has no effect until the management board has granted approval for such resolution. The management board shall refuse this approval only if it knows or should reasonably foresee that the company will be unable to continue to pay its short-term debts after the distribution. In calculating each distribution, the shares held by the company in its own capital shall be disregarded. In calculating the amount that will be distributed on each share, only the amount of the mandatory payment on the nominal amount of the shares is eligible. Deviation from the preceding sentence is possible with the consent of all shareholders. The right to receive a distribution shall expire five years from the day on which such a distribution became payable. No dividends were declared in 2016. F-420 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The result will be charged to the accumulated deficit.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: This reserve includes the retained profits or accumulated losses.

Subsubsection Text: As of 31 December 2016 and 31 December 2015 the Company had no outstanding guarantees.

The remuneration of the Company’s Management Board for 2016 amounted to EUR nil (2015: nil). The Company does not have any Supervisory Directors. The Company has not provided loans, guarantees or advances to members of the Company’s Management Board.

Section Title: NOTES TO THE COMPANY FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Company and its Dutch subsidiaries are part of a Dutch fiscal unity headed by the Company. Within the Dutch fiscal unity profits and losses of the group companies are offset. Over 2016 and 2015 the Dutch fiscal unity was in a tax loss position.
